questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman is currently in the intensive care unit due to severe Gram-negative sepsis. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient needs central venous access for the administration of vasopressors. The patient is prepped, draped, and a time-out is called for placement of a triple lumen catheter. After cannulation, the patient is noted to have increased work of breathing. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 87/60 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 89% on room air. A chest radiograph is obtained and shown below. This surgical error most likely occurred due to cannulation via which of the following anatomic spaces?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Fourth or fifth intercostal space midclavicular line

questions.solution:
This patient undergoes central venous access placement and subsequently develops hemodynamic instability. The chest radiograph demonstrates a pneumothorax with tension physiology combined with tachycardia and hypotension. Thus the triple lumen catheter was likely placed via the superior thoracic aperture, resulting in an iatrogenic tension pneumothorax.  

This area, also known as the thoracic inlet or outlet, is bounded posteriorly by the T1 vertebral body and costovertebral joints, laterally by the first ribs and their costal cartilages, and anteriorly by the superior border of the manubrium. The most commonly injured structures in this anatomic region are the cervical pleura and lung apex. Injuries to the cervical pleura and lung apex can occur via various procedures near the superior thoracic aperture in the neck. Standard procedures in this area include central venous access, pacemaker placement, Swan-Ganz catheter placement, and dialysis catheter placement.  

The pleura is exposed to potential injury from its inferior portion, which descends below the costal margin. The first region is the right part of the infrasternal angle. Surgeries near these areas can result in injury to the lung.  

Option Analysis

✅ Superior thoracic aperture :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lower thoracic aperture :
Incorrect: The lower thoracic aperture is bounded at the inferior aspect of the thorax by the ribs and diaphragm. It is not a potential space for central venous access. 
❌ Femoral triangle:
Incorrect: Central venous catheters can be placed in the groin via the femoral triangle. However, the placement of central catheters in this anatomic location is not associated with iatrogenic pneumothorax. 
❌ Second intercostal space midclavicular line  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the anatomic landmark for needle decompression of a tension pneumothorax. It is not a potential space for central line placement. 
❌ Fourth or fifth intercostal space midclavicular line :
Incorrect: This answer describes the anatomic landmark used to place a chest tube, not a central line.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate right wrist pain. The patient was playing pick-up basketball when he tripped, fell, and landed on an outstretched right hand. He states, “I thought I might have a wrist sprain, but my fourth and fifth fingers started feeling numb, so I came to the ED to get checked out.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation and swelling over the hypothenar eminence. The patient’s initial right hand and wrist radiographs are unremarkable. A carpal tunnel view of the right hand is subsequently obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures is at most significant risk of injury based on this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand. He has pain over the ulnar aspect of the wrist and numbness of the fourth and fifth digits. The carpal tunnel view demonstrates a fracture to the hook of the hamate, which carries a risk of compression injury to the ulnar nerve as it passes through the Gunyon canal.

Hook of the hamate injuries are uncommon but typically occur due to a mechanism of injury involving a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). Clinically, patients will experience pain and swelling over the ulnar aspect of the wrist and hypothenar eminence with associated ulnar nerve deficits if compression is present. Careful physical examination should be performed to assess ulnar nerve and artery function to ensure that neither is injured. This evaluation can be accomplished via 1) strength and sensation testing of the fourth and fifth digits and 2) pressing down on the radial artery and assessing if sufficient blood can reach the hand via the ulnar artery.

Hook of the hamate fractures are often missed on initial evaluation and misdiagnosed as wrist sprains, as frontal and lateral radiographs are often unremarkable.  A carpal tunnel view of the wrist can be obtained for further evaluation if suspicion remains despite normal radiographs.

Option Analysis

✅ Ulnar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Extensor digitorum  :
Incorrect: The extensor digitorum is located on the dorsal aspect of the hand. Injury to this structure can occur when a direct force is applied to a digit held in extension. In contrast, this patient sustained a fall onto an outstretched hand and has imaging that reveals a hook of the hamate fracture.  
❌ Median nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the median nerve is unlikely to occur from the hook of the hamate fractures.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury does not typically occur with the hook of the hamate fractures. Instead, it more commonly occurs with humeral shaft fractures.  
❌ Radial artery  :
Incorrect: Radial artery injury does not typically occur in the setting of the hook of the hamate fractures.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motorcycle collision. The motorcycle was stationary at a stoplight when rear-ended by a car. The patient fell backward off the bike onto the vehicle's hood and now has severe pain in her occipital region. The patient was wearing a helmet. An X-ray done in the emergency room reveals the finding shown below. Subsequent CT angiogram rules out injury to the adjacent vasculature. Which of the following is a common complication of this fracture?  


 Image reference: Wikipedia.

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the cervical foramen

questions.solution:
This patient sustained a head injury after she was struck from behind and fell backward onto the hood of a car. Notably, she was wearing a helmet. The mechanism of injury in this scenario involves anterior displacement of her neck due to the impact of the car and backward momentum of her head due to the increased weight of her head with her helmet. This pattern of injury, similar to a whiplash injury, can also cause fractures of the C2 vertebrae known as a Hangman’s fracture or traumatic spondylolisthesis of the axis.

Understanding the physiopathology of a Hangman’s fracture requires an appreciation of the unique features of the C1 and C2 vertebrae. Unlike the subaxial spine, the C1 and C2 vertebrae do not possess an intervertebral disc. Stabilization of these vertebrae, therefore, occurs via unique ligaments which allow for the support and rotational flexibility of the cranium. In a fracture of C2, this specialized anatomy becomes a great obstacle due to the physical instability of the fragments, which leads to impaired healing of the fracture and the potentially life-threatening complication of spinal cord laceration if the unstable bone fragments come in contact with the spinal cord posteriorly. Cervical orthostasis is usually achieved through a Halo-vest device.

Option Analysis

✅ Instability of the fracture  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Avascular necrosis of the cervical foramen  :
Incorrect: The vertebral bodies typically have abundant access to arterial blood flow, even in the setting of fractures. Avascular necrosis is more commonly a concern for hip and wrist fractures.  
❌ Neuropathy of the upper limbs:
Incorrect: Neuropathy of the upper limbs is not common in C2 fractures due to the comparatively larger spinal cord size at this level. Therefore, compression of the spinal column causing neuropathy is a rare occurrence. Rather, unstable fractured fragments have the potential to lacerate the spinal cord and cause traumatic injury, which can be lethal.  
❌ Respiratory depression  :
Incorrect: Respiratory depression occurs due to herniation of the brain secondary to traumatic brain injury or secondary to brainstem injury. This particular fracture pattern is not at risk of causing brainstem injury or brain herniation.  
❌ Unilateral facial weakness:
Incorrect: This answer describes the condition of Bell palsy, which is due to injury of the fifth cranial nerve, well above the fracture level at C2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after an episode of hematemesis. The patient was watching television when he felt nauseated and produced bright-red vomitus. Past medical history is notable for an ankle sprain, for which he is currently taking aspirin, and Helicobacter pylori infection, which was successfully treated 7 months ago. The patient consumes 4-6 beers per week and does not use tobacco products. His vitals are within normal limits. Endoscopy is performed and examination of the stomach reveals a protruding 2.5-mm arteriole that has eroded the overlying mucosa. There is active spurting of blood from the vessel. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a Dieulafoy lesion, which is a rare gastrointestinal (GI) condition characterized by an unusually dilated arteriole that erodes the overlying mucosa and is susceptible to bleeding from minor mucosal trauma. Dieulafoy lesions are most often located in the proximal stomach along the lesser curvature.  

The etiology of Dieulafoy lesion is unknown. However, individuals with comorbidities (e.g., cardiopulmonary dysfunction, chronic renal failure) and those taking medications that increase bleeding risk (e.g., aspirin, warfarin) have higher chances of developing Dieulafoy lesions.  

Patients with Dieulafoy lesions may experience signs of upper GI bleeding, including hematemesis, melena, and hematochezia. Endoscopy can be used to diagnose the condition and to perform epinephrine injections, thermocoagulation, and place hemostatic clips to treat it.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of intravenous octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide can stop active bleeding from ruptured esophageal varices. However, this patient has no history of portal hypertension. As a result, it would be unlikely for portacaval anastomoses to cause esophageal vein dilation in this patient.   
❌ Discontinuation of aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin may have contributed to this patient’s upper gastrointestinal tract bleed. Nonetheless, this patient is actively bleeding, and the next best step in management should involve trying to achieve hemostasis.  
❌ Surgical gastrectomy:
Incorrect: This patient has a Dieulafoy lesion, which is an unusually dilated arteriole that erodes the overlying mucosa and starts bleeding. Historically, surgical gastrectomy was used in the management of bleeding from Dieulafoy lesions. However, recent advances in endoscopy have made safer and less invasive interventions possible.  
✅ Thermal coagulation of bleeding site:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Initiation of propranolol therapy:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers are used for prophylaxis against variceal bleeds. However, this patient has a dilated arteriole in the stomach that has eroded overlying mucosa. This is more consistent with the presentation of a Dieulafoy lesion. Beta-blockers are not used in the prophylaxis or acute management of Dieulafoy lesion bleeding.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with worsening abdominal pain that began all of a sudden after eating pizza two nights ago. The patient reports the pain has progressively worsened and is now 8 out of 10 in severity. He reports no change in bowel movements during this time, but he has had a decreased appetite and moderate nausea. Medical history includes lactose intolerance. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 108/66 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows right lower quadrant pain with passive right hip extension. Which of the following will most likely provide definitive treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has worsening right lower quadrant (RLQ) abdominal pain for 2 days, mild fever, and positive Psoas sign (right lower quadrant pain elicited with passive right hip extension). He most likely has acute appendicitis. The treatment of choice is surgical removal of the appendix (appendectomy), which can be achieved via open surgery or laparoscopy.  

Diagnosis of appendicitis can be made clinically. However, abdominal CT scan can be used to confirm the diagnosis and for surgical planning prior to appendectomy.  

The abdominal pain associated with appendicitis typically begins as poorly localized pain in the periumbilical region, which then migrates to McBurney point in the RLQ. McBurney point is about two-thirds of the way from the umbilicus to the right anterior superior iliac spine. Patients with a retrocecal appendix may also report right flank pain due to psoas muscle irritation.  

Common physical exam findings include Rovsing, obturator, and psoas signs. Rovsing sign is RLQ pain elicited on palpation of the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. Obturator sign is RLQ pain with right hip flexion followed by internal rotation. Pain occurs since the inflamed appendix irritates the obturator internus muscle. Psoas sign is RLQ pain elicited with passive right hip extension, which stretches the psoas muscle and causes friction against the inflamed appendix. Common laboratory findings include a hypokalemic, hypochloremic, metabolic alkalosis due to vomiting and leukocytosis with left shift.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ IV antibiotics:
Incorrect: While some evidence exists for nonoperative management of non-perforated acute appendicitis with antibiotics, this option is only indicated for a very small subset of patients in which surgery is contraindicated or refused.   
❌ Oral rehydration:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration is the treatment of choice for gastroenteritis and small asymptomatic kidney stones less than 10 mm in diameter. Patients with gastroenteritis would present with fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Patients with kidney stones would present with flank pain and urinary symptoms. Psoas sign would be negative in either condition  
✅ Surgical intervention:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dietary restriction:
Incorrect: Dietary restriction is the treatment of choice for lactose intolerance. Patients with lactose intolerance present with temporary bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence shortly after consumption of dairy products. Psoas sign would be negative, and abdominal symptoms do not typically persist for 2 days.   
❌ Polyethylene glycol:
Incorrect: Laxatives, such as polyethylene glycol, are used in the treatment of constipation. Patients with constipation present with abdominal pain, decreased bowel movements, and bloating. However, constipation would not cause a positive Psoas sign.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the local paramedics after a motor vehicle collision. He was found approximately 1 hour after the accident occurred. At the scene, the patient was awake and complained of pain in his back and legs. His temperature is 35.6°C (96.1°F), his pulse is 106/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/88 mm Hg. Glasgow coma scale is 15. On physical examination, the patient is awake, his speech is clear and appropriate, and he has normal breath sounds over bilateral lung fields. He has palpable, equal femoral pulses. Multiple abrasions are noted over the neck, shoulders, abdomen, and legs. The chest wall is nontender. The abdomen is mildly tender. The pelvis is stable, but he has extensive swelling and tenderness of the right thigh. The patient has multiple scalp lacerations that continue to ooze. Which of the following best describes the location of the bleeding from the scalp seen in this patient?

choices.text: Between the arachnoid mater and dura mater
Between the brain and arachnoid mater
Between the scalp skin and epicranial aponeurosis
Between epicranial aponeurosis and loose connective tissue
Between the periosteum and epicranial aponeurosis

questions.solution:
The scalp is highly vascularized by the branches of the external and internal carotid arteries, which course within layer two of the scalp, the subcutaneous connective tissue layer between the skin and the epicranial aponeurosis. Most bleeding comes from the superficial temporal artery and the occipital artery.  

Scalp lacerations usually bleed profusely, primarily the result of abundant anastomosis. In addition, the severed arteries do not contract when they are cut because the vessel lumens are held open by the dense connective tissue in the second layer of the scalp.    

Scalp wounds can be classified as:  
  •  Superficial scalp wounds: Do not gape because of the strength of the underlying aponeurosis, which holds the margins of the wound together 
  •  Deep scalp wounds: The scalp is lacerated in the coronal plane. The wounds gape because of the contraction of the frontalis and occipitalis muscles in the opposite directions. This aponeurotic layer of the scalp is often tightened during cosmetic surgery (e.g., “facelifts”) to help reduce wrinkles in the face and forehead. 

Option Analysis

❌ Between the arachnoid mater and dura mater:
Incorrect: Bleeding between the arachnoid mater and dura mater is known as subdural hemorrhage. It usually results from tears in bridging veins that cross the subdural space. Patients with large bleeds may present with signs of increased intracranial pressure. External bleeding is not seen. 
❌ Between the brain and arachnoid mater:
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage develops between the brain and arachnoid mater. External bleeding is not seen. 
✅ Between the scalp skin and epicranial aponeurosis:
 Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Between epicranial aponeurosis and loose connective tissue:
Incorrect: The nerves and arteries of the scalp course within layer two, the subcutaneous connective tissue layer between the skin and the epicranial aponeurosis. The loose connective tissue (layer four) contains the emissary veins. It is a “danger area” because it allows the spread of infection to the intracranial structures. 
❌ Between the periosteum and epicranial aponeurosis:
Incorrect: Subgaleal hemorrhage results from bleeding from emissary veins between the periosteum and the epicranial aponeurosis. It can occur in neonates during birth and presents as diffuse, progressive, fluctuant scalp and neck swelling.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found down outside a bar. Emergency medical services were called to the scene after several bystanders saw the person lying in the street. The patient is poorly responsive and unable to provide a history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. The patient’s speech is slurred, and he responds only to pain. Physical examination reveals scattered abrasions over the arms and legs and a 1 cm laceration over the right occiput. The patient is further noted to have swelling of the right hand. A radiograph of the right hand is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury associated with this injury?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Force applied to a clenched fist
Direct force to the fifth digit held in extension
Sudden hyperextension of the fifth digit held in flexion
Lateral force applied to the fifth digit

questions.solution:
This patient presents after being found down with right-hand swelling, scattered abrasions, and a head laceration. Given these findings, he was likely involved in a physical altercation. Imaging demonstrates a fracture of the distal end of the fifth metacarpal, which is consistent with a boxer fracture. The most common mechanism of action leading to this injury pattern is a direct force applied to a clenched fist.  

Boxer fractures are common and represent approximately 10% of all hand fractures. It is most commonly seen amongst boxers (hence the name), individuals involved in physical altercations, and athletes participating in contact sports (e.g., football, rugby). The most common mechanism of injury for this fracture involves axial pressure applied to the metacarpal bone when the fist is in a clenched position.

Clinically, patients with boxer fractures will often experience dorsal hand pain, swelling, and possible deformity over the fifth knuckle. Treatment is generally conservative and involves analgesia with closed reduction and placement in an ulnar gutter splint. Surgical referral is indicated for severe deformity or a high degree of displacement and angulation.

Option Analysis

✅ Force applied to a clenched fist  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fall on an outstretched hand  :
Incorrect: Fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) represents the major mechanism of injury for many wrist pathologies, including scaphoid and distal radius fractures. However, this patient has a characteristic fracture of the fifth metacarpal, which is suggestive of a boxer fracture, most commonly caused by a direct force applied to a clenched fist.  
❌ Direct force to the fifth digit held in extension  :
Incorrect: A direct force to the fifth digit held in extension would result in a Mallet finger caused by rupture of the extensor tendon where it attaches to the distal phalanx. In contrast, this patient’s imaging shows a fracture of the fifth metacarpal bone.  
❌ Sudden hyperextension of the fifth digit held in flexion  :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action attributed to the Jersey finger, injuring the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. In contrast, this patient’s imaging shows a fracture of the fifth metacarpal bone.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the fifth digit  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the fifth digit would likely result in a dislocation injury rather than a fracture.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency room because of an episode of hematemesis, which occurred an hour ago. Medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and liver cirrhosis. Review of the electronic medical record shows that the patient had undergone upper endoscopy a year ago for evaluation of dysphagia and was diagnosed with esophageal varices. He was subsequently started on propranolol. Examination of the patient’s eyes reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam is notable for hepatomegaly and ascites. Intravenous fluids are administered, endoscopic band ligation is performed, and hemostasis is achieved. Ten-days later, however, the patient has another episode of hematemesis. Which of the following interventions will be most useful in preventing future gastrointestinal tract bleeding in this patient?

choices.text: Placement of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt

questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent variceal bleeding, which is defined as bleeding that occurs more than 120 hours after the first episode of hemorrhage, provided that hemostasis was initially achieved. As a result, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) is indicated to prevent future variceal rebleeding. The procedure involves creating an artificial shunt between the inflowing portal vein and outflowing hepatic vein, thereby reducing portal resistance and hypertension. TIPS is also indicated for patients with first time variceal bleeding that is refractory to treatment by medications (e.g. octreotide) and endoscopic band ligation.    

In either of the aforementioned scenarios, a balloon tamponade is temporarily placed in the esophagus to stop bleeding until TIPS can be performed.



Option Analysis

❌ Long-term octreotide therapy:
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to stop acute variceal bleeding and should be continued for 3-5 days. However, its efficacy as secondary prophylaxis has not been demonstrated. Moreover, the patient has had variceal rebleeding, defined as a bleeding episode occurring 120 hours or more after the initial episode. This is an indication for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting.  
❌ Long-term nadolol therapy :
Incorrect: Beta-blockers, such as propranolol and nadolol, can be used for prophylaxis against variceal bleeding. This patient was previously started on propranolol but nonetheless had variceal bleeding. As a result, switching to nadolol will most likely not help prevent future episodes of variceal bleeding. 
❌ Perform esophageal transection:
Incorrect: The Sugiura procedure involves removing and transecting the blood vessels that supply the esophagus and upper portion of the stomach. It can be used to treat esophageal variceal bleeding that is refractory to other interventions. However, the procedure has high mortality rates. As a result, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting is preferred over surgical intervention. 
✅ Placement of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Initiation of lactulose therapy:
Incorrect: Patients with gastrointestinal bleeding are at increased risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy. This is because hemoglobin in the gastrointestinal tract can be broken down into ammonia and absorbed into the bloodstream. Lactulose traps ammonia in the colon and prevents absorption. However, it would not reduce the risk of future variceal rebleeding.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in an altercation at a bar. He was stabbed multiple times with a pocket knife. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 135/87 mmHg, pulse is 20/min, and respiratory rate is 17/min. Physical examination reveals stab wounds over the anterior chest and left upper extremity. A chest x-ray is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the primary finding on this patient’s imaging?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient sustained numerous stab wounds. On chest imaging, there is a visible visceral pleural edge with an absence of distal lung markings. In addition, there is subtle leftwards deviation of the mediastinum. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of pneumothorax.  

Chest x-rays are typically the first-line imaging modality when a pulmonary or mediastinal etiology is suspected. Common indications for chest x-ray include chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough. It is also often used as a part of trauma evaluation (as in the case of this patient).  

Common pathologies and their associated findings on chest x-ray are summarized in the following table:  



Option Analysis

❌ Pneumomediastinum:
Incorrect: Pneumomediastinum presents as linear and curvilinear outlines surrounding the mediastinum. This finding is absent in this patient. In contrast, he has a collapsed right lung, consistent with pneumothorax.
❌ Displaced rib fracture:
Incorrect: This chest radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of a displaced rib fracture.
❌ Clavicular fracture:
Incorrect: The visualized portion of the bilateral clavicles are unremarkable and do not demonstrate evidence of fracture.
❌ Perforated bowel:
Incorrect: Stab wounds can lead to bowel perforation, which can manifest with free air under the diaphragm. In contrast, this patient has a collapsed right lung, which is consistent with pneumothorax.  
✅ Pneumothorax:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the hospital for evaluation of acute abdominal pain that began 12-hours ago. The pain is constant and stabbing. In addition, he endorses one episode of non-bloody non-bilious emesis. Medical history is notable for hypertension and intermittent episodes of abdominal pain, which are triggered by consuming fatty foods. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. On arrival, temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 103/71 mmHg, and pulse is 104/min. Physical exam is notable for scleral icterus. Abdominal exam reveals pain that is elicited with palpation of the right upper quadrant. The mucous membranes are dry, and the patient has a delayed capillary refill time. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of the patient’s presentation?  

 Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Total Bilirubin  4.5 mg/dL  45 g/L 
 Conjugated Bilirubin  3.8 mg/dL  64.98 µmol/L 
 Aspartate Aminotransferase  87 U/L  87 U/L 
 Alanine Aminotransferase  79 U/L  79 U/L 
 Lipase*  40 U/L  40 U/L 
*Reference range: 12-70 U/L

choices.text: Inflammation secondary to cystic duct obstruction
Obstruction of the common bile duct
Ascending infection of the biliary tract

questions.solution:
This patient likely has acute cholangitis, which is characterized by inflammation of the biliary ducts. The most common cause is gallstones, which impair bile outflow in the common bile duct, causing biliary stasis and creating an environment for the bacteria that have ascended the biliary tract to proliferate. Less common causes of cholangitis include strictures, cysts, parasites, and tumors.  

Patients with ascending cholangitis can have fever, nausea and vomiting, and constant right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain lasting more than 6 hours. In addition, patients can develop jaundice secondary to biliary tract obstruction. The combination of RUQ pain, fever, and jaundice makes up the Charcot triad. If the patient develops sepsis, the presentation can progress to the Reynolds pentad, which is the combination of the Charcot triad plus hypotension and altered mental status.

Laboratory testing will reveal a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated liver enzymes, and elevated alkaline phosphatase.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inflammation secondary to cystic duct obstruction :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes cholecystitis, which occurs when obstruction of the cystic duct causes gallbladder distention and inflammation. Patients can develop right upper quadrant pain and fever. However, patients would not develop jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, or elevated liver enzymes, because the common bile duct is unaffected, so bile can still be excreted into the intestines. 
❌ Obstruction of the common bile duct:
Incorrect: This describes choledocholithasis, which can cause right upper quadrant pain, nausea/vomiting, and extrahepatic cholestasis. However, the condition is not associated with infection or sepsis. As a result, uncomplicated choledocholithasis would not account for the patient’s fever, tachycardia, or borderline hypotension.
✅ Ascending infection of the biliary tract:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inflammation of the liver parenchyma:
Incorrect: This describes hepatitis, which can manifest with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes. However, patients with hepatitis generally have unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, whereas this patient has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which instead raises concern for a biliary tract obstruction. 
❌ Rupture of abdominal aneurysm:
Incorrect: A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) can cause tachycardia and hypotension. Patients with a smoking history are at increased risk of developing AAA. However, a ruptured AAA would not account for the hyperbilirubinemia, fever, and elevated liver enzymes observed in this patient.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient reports that he was sitting on the couch watching television when the symptoms started. He does not take any medications and is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 122/64 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 18/min, and the patient has an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals a tall thin male in no acute distress. A portable chest x-ray is ordered and reveals pleural markings approximately 1-2 centimeters away from the left chest wall. The original image is shown below:  

Image reproduced from

Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is a tall, thin male who developed sudden-onset chest pain and shortness of breath. The vital signs are notable for mild tachycardia. Chest x-ray reveals a small primary spontaneous pneumothorax, which is defined as one wherein the distance between the chest wall and visceral pleural margin is 2 cm or less. Patients with a small pneumothorax and minimal respiratory symptoms can be managed with supplemental 100% oxygen and an observation period of usually six hours. After the observation period, a repeat chest x ray is performed. If the pneumothorax is unchanged or has improved, then the patient is deemed stable for discharge. Most small pneumothoraces will resolve over approximately 7-10 days.  

For larger pneumothoraces (> 2cm distance between the visceral pleura and chest wall) causing prominent respiratory distress, a tube thoracostomy should be performed. This procedure is accomplished by inserting a chest tube at the 4th or 5th space mid axillary line on the affected side. Other indications for chest tube insertion include large traumatic pneumothorax, any pneumothorax with concomitant hemothorax, tension pneumothorax, bilateral pneumothorax, pneumothorax needing ventilator support, or exacerbation of a pneumothorax after conservative therapy.

Option Analysis

✅ 100% FiO2 and observation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tube thoracostomy:
Incorrect: Chest tube insertion is indicated for any traumatic pneumothorax, pneumothorax with a concomitant hemothorax, tension pneumothorax, or large pneumothorax (> 2 cm away from the chest wall) with significant respiratory symptoms. In contrast, this patient's pneumothorax is not causing respiratory distress and hence can be managed with a more conversative treatment approach.  
❌ Needle decompression:
Incorrect: Needle decompression is indicated for emergent treatment of a tension pneumothorax, which is performed at the second intercostal space, midclavicular line. However, this patient has no risk factors (e.g. penetrating injury) or physical examination findings (e.g., deviated trachea, distended jugular veins) suggestive of a tension pneumothorax.
❌ Video assisted thoracoscopic surgery :
Incorrect: Video assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) is a type of minimally invasive thoracic surgery for correction of large pneumothoraces, hemothorax, or lung resection. In contrast, this patient’s pneumothorax is limited to only the apex of the left lung.
❌ Pericardiocentesis:
Incorrect: Pericardiocentesis is the treatment for cardiac tamponade, a condition characterized by pooling of fluid around the heart. Cardiac tamponade classically presents with the Beck triad (hypotension, raised jugular venous pressure, muffled heart sounds). In contrast, this patient has none of the components of the Beck triad.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient was riding a motorcycle through a traffic intersection when he was hit by a pickup truck at high speed and was thrown from the bike. He did not sustain any head injuries or lose consciousness. Upon arrival, temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 122/71 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals diffuse bruising and lacerations. A portion of the right chest wall is noted to move outward during expiration and inwards on inspiration. No abdominal tenderness or distention is noted. Imaging is ordered and reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Insertion of a right-sided chest tube
Transfusion with packed red blood cells
Surgical reduction and fixation of fractured ribs

questions.solution:
This patient presents following a motor vehicle accident with paradoxical movements of the right chest wall and multiple broken ribs on imaging. Together, these findings are concerning for flail chest. Given he is hemodynamically stable and without signs of active bleeding, the next best step includes adequate analgesia.

A flail chest occurs when three or more ribs fracture in two or more places, allowing a segment of the thoracic wall to move freely. During normal inspiration, the thoracic wall expands outwards and increases its diameter, whereas during expiration, it decreases its diameter to expel air. With flail chest, paradoxical movement occurs such that during inspiration, the free segment moves inward, and during expiration, it moves outward. A flail chest is an extremely painful injury and may induce hypoventilation due to a patient’s reluctance to breathe adequately through the pain.

Management wise, the first step is to ensure adequate pain control and provide supplemental oxygen if needed. Positive pressure ventilation can be used to force the flail chest segment out during inspiration, should the patient decompensate. In extreme cases, surgical repair of the fractures may be necessary, such as in patients with severe chest wall instability or fracture nonunion.  



Option Analysis

✅ Administration of intravenous morphine  :
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Insertion of a right-sided chest tube  :
Incorrect: This patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident and imaging reveals four consecutive rib fractures, which is concerning for a flail chest. This patient does not have evidence of pneumothorax, hemothorax, or significant pleural effusions, and as a result, insertion of a chest tube is not necessary.  
❌ Transfusion with packed red blood cells  :
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically stable and has no signs of acute bleeding, such as abdominal tenderness due to splenic rupture or fluid accumulation within the chest due to hemothorax. As such, a blood transfusion is not indicated at this time.  
❌ Perform endotracheal intubation  :
Incorrect: Patients with flail chest may develop respiratory failure and require endotracheal intubation. This patient, however, has a normal oxygen saturation on room air. Should the patient’s oxygen saturation drop, non-invasive methods (e.g., nasal cannula, continuous positive airway pressure) should be attempted prior to proceeding to intubation.  
❌ Surgical reduction and fixation of fractured ribs  :
Incorrect: Surgical repair of a flail chest is reserved for severe cases. This includes patients who cannot be weaned from mechanical ventilation, have severe chest wall instability, or have persistent pain secondary to fracture malunion. In contrast, this patient is hemodynamically stable with adequate oxygen saturation.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute left shoulder pain. The patient was lowering himself from a pullup at the gym when he suddenly felt a “pop” followed by acute pain in the anterior left shoulder. The patient has a history of left supraspinatus tendinopathy that was treated with physical therapy. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Physical examination reveals ecchymosis, swelling, and tenderness over the anterior left deltoid. The patient's arm is pronated and flexed at the elbow to 90 degrees. The examiner attempts to supinate the arm against resistance, which elicits shoulder pain. A radiograph of the shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii
Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii

questions.solution:
This patient presents with anterior shoulder pain after a load is applied during eccentric contraction of the biceps brachii. Physical examination demonstrates a positive Yergason test. In combination, these findings are consistent with tendinopathy of the long-head of the biceps brachii.

Tear or rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii is associated with an eccentric force applied to a contracted biceps tendon. Patients often recall a “snap” or “pop” followed by ecchymosis, swelling, and pain immediately after the inciting mechanism of injury. Additionally, patients will often have a bulbous mass in the upper arm due to excessive retraction of the biceps muscle belly. This finding is known as a "Popeye deformity."

Specific examination findings may include a positive Yergason test, wherein pain is reproduced at the anterior shoulder when the patient attempts to supinate the arm against resistance after the examiner places the patient's arm in pronation and 90 degree flexion at the elbow. In addition, an exam maneuver known as the Speed test may also yield a positive test. In this exam, the patient's arm is extended in full supination with the shoulder flexed, and the patient is asked to elevate the arm against a resistive force; a positive test will produce the pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Supraspinatus tear  :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of rotator cuff injury, physical examination demonstrates a positive Yergason test. This physical examination maneuver has a high specificity for biceps injury. In contrast, a supraspinatus injury would demonstrate a positive empty can test.  
❌ Subacromial bursitis  :
Incorrect: Subacromial bursitis falls into the category of rotator cuff impingement injuries and presents with chronic shoulder pain. Patients with subacromial bursitis will demonstrate limited active range of motion but preserved passive range of motion.  
❌ Acromioclavicular joint separation  :
Incorrect: Acromioclavicular joint separation most commonly occurs due to a direct force to the lateral aspect of the shoulder while the arm is held in adduction. Clinical features include swelling and pain over the lateral aspect of the shoulder. Radiography will show widening of the acromioclavicular joint.  
❌ Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii  :
Incorrect: Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii is less common than rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii. A common mechanism of injury involves sudden forceful extension of the person's flexed elbow when the biceps muscle is fully contracted. Physical examination findings will demonstrate swelling of the antecubital fossa and a positive hook test.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate right lower quadrant abdominal pain. The pain is sharp, stabbing, and has progressively worsened. He has also had decreased oral intake and an episode of vomiting that has since resolved. Past medical and surgical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 107/67 mmHg, and pulse is 106/min. The examiner passively extends the patient’s right leg with the patient lying on his left side. This maneuver reproduces pain in the right lower quadrant. Which of the following best describes the physical examination finding present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features of acute appendicitis, including right lower quadrant pain, anorexia, and associated vomiting. Additionally, the pain is reproduced with passive extension of the right hip, consistent with a positive iliopsoas sign (also termed the Thomas test).

The iliopsoas muscle originates on the outer vertebral bodies of T12 and L1-L3. The muscle inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur. This muscle is largely responsible for hip flexion and thus is important for standing, walking, and running. Passive extension of the hip places strain on the iliopsoas and any nearby structures or anatomically associated pathology.

Common etiologies associated with a positive iliopsoas sign include acute appendicitis, sigmoid colitis, or lymphadenopathy. Rarely, a positive iliopsoas sign may indicate a psoas abscess, which is a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment. When these conditions are suspected, definitive diagnosis is best achieved with a contrast-enhanced CT.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliopsoas sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Murphy sign:
Incorrect: Murphy sign is performed by pressing firmly in the right upper quadrant, having the patient inspire, and then exhale slowly. A positive test indicates worsened pain with expiration and can signify underlying cholecystitis.  
❌ McBurney point tenderness  :
Incorrect: McBurney point tenderness is elicited by palpation at McBurney point, which is one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. Tenderness at this location suggests acute appendicitis.  
❌ Rovsing sign  :
Incorrect: Rovsing sign is performed by palpating the left lower quadrant. The test is positive if left lower quadrant palpation elicits pain in the right lower quadrant. A positive test can be suggestive of acute appendicitis.  
❌ Homan sign  :
Incorrect: Homan sign refers to reproducible pain with forced dorsiflexion of the foot. A positive test can be indicative of lower extremity deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the office because of pain and bulging in his groin. The patient reports that standing exacerbates the pain. The patient is otherwise healthy and has never had surgery. He does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the groin that is erythematous and painful to palpation. Scrotal examination is within normal limits. After further evaluation, the patient is diagnosed with a femoral hernia and is scheduled for an endoscopic repair under spinal anesthesia. Which of the following structures is at risk of injury in this patient during the repair?
questions.solution:
This patient with pain and bulging in the groin is found to have a femoral hernia. During femoral hernia repair, sometimes an artery called the aberrant, or accessory, obturator artery can be injured. Typically, the obturator artery branches from the internal iliac artery. In up to 20% of people, however, there can be an additional branch coming from either the inferior epigastric artery or external iliac artery that either replaces the obturator artery or joins it; this phenomenon is called an aberrant or accessory obturator artery. In these patients, the artery runs in close proximity to the femoral ring and courses along the superior pubic rami; so, during hernia repair, it can be injured or stapled.  

When injury occurs, the artery retracts, making it exceedingly difficult to locate and ligate, resulting in uncontrolled bleeding. This artery has been referred to as corona mortis, which means “crown of death,” as injury to it can be fatal.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
❌ Iliohypogastric nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
❌ Genitofemoral nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
✅ Aberrant obturator artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pudendal nerve:
Incorrect: The pudendal nerve is at risk of injury during sacrospinous ligament fixation or pelvic reconstructive procedures, during which sutures are placed in the arcus tendineus fasciae pelvis. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office of his maxillofacial surgeon for follow-up after having dental implant surgery on the lower molars. The patient has inadvertently bitten his inner cheek several times since the surgery due to reduced sensation around the gingiva. The patient also endorses persistent pain in the lower molars, gingiva, chin, and lower lip. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation over the lower teeth and chin. Oral examination shows well-appearing dental implants with superficial lacerations over the bilateral inner cheeks. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured given this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve

questions.solution:
The inferior alveolar nerve courses into the mandibular canal and provides sensation to the roots of the lower teeth. This nerve exits the skull through the mental foramen as the mental nerve and provides sensation to the lower lip and the skin of the chin. Before entering the mandible, the inferior alveolar nerve gives off a motor branch to the mylohyoid muscle, innervating the mylohyoid and anterior belly of the digastric muscles.

Because of its close relation to the teeth, the inferior alveolar nerve is the most commonly injured nerve during oral surgery. It can be injured during third molar extraction, dental implant surgery, or tumor removal. Injury symptoms include paresthesias, complete numbness, or pain in the teeth, gingiva, chin, and lower lip.  



Option Analysis

❌ Buccal nerve  :
Incorrect: The buccal nerve courses into the cheek and pierces the buccinator muscle. This nerve carries sensation from the skin over the cheek and the inner mucous membrane. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
❌ Lingual Nerve  :
Incorrect: The lingual nerve courses into the tongue and carries sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
✅ Inferior alveolar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve carries sensory information from the front of the hard palate, just behind the incisors. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
❌ Lesser palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser palatine nerve carries sensation from the soft palate. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate frequent headaches and worsening peripheral vision, especially when driving. Visual testing reveals bitemporal hemianopsia. The patient undergoes a brain MRI, which demonstrates an anterior pituitary mass. After further workup, the decision is made to perform hypophysectomy. Which of the following locations is most suitable for accessing the pituitary tumor for resection?
questions.solution:
Surgical resection of pituitary gland tumors is accomplished via access through the nasal cavity and into the sphenoid sinus, referred to as a transsphenoidal resection. Resection of pituitary tumors via this approach is easily accomplished as the sphenoid sinus is composed of fragile bone. The sphenoid sinus lies inferior to the sella turcica of the sphenoid bone and communicates with the nasal cavity via the sphenoethmoidal recess.



Option Analysis

❌ Frontal sinus  :
Incorrect: The frontal sinus is not close to the hypophyseal fossa and is not a suitable site for  hypophysectomy.  
✅ Sphenoid sinus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ethmoid bone  :
Incorrect: The ethmoid bone occupies a central position, with its horizontal component forming the central part of the anterior cranial fossa superiorly and the roof of the nasal cavity inferiorly. However, it is not close to the hypophyseal fossa.  
❌ Base of the maxillary sinus  :
Incorrect: The base of the maxillary sinus forms the inferior portion of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. It is not close to the hypophyseal fossa.  
❌ Apex of the maxillary sinus  :
Incorrect: The apex of the maxillary sinus extends into the zygomatic bone. It is not close to the hypophyseal fossa.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate a nodule on the wrist. The nodule appeared on the right wrist one month ago and has slightly increased in size since then. She has not experienced any pain or limitations in her daily activities but is worried it “might be cancerous.” Past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. She does not smoke, consume alcohol, or use illicit substances. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for the findings demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s clinical condition?  


 Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an asymptomatic nodule on the volar aspect of the wrist. This presentation is most consistent with a ganglion cyst based on the above image. In the absence of significant pain or limitations in functional mobility, she should be treated with close observation and surveillance.

Ganglion cysts are the most common soft tissue tumor of the hand. They arise from mucoid degeneration of periarticular structures and outpouching of synovial membranes lining the tendinous sheaths. Clinically, they present most commonly on the dorsal surface of the wrist as a firm, rubbery, smooth nodule (though they can also present on the volar aspect of the wrist, as with this patient). Ganglion cysts are most commonly painless. However, some may become inflamed and cause pain with repetitive wrist activity.

In most cases, ganglion cysts should be treated conservatively with reassurance and close observation as approximately 50% will self-resolve without treatment. If the cyst causes pain or limitations in daily activities, needle aspiration can be attempted. However, many ganglion cysts will recur despite treatment. Finally, surgical excision can be considered if the ganglion cyst is refractory to needle aspiration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reassurance and observation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Needle aspiration  :
Incorrect: Needle aspiration is recommended for ganglion cysts that are bothersome or inflamed. However, more than half of ganglion cysts that are aspirated will recur. This patient does not have symptoms associated with the ganglion cyst. As a result, reassurance and observation would be a better approach.  
❌ Surgical excision  :
Incorrect: Surgical excision is not recommended for the treatment of ganglion cysts. For bothersome or inflamed cysts, needle aspiration is generally preferred over surgical excision.  
❌ Topical nifedipine:
Incorrect: Topical nifedipine is used to treat external hemorrhoids, not ganglion cysts.  
❌ Screw and plate fixation  :
Incorrect: Fractures of wrist and hand bones can be repaired via screw and plate fixation. Fractures can present with pain, reduced range of motion, and overlying soft tissue swelling. In contrast, this patient has an asymptomatic nodule over the volar aspect of the wrist, which is more suggestive of a ganglion cyst.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after vomiting bright red blood. The patient was at home watching television when he suddenly felt nauseous and vomited. He denies any recent trauma. Examination of the eye reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam reveals the presence of ascites and hepatomegaly. An upper endoscopy is performed and confirms the presence of dilated veins in the distal esophagus which have ruptured. Which of the following is most likely present in this patient’s medical history?
questions.solution:
Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the lower third of the esophagus. They are most often caused by portal hypertension, which may be due to liver cirrhosis caused by viral hepatitis or chronic alcohol use. Portal hypertension leads to increased pressure within the small vessels that connect the portal circulation with the systemic circulation. Over time, these small vessels dilate and blood is shunted through these anastomoses, which have lower resistance than the cirrhotic liver. In particular, dilation of the left gastric and azygos veins contributes to the development of esophageal varices.    

If esophageal varices become perforated and rupture, such as when eating hard foods or during vomiting, patients can develop life-threatening hematemesis. Variceal bleeding has a mortality rate of 10-20%. 

Option Analysis

❌ Long-term aspirin use:
Incorrect: Aspirin impairs platelet function and increases the risk of bleeding, thus predisposing patients to gastrointestinal tract bleeding. However, it would be atypical for aspirin to cause portal hypertension and the subsequent formation of esophageal varices. 
✅ Hepatitis C infection :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hepatitis A infection:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A is a virus that can cause acute hepatitis, which can manifest with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and hepatomegaly. However, most infections self-resolve, and patients are unlikely to develop chronic liver damage or portal hypertension from the infection. 
❌ Bisphosphonate overuse:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates can lead to pill-induced esophageal ulcers and potentially esophageal perforation. However, this patient’s endoscopic findings of dilated and ruptured veins is more consistent with esophageal varices, which arise secondary to portal hypertension and subsequent shunting of blood between the left gastric and azygos veins. 
❌ Helicobacter pylori infection:
Incorrect: Infection by Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) can lead to peptic ulcers, which can cause upper gastrointestinal tract bleeding. However, H. pylori would not lead to portal hypertension or the subsequent development of esophageal varices.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain that began four-hours ago. The pain was initially localized in the epigastric region but subsequently spread to other parts of the abdomen. In addition, the patient has had two episodes of bloody emesis. Medical history is notable for intermittent epigastric pain that is exacerbated by meals, which began around a year ago. This has prompted the patient to eat less, and he has experienced a 5 kg (11 lb) weight loss. In addition, the patient has knee osteoarthritis, for which he is taking aspirin. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 94/71 mmHg, and pulse is 112/min. Physical exam is notable for marked abdominal distention and rigidity. Radiographic imaging reveals the finding shown below. Which of the following will most likely provide definitive management of the patient’s condition?



Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Surgical repair of gastrointestinal tract perforation
Placement of hemostatic clip via endoscopy

questions.solution:
This patient has a perforated peptic ulcer, which often manifests with the triad sudden onset abdominal pain, tachycardia, and abdominal rigidity. Patients may also present with abdominal distention secondary to free air accumulation and lightheadedness or syncope secondary to blood loss or sepsis.    

The first step in management is to stabilize the patient. This involves placing at least two large-bore intravenous catheters and starting intravenous fluids. In addition, patients should be started on broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g. piperacillin-tazobactam) for infection prophylaxis and proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for acid suppression. Patients should also be made NPO, a nasogastric tube should be placed, and relevant labs (e.g., complete blood count, type and screen) should be ordered.  

Once the patient has been stabilized, imaging (e.g., x-ray, CT) should be ordered and surgery should be consulted. Definitive treatment of a perforated peptic ulcer involves surgical repair.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Perform nasogastric decompression :
Incorrect: Nasogastric decompression is used in the treatment of a small bowel obstruction (SBO). Patients with SBO can present with abdominal distention, pain, and nausea/vomiting. However, SBO would not cause free air to accumulate under the diaphragm. 
❌ Initiation of pantoprazole therapy :
Incorrect: Intravenous proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are empirically given to patients with upper gastrointestinal tract bleeding. The medication reduces stomach acidity and helps promote clot formation. However, PPIs would not be able to definitively treat a perforated peptic ulcer. 
✅ Surgical repair of gastrointestinal tract perforation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Revascularization of occluded vessel:
Incorrect: Revascularization of an occluded vessel can be used to treat acute mesenteric ischemia, which can manifest as sudden onset severe abdominal pain. However, mesenteric ischemia would not account for the patient’s abdominal distention or the subdiaphragmatic free air seen on x-ray. 
❌ Placement of hemostatic clip via endoscopy:
Incorrect: Endoscopic placement of a hemostatic clip can be used to treat variceal or Dieulafoy lesion bleeding. However, this patient’s finding of subdiaphragmatic free air raises concerns for a gastrointestinal (GI) tract perforation. Endoscopy should be avoided in patients with GI tract perforations since air insufflation and instrumentation may exacerbate the condition.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain which began 12-hours ago. The patient endorses fever, chills, and three episodes of emesis. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, atherosclerosis, and type II diabetes mellitus. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. At arrival, temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 135/77 mmHg, pulse is 83/min, and respiratory rate is 17/min. Abdominal exam is notable for pain and crepitus in the right upper quadrant that is elicited with light palpation. The patient has dry oral mucosal membranes and a delayed capillary refill time. No jaundice or scleral icterus is observed. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. Imaging is ordered, and the results are shown below. Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Liver injury secondary to extrahepatic biliary tract obstruction
Infection of gallbladder by gas-forming pathogens
Infection of common bile duct by gram-negative bacteria
Gallstone obstruction of the small intestines

questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and imaging revealing air in the gallbladder wall, which raises concern for emphysematous cholecystitis. The condition occurs when vascular compromise of the cystic artery results in gallbladder wall ischemia. Necrosis and infection by gas-forming organisms (e.g., Clostridium perfringens, certain Escherichia coli species) subsequently occur. Patients with diabetes mellitus, vascular disease, and immunosuppression are at increased risk of developing the condition, since these factors contribute to both the formation of an ischemic environment and a weakened ability to fight off infections.  

Patients with emphysematous cholecystitis can develop fever and nausea/vomiting, as well as right upper quadrant pain and crepitus due to the presence of air within the gallbladder walls.  

A CT scan is the preferred imaging modality, since it can reveal the presence of an air-fluid-level (Figure 1A) and gas within the gallbladder wall (Figure 1A&B). In contrast, ultrasonography is less accurate, since air within the gallbladder walls can interfere with the organ’s visualization.  

Figure 1: Emphysematous cholecystitis CT scans with annotations  

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Caption: A) Axial CT slice revealing air within the gallbladder wall (arrow) and an air-fluid level within the gallbladder (asterisk). B) Coronal CT slice revealing air within the gallbladder wall (arrow). 

Option Analysis

❌ Liver injury secondary to extrahepatic biliary tract obstruction:
Incorrect: This describes choledocholithiasis, which occurs when a gallstone is lodged in the common bile duct. The condition does manifest with right upper quadrant pain. However, fever is not typically present, and choledocholithiasis would not explain why air is seen in the gallbladder walls on imaging. 
✅ Infection of gallbladder by gas-forming pathogens:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infection of common bile duct by gram-negative bacteria:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes acute cholangitis, which can result in fever, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain. The condition is most commonly due to obstruction of the common bile duct by gallstones. However, acute cholangitis would not typically affect the gallbladder or cause gas to be present in the gallbladder walls.  
❌ Gallstone obstruction of the small intestines:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes gallstone ileus, which occurs when adhesions form between the inflamed gallbladder and nearby small intestine, resulting in the creation of a fistula. Gallstones are able to pass through the fistula, enter the small intestines, and cause an obstruction. However, gallstone ileus would not account for the patient’s imaging findings or the presence of crepitus in the right upper quadrant. 
❌ Inflammation of the pancreas:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis can present with epigastric pain radiating to the back. On imaging, pancreatitis can manifest with calcifications since lipase released from the injured pancreas can break down fatty acids, which subsequently bind to calcium. However, pancreatitis would not account for the right upper quadrant crepitus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after complaining of excruciating chest pain that radiates to the back. He also reports shortness of breath and pain with swallowing. The symptoms began 30 minutes ago, after the patient consumed a large quantity of alcohol and had several episodes of forceful vomiting. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, alcohol use disorder, and liver cirrhosis. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 142/78 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Physical exam shows crepitus on palpation of the upper chest wall. Abdominal exam is notable for hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Order computed tomography of the chest

questions.solution:
This patient has Boerhaave syndrome, which is a transmural rupture of the distal esophagus secondary to increases in intraesophageal pressure. Vomiting is the most common cause of Boerhaave syndrome. The condition can manifest with chest pain, vomiting, and subcutaneous emphysema, which can cause crackles to be heard on palpation of the skin (crepitus).  

Diagnosis is made using x-ray, which will show air that has escaped the esophagus, followed by a contrast esophagram, which will confirm the diagnosis, as well as determine the location and size of the perforation. A CT scan can be used in cases when a contrast esophagram cannot be performed (e.g. if a patient is hemodynamically unstable or uncooperative) or if the results come back inconclusive.  

Management varies depending on the severity of the perforation. Patients with small ruptures can be treated with volume replacement, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and avoidance of all oral intake. In contrast, patients with large perforations, fever, sepsis, pneumomediastinum or pneumothorax will require surgical intervention.   

Option Analysis

❌ Perform diagnostic endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient likely has Boerhaave syndrome, which is a rupture of the distal esophagus due to sudden increases in esophageal pressure. The work-up process involves a chest x-ray followed by esophagram to confirm the diagnosis. Endoscopy is not used in the work-up of Boerhaave syndrome, since the procedure can lead to further esophageal damage.  
❌ Administration of octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to treat acute variceal bleeding. The patient’s history of alcohol use disorder and liver cirrhosis increase his risk of developing esophageal varices. However, it would be atypical for a variceal bleeding to cause crepitus on palpation, which suggests subcutaneous emphysema.  
❌ Immediate surgical repair:
Incorrect: Surgical intervention may be needed to close the ruptured esophageal segment. However, a chest x-ray or esophagram should be ordered first to confirm the diagnosis, as well as to assess the location and size of the perforation.  
❌ Order computed tomography of the chest  :
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation raises concerns for Boerhaave syndrome. A CT scan is an alternative work-up approach for patients who are hemodynamically unstable or have inconclusive esophagram results. In contrast, this patient is hemodynamically stable and an esophagram should be attempted first.   
✅ Perform contrast esophagram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman undergoes a cardiac ablation for treatment of symptomatic atrial fibrillation. Several weeks postoperatively, the patient reports shortness of breath with exertion and difficulty initiating a deep breath. She additionally reports a morning headache as well as daytime fatigue. She has not noted any voice changes. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Vitals are within normal limits. Diminished breath sounds are noted over the right lung. No cardiac murmurs are appreciated. A chest radiograph is obtained, as demonstrated below. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?  



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and X-rays findings suggestive of injury to the phrenic nerve following a cardiac ablation procedure. Cardiac ablation is a standard procedure that uses radiofrequency or cryothermal energy to manage supraventricular arrhythmias non-pharmacologically.  

While this procedure is considered low risk, several structures are at risk of injury, including the phrenic nerve, right heart structures, and vascular access sites. Injury to the phrenic nerve results in ipsilateral paralysis of the diaphragm, which can be visualized on chest X-ray as elevation of the hemidiaphragm on the affected side.  Patients with a paralyzed hemidiaphragm can present with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, recurrent pneumonia, anxiety, insomnia, morning headache, excessive daytime somnolence, orthopnea, fatigue, or difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Phrenic nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve does not commonly occur with cardiac ablation procedures. Moreover, unilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve would manifest with hoarseness.
❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: Vascular injury would manifest with evidence of hematoma, swelling, or diminished pulses over the access site. This patient’s chest x-ray suggests injury to a different structure. 
❌ Pulmonary vein :
Incorrect: Injury to the pulmonary vein can occur following cardiac ablation procedures. This patient’s chest x-ray suggests injury to the phrenic nerve, which can result in pulmonary vein stenosis and subsequent pulmonary hypertension. 
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: Direct cardiac damage following cardiac ablation can occur, including injury to the tricuspid valve. However, injury to this structure would manifest with a systolic murmur, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being assaulted at a local bar. He sustained facial trauma, including multiple lacerations and multiple punches to the face. He reports right-sided jaw pain and teeth malalignment. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mmHg. CT of the facial bones demonstrates a right-sided displaced mandibular fracture. The patient is subsequently taken to the operating room for operative repair by otolaryngology. The anesthetist injects a local anesthetic agent between the coronoid notch and the pterygomandibular raphe of the right mandible. Injection of an anesthetic into this space is likely to anesthetize which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
An inferior alveolar nerve block is the most common anesthetic procedure performed in dental surgery.  The most critical clinical landmarks used to locate the inferior alveolar nerve include the coronoid notch and the pterygomandibular raphe–the preferred needle insertion site lies between these two landmarks. Successful injection anesthetizes all mandibular teeth to the median plane, the skin and mucous membrane of the lower lip, the labial alveolar mucosa and gingiva, and the skin of the chin.


Other nerves anesthetized during dental procedures are summarized in the table below:  


Option Analysis

❌ Greater palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The greater palatine nerve is best anesthetized by injecting an anesthetic into the greater palatine foramen. This nerve block anesthetizes the palatal mucosa and lingual gingiva posterior to the maxillary canine teeth and underlying palate. This nerve emerges between the 2nd and the 3rd molars.  
❌ Lesser palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser palatine nerves pass through the lesser palatine foramina posterior to the greater palatine foramen. This nerve supplies sensation to the soft palate, tonsils, and uvula.  
❌ Nasopalatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The nasopalatine nerve can be anesthetized via anesthetic injection into the incisive fossa. Affected tissues include the palatal mucosa, the lingual gingiva and alveolar bone of the six anterior maxillary teeth, and the hard palate.  
✅ Inferior alveolar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anterior superior alveolar nerve  :
Incorrect: The anterior superior alveolar nerve (or anterior superior dental nerve) is a branch of the infraorbital nerve that innervates the anterior teeth and joins the middle superior alveolar nerve to form the superior dental plexus.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall on an outstretched hand. During the fall, the patient hyperextended his right wrist and felt a “pop.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals ecchymosis and swelling of the volar aspect of the right wrist. A lateral radiograph of the right wrist is obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures is at risk of injury based on this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
After a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury), this patient presents with evidence of volar swelling and deformity. Imaging demonstrates the “spilled teacup” sign, pathognomonic for a lunate dislocation.

Lunate dislocations represent a relatively uncommon pattern of wrist injuries, but the most common mechanism of injury involves a FOOSH injury or high-energy trauma. The capitate stays in place in lunate dislocations, while the lunate is displaced. A closely related injury pattern is perilunate dislocation, in which the lunate stays, but the capitate is displaced.

Clinically, lunate dislocations present with pain on the volar-radial aspect of the wrist, with associated pain and swelling. Assessment of median nerve function is paramount in patients with this injury pattern, as lunate dislocations are often associated with compressive radiculopathy of the nerve. The most common radiographic feature associated with lunate dislocations is the spilled tea-cup sign on lateral x-rays, which represents the lunate being pushed off the radius into the palm.  

Option Analysis

✅ Median nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury does not typically occur with lunate dislocations. Instead, it more commonly occurs with humeral shaft fractures.  
❌ Ulnar nerve  :
Incorrect: Injury to the ulnar nerve more commonly occurs due to injury to the hook of the hamate, not the lunate.  
❌ Radial artery  :
Incorrect: Radial artery injuries are uncommon in the setting of lunate dislocations.  
❌ Ulnar collateral ligament  :
Incorrect: The ulnar collateral ligament is not typically damaged in the setting of lunate dislocations.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed rollover motor vehicle collision (MVC). Emergency medical services report the patient was wearing a seatbelt and was retrieved from an inverted vehicle. A cervical collar was secured in the field. The patient is alert and oriented to person but not place or time. On neck exam, she expresses pain with movement and is tender to palpation. An emergent X-ray reveals a fracture of the C1/C2 foramina. A subsequent axial CT is shown below. Which of the following is a potentially severe complication of this fracture?  


Image credit: Wikipedia.

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the vertebral dens

questions.solution:
This patient was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision (MVC) wherein the vehicle was inverted. In these scenarios, it is important to consider head and neck injuries, as the body is secure (if the patient has worn a seatbelt), leaving the head at increased risk of traumatic forces and blunt injury. For this reason, 80% of burst fractures (Jefferson fractures) occur due to MVCs. Of note, the term “Jefferson fracture” refers to a fracture of the C1 vertebra. However, concomitant fractures of the C2 vertebra are commonplace.

The first step in suspected vertebral injuries is to stabilize the neck until radiographic imaging (X-ray and CT, or CT-angiography). Treatment of the injury is dependent on the severity of the fracture, from simple immobilization to the use of a Halo stabilizer. There are many varieties of Jefferson fractures, which are classified with attention to orthopedic treatment modalities.
