Overall, it is essential to remember the anatomic relationship between the C1 and C2 vertebrae with the vertebral artery. Bruising or laceration of the vertebral artery will result in basilar insufficiency and must be emergently evaluated via CT angiogram.

Option Analysis

❌ Atlanto-axial instability:
Incorrect: Atlanto-axial instability is a common feature of Down syndrome or other connective tissue disorders affecting the transverse ligament.  
❌ Avascular necrosis of the vertebral dens:
Incorrect: The vertebral bodies and the dens typically have abundant access to arterial blood flow, even in the setting of fractures. Avascular necrosis is more commonly a concern for hip and wrist fractures.  
✅ Basilar insufficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Middle cerebral artery insufficiency  :
Incorrect: The MCA is primarily supplied by the carotid artery. In a C1 or C2 vertebral fracture, the vertebral arteries are at most risk, not the carotids.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate acute chest pain. Before obtaining a clinical history, the patient becomes unresponsive. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 186/92 mmHg. A chest radiograph is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Large cell adenocarcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of acute chest pain. Chest radiography demonstrates a widened mediastinum, which can be due to many possible etiologies. However, of the diagnoses listed, only a thoracic aortic aneurysm is causative of a widened mediastinum.  

The mediastinum is the central thoracic cavity that contains the heart, esophagus, trachea, thoracic duct, thymus, and lymph nodes of the central chest. Radiographically, this space is defined by the right heart border, ascending aorta, superior vena cava, aortic knob, descending aorta, and left heart border. A widened mediastinum is defined as greater than 6-8 cm and can be caused by several pathologies.  

Most importantly, the life-threatening etiologies of a widened mediastinum include aortic pathologies such as traumatic rupture of the aorta, aortic dissection, and thoracic aortic aneurysm. Additional etiologies of a widened mediastinum include hilar lymphadenopathy, mediastinal masses, mediastinitis, cardiac tamponade, and vascular anomalies.   

Option Analysis

✅ Thoracic aortic aneurysm  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Large cell adenocarcinoma of the lung:
Incorrect: The lung's large cell adenocarcinoma presents radiographically as a large radiopaque mass with irregular margins. It would not typically present with mediastinal widening.
❌ Massive pulmonary embolism :
Incorrect: A massive pulmonary embolism often demonstrates pulmonary venous congestion and prominence of the right heart border. It would not cause mediastinal widening. 
❌ Left ventricular aneurysm:
Incorrect: Left ventricular aneurysm may demonstrate an enlarged cardiac silhouette but would not cause widening of the mediastinum.   
❌ Esophageal rupture :
Incorrect: Esophageal rupture is most commonly caused by instrumentation, trauma, or forceful vomiting. Patients present with severe retrosternal chest pain that may increase with swallowing or deep breathing. While patients can have some widening of the mediastinum, patients also frequently have subcutaneous and mediastinal emphysema.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room after vomiting bright red blood several times over the past hour. The patient was at home reading a book when she suddenly felt nauseous and vomited. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 95/66 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. Examination of the eyes reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam reveals hepatomegaly. Two peripheral intravenous catheters are placed, and the patient is started on a normal saline infusion. Repeat of the vitals reveals a blood pressure of 120/77 mmHg, and pulse of 86/min. Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin level of 9.2 g/dL. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting

questions.solution:
Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the lower third of the esophagus. They are most often caused by portal hypertension, which may be due to liver cirrhosis brought about by viral hepatitis or chronic alcohol use. Patients with esophageal varices can have life-threatening hematemesis if the varices rupture. This complication may occur when eating hard food or during vomiting.  

The first step in management is to place at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards, intravenous fluids, octreotide, and broad-spectrum antibiotics can be administered. Octreotide induces splanchnic vasoconstriction, decreases portal blood flow, and ultimately reduces the amount of blood lost via the varices. Broad spectrum antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone, are administered to prevent infection. Antibiotic administration is particularly important in patients with liver cirrhosis, as they are at increased risk of developing spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Patients should also be made NPO.  

After the patient is hemodynamically stable, endoscopy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis and ligate the bleeding site.



Option Analysis

❌ Initiation of propranolol therapy:
Incorrect: Propranolol can be used for bleeding prophylaxis in patients with esophageal varices. However, this patient has active bleeding, as suggested by the bright red emesis, tachycardia, and borderline hypotension. Propranolol is ineffective at stopping active variceal bleeding. 
❌ Perform upper gastrointestinal endoscopy :
Incorrect: This patient likely has variceal bleeding. The first step is to ensure the patient is hemodynamically stable. Next, medications such as octreotide and broad-spectrum antibiotics can be administered to reduce bleeding and prevent infection, respectively. Only then should an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy be performed to confirm the diagnosis and stop the bleeding.  
❌ Initiation of whole blood transfusion :
Incorrect: Although this patient has an active gastrointestinal tract bleed, her hemoglobin level is not low enough to warrant a transfusion. Generally, a transfusion is indicated only when a patient’s hemoglobin level falls below 7 g/dL. 
❌ Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting:
Incorrect: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) is a procedure that can be performed on patients with recurring or treatment-resistant variceal bleeding secondary to portal hypertension. In contrast, this patient has no history of prior bleeding. Moreover, medications (e.g. octreotide) and endoscopic procedures (e.g. band ligation) should be tried first before proceeding to TIPS.  
✅  Initiation of octreotide therapy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of excruciating chest pain. The patient endorses shortness of breath and pain with swallowing. The symptoms began one-and-a-half hours ago, after the patient consumed large quantities of whiskey with friends and subsequently had several episodes of forceful vomiting. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder, peptic ulcer disease, and hepatitis B infection. Three days ago, he underwent endoscopic evaluation for peptic ulcer disease. The patient’s temperature is 37.9°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 25/min. Physical exam is notable for crepitus on palpation of the upper chest wall. Chest radiography reveals a widened mediastinum. Which of the following risk factors most likely contributed to the patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has Boerhaave syndrome, which is transmural rupture of the distal esophagus secondary to increases in intraesophageal pressure. Vomiting is the most common cause of Boerhaave syndrome. Other potential causes include epileptic seizures, abdominal trauma, and childbirth, all of which can increase pressure within the esophagus. The condition can manifest with chest pain, vomiting, and subcutaneous emphysema, which can cause crackles to be heard on palpation of the skin.  

One commonly tested concept is the difference between Boerhaave syndrome and a Mallory-Weiss tear. Boerhaave syndrome is much more severe, and since it involves a full-thickness tear, air can escape into the mediastinum causing crepitus and Hammond sign (precordial crackles that occur synchronously with the heartbeat). In contrast, Mallory-Weiss syndrome causes only a partial thickness tear, so no air is able to escape the esophagus. 

Option Analysis

❌ Peptic ulcer disease :
Incorrect: An untreated gastric ulcer may perforate, allowing air and gastric contents to enter the abdominal cavity. This would cause pneumoperitoneum, and an x-ray would reveal subdiaphragmatic free air. In contrast, it would be atypical for a perforated gastric ulcer to cause mediastinal widening.  
❌ Alcohol use disorder :
Incorrect: Excess alcohol use would not directly contribute to the development of esophageal perforation. However, alcohol overconsumption may lead to repeated episodes of forceful emesis, which can in turn cause esophageal perforation.  
❌ Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Incorrect: It is possible for an endoscope to perforate the esophagus. This would account for the patient’s chest pain, crepitus, and widened mediastinum. However, the endoscopic procedure was performed three days ago. It would be unusual for an esophageal perforation to first become symptomatic several days later. 
✅ Repeated episodes of emesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hepatitis B infection :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B infection can lead to liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension. This can predispose patients to developing esophageal varices. However, this patient’s presentation of chest pain and crepitus after several episodes of forceful emesis is more consistent with Boerhaave syndrome. Hepatitis B infection is not a risk factor for developing this condition.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of a 6-week history of intermittent abdominal pain. The patient states the pain is located mainly in the right upper quadrant and typically occurs after meals. The patient denies any past medical history. He states his father had his spleen removed at a young age but is unsure of the details. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and scleral icterus. There is no pain on palpation of the abdomen. The spleen tip is palpable. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?  

Laboratory value  Result (U.S. conventional units) Results (SI units) 
 Hematologic   
 Leukocyte count   6,000/mm3  6 *10^9/L 
 Platelet count  175,000/mm3   175 *10^9/L 
 Hemoglobin  10.1 g/dL  101 g/L 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)   84  μm3  84 fL 
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)  40 g/dL  400 g/L 
 Red cell distribution width (RDW)  15%  - 
 Reticulocyte count   8.1%  -

choices.text: Intermittent common bile duct obstruction with brown pigment gallstones
Intermittent gallbladder obstruction with black pigment gallstones
Spasm of the biliary tracts secondary to cholesterol stone obstruction

questions.solution:
This young adult, who presents with complaints of postprandial right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain and laboratory results showing anemia and elevated mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), likely has black pigment gallstone formation secondary to hereditary spherocytosis (HS).  

Black pigment gallstones form when the bile contains a high concentration of unconjugated bilirubin in the bilirubin tree, such as in patients with chronic extravascular red cell hemolysis. This can be seen in patients with sickle cell disease or hereditary spherocytosis. Brown pigment stones, on the other hand, can precipitate when the biliary tract is infected by certain microbes (e.g., E. coli, Clonorchis sinensis) that produce β-glucuronidase, an enzyme that unconjugates previously conjugated bilirubin. Unconjugated bilirubin is water insoluble and combines with calcium to form brown pigment stones.  

However, the most common gallstones are cholesterol stones. Bile formation is the only significant pathway for the body to eliminate excess cholesterol, either as free cholesterol or as bile salts. Cholesterol becomes water-soluble when combined with bile salts; therefore, when cholesterol concentrations exceed the solubility capacity of bile salts (supersaturation), cholesterol stones can form. Conditions that increase cholesterol synthesis (e.g. obesity) or decrease bile salt formation (e.g., malabsorptive conditions, medications such as fibrates) predispose individuals to forming gallstones. Additionally, hypomotility of the gallbladder results in bile stasis, which also promotes gallstone formation (e.g., pregnant women, patients on total parenteral nutrition). This patient did not have risk factors for cholesterol stones. Instead, his physical exam and laboratory values suggested a risk for pigment stones.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Acalculous inflammation of the gallbladder :
Incorrect: Acalculous cholecystitis is an acute inflammatory disorder of the gallbladder that is most commonly seen in conditions that cause biliary stasis, such as in critically ill patients (e.g., multiorgan failure, post-surgery, trauma) or those on prolonged total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Patients typically present with fever and persistent right upper quadrant pain, neither of which are seen in this patient.  
❌ Intermittent common bile duct obstruction with brown pigment gallstones :
Incorrect: Brown pigment stones are associated with bacterial (e.g. E. coli) or parasitic (e.g. liver fluke) infections of the biliary system. Brown pigment stones are prevalent in Asian countries but are rarely seen in patients in the United States. Additionally, this patient’s underlying condition predisposes him to a different type of stone composition.
✅ Intermittent gallbladder obstruction with black pigment gallstones:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Spasm of the biliary tracts secondary to cholesterol stone obstruction:
Incorrect: Spasm of the biliary tract secondary to obstruction of the common bile duct is seen in patients with choledocholithiasis. Although cholesterol gallstones are the most common stones found in the gallbladder, this patient’s underlying condition predisposes him to a different type of stone composition. 
❌ Fibrotic and calcified gallbladder:
Incorrect: Porcelain gallbladder refers to a fibrotic and calcified gallbladder that occurs after recurrent episodes of cholecystitis. Although this patient’s current condition may predispose him to developing porcelain gallbladder, it most commonly presents much later in life (usually around the 6th decade).

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate acute onset chest pain. The patient was lifting a heavy box at work when he experienced the sensation of intense pressure across his chest. His past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, end-stage renal disease, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 144/84 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% of room air. Examination demonstrates a diaphoretic male in moderate distress clutching the front of his chest. A dialysis graft is noted in the left upper extremity. An initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. The procedure required to treat this patient’s disease process requires access through the following blood vessels?  

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with classic comorbidities presents with characteristic features of acute coronary syndrome, including exertional chest pressure not relieved by rest. His initial electrocardiogram meets the criteria for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), with notable elevations in the anterolateral leads of the heart with reciprocal depressions inferiorly. Given these findings, this patient most likely has occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery.   

In the setting of acute myocardial infarction, revascularization via percutaneous coronary artery intervention (PCI) remains paramount (with a “door to balloon” time ideally <90 minutes). During this procedure, either the radial artery or femoral artery are accessed for catheter insertion. This catheter is fed to the diseased coronary artery, which is subsequently stented to restore blood flow to the ischemic portion of the heart. Indications for performing PCI include acute STEMI and unstable angina.  



Option Analysis

✅ Femoral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Femoral vein:
Incorrect: The venous system does not allow percutaneous access to the coronary arteries. Access through the femoral vein would only allow access to the venous system and the right side of the heart (typically used for ablation procedures).  
❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: The radial artery is reasonable access for PCI; however, a different site should be accessed given this patient's history of end-stage renal disease and left arm dialysis access site. 
❌ Internal thoracic artery :
Incorrect: The internal thoracic artery is not a commonly used site for percutaneous coronary artery intervention. 
❌ Carotid artery:
Incorrect: The carotid artery is not accessed for PCI, as there is a high risk of intraprocedural injury resulting in a stroke.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was a restrained driver when he suddenly slammed into the back of a stopped truck while traveling approximately 70 miles per hour. Upon arrival at the emergency department, the patient has a Glasgow coma scale of 4 and is subsequently intubated for airway protection. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 67/30 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising over the anterior chest wall, but no crepitus is felt on palpation. A chest X-ray is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Rotary force applied to the torso
Vertical compression force applied to the neck
Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest

questions.solution:
Traumatic rupture of the aorta is a potentially life-threatening injury, with most cases occurring due to sudden deceleration related to automobile accidents.  

Approximately 80-90% of aortic tears occur in the descending aorta at the isthmus, which is just distal to the left subclavian artery and firmly tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. The more mobile aortic arch swings forward during deceleration, producing a shearing force or “whiplash effect” on the aorta at the isthmus. This shearing force at the isthmus results in a tear. A widened mediastinum may be visible on chest radiography. Many patients will have retrosternal or scapular pain.  

Less common sites of aortic trauma include the ascending aorta, distal descending aorta at the level of the diaphragm, and the mid-thoracic descending aorta because these areas of the aorta are more anatomically fixed and thus less subject to movement in rapid deceleration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Sudden deceleration :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Direct, blunt anterior chest trauma :
Incorrect: Blunt chest trauma may result in sternal fractures, rib fractures, and cardiac or pulmonary contusions. It is not the most common mechanism of injury associated with aortic rupture. 
❌ Rotary force applied to the torso:
Incorrect: A rotary force applied to the torso is not the most common mechanism associated with traumatic rupture of the aorta. 
❌ Vertical compression force applied to the neck:
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture and is considered an unstable C-spine injury. It often occurs due to a vertical compression force applied to the neck. 
❌ Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest:
Incorrect: Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest is a less common cause of the traumatic aortic rupture. Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest is more likely to result in cardiac tamponade, pneumothorax, or perforation of the right ventricle.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after an episode of hematemesis. The patient was at home reading a book when he felt nauseous and produced bright-red emesis. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is currently taking propranolol and atorvastatin. The patient consumes 1-2 beers per week and has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Upon arrival, blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg and pulse is 85/min. Physical exam reveals a nontender and nondistended abdomen with no hepatomegaly. Endoscopy is performed, and visualization of the stomach reveals a protruding 2.7-mm arteriole that has eroded the overlying mucosa. There is active spurting of blood from the vessel. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Placement of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
Endoscopic thermal coagulation of bleeding site

questions.solution:
This patient has a Dieulafoy lesion, which is a rare condition characterized by an unusually dilated arteriole that erodes the overlying mucosa and starts bleeding. Dieulafoy lesions are most often located in the proximal stomach along the lesser curvature.    

The etiology of Dieulafoy lesions is unknown. However, individuals with comorbidities (e.g., cardiopulmonary dysfunction, chronic renal failure) and those taking medications that increase bleeding risk (e.g., aspirin, warfarin) have higher chances of developing Dieulafoy lesions. Patients with Dieulafoy lesions may experience hematemesis, melena, and hematochezia.    

Patients with bleeding from a Dieulafoy lesion should have at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Patients should also be started on intravenous fluids and a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and be made NPO (nothing by mouth).  

Once hemodynamic stability has been achieved, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and stop the bleeding. Hemostasis can be achieved by epinephrine injections along with thermocoagulation or hemostatic clip placement.    

In cases wherein endoscopy cannot stop the bleeding, a subtotal gastrectomy may be necessary.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of intravenous octreotide :
Incorrect: Octreotide can help reduce bleeding from ruptured esophageal varices. However, this patient has no signs of liver cirrhosis or portal hypertension. As a result, it is unlikely that portacaval shunting and esophageal vein dilation would have developed in this patient. 
❌ Placement of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt  :
Incorrect: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) involves creating an artificial shunt between the inflowing portal vein and outflowing hepatic vein. This reduces portal hypertension. TIPS can treat recurrent variceal bleeding or first-time variceal bleeding that is refractory to medical or endoscopic management. However, TIPS is not effective in treating bleeding from a Dieulafoy lesion.  
❌ Surgical gastrectomy :
Incorrect: This patient has a Dieulafoy lesion, which is an unusually dilated arteriole that erodes the overlying mucosa and starts bleeding. Historically, surgical gastrectomy was used to treat bleeding from Dieulafoy lesions. However, recent advances in endoscopy have made safer and less invasive interventions available. 
❌ Initiation of ampicillin-sulbactam therapy:
Incorrect: Ampicillin-sulbactam is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that provides coverage against aerobic and anaerobic pathogens. It can be administered to patients with gastrointestinal tract perforation (e.g., esophageal rupture, perforated gastric ulcer) to reduce infection risk. However, this patient’s endoscopic findings are more consistent with that of a Dieulafoy lesion. Patients with bleeding from a Dieulafoy lesion would not need antibiotic therapy. 
✅ Endoscopic thermal coagulation of bleeding site:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain that began 18-hours ago. In addition, the patient endorses nausea and one episode of non-bloody non-bilious emesis. Past medical history is notable for three uncomplicated vaginal deliveries and abdominal pain that is exacerbated by fatty meals. On arrival, temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 130/78 mmHg, heart rate is 76/min, and respiratory rate is 17/min. Abdominal exam reveals right upper quadrant and epigastric tenderness. Cardiovascular and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the work-up of this patient’s condition?  

 Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Hemoglobin  12.7 g/dL  127 g/L 
 Leukocyte Count  10,000/mm3  10*109/L 
 Total Bilirubin  3.2 mg/dL  54.72 µmol/L 
 Conjugated Bilirubin  2.5 mg/dL  42.75 µmol/L 
 Aspartate Aminotransferase  72 U/L  72 U/L 
 Alanine Aminotransferase  77 U/L  77 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in the setting of a probable history of gallstones. These factors raise concern for choledocholithiasis, which is the presence of stones within the common bile duct.   

Patients can present with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, nausea, and vomiting. In addition, patients can develop pruritus and jaundice secondary to biliary tract obstruction. Laboratory testing will reveal elevated liver enzymes and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.   

If the obstruction occurs distal to where the pancreatic duct joints the common bile duct, then patients can develop pancreatitis, which manifests with epigastric pain. In this case, laboratory testing will also reveal elevated lipase and amylase levels.  

The first step in diagnosis is to perform a RUQ ultrasound, which will show dilated biliary ducts. If the ultrasound is negative but clinical suspicion is high, then further imaging such as magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) should be performed.  



Option Analysis

❌ Obtain abdominal CT:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. These symptoms raise concerns for choledocholithiasis.   Abdominal CTs can detect many pathologies in the upper abdomen, but they expose patients to unnecessary ionizing radiation when the primary concern focuses on the common bile duct. Moreover, many gallstones are isodense to bile, making it difficult to visualize them on CT. As a result, ultrasound is the preferred first-line imaging modality.  
❌ Order abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which raises concerns for a gallstone-related etiology (e.g., choledocholithiasis, ascending cholangitis). However, most gallstones are radiolucent. As a result, x-rays are rarely used in the work-up of gallstone-related etiologies.
❌ Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: An endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) can be used in the work-up and treatment of patients with choledocolithiasis. However, most patients (including the one in this vignette) should first get an ultrasound. The exceptions are high risk patients, such as those who have a total bilirubin level exceeding 4 mg/dL or patients with acute cholangitis. These patients can proceed directly to ERCP. 
✅ Perform right upper quadrant ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Order urease breath test:
Incorrect: A urease breath test is used in the work-up of a suspected Helicobacter pylori infection. Patients with this infection are at increased risk of developing peptic ulcers, which can present as epigastric pain that is exacerbated by meals. However, a peptic ulcer would not explain the patients elevated liver enzymes or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a mass on the right side of his groin. The patient first noted the mass after helping his daughter move to a new home. He reports sharp discomfort in the right groin worsens with walking and heavy lifting. Resting supine decreases the severity of the pain. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. BMI is 37 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament which increases in size when the patient coughs. There is no overlying erythema or warmth. The patient is referred to a surgeon and scheduled for a laparoscopic repair.



Which of the following landmarks will help the surgeon to differentiate a direct versus an indirect inguinal hernia?
questions.solution:
This patient with an examination finding of a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament has most likely developed an inguinal hernia. Inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament. They are classified into direct and indirect hernias. The inferior epigastric vessels are easily visible during laparoscopic hernia repair and are an important landmark to differentiate between the two types of inguinal hernias.

Direct inguinal hernias result from weakness of the transversalis fascia, which makes up the floor of the Hesselbach triangle. Other boundaries include the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the inguinal ligament inferiorly, and the rectus abdominis muscle medially.

Indirect inguinal hernias are the most common type of groin hernia and result from a patent processus vaginalis. They are bounded medially by the inferior epigastric artery. The herniated abdominal contents enter through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal and exit through the superficial inguinal ring. The deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the transversalis fascia located at the midpoint of the inguinal ligament (between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle).

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Structure A represents the inguinal ligament, which stretches from the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle. It is an important landmark to differentiate between inguinal and femoral hernias but cannot differentiate between direct and indirect inguinal hernias.
❌ B:
Incorrect: Structure B represents the transversalis fascia, which forms the posterior wall of inguinal canal, and its weakness can result in the development of direct inguinal hernia. However, the transversalis fascia is not used for inguinal hernia differentiation.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: Structure D represents the deep inguinal ring, which is the entrance site of the inguinal canal. It is found above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament, lateral to the epigastric vessels.
❌ E:
Incorrect: Structure E represents the spermatic cord. Indirect inguinal hernias follow the path of the spermatic cord via the deep inguinal ring. However, the spermatic cord is not used for inguinal hernia differentiation..

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining an injury to the right middle finger. The patient was outside playing baseball with his friends when he sustained the injury. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 115/79 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination demonstrates an inability to extend the right middle finger's distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. Flexion at the DIP joint of this digit is preserved. A picture of the patient’s hand is demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury associated with this pathology?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Direct force to the third digit held in extension
Lateral force applied to the third digit
Sudden hyperextension of the third digit held in flexion
Direct force applied to a clenched fist

questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of a mallet finger (baseball finger), which refers to an injury to the extensor digitorum as it crosses the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this pathology is a direct force to the digit held in extension. This injury pattern results in an inability to extend the finger at the DIP joint.

Mallet finger is the most common closed tendon injury of the finger and is a common injury pattern in baseball players. The mechanism of injury involves a direct force to a digit held in extension, such as when a baseball strikes the distal end of the finger resulting in forced flexion of the DIP joint. Clinically, this manifests with pain and swelling over the dorsum of the DIP joint, DIP flexion deformity, and an inability to extend the DIP joint actively.

Treatment for a simple mallet finger (without an associated fracture) involves splinting the finger in extension for six to eight weeks. If left in flexion, the finger is more prone to developing osteoarthritis or a swan neck deformity. If the mallet finger is associated with a fracture, surgical referral, in addition to splinting, is indicated.

Option Analysis

✅ Direct force to the third digit held in extension  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the third digit  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the third digit would likely result in a dislocation injury, manifesting with difficulty both flexing and extending the affected joint.  
❌ Fall on an outstretched hand  :
Incorrect: Wrist pathologies (e.g., scaphoid fracture, distal radius fracture) can arise following a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). In contrast, this patient presents with drooping and an inability to extend the fingertip, which is more consistent with a mallet finger.  
❌ Sudden hyperextension of the third digit held in flexion  :
Incorrect: This mechanism of action will result in injury to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. Patients with this injury pattern will extend, but not flex, the fingertip.  
❌ Direct force applied to a clenched fist  :
Incorrect: A direct force applied to a clenched fist will often fracture the fifth metacarpal. This fracture pattern is termed a boxer fracture. In contrast, this patient presents with drooping and an inability to extend the fingertip, which is more consistent with a mallet finger.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after an episode of hematemesis. The patient spent last night at a bar drinking with his colleagues. After leaving the bar, he vomited four times, and during the last episode, he noticed bright-red blood mixed with the vomitus. Past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia and peripheral artery disease, for which he is taking atorvastatin and aspirin. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 130/74 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 17/min. During the physical exam, the patient is anxious but not in acute distress. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Laboratory testing yields the results shown below. Which of the following additional findings will most likely develop in this patient?

Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Sodium  142 mg/dL  142 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.8 mg/dL  3.8 mmol/L 
 Chloride  100 mg/dL  100 mmol/L 
 Bicarbonate  35 mg/dL  35 mmol/L

choices.text: Passage of bright-red blood from the anus
Presence of multiple spider angioma on the body

questions.solution:
This patient likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear, which is a partial-thickness laceration of the esophageal mucosa secondary to forceful and repeated vomiting. Mallory-Weiss tears can lead to gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.    

GI bleeding can be divided into upper and lower bleeding. Upper GI bleeding arises above the ligament of Treitz (also termed suspensory ligament of the duodenum) and includes bleeding from the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum. Symptoms include hematemesis (vomiting of fresh red blood), ‘coffee ground’ vomitus (vomiting of blood that has been oxidized by stomach acids), and melena (black and tarry stools). In rare cases, if an upper GI lesion is bleeding briskly, blood may pass through the remainder of the GI tract too quickly to be oxidized, in which case fresh blood may pass from the anus. However, it would be highly unusual for a Mallory-Weis tear to bleed so severely, particularly in this patient with stable vital signs.    

In contrast, lower GI bleeding arises below the ligament of Treitz and includes bleeding from the small intestine distal to the duodenum, large intestines, rectum, and anus. Typical presentation includes hematochezia (fresh blood passing through the anus).    

If individuals lose significant quantities of blood via GI bleeding, they can develop anemia. 

Option Analysis

✅ Black tarry stools:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Passage of bright-red blood from the anus:
Incorrect: Patients with lower gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding may notice bright-red blood mixed with their stool. In contrast, this patient most likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear, which is an upper GI bleed caused by forceful and repeated vomiting. Blood from an upper GI bleed will have oxidized by the time it is expelled and appear dark in color. 
❌ Foul-smelling oily stools:
Incorrect: Foul-smelling and oily stools may be observed in patients with fat malabsorption. This can be due to various conditions, including pancreatic insufficiency, inflammatory bowel disease, and Giardia infection. However, it would be atypical for a patient to develop this symptom after an episode of GI bleeding. 
❌ Presence of multiple spider angioma on the body:
Incorrect: Patients with cirrhosis can develop multiple spider angiomas on their bodies, due to the damaged liver’s inability to metabolize estrogen. Hyperestrogenism in turn causes vasodilation. However, this patient lacks symptoms suggestive of liver cirrhosis, such as jaundice, ascites, or hepatomegaly. 
❌ Sloughed mucosa mixed with stool:
Incorrect: This describes currant jelly stools, which occur when sloughed mucosa, blood, and mucus are mixed with the stool. This phenomenon is often found in patients with intestinal ischemia or intussusception, both of which can lead to lower GI bleeding. In contrast, this patient has upper GI bleeding. Blood from an upper GI bleed will have oxidized by the time it is expelled with feces.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency room for hematemesis that occurred an hour ago. Earlier in the evening, the patient had consumed large quantities of vodka at a bar and subsequently vomited four times. The last episode of vomiting resulted in a bright red emesis. At arrival, temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 116/75 mmHg, and pulse is 68/min. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. While in the emergency room, the patient has another episode of hematemesis. Two large-bore peripheral catheters are placed, and the patient is stated on intravenous fluids and pantoprazole. Which of the following interventions is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a Mallory-Weiss tear, also termed gastro-esophageal laceration syndrome, which manifests as a longitudinal, partial-thickness tear of the gastroesophageal junction mucosa. The condition most often occurs due to forceful vomiting, which increases intra-abdominal pressure.      

Patients with Mallory-Weiss tears, similar to those with other upper gastrointestinal bleeds, should get at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards they should be started on intravenous fluids and a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).    

For patients whose bleeding has spontaneously stopped, no additional intervention is required. For those with active bleeding, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and achieve hemostasis. This can be achieved via thermal coagulation, hemoclips, or band ligation. 

Option Analysis

❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: A chest radiograph is useful in the work-up of patients with esophageal perforation. Imaging may show mediastinal widening and pneumomediastinum, due to free air accumulation. Esophageal perforation will cause dyspnea, chest pain, crepitus on palpation, and crackles on auscultation. In contrast, this patient has none of the aforementioned symptoms. 
❌ Esophageal barium swallow:
Incorrect: An esophageal barium swallow study can reveal mucosal lacerations. However, upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy is more accurate and is necessary to definitively diagnose a patient with a Mallory-Weiss tear. Moreover, endoscopy can also be used to achieve hemostasis. 
✅ Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography of the chest:
Incorrect: This patient has upper gastrointestinal bleeding after heavy drinking and vomiting, which is concerning for a Mallory-Weiss tear. The absence of crepitus makes full-thickness esophageal perforation unlikely. Since Mallory-Weiss tears are partial-thickness lacerations, they will most likely be radiographically occult and missed on a CT scan. 
❌ Blood alcohol level :
Incorrect: This patient has been consuming large quantities of alcohol and will have an elevated blood alcohol level. However, this test does not help differentiate between the different potential sources of GI bleeding (e.g., Mallory-Weiss syndrome, Boerhaave syndrome, gastric ulcer, etc.), and it is therefore not useful in management.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to sudden onset right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began several hours ago. The patient has a past medical history significant for sickle cell disease, and he underwent a splenectomy at the age of 18. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 124/84 mmHg, and pulse is 92/min. Physical examination shows a thin man in mild distress. Abdominal examination reveals inspiratory arrest during palpation of the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies are shown below. An ultrasound is performed and reveals a normal common bile duct with concomitant gallbladder wall thickening and free fluid around the gallbladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?  

 Laboratory value  Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)
 Hemoglobin  13.5 g/dL  135 g/L 
 Leukocyte count  13,000 mm3  13 *10^9/L 
 Total bilirubin  1.1 mg/dL  18.81 µmol/L 
 Direct bilirubin  0.4 mg/dL  6.84 µmol/L 
 Alanine aminotransferase  31 U/L  31 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  36 U/L  36 U/L 
 Lipase  55 U/L  55 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   55 U/L  55 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with a chronic hemolytic anemia (sickle cell disease) is presenting with fever and acute right upper quadrant pain; in conjunction with his laboratory values showing leukocytosis, and ultrasound imaging demonstrating a thickened gallbladder wall and pericholecystic fluid, he likely has acute cholecystitis, the most common complication of cholelithiasis. In patients with chronic hemolytic anemias (e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis), the excess unconjugated bilirubin from the lysed red blood cells results in increased liver uptake and conjugation of bilirubin, ultimately leading to the precipitation of bilirubin into black pigment gallstones.  

Acute cholecystitis is an acute inflammation of the gallbladder caused by obstruction of the cystic duct. When the cystic duct becomes obstructed by a stone, there is distension and inflammation of the gallbladder, triggering an inflammatory response within the gallbladder. Clinical features typically include intense RUQ pain, fever, and nausea. Additionally, this patient demonstrated a positive Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory pause upon palpation of the RUQ). Laboratory findings typically demonstrate leukocytosis. Marked elevation in the serum total bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase concentrations are not common in uncomplicated acute cholecystitis, since obstruction of bile flow is limited to the gallbladder (mild elevations may be present, however).  

Diagnosis relies on a transabdominal ultrasound that helps to visualize the gallbladder. Typical findings in acute cholecystitis include a positive sonographic Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory arrest upon placing the ultrasound probe directly on the gallbladder), gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid (hypoechoic free fluid around the gallbladder). If an ultrasound is inconclusive, a HIDA scan (cholescintigraphy) can be performed, in which a radioactive tracer is injected intravenously; normally, the radioactive tracer would fill the gallbladder, but in cases of cystic duct obstruction, the gallbladder would not be visualized.  



Option Analysis

❌ Acute cholangitis:
Incorrect: Acute cholangitis is an ascending infection of the biliary tract due to an obstruction, most commonly from a gallstone. Although it also presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis, patients have evidence of cholestasis (elevated direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase) on laboratory testing, as well as biliary dilation on imaging.
✅ Acute cholecystitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Splenic sequestration crisis:
Incorrect: Splenic sequestration crisis is a vaso-occlusive episode in the spleen that results in pooling of large amounts of blood in the spleen, resulting in acute left upper quadrant pain, anemia, and signs of intravascular volume depletion (e.g. hypotension). This patient has pain localized to the right upper quadrant and normal hemoglobin levels, suggesting a different diagnosis. Additionally, he had his spleen removed, which makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Gallstone pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Gallstones are the most common cause of acute pancreatitis in the United States. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically present with acute, persistent epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back. In contrast, this patient has pain localized to the right upper quadrant; in addition, the laboratory values showing normal lipase levels essentially excludes pancreatitis as a diagnosis.
❌ Vaso-occlusive crisis:
Incorrect: Vaso-occlusive crisis (sickle cell crisis) is a major complication of sickle cell disease that is characterized by severe pain and tissue ischemia. Episodes typically present with severe deep bone pain and dactylitis (acute pain and swelling in the hands and feet). This patient’s abdominal ultrasound, however, suggests a different diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is brought to the hospital for evaluation of abdominal pain that began 28 hours ago. She describes the pain as constant and stabbing. In addition, the patient has had several episodes of emesis. Medical history is notable for three uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 120/73 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and body mass index is 31 kg/m2. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed, and the patient is started on normal saline. An abdominal ultrasound is performed, but the findings are inconclusive. A CT scan is subsequently performed, revealing the findings shown below. Physical exam is notable for tenderness in the right upper abdominal quadrant and dry mucosal membranes. No jaundice or scleral icterus is observed. Which of the following medications will be most useful in managing this patient’s condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and imaging revealing a gallstone in the common bile duct, which raises concerns for acute cholangitis. The patient has a history of multiple prior pregnancies and an elevated BMI, which are risk factors for developing gallstones. Gallstones can obstruct the common bile duct, causing biliary stasis and creating an environment for the bacteria that have ascended the biliary tract to proliferate, resulting in acute cholangitis.  

Acute cholangitis is a potentially life-threatening condition. The first step in management is to ensure the patient is hemodynamically stable, which involves placing at least two large bore intravenous catheters and initiating intravenous fluids. In addition, patients should be started on antibiotics with coverage for gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam, or ceftriaxone plus metronidazole). Patients should also be made NPO.   

Laboratory testing, such as a complete blood count, liver enzymes, and bilirubin levels, can be ordered. For patients with a high clinical suspicion, such as those presenting with the Charcot triad or Reynolds pentad, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) should be directly performed for diagnosis and treatment. For patients with lower clinical suspicion, a right upper quadrant (RUQ) ultrasound should be performed to evaluate for obstruction, common bile duct dilation, and thickened bile duct walls. If the ultrasound is inconclusive, a CT can be subsequently performed. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, patients should undergo ERCP for treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Piperacillin-tazobactam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and imaging revealing a gallstone in the common bile duct. She likely has ascending cholangitis, which is most often caused by gram-negative and anaerobic pathogens. While ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, has gram-native coverage, it lacks anaerobic coverage.   
❌ Vancomycin:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has ascending cholangitis, which is usually secondary to gram-negative and anaerobic pathogens. Vancomycin provides only gram-positive coverage. As a result, it would not be useful in treating ascending cholangitis. 
❌ Albendazole:
Incorrect: Infection by the Echinococcus tapeworms can result in the formation of hydatid cysts, which often manifest in the liver. The cyst can have eggshell calcification, meaning the cyst appears as a calcified (white) rim and fluid-filled (dark) center on CT. This classic finding is absent on the patient’s scan, and the patient’s history of multiparity and obesity are more concerning for a gallstone-related etiology.  
❌ Norepinephrine:
Incorrect: Norepinephrine is a vasopressor that can be used in patients with septic shock. This patient has fever and findings that are concerning for acute cholangitis, which can lead to sepsis. However, her blood pressure is within normal limits, and therefore, she does not need to be started on a pressor at this time.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider seeking evaluation for postprandial abdominal pain. The symptoms started 6 months ago and have progressively worsened. She reports that the pain begins 30-40 minutes after meals. She has been eating less due to the pain, and she has experienced a 5 kg (11 lb) weight loss since symptom onset. The patient denies nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Her younger sister was diagnosed with colorectal cancer at age 54. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  15.2 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  6,500/mm3 
 Total bilirubin  0.6 mg/dL 
 Direct bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase  14 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  17 U/L 
Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Initiation of treatment with pantoprazole, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin

questions.solution:
This patient has postprandial abdominal pain and a history notable for hyperlipidemia and cigarette smoking. Thus the most likely cause of her pain is chronic mesenteric ischemia, which is characterized by constant or episodic hypoperfusion of the small intestines. The most common cause is atherosclerosis. Mesenteric ischemia can also occur after volvulus or intussusception, which cause compression of the arteries supplying the small intestines.  

Patients with chronic mesenteric ischemia will have mild or no pain on physical exam. However, they will experience severe epigastric or periumbilical pain 30-60 minutes after eating. This is because atherosclerotic vessels are unable to sufficiently dilate in response to the increased blood requirement for digestion and absorption of nutrients (this phenomenon is often referred to as “intestinal angina”).  

CT angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of chronic mesenteric ischemia. Patients with abdominal pain and weight loss typically need to undergo revascularization procedures. Asymptomatic patients are managed with smoking cessation, which will limit the progression of atherosclerotic disease.  



Option Analysis

❌ Surgical resection of necrosed bowel:
Incorrect: This is necessary for patients with bowel necrosis. Bowel necrosis can cause acute-onset abdominal pain, peritoneal irritation, and sepsis secondary to gastrointestinal bacteria entering the abdominal cavity. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms have been present for several months, making a chronic etiology more likely.  
❌ Initiation of treatment with pantoprazole, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin :
Incorrect: Triple therapy, consisting of two antibiotics and one proton-pump inhibitor, is a recommended treatment strategy for Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infections. H. pylori infection can cause gastric ulcers, which present with pain that is worse with food consumption. However, this patient’s history of hyperlipidemia and cigarette smoking makes chronic mesenteric ischemia a more likely explanation for the abdominal pain.
❌ Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Patients with suspected choledocoliathiasis need endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for both diagnosis and treatment. Choledocolithiasis can present with hyperbilirubinmeia and elevated liver enzymes. In contrast, this patient’s bilirubin levels and liver enzymes are within normal range.
✅ Perform CT angiography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform abdominal x-ray:
Incorrect: The patient’s postprandial abdominal pain, in combination with her past medical history of hyperlipidemia, raises concerns for chronic mesenteric ischemia. An x-ray may reveal calcification of the mesenteric arteries, which would suggest underlying atherosclerosis; however, x-ray findings are neither specific nor sufficient to give a definitive diagnosis of chronic mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate syncope and right flank pain. The patient experienced severe right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin while getting out of bed this morning. He subsequently “blacked out.” His partner found him on the ground moaning in pain and brought him to the emergency department. The patient has a remote history of kidney stones. He has not seen a physician in many years. He has been smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for fifty years. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), blood pressure is 93/67 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates a tachypneic male in moderate pain. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. An abdominal radiograph is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
Which of the following best identifies the anatomic location of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
An older patient with a significant smoking history presents with unexplained syncope following severe flank pain. Abdominal radiography demonstrates calcification and ballooning of the abdominal aorta. These findings are concerning for a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm with impending rupture.

The vast majority of aortic aneurysms are present in the infrarenal region and are clinically defined as dilating the aorta to greater than 50% of its normal diameter. Typically, this value is 3 cm, with large aneurysms defined as those greater than 5 cm. Known risk factors include male sex, older age, significant smoking history, uncontrolled hypertension, family history, and atherosclerotic disease. These aneurysms are due to chronic arterial wall inflammation, extracellular matrix degradation, and subsequent balloon dilation.

Clinically, most abdominal aortic aneurysms are silent and present with symptoms only at the time of rupture or impending rupture. With partial or immediate rupture, most patients present with symptoms that mimic renal colic, including back or flank pain radiating to the groin. Other findings include hypotension, abdominal pain, or a pulsatile abdominal mass (however, this finding is not always present).

In symptomatic patients, diagnosis is best achieved with CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis. However, ultrasound can also quickly detect large aneurysms. Abdominal radiographs can detect calcifications and subsequent dilation of the aorta.  

Option Analysis

✅ Infrarenal aorta  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Suprarenal aorta  :
Incorrect: Abdominal aortic aneurysms almost always occur in the infrarenal aorta. Thoracic aortic aneurysms may occur proximal to the renal arteries and track inferiorly over time.  
❌ Ureteropelvic junction  :
Incorrect: Impacted renal stones may be present at the ureteropelvic junction. An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) often mimics the symptoms of renal colic. However, given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic AAA with impending rupture is more likely.  
❌ Proximal ureter  :
Incorrect: Proximal ureteral stones often present with symptoms similar to that of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic AAA with impending rupture best explains his symptoms.  
❌ Terminal Ileum  :
Incorrect: The terminal ileum is the location of intra-abdominal pathologies, including colitis and Crohn disease. In addition, acute appendicitis can cause inflammation and wall thickening of the adjacent terminal ileum. However, given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm with impending rupture best explains his symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distention for the past 12 hours. She has had vague abdominal pain for the past few months but did not seek medical care. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with metformin. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows moderate abdominal distension. There is a 3 cm erythematous and tender palpable mass in the right groin below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The mass is tympanitic to percussion and cannot be reduced. CT scan of the abdomen shows evidence of small bowel obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an irreducible groin bulge lateral to the pubic tubercle and below the inguinal ligament; she most likely has an incarcerated femoral hernia. Since it is erythematous and is associated with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high-grade fever, it has most likely strangulated.

Femoral hernias are the result of herniation of abdominal contents through the femoral canal below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vein, and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Femoral hernias are more common in females and often occur on the right side. Advanced age is the most important risk factor, as the femoral ring can widen. Because the femoral canal is small, femoral hernias often become incarcerated (irreducible), which can lead to bowel obstruction (resulting in pain, nausea, and abdominal distension). Over time, strangulation (ischemia and necrosis) can occur due to worsening edema secondary to impaired blood flow.

In contrast, inguinal hernias are associated with a comparatively lower risk of incarceration and strangulation, as the bowel contents protrude via a wider orifice.

Femoral hernias require surgical repair to decrease the morbidity and mortality associated with potentially life-threatening complications. In some patients, an accessory (or aberrant) obturator artery (a branch of inferior epigastric artery) passes medial to the femoral ring along the margin of the lacunar ligament. The surgeon must be careful to avoid its injury while cutting the lacunar ligament to enlarge the femoral ring to reduce the hernia.



Option Analysis

❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A patent processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernia, which would present above the inguinal ligament.
✅ Widening of the femoral ring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Weakness of transversalis fascia:
Incorrect: Weakness of transversalis fascia can result in a direct inguinal hernia, which protrudes medially to the inferior epigastric vessels within the Hesselbach triangle and appear in the groin. Inguinal hernias are found above the inguinal ligament.
❌ Defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis:
Incorrect: A defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis can result in a Spigelian hernia, which would be located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse, 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line (the caudal-most extent of the posterior rectus sheath). This patient instead has a femoral hernia, which results from laxity of the femoral ring.
❌ Dilatation of long saphenous vein:
Incorrect: Saphenous varix is the dilatation of a long saphenous vein at its junction with the femoral vein in the groin. It appears as a bulge with bluish tinge below the inguinal ligament. It disappears on lying down and exhibits a thrill on auscultation. It is usually associated with varicose veins. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a femoral hernia.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a firm, nontender swelling over her right cheek for the past five months. The patient does not have a sore throat, runny nose, headache, or fever. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks one glass of wine after dinner most nights. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows fullness of the right preauricular space. An MRI of the face demonstrates a 3 cm mass of the right parotid gland, which is determined to be neoplastic on a subsequent core-needle biopsy. An elective parotidectomy is performed, and an important nerve embedded within the parotid gland is accidentally injured. Which of the following clinical features is the patient most likely to develop as a result of this injury?

choices.text: Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded
Inability to close the right eye entirely
Loss of sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue
Down and out deviation of the right eye
Visual defect affecting the left half of the visual field

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with a parotid gland neoplasm and underwent subsequent surgical excision of the parotid gland (parotidectomy). The facial nerve CN VII (parotid plexus) can be injured during parotidectomy or from compression by a parotid gland tumor. Damage to the CN VII or its branches will cause paralysis of the facial muscles, causing them to lose tone. The inferior eyelid can be particularly affected, resulting in an inability to close the eye entirely.

Similarly at risk during parotid pathologies, the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), is closely related to the parotid gland and passes superior to it along with the superficial temporal vessels. The auriculotemporal nerve innervates the parotid sheath as well as the overlying skin. Therefore, patients with parotitis (parotid gland inflammation) often experience external auricular pain.


Option Analysis

❌ Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) innervates the genioglossus, which is responsible for tongue protrusion. CN XII is most frequently injured during carotid endarterectomy, which can result in ipsilateral genioglossus weakness with a deviation of the tongue toward the ipsilateral side with tongue protrusion. CNXII does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
✅ Inability to close the right eye entirely  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Loss of sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue  :
Incorrect: General sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by a branch of the trigeminal nerve. This nerve does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
❌ Down and out deviation of the right eye  :
Incorrect: Oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy causes down and out deviation of the eye. CN III does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
❌ Visual defect affecting the left half of the visual field  :
Incorrect:  Homonymous hemianopia is a defect that affects half of the visual field due to a contralateral optic nerve (CN II) lesion posterior to the optic chiasm. CN II does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with exertional chest pressure and is found to have complex, multi-vessel coronary artery disease. His past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, end-stage renal disease, and a thirty-pack-year smoking history. After discussing options, the patient elects to have a coronary artery bypass graft operation. A vessel from which of the anatomic locations is preferred for this patient’s procedure?

choices.text: An artery from the left thoracic wall
An artery from the radial aspect of the forearm
A vein from the medial calf
An artery from the ulnar aspect of the forearm
A vein from the medial neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a coronary artery bypass graft  (CABG) operation, a procedure in which diseased coronary arteries are bypassed using native, healthy blood vessels. The primary indications for this procedure include disabling angina despite maximum medical therapy, significant stenosis (> 70%) of the proximal left anterior descending artery with 2-vessel or 3-vessel disease, primary left main coronary artery disease, or multivessel coronary artery disease with high anatomic complexity.  

In general, arterial grafts are preferred over venous grafts due to their durability and decreased risk of thrombosis compared with venous grafts. The most commonly harvested arterial grafts are internal thoracic and radial arteries. The great saphenous vein continues to be harvested for some patients requiring CABG.    



Option Analysis

✅ An artery from the left thoracic wall:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ An artery from the radial aspect of the forearm:
Incorrect: The radial artery has been increasingly used as an arterial graft for coronary artery bypass grafting; however, it should not be accessed in patients with underlying end-stage renal disease, as it precludes the use of the ipsilateral arm for dialysis access grafting. 
❌ A vein from the medial calf:
Incorrect: In general, arterial grafts are preferred due to their longevity and lower propensity towards thrombosis. The saphenous vein may be utilized when arterial grafts are non-accessible. 
❌ An artery from the ulnar aspect of the forearm:
Incorrect: The ulnar artery is not routinely used in coronary artery bypass grafting. 
❌ A vein from the medial neck:
Incorrect: The jugular veins and arteries are not used for coronary artery bypass grafting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to a surgeon after her primary care physician noticed a lump in her neck. A biopsy is performed, and the samples are sent to pathology for analysis, revealing follicular thyroid cancer. The patient is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. During the operation, a nerve near the superior thyroid artery is injured. Which of the following structures was most likely injured?

choices.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve

questions.solution:
The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve travels close to the superior thyroid artery and can be easily injured in thyroid surgeries.  

The superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. It subsequently divides into the external and internal branches. The external branch supplies the cricothyroid muscle and helps tense the vocal cords. This branch travels along the lateral surface of the inferior constrictor muscle of the pharynx and closely follows the superior thyroid artery. As a result, it is susceptible to injury during thyroidectomy. The resultant neurological effects include ipsilateral anesthesia of the larynx above the level of the vocal cords and paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle. Most cases of unilateral paralysis are asymptomatic. However, symptomatic patients may experience a weak voice, occasional hoarseness, and voice quality and pitch changes.  



The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the supraglottic larynx. This branch enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and courses relatively far from the thyroid. As a result, it is not typically injured in thyroidectomy. However, the superior laryngeal nerve as a whole can be damaged during skull base surgery, resulting in a loss of sensation of the superior laryngeal mucosa.   

Option Analysis

✅ External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve :
Incorrect: The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane. The nerve does not course near the thyroid and, as a result, is not commonly injured during thyroidectomies. 
❌ The recurrent laryngeal nerve :
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve can be injured during thyroidectomies when dissecting the inferior thyroid artery due to their proximity. However, the nerve injured in this patient courses near the superior thyroid artery.
❌ Accessory nerve:
Incorrect: The accessory nerve is not susceptible to injury during thyroidectomies. 
❌ Pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve :
Incorrect: The pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve are not susceptible to injury during thyroidectomies.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. The patient was rear-ended by a fast-moving vehicle and subsequently suffered a whiplash injury with immediate neck pain following the crash. The patient has a history of osteoporosis and type II diabetes mellitus. EMS placed a cervical collar on arrival at the scene. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is neurologically intact in the upper and lower extremities and only complains of neck pain. A CT scan of the neck is performed, and a sagittal cross-section of the cervical spine is shown below. Which of the following best describes this patient’s injury?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

choices.text: Traumatic spondylolisthesis of the vertebral arches of the axis

questions.solution:
In severe neck injuries, the body of the C2 vertebrae is often displaced anteriorly, and spinal cord injury can occur, which can cause paralysis of all four limbs and even death. The dens of the axis (also called the odontoid process) can also be fractured, usually because of forced flexion or extension in the anterior/posterior plane.

There are three types of dens or odontoid fractures:  
  •  Type I is the most uncommon type. The fracture occurs above the transverse ligament, resulting in a relatively stable fracture.  
  •  Type II is the most common pattern. The fracture is usually located at the base of the dens, where it attaches to C2. These fractures tend to be unstable and complicated by nonunion or failure to heal correctly, secondary to poor blood supply, excessive movement at the fracture site, infection, or a combination of all three. 
  •  Type III fractures occur below type II fractures, at the vertebral body inferior to the base of the dens. These fractures heal faster because the fragments retain their blood supply. However, they are mechanically unstable, as this fracture moves with the occiput as one unit.  
Open mouth radiographs help diagnose dens fractures, but thin-cut CT images with coronal and sagittal reconstructions are the best way to visualize dens fractures.  



Option Analysis

❌ Burst fracture of C1 vertebrae:
Incorrect: A Jefferson, or burst, fracture occurs due to a downward force on the C1 vertebrae leading to fracture of the anterior and posterior arches.  
❌ Hyoid bone fracture:
Incorrect: Hyoid bone fractures usually result from strangulation, where the body of the hyoid bone is pushed back onto the thyroid cartilage.  
✅ Type II dens fracture  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Traumatic spondylolisthesis of the vertebral arches of the axis:
Incorrect: Fractures of the C2 vertebrae are known as a “Hangman’s” fracture or traumatic spondylolisthesis of the axis.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room after vomiting bright red blood several times over the past hour. She denies any recent trauma. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 95/68 mmHg, and pulse is 107/min. Examination of the eyes reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam reveals hepatomegaly and the following shown below. Two peripheral intravenous catheters are placed, and a normal saline infusion is started. Repeat vitals are obtained, revealing a blood pressure of 120/77 mmHg, and pulse of 83/min. Octreotide and ceftriaxone therapy are also initiated. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Placement of a central venous catheter
Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting

questions.solution:
This patient has hematemesis in the setting of liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension (as evidenced by exam findings of scleral icterus, ascites, and hepatomegaly, in the setting of alcohol use disorder); this presentation is highly concerning for an esophageal variceal bleed. Variceal bleeding can cause life-threatening hematemesis, with mortality rates between 10-20%.    

The first step in management is to place at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards, intravenous fluids, octreotide, and broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered. Octreotide induces splanchnic vasoconstriction, decreases portal blood flow, and ultimately reduces the amount of blood that is lost via the varices. Broad spectrum antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone, are administered to prevent infection. Antibiotic administration is especially important in patients with liver cirrhosis, as they are at increased risk of developing spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Patients should also be made NPO (nothing by mouth).  

Once the patient has been stabilized, the next step is to perform upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy. This will help both confirm the diagnosis and ligate the bleeding source.  


Option Analysis

❌ Placement of a central venous catheter:
Incorrect: A central venous catheter is helpful in patients who require hemodynamic monitoring, require medications that cannot be given peripherally (e.g., vasopressors, chemotherapy), or have inadequate peripheral venous access. At present, this patient lacks any indications for central venous catheter placement. 
✅ Perform upper gastrointestinal endoscopy :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Initiation of liver function testing:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has liver cirrhosis, as suggested by the scleral icterus, hepatomegaly, and abdominal ascites. Testing will reveal elevated liver enzymes. However, this patient has active bleeding and achieving hemostasis should be the top priority. 
❌ Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting:
Incorrect: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) is a procedure that can be performed on patients with recurring or treatment-resistant variceal bleeding arising secondary to portal hypertension. In contrast, this patient has no prior episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. Hence, medications (e.g. octreotide) and endoscopic procedures (e.g. band ligation) should be tried first before proceeding to TIPS.  
❌ Initiation of propranolol therapy:
Incorrect: Propranolol can be used for secondary prophylaxis to reduce the risk of future bleeding from esophageal varices. However, this patient had an episode of active variceal bleeding an hour ago. Propranolol is not effective against active bleeds.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain that started one-day ago. In addition, the patient has had one episode of emesis. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and abdominal pain that is worse after heavy meals. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg, heart rate is 77/min, and respiratory rate is 19/min. Abdominal exam reveals right upper quadrant pain that is elicited with palpation. Cardiovascular and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Endoscopy is performed to relieve the obstruction. The patient is currently not in any pain or discomfort. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?  

 Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Hemoglobin  13.0 g/dL  130 g/L 
 Leukocyte Count  10,400/mm3  10.4 * 109/L 
 Total Bilirubin  3.0 mg/dL  51.3 µmol/L 
 Conjugated Bilirubin  2.5 mg/dL  42.75 µmol/L 
 Aspartate Aminotransferase  81 U/L  81 U/L 
 Alanine Aminotransferase  79 U/L  79 U/L 
 Alkaline Phosphatase  120 U/L  120 U/L
questions.solution:
