This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes and alkaline phosphatase, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with a history of postprandial pain that is most likely secondary to gallstones. These findings are consistent with the presentation of choledocholithiasis, which occurs when a stone enters and obstructs the common bile duct.

The first step in management is to ensure hemodynamic stability. Even in stable patients (such as this patient), this priority should be achieved by placing at least two large-bore intravenous catheters and starting intravenous fluids. In addition, patients should not be allowed to consume any food or liquids by mouth (NPO).   

Once the patient is stable, imaging can be performed to make the diagnosis. The first test is a right upper quadrant (RUQ) ultrasound, which may show an obstructing gallstone, common bile duct dilation, and thickened bile duct walls. If the ultrasound does not reveal any findings but clinical suspicion is high, additional imaging such as magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) should be performed.    

Once the diagnosis has been confirmed, treatment can be achieved via endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) to remove the obstructing gallstone. Lastly, a cholecystectomy should be performed to prevent future episodes of choledocholithiasis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Discharge patient from hospital:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, and a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which raises concerns for choledocholithiasis. Endoscopy can be performed to remove the obstructing gallstone. However, patients would also need a cholecystectomy to prevent future episodes of choledocholithiasis.
❌ Obtain serum lipase levels:
Incorrect: Endoscopic removal of the obstructing gallstone can cause tissue injury and result in pancreatitis as a complication. However, this patient has no signs of pancreatitis (e.g., epigastric pain radiating to the back, periumbilical bruising), so it is not necessary to obtain a serum lipase level at this time.
✅ Perform cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiation of piperacillin-tazobactam therapy:
Incorrect: Antibiotic prophylaxis can be given during endoscopic procedures. However, antibiotics are generally not required after the procedure unless the patient has cholecystitis, cholangitis, or another infection. In contrast, this patient does not have fever, leukocytosis, or signs of sepsis (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension), making the likelihood of an infection low.
❌ Administration of indomethacin:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis is a side-effect of endoscopic gallstone removal. This side-effect is due to a combination of mechanical injury from instrumentation of the pancreatic duct and hydrostatic injury from contrast injection. Administering NSAIDs before the procedure can reduce inflammation and the risk of pancreatitis. However, administering NSAIDs after the procedure would not yield this benefit.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate left wrist pain. The patient was cleaning the bathroom when she slipped, fell, and landed on an outstretched left arm. She was subsequently unable to move her left wrist due to pain. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and she takes amlodipine daily. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates swelling and deformity of the left wrist. Plain films of the left wrist are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Image reproduced from Radiopedia.
questions.solution:
This older patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). Imaging of the wrist demonstrates a distal radius fracture with dorsal angulation, which is consistent with a Colles fracture.

Colles fractures are the most common wrist fracture and typically occur after sports-related injuries in younger patients or low-energy trauma in older patients with osteoporosis. A fracture will appear on plain films of the distal radius, with varying degrees of impaction, displacement, and associated intra-articular fractures. The most common mechanism of injury involves a fall on an outstretched hand, such that the direction of force displaces the radial fragment dorsally.

Smith fractures are distal radius fractures with volar angulation. The most common mechanism of injury for this fracture pattern is falling onto flexed wrists. This contrasts to Colles fractures, wherein the wrist is held in extension during the fall. Smith fractures can be diagnosed via plain films.

Clinically, both fracture patterns will demonstrate swelling and deformity of the wrist with limited passive and active range of motion due to pain. Assessment of neurovascular status should take place before and after closed reduction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Colles fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Smith fracture:
Incorrect: A Smith fracture involves volar displacement of the distal radius fracture fragment. In contrast, this patient’s radiograph demonstrates dorsal displacement of the distal radius fracture fragment.  
❌ Galeazzi fracture  :
Incorrect: A Galeazzi fracture is a transverse dorsally displaced fracture of the mid-radius with subsequent widening of the distal radio-ulnar joint.  
❌ Monteggia fracture:
Incorrect: Monteggia fractures are ulnar fractures with associated dislocation of the radial head from its articulation with the capitellum.  
❌ Bennett fracture:
Incorrect: A Bennett fracture occurs at the base of the first metacarpal. It is an intraarticular fracture wherein the palmar ulnar aspect of the first metacarpal base is separated from the remainder of the first metacarpal.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for an evaluation of hoarseness. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy for treatment of thyroid carcinoma one month ago and subsequently developed hoarseness of the voice. Initially, she thought the symptom was just a transient side effect of the operation. However, when the symptoms persisted, she decided to seek further medical care. Vitals are within normal limits. The strength and sensation of the head and neck are intact. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Direct laryngoscopy reveals paralysis of the right vocal cord. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery
Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery
Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery.
Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery
Injury to the right internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hoarseness and unilateral vocal cord paralysis following a thyroidectomy. These findings are most likely due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury during intraoperative dissection of the inferior thyroid artery.  

The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is a branch of the vagus nerve. The RLN innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle, which is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. The recurrent laryngeal nerve also provides sensory supply to the larynx below the level of the vocal cords (subglottic sensation) and motor supply to the vocal cords.  

The right RLN descends with the rest of the vagus nerve anterior to the right subclavian artery before branching off and winding back around it posteriorly to course cranially in the tracheoesophageal groove toward the larynx. The right laryngeal nerve courses closely with the inferior thyroid artery at the junction of the lower and middle thirds of the thyroid. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve courses with the vagus nerve before branching and winding posteriorly around the aortic arch, subsequently ascending through the superior mediastinum and the tracheoesophageal groove towards the larynx. Both branches of the recurrent laryngeal nerve then enter the larynx below the inferior constrictor to supply the muscles and mucosa of the larynx.  

 


During a total thyroidectomy, patients are at risk of developing unilateral or bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis. Unilateral injury can cause paralysis to the true vocal cord and intrinsic muscles of the larynx. Clinically, patients can present with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can cause stridor, airway compromise, and respiratory distress. It may necessitate a tracheostomy.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery:
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the inferior thyroid artery, not the superior thyroid artery. 
❌ Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery. :
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery. This nerve is responsible for supplying the cricothyroid muscle of the larynx. Damage to this nerve may cause changes to the pitch of a patient’s voice. However, vocal cord paralysis is more suggestive of recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery:
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery, not the inferior thyroid artery. Injury to this nerve may cause changes to the pitch of a patient’s voice. However, vocal cord paralysis is more suggestive of recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Injury to the right internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery :
Incorrect: The internal branch provides sensory supply to the mucosa of the supraglottic larynx. It enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and courses relatively far from the thyroid. As a result, it is not typically injured in thyroidectomy.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He is experiencing severe pain in his face and neck. He has significant neck swelling with odynophagia localized to the left side. The odynophagia is worsened with opening his mouth, speaking, or swallowing. The patient has no dyspnea or signs of airway compromise. Head CT and sagittal neck X-ray are shown. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of injury?  


Image credit: Pubmed

choices.text: Blunt force trauma to the neck
Chronic avascular necrosis of the axis

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with a hyoid fracture. For these fractures, it is critically important to closely understand the true mechanism of injury. Approximately 50% of hyoid fractures occur due to strangulation, with an additional 37% due to hangings. Due to the anatomical location and close interrelationship of the hyoid bone with the trachea, esophagus, and carotids, early complications of hyoid fractures include subcutaneous emphysema, crepitus dyspnea, pharyngeal tears, and thyroid cartilage injury. Late complications include dyspnea, stridor, and pseudoaneurysm of the external carotid. For this reason, close observation for 72 hours is strongly recommended. Surgical intervention is not required for most of these complications unless respiratory compromise becomes imminent, in which case laryngoscopic evaluation is common.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blunt force trauma to the neck  :
Incorrect: Although this patient reports being in a motor vehicle collision, the hyoid fracture shown in the above radiograph is most likely from either strangulation (50% of cases) or hanging (37% of cases).  
✅ Strangulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Carotid artery laceration:
Incorrect: Imaging here shows a fracture of the hyoid bone. Lacerations of the carotid at this level are less likely.  
❌ Chronic avascular necrosis of the axis  :
Incorrect: Imaging here shows a fracture of the hyoid bone. A fracture of the axis (or C2 vertebrae) would be seen much higher (at the level of the occiput) on imaging.  
❌ Malignant fracture:
Incorrect: Discovering novel osteosarcoma or soft tissue tumor affecting the hyoid bone is extremely rare. Moreover, most fractures related to the hyoid are due to strangulation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is currently postoperative day two in the surgical intensive care unit post total thyroidectomy for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. During rounds, the patient reports a sensation of numbness around her lips and mouth and intermittent twitching of her upper and lower extremities. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 156/67 mmHg, and O2. is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an intact incision over the anterior neck without edema or erythema.  A routine electrocardiogram is demonstrated below.  Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be present based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after total thyroidectomy with findings of circumoral numbness, tetany, and a prolonged QT interval on routine electrocardiographic screening, consistent with hypocalcemia. In the setting of a recent thyroidectomy, the most likely etiology of hypocalcemia is removal or damage to the parathyroid glands, resulting in hypoparathyroidism. The laboratory findings most reflective of this clinical condition is choice A.  

Multiple structures are at risk of injury during thyroidectomy or hemithyroidectomy, including surrounding glands, vasculature, and nerves (e.g., recurrent laryngeal nerves, external branches of the superior laryngeal nerves). Injury to the parathyroid glands can produce transient or permanent hypoparathyroidism. For this reason, many patients undergoing this procedure are empirically prescribed calcium supplementation to avoid complications associated with hypocalcemia.    

Symptoms of hypoparathyroidism and associated hypocalcemia include muscle tetany, paresthesias, seizures, and psychiatric symptoms (e.g., emotional instability, anxiety, depression). Moreover, hypocalcemia can cause cardiovascular compromise, resulting in QT interval prolongation on ECG, which can degenerate into torsade de pointes. Physical exam findings include the Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign (carpal spasms triggered by inflation of a sphygmomanometer).  

Option Analysis

✅                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↑  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↑  ↑:
Incorrect: Secondary hypoparathyroidism, due to chronic kidney disease, manifests with decreased levels of calcium, increased levels of phosphate, and increased parathyroid hormone. These effects are secondary to the kidney’s inability to respond to parathyroid hormone appropriately. 
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↓ ↑:
Incorrect: Vitamin D deficiency is characterized by decreased calcium, decreased phosphate, and increased parathyroid hormone levels.
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are not consistent with calcium, phosphorus, and parathyroid hormone homeostasis disorders. 
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↑  ↑  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are not consistent with calcium, phosphorus, or parathyroid hormone homeostasis disorders.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate syncope and chest pain. Family members found the patient passed out next to his bed this morning. Upon arousal, the patient experienced chest pain radiating to the back. He has not seen a physician in more than twenty years. He has a thirty-pack-year smoking history and consumes 4-5 beers daily. Temperature is now 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 207/99 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. The patient subsequently undergoes a CT-angiogram of the chest, which is demonstrated below. Which of the following anatomic structures differentiates the appropriate management strategy for this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient had a sudden onset and sharp chest pain radiating to the back, which is concerning for an aortic dissection. CT-angiography of the chest confirms the diagnosis. Specifically, the patient is found to have a type B aortic dissection, which is defined as a dissection flap distal to the left subclavian artery.   

Aortic dissections are caused by longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media created by a dissecting column of blood. They are a potentially catastrophic vascular complication that can lead to ischemia in various organs, namely the brain and the heart. Aortic dissections are divided into two categories: Stanford type A and Stanford type B.  

Stanford type A dissection involves the ascending aorta and more commonly leads to hypotension, pericardial tamponade, stroke, and myocardial infarction (MI). The definitive management of Type A dissection is surgical repair.  

Stanford type B dissections occur distal to the left subclavian artery and involve only the descending aorta. Type B dissections can potentially progress retrograde and present with stroke-like symptoms secondary to involvement of the common carotid artery. However, retrograde progression of type B dissections is quite rare. Instead, they typically progress anterograde to compromise blood flow to the renal arteries, resulting in acute renal failure. The definitive therapy for Stanford type B dissections is blood pressure control with either beta-blockers (e.g. esmolol) or vasodilators.   

Option Analysis

✅ Left subclavian artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Left common carotid artery:
Incorrect: The left common carotid artery is not the anatomic landmark differentiating between type A versus type B aortic dissections. 
❌ Right common carotid artery :
Incorrect: The right common carotid artery is not the anatomic landmark differentiating between type A versus type B aortic dissections. 
❌ Right subclavian artery :
Incorrect: The right subclavian artery is not the anatomic landmark differentiating between type A versus type B aortic dissections. 
❌ Right and left coronary arteries:
Incorrect: The right and left coronary arteries are not the anatomic landmarks differentiating between type A versus type B aortic dissections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner after multiple episodes of hematemesis. The patient is unresponsive and unable to provide a history. According to his partner, the patient had spent the evening at a bar where he consumed more than 10 shots of liquor. After leaving the bar, he vomited multiple times. There was bright-red blood mixed with the vomitus. While in the emergency department, the patient has two additional episodes of hematemesis. During the physical exam, the patient mumbles incoherently, is unable to follow commands, and tries to push away the examiner’s hands. Pupils are 3 centimeters bilaterally and reactive to light. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has hematemesis in the setting of multiple episodes of vomiting, which is most consistent with a Mallory-Weiss tear. Mallory-Weiss tears are partial-thickness lacerations to the esophageal mucosa that occur secondary to forceful and repeated vomiting.  

In addition, this patient has an altered level of consciousness, which is a major risk factor for the aspiration of blood and gastric contents. As a result, the patient should undergo endotracheal intubation to prevent aspiration.



Option Analysis

❌ Order urine toxicology:
Incorrect: This patient has altered mental status. Substances, such as benzodiazepines and opiates, can potentially be the underlying cause and will show up on a urine toxicology study. However, this patient has active hematemesis and altered consciousness, which increases his risk of aspiration. As a result, the patient should be immediately intubated to prevent airway compromise. 
❌ Initiation of octreotide therapy  :
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to reduce variceal bleeding, a condition that usually develops in patients with portal hypertension. In contrast, this patient has no history or physical exam findings suggestive of liver cirrhosis or portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, caput medusae, jaundice). As a result, it is unlikely this patient’s bleeding is secondary to ruptured varices. 
✅  Perform endotracheal intubation :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Administration of naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone can be used to reverse acute opioid intoxication, which manifests with altered mental status, miosis, and respiratory depression. In contrast, this patient has normal sized pupils. His history of alcohol overconsumption provides a more likely explanation for his altered mental status. 
❌ Perform upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Incorrect: An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy can be used to confirm the bleeding source. However, this patient has active hematemesis and reduced consciousness, which increases his risk of aspiration. As a result, intubation should first be performed to prevent airway compromise.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of intense abdominal pain for the past several weeks. She states that the pain typically occurs in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen an hour after eating meals, and it is associated with nausea. Past medical history is significant for 3 spontaneous vaginal deliveries and obesity. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 122/82 mmHg, and pulse is 83/min. BMI is 38 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is resting comfortably on the examination table. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant and epigastrium. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Leukocyte count is 6,000/mm3 and hemoglobin is 13.6 g/dL. Liver enzymes are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with classic signs of symptoms of biliary colic secondary to gallstones. Cholesterol gallstones form when there is an increase in cholesterol concentration or decrease in bile salt concentration of the bile; this ultimately leads to precipitation of cholesterol in the form of gallstones, also known as cholelithiasis.  

Most gallstones are asymptomatic and are often found incidentally on abdominal imaging (e.g. ultrasound for other purposes). When symptomatic, the main presenting symptom is biliary colic, which occurs when the stone blocks the cystic duct. This causes pressure in the gallbladder to increase as it tries to contract, leading to pain in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium that radiates to the right shoulder (due to referred pain from diaphragmatic irritation). The pain often occurs after eating a large or fatty meal and lasts for 1-5 hours before subsiding as the gallbladder relaxes.  

If gallstones are suspected based on the symptoms and history of the patient, confirmation of the diagnosis can be done with a right upper quadrant ultrasound. Ultrasounds are the gold standard study for diagnosing gallstones since they are quick, noninvasive, inexpensive and sensitive enough to detect even tiny stones, and they can additionally detect the dilation of the gallbladder and bile duct. Ultrasound findings typically demonstrate posterior acoustic shadows (indicative of the gallstones), as well as sludge (which corresponds to thickened bile).   

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal x-ray:
Incorrect: An abdominal x-ray may be helpful in determining if there is perforation of a hollow organ leading to pneumoperitoneum; however, this complication would present with severe abdominal pain, diffuse guarding, and rebound tenderness. Plain radiographs have a very low sensitivity for gallstones, and therefore, another imaging modality is preferred. 
❌ HIDA scan :
Incorrect: Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan, also known as a cholescintigraphy, is used to diagnose acute cholecystitis if ultrasound is inconclusive. Since it is a relatively invasive test (requires intravenous injection of a radiotracer), another less invasive test should be performed first. 
❌ Serum lipase:
Incorrect: Elevated serum lipase is a sensitive and specific serum marker found in patients with acute pancreatitis. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically present with acute, persistent epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back. In contrast, this patient is presenting with recurrent episodes of postprandial right upper quadrant pain, suggestive of a different underlying condition.
✅ Abdominal ultrasound :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is recommended in patients with gallstone pancreatitis. These patients typically present with nausea, vomiting, leukocytosis, and elevated ALT levels (>150 U/L).

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain that began seven hours ago. The pain is most prominent in the epigastric region and radiates to the back. In addition, he has had two episodes of emesis. Medical history is notable for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with metformin. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 137/86 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Abdominal exam reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastrium. The mucosal membranes appear dry, and the patient has a delayed capillary refill time. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Right upper quadrant ultrasound reveals the presence of one gallstone in the gallbladder and another obstructing the common bile duct. Laboratory testing reveals a lipase of 820 U/L and amylase of 650 U/L. Endoscopy is performed and successfully removes the stone obstructing the common bile duct. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Order CT evaluation of pancreatic pseudocysts

questions.solution:
This patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back, serum amylase and lipase levels greater than three times the upper limit, and the presence of cholelithiasis on imaging. These findings are diagnostic for gallstone pancreatitis, which arises when a gallstone obstructs the common bile duct and impairs pancreatic enzyme outflow.

The first step in management is to stabilize the patient, which involves first placing at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards, patients should be started on intravenous fluids and, if necessary, intravenous analgesics (e.g. fentanyl). Patients should not be allowed to consume anything by mouth (NPO). Laboratory testing (e.g., liver enzymes, bilirubin levels, trending lipase levels) should also be ordered.    

After the patient is hemodynamically stable, a right upper quadrant (RUQ) ultrasound should be performed to evaluate for gallstones. In patients meeting one of the following criteria, an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) should be done within 24 hours to relieve the obstruction:    

1) If the patient has concurrent cholangitis  
2) If RUQ ultrasound reveals a stone obstructing the common bile duct or dilation of the duct  
3) If liver enzymes and bilirubin levels are increasing  

If none of these criteria are met, an ERCP is not necessary. However, all patients with gallstone pancreatitis should undergo cholecystectomy prior to discharge from the hospital to prevent recurrent episodes.  

Option Analysis

❌ Discharge patient from hospital:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, as well as elevated lipase and amylase levels, which raises concerns for gallstone pancreatitis. Endoscopy can be performed to remove the obstructing gallstone. However, patients would also need a cholecystectomy to prevent recurrent episodes of pancreatitis.
❌ Administration of piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Piperacillin-tazobactam is a broad spectrum antibiotic that has gram-negative and anaerobic coverage. It can be used to treat infections arising from pancreatic necrosis. In addition, the agent can be used to treat gallstone-related etiologies such as emphysematous cholecystitis and acute cholangitis. However, this patient has no signs of infection (e.g., fever), and the use of prophylactic antibiotics is not recommended in sterile pancreatitis.
✅ Perform laparoscopic cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Order CT evaluation of pancreatic pseudocysts:
Incorrect: Pancreatic pseudocysts are collections of fluid rich in pancreatic enzymes, blood, and necrotic tissue. They are a complication of pancreatitis and can manifest with abdominal pain and bloating. However, this patient currently has no cyst-related symptoms. Moreover, most cysts develop more than four weeks after the initial episode of pancreatitis.  
❌ Perform percutaneous gallstone extraction:
Incorrect: Severely ill patients, such as those with myocardial infarction or end-stage renal disease, may be unsuitable candidates for surgical cholecystectomy. In these patients, a percutaneous gallstone extraction can be performed as an alternative. However, this patient has no contraindications to a surgical cholecystectomy.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with worsening right shoulder pain. The patient has difficulty pulling items off the shelf and can no longer do overhead weight exercises. Additionally, the pain often wakes the patient from sleep at night, especially when she lies on the right shoulder. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. On physical examination, the shoulder and elbow are placed at 90 degrees of flexion in front of the body. The patient experiences pain when the examiner internally rotates the shoulder. The left shoulder has a full range of motion. There is no reproducible tenderness on palpation or flexion of the cervical spine. A radiograph of the right shoulder is shown below:  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with intermittent shoulder pain that worsens with overhead movements, but she has a normal shoulder radiograph. In addition, she has a positive Hawkins test, which is indicative of rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy.

Rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy is a common cause of shoulder pain. It often occurs due to repetitive overhead activity that results in inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons. Patients often describe pain over the lateral deltoid that is worse with overhead activity or while lying on the affected shoulder at night.

Physical examination will often demonstrate a positive Neer impingement test, wherein the patient experiences pain as the arm is passively flexed while in internal rotation. In addition, the Hawkins test can be used to diagnose rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy. In this test, the examiner passively positions the shoulder and elbow at 90 degrees of flexion in front of the body, and patients will experience pain when the examiner passively internally rotates the shoulder.

Treatment of rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy is centered on conservative management with physical therapy, analgesia, and rest.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rotator cuff tendinopathy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Incorrect: Adhesive capsulitis, also known as “frozen shoulder syndrome,” manifests with gross stiffness of the shoulder and nagging pain. Physical examination will demonstrate significant reductions in active and passive range of motion in two or more planes of movement.  
❌ Osteoarthritis  :
Incorrect: This patient’s above radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of glenohumeral joint space narrowing or bony erosion. Thus osteoarthritis is unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Biceps tendinopathy  :
Incorrect: Biceps tendinopathy manifests with pain focused in the anterior shoulder with radiation distally over the biceps muscle.  
❌ Cervical spondylosis  :
Incorrect: Cervical spondylosis can mimic rotator cuff tendinopathy. However, in this condition, pain is often localized over the cervical spine, and patients can have a positive Spurling test (reproduction of symptoms when the patient’s head is turned towards the affected side, and pressure is applied to the top of the head).

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided back pain. For several weeks, the patient has had worsening, poorly localized right back pain. The pain radiates to the thigh and knee. He does not have a recent history of trauma. Past medical history includes poorly controlled HIV, chronic hepatitis C, and intravenous heroin use. The patient last injected heroin two days ago. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 107/67 mmHg, and pulse is 106/min. Pain is elicited with passive extension of the right leg. Physical examination of the back is without focal tenderness, step-offs, or deformities. The patient has an antalgic gait. Neurovascular examination of the bilateral lower extremities is non-contributory, and the patient can void freely. If untreated, this patient is at risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of immunosuppression presents with poorly localized right back pain and a positive iliopsoas sign. The physical examination is negative for findings of cauda equina syndrome, epidural abscess, or other sources of infection. Together, these clinical findings are concerning for a psoas abscess, which can lead to femoral nerve damage if untreated.

A psoas abscess is a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment; it may result from an infection's contiguous, hematogenous, or postoperative spread. While rare, it more commonly presents in patients with underlying immunosuppression, diabetes, or intravenous drug use.

Clinically, this disease presents with fever and subacute, poorly localized back or flank pain radiating to the knee, in addition to gait disturbance or neuropathy if the femoral nerve is implicated. If the abscess becomes large enough, it may be palpable in the inguinal region and mistaken for an inguinal hernia, lymphadenopathy, or saphenous vein varix.

The femoral nerve courses anteriorly along with the iliopsoas and thus may become damaged as the disease progresses. Damage to this nerve may ultimately result in femoral neuropathy, manifesting with quadriceps weakness, decreased patellar reflexes, as well as sensory loss along the medial thigh and leg. Diagnosis is best achieved via a contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis. Management includes empiric antibiotics and source control via percutaneous or surgical intervention.  

Option Analysis

✅ Femoral neuropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: Injury to the inferior epigastric artery may occur with incisions or surgical procedures performed below the arcuate line (e.g. cesarean section). Failure to identify and ligate these arteries may result in rectus sheath hematoma formation. However, this patient does not have a history of recent surgeries or trauma.  
❌ Diverticulum perforation:
Incorrect: Diverticulum perforation can occur in the setting of untreated, complex diverticulitis. Diverticulitis more commonly presents in the left lower quadrant with alternating diarrhea, constipation, and fever. Diverticula typically develop in elderly individuals and thus would be unlikely in this patient, given his age.  
❌ Pyogenic liver abscess  :
Incorrect: Pyogenic liver abscesses may result from bacterial seeding or a complication from biliary tract pathology. This patient’s clinical presentation reflects a psoas abscess given his age and risk factors.  
❌ Bilateral lower extremity paraplegia  :
Incorrect: Bilateral lower extremity paraplegia is a devastating consequence of acute spinal cord compression or cauda equina syndrome. In contrast, this patient has a history of intravenous drug use, immunosuppression, and positive iliopsoas sign. Neurovascular examination of the lower extremities is unremarkable. In combination, these findings are more suggestive of a psoas abscess.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office for the evaluation of an abnormal protrusion in her abdomen. She is 6 weeks postpartum and reports that there has been a protrusion since she delivered the baby. The pregnancy was uncomplicated and ended with a normal vaginal delivery of a 7-lb. infant. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a slight bulge in the epigastric region. The patient is asked to raise her head while being in the supine position with knees flexed. A diffuse fusiform bulge becomes prominent extending from the xiphoid to the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This postpartum patient presents with a midline abdominal bulge that becomes prominent on the contraction of the rectus abdominis muscle. She most likely has rectus abdominis diastasis, which refers to an abnormal separation between the two medial sides of the rectus muscles, with a laxity at the linea alba. A distance of two centimeters is usually considered abnormal in the midline abdomen above the umbilicus.



Risk factors include elevated intra-abdominal pressure, including obesity and pregnancy; conditions that weaken the abdominal wall (e.g. connective tissue disorders); and prior abdominal surgery. It most commonly affects infants (due to the partially developed rectus abdominis) and pregnant people (especially multiparous, due to repetitive stretching of the abdominal muscles). Of note, rectus abdominis diastasis is not a true hernia, as the midline fascial layer of the abdominal wall is intact; therefore, incarceration and strangulation do not occur.

Affected patients usually present with a midline abdominal ridge that becomes more prominent with straining and may disappear when the abdominal muscles are relaxed. Diagnosis is based on physical examination, and abdominal ultrasound can be performed to rule out hernia.

Option Analysis

❌ Epigastric hernia:
Incorrect: Although an epigastric hernia can present as a bulge between the umbilicus and xiphoid process, it is not usually fusiform, as it is a result of a defect in the linea alba of the abdominal wall. Moreover, it is less commonly associated with pregnancy than diastasis recti.
✅ Rectus divarication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: A rectus sheath hematoma results from the disruption of one of the branches of the inferior epigastric artery. This condition presents with acute abdominal pain and a palpable abdominal wall mass that does not change during contraction of the rectus muscle.
❌ Incisional hernia:
Incorrect: An incisional hernia can develop at the site of a previous abdominal incision. Important risk factors include diabetes, immunosuppression, obesity, smoking, malnutrition, and connective tissue disorders. This patient has no surgical history.
❌ Lipoma:
Incorrect: A lipoma is a lump under the skin that results from the overgrowth of fat cells. Physical examination usually shows a mobile, painless mass with a soft consistency. This patient, with a new bulge postpartum, is more likely to have diastasis recti.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the office because of a small bulge on the right side of his groin. The patient first noted the lesion after helping his daughter move to a new home. He reports sharp discomfort in the right groin worsens with walking and heavy lifting. Resting supine decreases the severity of the pain. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. BMI is 35.5 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament, which increases in size when the patient coughs. There is no overlying erythema or warmth. An ultrasound reveals that the bulge originates medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Dilatation of the long saphenous vein
Failure of closure of the processus vaginalis

questions.solution:
This patient’s groin mass protruding medial to the inferior epigastric vessels is characteristic of a direct inguinal hernia in the Hesselbach triangle.

Inguinal hernias make up to 96% of groin hernias. They can be classified into direct or indirect hernias. They develop more frequently on the right in both sexes, which is thought to be due to a later descent of the right testicle in males and due to the asymmetry of the pelvis in females.

Direct inguinal hernias result from weakness of the transversalis fascia that makes up the floor of the Hesselbach triangle. Other boundaries include inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the inguinal ligament inferiorly, and the rectus abdominis muscle medially. Contents bulge through the external or superficial inguinal ring only and are covered by the external spermatic fascia. Inguinal hernias are most commonly seen in older males.



Indirect hernias are the most common type of groin hernia and result from a patent processus vaginalis. They are located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and protrude through the internal inguinal ring, which is the site where the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females exits the abdomen.



Option Analysis

❌ Dilatation of the long saphenous vein:
Incorrect: Saphenous varix is the dilatation of the long saphenous vein at its junction with the femoral vein in the groin. It appears as a bulge with a bluish tinge below the inguinal ligament. It disappears on lying down and exhibits a thrill on auscultation. It is usually associated with varicose veins. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a direct inguinal hernia.
❌ Testicular neoplasm:
Incorrect: Testicular neoplasm is a rare condition that presents a firm testicular mass that does not change with positioning or Valsalva maneuver. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a direct inguinal hernia.
✅ Weakness of the transversalis fascia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Failure of closure of the processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: Failure of closure of the processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernias, which present lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels (unlike this patient).
❌ Widening of the femoral ring:
Incorrect: Widening of the femoral ring can result in a femoral hernia, which protrudes in the upper thigh medial to the femoral vein (not epigastric vessels).

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the cardiologist for evaluation of persistent atrial fibrillation. The patient had four emergency department visits for recurrent atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response in the past month. Without relief, the patient has tried several rate-controlling medications, including metoprolol and diltiazem. The patient and cardiologist discuss further treatment options and agree to proceed with cardiac catheter ablation.  Performance of this procedure requires access through which of the following blood vessels?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for treatment of atrial fibrillation refractory to medical therapy and elects to undergo cardiac catheter ablation. In this procedure, the venous system, specifically the femoral vein, serves as the site of access to the heart.  

Venous cardiac catheterization refers to a procedure in which a catheter is inserted through the femoral vein, up the inferior vena cava, and into the right atrium. Once inside the heart's chambers, the catheter can detect arrhythmogenic foci or take measurements such as intracardiac or pulmonary pressures. In addition, the catheter may also be threaded through a patent foramen ovale or trans-septally into the left atrium and used to perform ablation procedures, in which radiofrequency or cryothermal energy is applied to areas of arrhythmogenicity in the heart to manage supraventricular arrhythmias.    



Option Analysis

✅ Femoral vein:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Femoral artery:
Incorrect: The arterial system is used for percutaneous access to the coronary arteries. However, when accessing the right side of the heart for an ablation, a catheter is introduced into the femoral vein.
❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: The radial artery is a reasonable choice of access for percutaneous coronary intervention; however, this patient is undergoing a cardiac ablation for atrial fibrillation, and therefore venous access is necessary.
❌ Internal thoracic artery :
Incorrect: The internal thoracic artery is not a commonly used site for cardiac catheterization and ablation.
❌ Carotid artery:
Incorrect: The carotid artery is not used as an access site for cardiac ablation as there is a high risk of intraprocedural injury resulting in a stroke.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a stab wound to the right chest. Per EMS, the patient was involved in an altercation at home and was stabbed over the right chest wall. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 120/71 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates diminished breath sounds over the right chest and moderate tachypnea without evidence of tracheal deviation. Based on the diagram below, which of the following best identifies the appropriate site for procedural intervention to manage this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with respiratory distress, reduced breath sounds in the right lung, and a history of penetrating chest trauma. These findings are consistent with a traumatic pneumothorax.   

In traumatic pneumothorax, air can pass from the outside atmosphere into the pleural space, resulting in a compressive force on the lung. Patients typically present with tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxia, diminished breath sounds, and signs of trauma.  

In the absence of tension physiology (discussed below), patients with pneumothorax should have a tube thoracostomy performed, with the placement of a chest tube on the affected side at the fourth or fifth intercostal space, midaxillary line. This landmark can be approximated by following the nipple line to the midaxillary line on the affected side. With the correct placement, a gush of air is often audible. Subsequent lung re-expansion leads to improvement in oxygenation, heart rate, and blood pressure.  

When performing this procedure, care should be taken to identify the appropriate anatomic space. If placed too high, there is a risk of damage to the brachial plexus and subclavian vasculature. If placed too low, there is an increased risk of damage to intra-abdominal organs. Furthermore, the tube should be inserted over the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damaging the intercostal vessels and nerves (which run along the inferior aspect of the ribs).    

Patients may present with evidence of tension physiology, which includes tracheal deviation, jugular venous distension, and hemodynamic instability. A tension pneumothorax is emergently treated with needle decompression by placing a large-bore angiocatheter (14-16 Gauge) at the second or third intercostal space at the midclavicular line.  

Option Analysis

✅ Site A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Site B:
Incorrect: Site B refers to the third intercostal space at the midaxillary line, which is too high for chest tube placement. Entering the chest cavity at this anatomic landmark increases the risk for trauma to the brachial plexus and subclavian vasculature. 
❌ Site C:
Incorrect: Site C refers to the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line, which is an appropriate site for needle decompression of a tension pneumothorax. However, based on this patient’s clinical presentation, there is no evidence of tension physiology. 
❌ Site D:
Incorrect: Site D refers to the eighth intercostal space at the midaxillary line, which is too low for chest tube placement. Placement of a chest tube at this site increases the risk of diaphragmatic and liver injury. 
❌ Site E:
Incorrect: Site E refers to the fourth intercostal space at the midclavicular line, which is not a site for chest tube placement.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room because of abdominal pain that began one-day ago. She also endorses fever, nausea, and vomiting. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, choledocholithiasis, and osteoarthritis. She underwent a left total knee arthroplasty four-months ago. The procedure was complicated by excess blood loss and a transfusion was required. On arrival, temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 115/76 mmHg, and pulse is 96/min. Abdominal exam is notable for pain that is elicited with palpation of the right upper quadrant and epigastrium. Jaundice and scleral icterus are observed. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Laboratory testing reveals an aspartate aminotransferase level of 75 U/L and alanine aminotransferase level of 72 U/L. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, fever, and jaundice in the setting of a history of gallstones, which raises concerns for acute cholangitis. It is a potentially life-threatening condition and the work-up process varies depending on the extent of clinical suspicion.  

For patients with high clinical suspicion for acute cholangitis, such as those presenting with the Charcot triad (RUQ pain, fever, and jaundice) or Reynolds pentad (Charcot triad, hypotension, altered mental status), endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) should be performed. ERCP can confirm the diagnosis and treat the condition by removing the gallstone via sphincterotomy. Of note, the patient in this vignette has the Charcot triad.  

For patients with lower clinical suspicion, a right upper quadrant ultrasound should be performed to evaluate for obstruction, common bile duct dilation, and thickened bile duct walls, which, if present in the setting of fever, would raise clinical suspicion for acute cholangitis. If the ultrasound is inconclusive, an abdominal CT can be performed. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, patients should also undergo ERCP for gallstone removal.



Option Analysis

❌ Order upright abdominal x-ray:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and elevated liver enzymes, which raises concerns for a gallstone-related etiology (e.g., cholecystitis, acute cholangitis). However, most gallstones are radiolucent, and as a result, x-rays are rarely used in the work-up of gallstone-related etiologies.
❌ Obtain hepatitis C serology titers:
Incorrect: This patient had a recent blood transfusion, which is a risk factor for contracting hepatitis C. Hepatitis C may cause elevated liver enzymes and right upper quadrant pain. However, transmission of hepatitis C via blood transfusions has been very rare since universal screening was begun in 1992. Furthermore, patients with viral hepatitis often have markedly elevated aminotransferase levels that are 10-20 times the upper limit of normal. Lastly, the patient’s history of choledocholithiasis raises suspicions for a gallstone-related etiology. 
✅ Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform right upper quadrant ultrasound:
Incorrect: The patient has the Charcot triad, which consists of right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice. As a result, clinical suspicion is high for acute cholangitis, and the patient should proceed to endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). In contrast, for patients with lower clinical suspicion, an ultrasound should first be performed to confirm the diagnosis before ERCP is performed.
❌ Order hepatobiliary scintigraphy scan:
Incorrect: A hepatobiliary scintigraphy scan, also termed HIDA scan, can be used to evaluate the biliary tree. It can be used in the work-up of certain patients with inconclusive ultrasound results. For instance, in the case of cholecystitis, an inconclusive ultrasound result should be followed-up by a HIDA scan. However, the patient in this vignette most likely has acute cholangitis and the next step would be to follow-up with a CT scan.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to worsening abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting for the last 2 days. Her parents report she has also had mild non-bloody diarrhea and the pain does not improve with defecation. When asked to localize the pain, the patient points to the right lower quadrant of her abdomen. She rates the pain as a 9 on a 10-point scale. Her medical history is non-contributory. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mmHg. On examination, palpation of the left lower quadrant of the abdomen elicits pain in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory tests are obtained and reveal a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. Which of the following is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This 8-year-old girl presents with greater than 24 hours of fever, nausea, vomiting, positive Rovsing sign (right lower quadrant pain that is elicited with palpation of the left lower quadrant), and worsening right lower quadrant abdominal pain. She most likely has appendicitis.  

Appendicitis is caused by an initial obstruction of the appendix, which leads to buildup of intestinal fluid, mucous, and gut flora (primarily Escheria coli and Bacillus fragilis) in the obstructed appendix. In children, the most common cause of appendiceal obstruction is lymphoid hyperplasia. In adults, the most common cause of obstruction is fecalith impaction. Other rarer causes include carcinoid tumor of the appendix, pinworm, eosinophilic appendicitis, and actinomycosis.  

As a result of the obstruction and subsequent buildup, the appendix grows in size and compresses the nearby afferent visceral nerves, which are carried to the T10 segment of the spinal cord, resulting in the initial periumbilical pain. The inflammation can then spread to the serosa of the appendix and the parietal peritoneum of the abdomen. Irritation of the parietal peritoneum, which is innervated by somatic nerves that also supply the overlying skin, results in migration of the pain to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.    

The spread of this inflammation ultimately leads to weakening of the appendix wall, which can lead to appendiceal rupture. Bacteria can then escape into the peritoneum, leading to peritonitis and abscess formation.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Noncaseating granulomas:
Incorrect: Noncaseating granulomas can be seen in the affected bowel segments of patients with Crohn disease. Crohn disease typically presents with chronic fatigue, crampy abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and low-grade fever. Moreover, non-caseating granulomas are also classically seen in sarcoidosis. However, this condition rarely causes gastrointestinal symptoms.  
❌ Ectopic gastric tissue  :
Incorrect: Ectopic gastric tissue is associated with Meckel diverticulum, a congenital gastrointestinal anomaly which results from failure of involution of the omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct. Patients with Meckel diverticulum would present with abdominal pain and hematochezia. In this case, however, appendicitis is a much more likely diagnosis.  
✅ Lymphoid hyperplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gram-negative bacterial infection:
Incorrect: Yersinia enterocolitica, a gram-negative bacteria, can cause mesenteric lymphadenitis, which is also known as pseudoappendicitis due its similar presentation. Moreover, patients may experience bloody diarrhea. The pathogen is transmitted via undercooked foods, contaminated water, and contact with infected animals and their feces. In contrast, this patient has nonbloody diarrhea and no history of risk factors that may expose her to the pathogen.  
❌ “Target sign” on ultrasound:
Incorrect: A “target sign” on ultrasound is associated with intussusception, which is defined as telescoping of one segment of the bowel into an adjacent segment. Patients with intussusception would present with colicky abdominal pain and currant jelly stools. Moreover, a sausage-shaped mass may be palpable on physical examination.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of left leg pain for three months. The pain is characterized by a continuous cramping in the left calf that starts after walking two blocks and goes away with rest. The patient has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Family history includes a pulmonary embolism experienced by his mother at age 55. The patient quit smoking 5 years ago. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and left arm blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. Left ankle blood pressure is 210/150. Physical exam shows symmetric legs without swelling, redness, or skin breakdown. Which of the following studies is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms and risk factors concerning for peripheral vascular disease (PVD). The leg pain that worsens with walking and resolves with rest is consistent with claudication, which is pain caused by ischemia when the working extremity fails to get adequate blood supply. Atherosclerotic blockages in peripheral arteries along the legs begin to cause symptoms when the vessel’s internal diameter is decreased by 70%.

When there is suspicion of peripheral artery disease (PAD), an ankle-brachial index test (ABI) is performed. ABI is the ratio of ankle systolic blood pressure to brachial systolic blood pressure. Normally, both pressures are about equal, so the ratio is between 1.0 and 1.4. In individuals with intermittent claudication (mild to moderate disease), the ABI usually lies between 0.4 and 0.9, since blood pressure in the ankle is decreased. In individuals with resting pain (severe PAD), the ABI is less than 0.4.  

 


An ABI greater than 1.4 can indicate vessel wall stiffness caused by calcification, as in this patient with an ABI of 1.5. To prevent false negatives, patients with an ABI greater than 1.4 should have a toe-brachial index (TBI) performed. In general, a TBI below 0.5 is considered diagnostic of peripheral vascular disease.  

Individuals with suspected PVD with normal or borderline ABIs (between 0.9 and 1.0) can undergo exercise testing. In this test, a baseline ABI is obtained prior to exercise, and the individual is then asked to exercise until claudication pain occurs; the ABI is then re-measured. A decrease in ABI of 15 to 20% is diagnostic for PVD. If PVD is suspected based on the ABI or TBI, the next step is to perform a lower limb Doppler ultrasound to determine the location and severity of arterial obstruction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Toe-brachial index:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Exercise ankle-brachial index:
Incorrect: Exercise ankle-brachial index (ABI) is reserved for patients with equivocal resting ABI values between 0.9 and 1.0. A decrease in exercising ABI of 15 to 20% is considered diagnostic for peripheral vascular disease.   
❌ Doppler ultrasound  :
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound employs the Doppler effect to measure the velocity of body fluids in relation to the ultrasound probe. Patients with a pathologic positive ankle-brachial index (less than 0.9) should undergo duplex ultrasonography of their leg to identify the location and extent of the stenosis.  
❌ CT angiogram:
Incorrect: CT angiogram is reserved for patients in whom ABI and Doppler ultrasound are equivocal for peripheral artery disease, and may play a role in preoperative revascularization surgery planning.  
❌ MR arteriography:
Incorrect: MR arteriography is reserved for patients in whom ABI and Doppler ultrasound are equivocal for peripheral artery disease, and may play a role in preoperative revascularization surgery planning.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for preoperative clearance for surgical placement of false teeth. The patient has a history of aortic stenosis and had a bioprosthetic replacement five years ago. The patient has no allergies. Which of the following describes the best treatment regimen prior to the surgery?

choices.text: Oral amoxicillin prior to the procedure
Oral ciprofloxacin prior to the procedure
Oral amoxicillin for two weeks prior to the procedure
Oral tetracycline prior to the procedure
Oral nafcillin prior to the procedure

questions.solution:
Patients at high risk for the development of endocarditis include patients with a history of prosthetic heart valves, history of infective endocarditis, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, or repaired congenital heart disease.  Patients with a history of these conditions that are undergoing dental procedures, skin or soft tissue procedures, or cardiorespiratory procedures should receive appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis.  

In most situations, appropriate antimicrobial prophylaxis includes a single dose of amoxicillin 30-60 minutes prior to the procedure. If patients are unable to tolerate oral intake, or they are undergoing an invasive procedure requiring sedation, intravenous third generation cephalosporins may be administered 30-60 minutes prior to the procedure. If allergic to penicillins, vancomycin can be administered 120 minutes prior to the procedure.    

Option Analysis

✅ Oral amoxicillin prior to the procedure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral ciprofloxacin prior to the procedure:
Incorrect: Oral ciprofloxacin is commonly administered to patients for outpatient treatment of pyelonephritis. It is not considered a first line agent for antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients with a history of valvular disease undergoing surgical or dental procedures.   
❌ Oral amoxicillin for two weeks prior to the procedure:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin is the appropriate agent to use as prophylaxis for those with risk factors for endocarditis; however, administration two weeks prior to the procedure is inappropriate and will likely lead to unwanted side effects.   
❌ Oral tetracycline prior to the procedure:
Incorrect: Oral tetracycline is more commonly used for the outpatient treatment of community acquired pneumonia, rickettsial infections, and Lyme disease. It is not considered a first line agent for antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients with a history of valvular disease undergoing surgical or dental procedures.   
❌ Oral nafcillin prior to the procedure:
Incorrect: Nafcillin is effective against methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). However, it is not considered a first line agent for antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients with a history of valvular disease undergoing surgical or dental procedures.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to right-sided abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 3 hours. The patient reports the pain started after he ate lunch. He describes the pain as sharp and localized to the right upper quadrant with radiation to the right shoulder blade. Medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears in discomfort and scleral icterus is observed. On abdominal examination, bowel sounds are present, and there is tenderness in the right upper quadrant.  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  16 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  16,000 mm3 
 Platelet count    260,000 mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume  95 μm3 
Serum  
 Creatinine   0.7 g/dL 
 BUN  14 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   3.7 mg/dL 
 Direct  2.5 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase   210 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  190 U/L 
 Amylase  60 U/L 
 Lipase  54 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   220 U/L 
 Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on imaging in this patient?

choices.text: Distended bowel loops on abdominal x-ray
Failure to visualize radiotracer in the gallbladder on hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan
Diffuse parenchymal enlargement of the pancreas on CT contrast
Dilated common bile duct on magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography
Gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid on abdominal ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting in conjunction with laboratory results showing a cholestatic pattern; he most likely has choledocholithiasis.   

Choledocholithiasis refers to the presence of gallstones obstructing the common bile duct. Patients typically present with right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice. Laboratory results may show a cholestatic pattern manifested as an elevation of ALP, GGT, direct bilirubin, and/or AST/ALT.  

Diagnosis can be made with the following imaging techniques:  
● Transabdominal ultrasound, which would show a dilated common bile duct  
● Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), which is both therapeutic and diagnostic  
● Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)  
● Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)  
● Intraoperative cholangiography or ultrasonography  



Option Analysis

❌ Distended bowel loops on abdominal x-ray:
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with bowel obstruction. Patients with bowel obstruction typically present with diffuse abdominal pain, distention, and hyperactive bowel sounds. This patient’s presentation suggests another diagnosis.   
❌ Failure to visualize radiotracer in the gallbladder on hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan:
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with cholecystitis. In healthy individuals, the radiotracer is injected into the bloodstream, absorbed by the liver, then travels with the bile into the gallbladder and the small intestine. Failure to visualize radioactive tracer within the gallbladder during HIDA scan is considered diagnostic for cholecystitis. Patients with uncomplicated cholecystitis typically present with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis; however, liver enzymes are normal and no jaundice is expected.  
❌ Diffuse parenchymal enlargement of the pancreas on CT contrast:
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with pancreatitis. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically experience acute epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevation of serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal, and/or characteristic enlargement of the pancreas on CT with contrast. This patient’s laboratory results and presentation suggest another diagnosis. 
✅ Dilated common bile duct on magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid on abdominal ultrasound :
Incorrect: These findings suggest cholecystitis. Patients with uncomplicated cholecystitis typically present with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis; however, liver enzymes are normal and no jaundice is expected.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office due to progressive back pain over the past few months. The patient has had back pain for many years, which he attributes to physical work as a gardener. He never sought care as he managed it with analgesic medication, but the pain recently got worse, which prompted him to make an appointment. Medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years. Medications include multivitamins and hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, mild tenderness is noted in the paraspinal lumbar area. There is a full range of motion in all directions. Palpation of the abdomen shows fluctuating mass. The rest of the physical examination, including neurologic examination, is within normal limits. Which of the following tests will most likely reveal the underlying cause for the patient's back pain?

choices.text: Measurement of estimated erythrocyte sedimentation sedimentation rate

questions.solution:
This patient has long-standing hypertension and a history of smoking, and he now presents with chronic back pain and a pulsatile abdominal mass. These findings raise concern for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An abdominal ultrasound can establish the diagnosis.  

AAA is the most common type of true arterial aneurysm, which is defined as a segmental, full-thickness dilation of a blood vessel that is greater than 50% of the normal diameter. The pathogenesis is multifactorial and involves alterations in the vascular wall, which leads to a loss of vascular structural proteins and reduction of wall strength. Risk factors include older age, male gender, cigarette smoking, Caucasian race, atherosclerosis, hypertension, and family history of large artery aneurysms (e.g., iliac, femoral, popliteal).  

The majority of patients are asymptomatic and diagnosis is made via screening or is discovered incidentally on routine physical examination. Those with symptoms often present with abdominal, back, or flank pain. When a rupture occurs, the classic presentation is severe pain, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass. When addressing back pain, it is important to keep in mind visceral pain as a differential diagnosis. Current guidelines include a single screening for AAA in men ages 65 to 75 who: 1) have smoked, or 2) have never smoked but have a 1st-degree relative who had an AAA repair or died from an AAA rupture.  

Option Analysis

❌ Prostate biopsy:
Incorrect: Prostate cancer can metastasize to the spine, causing pain and compression fractures. A biopsy is considered if a digital rectal exam demonstrates abnormal findings (e.g., nodule, induration, asymmetry) and/or if elevated prostate-specific antigen levels are detected. However, prostate cancer is not associated with a fluctuating abdominal mass.
✅ Abdominal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ MRI of the back:
Incorrect: The majority of patients with low back pain less than a month in duration do not require imaging. This patient has long-standing back pain that has recently become more severe, and imaging may be considered in the future. However, this patient has an abdominal mass that is concerning for an abdominal aortic aneurysm, which is usually worked-up via ultrasound.
❌ X-ray of the back:
Incorrect: The majority of patients with low back pain less than a month in duration do not require imaging. This patient had long-standing back pain that has recently become more severe, and imaging may be considered in the future. However, this patient has an abdominal mass that is concerning for an abdominal aortic aneurysm, which is usually worked-up via ultrasound.
❌ Measurement of estimated erythrocyte sedimentation sedimentation rate:
Incorrect: Estimated sedimentation rate (ESR) is a non-specific measure of inflammation which can help in the diagnosis of certain conditions (e.g., temporal arteritis, ankylosing spondylitis). It is not useful in the work-up of a suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute epigastric pain. He was in his usual state of health until he developed severe, persistent upper abdominal pain while in the shower. He has been taking naproxen and ibuprofen daily to manage knee arthritis. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 86/56 mmHg, and pulse is 111/min. The patient is uncomfortable and ill-appearing. When attempting to palpate the abdomen, the patient pushes away the examiner’s hand. With distraction, the abdomen is noted to tense with palpation. IV fluid resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast
Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings of an acute surgical abdomen, including voluntary guarding and rigidity. Given his history of chronic NSAID usage, these findings are likely secondary to a perforated gastric ulcer. When a perforated viscus is suspected in an unstable patient, the most appropriate step after fluid resuscitation is to obtain an upright chest x-ray to evaluate for free air under the diaphragm.

Several features on physical examination increase the urgency for surgical evaluation. Of note, voluntary guarding (conscious contraction of the abdominal wall musculature in anticipation of an exam) and rigidity (also called involuntary guarding) indicate peritoneal inflammation and an underlying surgical process. These findings reflect a tensing of the abdominal wall musculature in response to the inflamed organs beneath them. Other findings that suggest peritoneal inflammation include unstable vital signs and rebound tenderness (tenderness with the removal of pressure).

When present, these examination findings should prompt consideration for a perforated ulcer, appendix, diverticulum, or gallbladder. Providers should subsequently obtain an upright chest x-ray and immediate surgical consultation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Upright chest x-ray  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bedside FAST examination:
Incorrect: A FAST examination, or focused assessment with sonography for trauma, may provide evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding. However, based on this patient’s history, an upright chest x-ray is the appropriate choice given clinical concern for a perforated viscus.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast  :
Incorrect: A CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast would likely delay this unstable patient's care and surgical management. An upright chest X-ray with evidence of free air would be sufficient to prompt immediate operative exploration.  
❌ Administration of ketorolac  :
Incorrect: It is important to provide analgesia to patients with significant abdominal pain. However, ketorolac is an inappropriate choice given this patient likely requires operative management, and the medication could potentially exacerbate intraoperative bleeding. Additionally, diagnostic imaging is of greater importance for this clinically unstable patient at this time.  
❌ Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis  :
Incorrect: A CT of the abdomen and pelvis without intravenous contrast would likely delay this unstable patient's care and surgical management. An upright chest X-ray with evidence of free air would be sufficient to prompt immediate operative exploration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of groin pain, nausea, and abdominal distention for the past 12 hours. She has not experienced similar symptoms before. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with metformin. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild abdominal distension. There is a 5cm palpable mass in the left groin that cannot be reduced and has overlying erythema. It is bounded medially by the pubic tubercle and laterally by a pulsating artery. Which of the following structures is most likely immediately superior to the bulge?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with groin discomfort and a bulge lateral to the pubic tubercle and medial to a pulsating artery (femoral artery) with associated nausea and abdominal distension; she most likely has a strangulated femoral hernia, which is a herniation of the bowel through the femoral canal below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vessels, and lateral to the pubic tubercle and pectineal ligament.

Femoral hernias occur more often in females, though advanced age is the most important risk factor as the femoral ring can widen with age. Because the femoral canal is small, femoral hernias often become incarcerated (irreducible), and patients can present with signs of a bowel obstruction (pain, nausea, abdominal distension) if a bowel segment is herniated in the sac. Over time, strangulation (ischemia and necrosis) can occur due to worsening edema secondary to impaired blood flow.

In contrast to femoral hernias, direct and indirect inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament. These are more common in males. Chronic increase in intra-abdominal pressure and advanced age are important risk factors. The incidence of incarceration and strangulation is low as compared to femoral hernia.



Option Analysis

❌ Pectineal ligament:
Incorrect: The pectineal ligament is an extension of the lacunar ligament and runs along the pectineal line of the pubic bone. It forms the posterior border of the femoral canal.
✅ Inguinal ligament:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rectus muscle sheath:
Incorrect: The rectus muscle sheath is an aponeurosis that encloses the rectus abdominis muscle. It forms the medial border of the Hesselbach triangle and is medial to direct inguinal hernias. It is not related to the femoral ring or femoral hernias.
❌ Round ligament:
Incorrect: The round ligament is homologous to the spermatic cord in males. It passes through the deep inguinal ring to enter the inguinal canal. The round ligament is not associated with the anatomy of a femoral hernia.
❌ Inferior epigastric vessels:
Incorrect: The inferior epigastric vessels are an important landmark for the differentiation of direct and indirect inguinal hernias.
