Direct hernias protrude medial to inferior epigastric vessels, whereas indirect inguinal hernias run lateral to them before entering the inguinal canal. However, this patient has a femoral hernia.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an altercation. Per emergency medical services, the patient sustained a stab wound to the right anterior chest. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 90/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a 1 cm stab wound at the fourth intercostal space parasternally,  in addition to jugular venous distension. A bedside ultrasound of the patient’s heart is demonstrated below. A procedure to alleviate the worsening of this patient’s clinical condition should take place at which of the following anatomic locations?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia

choices.text: 4th or 5th intercostal space mid axillary line
4th or 5th intercostal space mid clavicular line

questions.solution:
This trauma patient presents with evidence cardiac tamponade on exam and bedside echocardiography. Pericardiocentesis is the treatment of choice in diagnosing and managing large, symptomatic pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade.  This procedure involves using a large-bore needle to aspirate fluid from the pericardial sac to restore hemodynamic stability and improve cardiac output.  

The xiphoid process is palpated, and a needle is inserted inferiorly to the left costal margin at a 30-degree angle while aiming towards the left shoulder and aspirating in an apical approach. The physician may utilize an apical or parasternal approach to perform this procedure. An ultrasound may be performed to locate the largest effusion area at the 5th or 6th intercostal space parasternally if using the parasternal approach. Under ultrasound guidance, the needle may be inserted at this location, with a continual aspiration of fluid from the pericardium.  

During this procedure, structures at risk of injury include the internal thoracic artery, diaphragm, lungs, pleura, and the myocardium itself.    

 

Option Analysis

✅ Subxiphoid space:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 4th or 5th intercostal space mid axillary line:
Incorrect: The 4th or 5th intercostal space midaxillary line is the appropriate anatomic landmark for tube thoracostomy, not pericardiocentesis. 
❌ 2nd intercostal space midclavicular line :
Incorrect: The 2nd intercostal space midclavicular line is the appropriate location for needle decompression in the setting of tension pneumothorax, not for pericardiocentesis. 
❌ 4th or 5th intercostal space mid clavicular line:
Incorrect: The 4th or 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line is not appropriate for performing a pericardiocentesis. 
❌ Suprasternal space :
Incorrect: The suprasternal space is not an appropriate anatomical location for performing a pericardiocentesis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency room due to acute-onset vomiting of large volumes of bright red blood. He has had intermittent epigastric pain that is exacerbated by food intake for the last seven-months. Medical history is notable for atherosclerosis and a transient ischemic attack, for which he is taking aspirin. Physical exam is notable for epigastric tenderness that is elicited with light palpation. Cardiovascular and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. Two peripheral intravenous catheters are placed and a saline infusion is started. A blood type and screen is ordered. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?  

 Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Hemoglobin  6.4 g/dL  64 g/L 
 Leukocyte count  7,100/mm3  7.1 *109/L 
 Platelet count  220,000/mm3  220 *109/L 
 Prothrombin time  12 seconds  - 
 Partial thromboplastin time  36 seconds  - 
 Bleeding time*  6.5 minutes  - 
  *Reference Range: 2-5 minutes

choices.text: Initiation of packed red blood cells transfusion

questions.solution:
This patient has hematemesis in the setting of chronic epigastric pain and aspirin use, which is most consistent with a peptic ulcer bleed. This patient has a low hemoglobin level in the setting of active bleeding and an elevated bleeding time secondary to aspirin use.    

In general, stable patients without any major comorbidities should receive pack red blood cell transfusions if their hemoglobin falls below 7 g/dL. For patients with coronary artery disease, a higher transfusion threshold of 8 g/dL can be used.    

In regards to the elevated bleeding time, this finding is actually not an indication for transfusion. Prior studies have demonstrated that platelet transfusions in patients with gastrointestinal bleeding who are taking antiplatelet agents but have normal platelet levels increased mortality rates. This trend could be secondary to inflammation and increased thrombosis risk associated with platelet transfusions.  

Lastly, some patients with gastrointestinal bleeding may require fresh frozen plasma (FFP) transfusions, which consist of clotting factors, plasma proteins, but no cellular components. FFP can be administered to patients with coagulopathy, such as cirrhosis or raised prothrombin time secondary to medications.



Option Analysis

❌ Administration of platelet transfusion :
Incorrect: The patient’s platelet count of 220,000/mm3 is within normal limits. Although he is taking an antiplatelet agent, he does not have an indication for platelet transfusion. Studies have shown that administering platelet transfusions to patients with gastrointestinal bleeding who are on antiplatelet agents but have no thrombocytopenia is associated with higher mortality rates. 
❌ Initiation of octreotide therapy :
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to reduce acute variceal bleeding. Esophageal varices develop in patients with portal hypertension. In contrast, this patient has no history or physical exam findings suggestive of liver cirrhosis or portal hypertension (e.g. ascites, caput medusae, jaundice). As a result, it is unlikely this patient has variceal bleeding. 
❌ Perform urease breath test:
Incorrect: A urease breath test can be used in the work-up of a suspected Helicobacter pylori infection, which can predispose patients to peptic ulcers. However, it would be inappropriate to perform the test right now. This patient has an active bleed, a low hemoglobin level, and needs a red blood cell transfusion.  
✅ Initiation of packed red blood cells transfusion :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Administration of fresh frozen plasma :
Incorrect: Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) contains coagulation factors and proteins, but no cellular components. FFP can be administered to patients with warfarin overdose or clotting factor deficiency (e.g. liver cirrhosis). In contrast, this patient’s normal PT and PTT suggest that he has sufficient clotting factor levels. In contrast, this patient has a low hemoglobin level and needs a red blood cell transfusion.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain that began one day ago. He has also had three episodes of vomiting. Medical history is notable for hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, and type II diabetes mellitus. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history and consumes 2-3 beers per evening. On arrival, temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 112/73 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Abdominal exam is notable for pain and crepitus in the right upper quadrant. The patient has dry mucosal membranes and a delayed capillary refill time. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following interventions will be most useful in treating this patient’s condition?  

 Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Hemoglobin  16.1 g/dL  161 g/L 
 Leukocyte Count  15,000/mm3  15*109/L 
 Total Bilirubin  0.7 mg/dL  11.97 µmol/L 
 Conjugated Bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL  5.13 µmol/L 
 Aspartate Aminotransferase  17 U/L  17 U/L 
 Alanine Aminotransferase  19 U/L  19 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant pain and crepitus, fever, and leukocytosis, which raises concern for emphysematous cholecystitis. The condition occurs when vascular compromise of the cystic artery results in gallbladder wall ischemia. Necrosis and infection by gas-forming organisms (e.g., Clostridium perfringens, certain Escherichia coli species) subsequently occur. The patient’s history of diabetes mellitus and vascular disease are risk factors for developing the condition.  

The first step in management is to ensure hemodynamic stability. This goal can be achieved by placing at least two large-bore intravenous catheters and initiating intravenous fluids. Patients should also be started on broad-spectrum antibiotics with gram-negative and anaerobic coverage (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam, metronidazole and ceftriaxone).    
The condition can be diagnosed via a CT scan, which can reveal gas in the gallbladder wall (Figure 1) and an air-fluid-level (Figure 1). In contrast, ultrasonography is less accurate, since air within the gallbladder walls can interfere with the organ’s visualization.  

Patients should be treated with an emergency cholecystectomy to remove the necrotic and infected gallbladder.  

Figure 1: Emphysematous cholecystitis CT scans with annotations 


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Caption: A) Axial CT slice revealing air within the gallbladder wall (arrow) and an air-fluid level within the gallbladder (asterix). B) Coronal CT slice revealing air within the gallbladder wall (arrow).   

Option Analysis

❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) uses a combination of endoscopy and fluoroscopy to diagnose and treat certain biliary tree conditions. Such conditions range from sphincter of Oddi dysfunction to acute cholangitis. However, ERCP is not used in the treatment of emphysematous cholecystitis.
❌ Perform endovascular aneurysm repair:
Incorrect: A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) can manifest with abdominal, back, or flank pain. The patient’s history of smoking places him at increased risk. However, an AAA would not explain the patient’s fever, leukocytosis, or abdominal crepitus.
✅ Perform emergency cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administration of vancomycin monotherapy:
Incorrect: This patient has right upper quadrant pain and crepitus in the setting of a history of diabetes mellitus and vascular disease, which raises concern for emphysematous cholecystitis. The condition is most often due to infection of the gallbladder by gram-negative and anaerobic pathogens. In contrast, vancomycin has predominantly gram-positive coverage and would not be useful in treating this condition.  
❌ Perform endoscopic thermocoagulation:
Incorrect: This technique can be used to treat bleeding from peptic ulcers and other sources of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. A peptic ulcer can manifest with pain in the upper abdominal quadrants. However, it would be unusual for a peptic ulcer to cause abdominal crepitus, fever, or leukocytosis.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. The pain has been present for years, but she now is having difficulty writing on the chalkboard during her elementary school classes. The patient was a professional soccer player in her early adulthood, and she sustained a rotator cuff injury that was repaired surgically. Medical history is also notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On physical examination, the patient has marked tenderness to palpation at the glenohumeral joint and limited abduction and external rotation secondary to pain. A radiograph of the left shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic left shoulder pain and a limited range of motion due to pain. The patient’s radiograph demonstrates glenohumeral joint space narrowing, sclerosis, and osteophyte formation. These findings are consistent with glenohumeral osteoarthritis.

Glenohumeral osteoarthritis is a relatively uncommon form of osteoarthritis. However, it more commonly occurs in older females with a history of prior shoulder surgery, injury, or trauma. Conditions that predispose to glenohumeral osteoarthritis include shoulder dislocation, rotator cuff tears, rheumatoid arthritis, and humeral head/neck fracture.

Most cases of glenohumeral osteoarthritis present clinically with chronic, nagging, and deep shoulder pain that is exacerbated with movement. Shoulder mobility is typically limited due to pain, especially during abduction and external rotation. Treatment involves analgesia and shoulder replacement surgery in advanced cases of the disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Glenohumeral osteoarthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteosarcoma  :
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma arises from pleomorphic osteoid producing cells and presents as a painful mass or pathologic fracture. Radiographic features include lytic bone lesions and a sunburst pattern, which is secondary to aggressive periosteal reaction.  
❌ Supraspinatus tendinopathy  :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of rotator cuff injury, the physical examination and radiograph are more consistent with glenohumeral osteoarthritis.  
❌ Cervical spondylosis  :
Incorrect: Cervical spondylosis can mimic disorders of the glenohumeral joint. However, in this condition, pain is more often localized over the cervical spine. In addition, patients with cervical spondylosis may have a positive Spurling test (in which symptoms are reproduced when the patient’s head is turned towards the affected side, and pressure is applied to the top of the head).  
❌ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Incorrect: Adhesive capsulitis, also known as “frozen shoulder syndrome,” manifests with gross stiffness of the shoulder and nagging pain. Physical examination will demonstrate significant reductions in active and passive range of motion in two or more planes of movement. It can be differentiated from osteoarthritis as early disease typically demonstrates a normal shoulder radiograph (unlike that of this patient) and presents subacutely over the course of days to weeks (whereas this patient’s symptoms are chronic).

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is currently on postoperative day one after having an uncomplicated open appendectomy. The patient’s pain is well-controlled, but he has noticed diminished sensation and burning pain in the area just below the belly button. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient's surgical incision appears to be healing well without extravasation of fluids on gentle palpation. The patient has diminished sensation suprapubically. Strength and sensation testing throughout the bilateral lower extremities is intact. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
This patient has paresthesias and diminished sensation in the suprapubic region on postoperative day one. These findings are most reflective of injury to the iliohypogastric nerve, likely due to a Lanz incision performed too far laterally or inferiorly.

Several superficial abdominal nerves are at increased risk of injury depending on the incision and surgery performed. Nerves at risk primarily include the inferior thoracic spinal nerves T7-T12, the iliohypogastric nerve, and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Specifically, any incision made too far lateral, inferior, or superior to the correct anatomic site may injure a thoracic spinal nerve, resulting in numbness and paresthesias at that level. For example, a  Kocher incision may injure the 7th and 8th thoracic spinal nerves.

Injury to the iliohypogastric or ilioinguinal nerves can arise from lower abdominal incisions. For example, a Pfannenstiel incision extended too far inferiorly or laterally may injure either nerve. Injury to the iliohypogastric nerve manifests with pain and paresthesias suprapubically, whereas injury to the ilioinguinal nerve manifests with these symptoms over the labia, scrotum, or thigh.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliohypogastric nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Femoral nerve:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve lies deep in the pelvis and is rarely injured during an open appendectomy. Injury to the femoral nerve would present with weakness in the quadriceps and iliopsoas muscles. In contrast, this patient has normal strength in the lower extremities.  
❌ Inferior epigastric artery  :
Incorrect: A pfannenstiel incision or a paracentesis performed too medially may result in injury to this artery. In addition, injury to the inferior epigastric artery would more likely result in hematoma formation, as opposed to diminished sensation in the suprapubic region.  
❌ T10 thoracic spinal nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to this nerve would manifest with paresthesias at the level of the umbilicus. In contrast, this patient has paresthesias in the region inferior to the umbilicus.  
❌ 7th and 8th thoracic spinal nerves  :
Incorrect: A right-sided Kocher incision extended too far laterally or inferiorly can injure the 7th and 8th thoracic spinal nerves. However, Kocher incisions are typically done for biliary procedures or splenectomies instead of appendectomies.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman patient is currently undergoing a coronary artery bypass graft operation. An internal thoracic artery is harvested, a sternotomy is performed, and the heart is exposed for the coronary artery bypass. Before diverting circulation, the surgeon must palpate which of the following anatomic structures to ensure proper aorta and pulmonary artery cross-clamping?
questions.solution:
The transverse pericardial sinus is a funnel-shaped passage that lies posterior to the aorta and pulmonary trunk and anterior to the superior vena cava. This sinus is clinically significant during open-heart surgery as its identification allows for cross-clamping of the aorta and pulmonary artery for circulation diversion via a coronary bypass machine. The surgeon passes a finger posterior to the heart to palpate this passage, dividing the aorta and pulmonary trunk from the vena cava. A ligature can be placed around the aorta and pulmonary artery following identification, leaving the vena cava free.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Transverse pericardial sinus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Auricle of the left atrium:
Incorrect: The auricle of the left atrium is a small, muscular pouch at the upper corner of the left atrium. It is not used to identify and ligate the aorta and pulmonary artery during open-heart surgery. 
❌ Oblique pericardial sinus :
Incorrect: The oblique pericardial sinus is a blind-ending pericardial cul-de-sac behind the heart, which opens into the pericardial space. It is not used to identify and ligate the aorta and pulmonary artery during open-heart surgery. 
❌ Superior pericardial sinus:
Incorrect: The superior sinus is anterior to the ascending aorta and the pulmonary trunk. It is not used to identify and ligate the aorta and pulmonary artery during open-heart surgery. 
❌ Chordae tendineae:
Incorrect: The chordae tendinae are internal cardiac structures responsible for tension amongst valve leaflets. They are not directly palpable at this stage of open-heart dissection, and they are not used to identify and ligate the aorta and pulmonary artery during open-heart surgery.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to an ambulatory surgical center for evaluation of dysphagia that began six-months ago. Endoscopy is performed and reveals the presence of benign esophageal strictures. While in the post-anesthesia care unit, the patient begins complaining of severe chest pain radiating to the back. She also endorses nausea and has an episode of hematemesis. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. Crackles are heard while auscultating over the heart. Crepitus is elicited on palpation of the upper chest wall. Pulmonary and abdominal exams are noncontributory. The patient already has two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters in place. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform computed tomography of the chest

questions.solution:
This patient has an esophageal perforation, which can cause chest pain radiating to the back, vomiting, and hematemesis. The complication can also lead to mediastinitis (inflammation of the mediastinum), pneumomediastinum (air surrounding the heart), and subcutaneous emphysema (presence of air in the subcutaneous tissue).    

The causes of esophageal perforation can be divided into iatrogenic and non-iatrogenic causes. Perforation during endoscopic procedures is the most common iatrogenic cause. Non-iatrogenic causes include spontaneous rupture, trauma, and foreign body ingestion.  

The first step in management is to stabilize the patient. This involves placing at least two large-bore intravenous catheters and starting intravenous fluids. In addition, patients should be started on broad-spectrum antibiotics for infection prophylaxis and proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for acid suppression. Patients should also be made NPO and relevant labs (e.g., complete blood count, type and screen) should be ordered.  

Diagnosis can be made using x-ray, which will show air that has escaped the esophagus, followed by a contrast esophagram, which will confirm the diagnosis as well as determine the size and location of the perforation. A CT scan can be used in cases wherein a contrast esophagram cannot be performed (e.g. patient is hemodynamically unstable despite resuscitation or is uncooperative) or if the results come back inconclusive. A surgery consult should then be placed.



Option Analysis

❌ Perform computed tomography of the chest:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation raises concerns for esophageal perforation. Attempts should be first made to stabilize the patients. Afterwards diagnostic testing, such as an esophagram or CT scan, can be performed.   
✅ Initiation of normal saline infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Call surgical consultation:
Incorrect: Many patients with esophageal perforation will need surgical repair. However, this patient is tachycardic and borderline hypotensive. Attempts should be made to first stabilize the patient before calling surgery.  
❌ Administration of octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to treat acute variceal bleeding, which can cause hematemesis and hemodynamic instability. However, it would be atypical for variceal bleeding to cause crepitus on palpation or crackles to be heard on auscultation. Both of these findings are suggestive of subcutaneous emphysema. 
❌ Obtain twelve-lead electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: Acute coronary syndrome (e.g., angina, myocardial infarction) can cause chest pain and can be diagnosed using an electrocardiogram (ECG). However, this patient also has crackles on auscultation and crepitus on palpation. These findings, in combination with a history of recent endoscopy, are most consistent with esophageal perforation. An ECG is not needed in the work-up of esophageal perforation.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to an ambulatory surgical center for evaluation of substernal chest pain that is exacerbated by coffee and heavy meals. Endoscopy is performed and reveals mucosal irregularity and ulceration at the distal esophagus, near the lower esophageal sphincter. Multiple biopsies of the affected area are obtained. Two-hours later, while in the post-anesthesia care unit, the patient starts complaining of severe chest pain that radiates to the back. She also endorses nausea and has an episode of hematemesis. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 135/77 mmHg, pulse is 86/min, and respirations are 21/min. Crackles are heard while auscultating over the heart. Crepitus is elicited on palpation of the upper chest wall. A contrast esophagogram is performed and reveals findings similar to those shown in the image below. Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin of 10.3 g/dL. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Initiation of packed red blood cells transfusion
Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting

questions.solution:
This patient has an esophageal perforation secondary to an iatrogenic cause (endoscopy). The diagnosis is supported by elements from the patient’s history and physical exam, such as chest pain radiating to the back, crepitus on palpation, and crackles on auscultation. The esophagram, which reveals extravasation of contrast media into the left pleural space, helps confirm the diagnosis.    

The first step in management is to stabilize the patient. This involves placing at least two large-bore intravenous catheters and starting intravenous fluids. In addition, patients should be started on broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ampicillin-sulbactam, piperacillin-tazobactam) for infection prophylaxis and proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for acid suppression. Patients should also be made NPO and relevant labs (e.g., complete blood count, type and screen) should be ordered.  

Diagnosis can be made using x-ray, which will show air that has escaped the esophagus, followed by a contrast esophagram, which will confirm the diagnosis as well as determine the size and location of the perforation.  

Afterwards, immediate surgical consultation and repair of the perforation is necessary to minimize morbidity and mortality.  



Option Analysis

❌ Perform endoscopic band ligation:
Incorrect: Endoscopic band ligation can be used in the management of variceal bleeding. However, this patient’s imaging reveals extravasation of contrast media into the left pleural space, which is consistent with an esophageal perforation. Band ligation is not useful in treating esophageal perforation. 
❌ Initiation of packed red blood cells transfusion :
Incorrect: This patient has an esophageal perforation and likely has active bleeding from the site. Blood transfusions are generally indicated in patients with hemoglobin levels less than 7 g/dL. In contrast, this patient has a hemoglobin level of 10.3 g/dL and does not need a transfusion at this time. 
✅ Immediate surgical consultation and repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting :
Incorrect: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) is a procedure that can be performed on patients with recurring or treatment-resistant variceal bleeding arising secondary to portal hypertension. In contrast, this patient’s presentation of chest pain and crepitus after an endoscopic procedure is most consistent with esophageal perforation.  
❌ Initiation of vancomycin monotherapy :
Incorrect: This patient’s esophagram findings are consistent with an esophageal perforation. Patients should be started on broad-spectrum antibiotics with both aerobe and anaerobe coverage, such as ampicillin-sulbactam and piperacillin-tazobactam. In contrast, vancomycin is a narrow-spectrum antibiotic with predominantly gram-positive coverage.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with intense, sudden-onset right flank pain. She also describes dysuria and dark urine for the past several hours. She states she has felt “waves of nausea” but denies any vomiting. She has never had these symptoms before, and she has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 122/82 mmHg, and pulse is 95/min. BMI is 37 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals no flank pain. Abdominal imaging is performed, which reveals a 4-mm radiopaque stone in the right upper ureter. Additionally, there are several gallstones visualized in the gallbladder. After administration of analgesics and intravenous fluids, the kidney stone passes with no complications. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient’s gallstones?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with a kidney stone, was found to have asymptomatic gallstones during imaging. Most individuals with gallstones are asymptomatic throughout their life, and incidentally finding gallstones is a very common occurrence. Approximately 20% of patients with asymptomatic gallstones will become symptomatic after 10-15 years of follow-up. Management of patients with gallstones is summarized in the following table:  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Fenofibrate therapy:
Incorrect: Fenofibrate therapy can be used in patients with hyperlipidemia as a method to lower triglyceride levels. Since fibrates inhibit cholesterol 7α hydroxylase, there is decreased synthesis of bile acids, which results in supersaturation of bile with cholesterol; therefore, fenofibrate is associated with formation of gallstones and has no role in the treatment of them.
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that helps visualize and remove a problematic gallstone. ERCP is commonly used in cases of gallstone complications, such as pancreatitis or choledocholithiasis; however, this patient has asymptomatic gallstones, and therefore another approach is more appropriate. 
❌ Laparoscopic cholecystectomy :
Incorrect: An elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy may be necessary in patients with symptomatic gallstones (e.g. a patient with postprandial right upper quadrant abdominal pain) to prevent complications. This patient was found to have incidental gallstones, and therefore another approach is more appropriate.
❌ Ursodeoxycholic acid therapy :
Incorrect: Therapy with ursodeoxycholic acid may be necessary in patients with symptomatic gallstones who are poor surgical candidates (e.g. concomitant underlying conditions such as uncontrolled diabetes or congestive heart failure) or refuse to undergo surgery. This patient was found to have asymptomatic gallstones, and therefore another approach is more appropriate.
✅ Reassurance and expectant management :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. She is minimally responsive, and injuries include a left femoral fracture and various ecchymoses across the chest. The patient receives multiple blood product transfusions and undergoes repair of the femoral fracture. The patient is intubated and admitted to the intensive care unit. On the 4th day in the intensive care unit, she remains minimally responsive. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 120/82 mmHg, and pulse is 90/min. Palpation of the right upper quadrant of the abdomen elicits groaning and facial grimacing. No rebound tenderness or involuntary guarding is noted. Ultrasound imaging reveals a normal common bile duct with concomitant gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid, but no gallstones are visualized. No gallbladder perforations, intramural gas, or necrosis are noted. In addition to administration of intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics, which of the following is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This severely ill patient is presenting with a fever and acute right upper quadrant pain; in conjunction with the history of trauma and multiple blood transfusions, and ultrasound imaging demonstrating a thickened gallbladder wall with no visible gallstones, she likely has acute acalculous cholecystitis. This is more common in elderly patients, those who are already seriously ill, or those who have been on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) for a prolonged period of time. The cause is gallbladder hypomotility and subsequent bile stasis which concentrates the bile, creating a toxic effect on the gallbladder walls, resulting in necrosis and inflammation.  

Acalculous cholecystitis is a serious condition that can ultimately lead to sepsis and death if untreated. Since these patients are often severely ill, there must be a low threshold for clinical suspicion. Patients may initially present with vague abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis on laboratory examination. The best initial step involves abdominal imaging, most commonly with a right upper quadrant ultrasound. Common radiologic signs of acalculous cholecystitis include gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and the absence of gallstones. If complications are present, such as necrosis, perforation, or emphysematous cholecystitis, an emergency cholecystectomy should be performed. However, if these complications are not present, percutaneous cholecystostomy should be done under radiologic guidance. If patients show improvement over the next several days, another RUQ ultrasound can be done to look for gallstones or biliary sludge. If either are present, an elective cholecystectomy can be done when the patient recovers from their illness. However, if neither are present, a cholecystectomy is not needed.  



Option Analysis

❌ Observation and expectant management :
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with acalculous cholecystitis, which requires a definitive treatment. Observation and expectant management are not appropriate for this patient. 
❌ Open laparotomy :
Incorrect: Open laparotomy can be considered in patients presenting with signs of peritonitis (e.g. guarding and rebound tenderness). However, this patient has pain localized to the RUQ, and therefore, a more conservative approach is appropriate. 
❌ Emergent cholecystectomy :
Incorrect: In some patients with acute acalculous cholecystitis, severe complications can occur, such as gallbladder necrosis, emphysematous cholecystitis, and gallbladder perforation. These would be indications for an emergency cholecystectomy; however, none of these are present in this patient, and therefore a more conservative approach is warranted.
✅ Percutaneous drainage of the gallbladder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography :
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that helps visualize and remove a problematic gallstone. ERCP is commonly used in cases of gallstone complications, such as pancreatitis or choledocholithiasis; however, this patient has acalculous cholecystitis, and therefore, another approach is more appropriate.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain that began seven hours ago. The pain is most prominent in the epigastric region and radiates to the back. In addition, the patient has had several episodes of vomiting. Medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and right upper quadrant pain that is worse after greasy meals. The patient does not smoke and consumes 3-4 beers per month. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 152/93 mmHg, pulse is 83/min, and respiratory rate is 19/min. Physical exam reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastric regions of the abdomen. Bowel sounds are normal, and no hepatosplenomegaly is noted. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?  

 Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Total Bilirubin  3.1 mg/dL  31 g/L 
 Conjugated Bilirubin  2.4 mg/dL  41.04 µmol/L 
 Aspartate Aminotransferase  93 U/L  93 U/L 
 Alanine Aminotransferase  85 U/L  85 U/L 
 Alkaline Phosphatase  120 U/L  120 U/L 
 Lipase*  780 U/L  780 U/L 
*Reference Range: 30-110 U/L

choices.text: Order computed tomography of the abdomen

questions.solution:
This patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back, an elevated lipase level, and likely history of gallstones. These findings are suggestive of gallstone pancreatitis. Gallstone disease is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis in the Western world. The condition arises when a gallstone enters the common bile duct and obstructs outflow from the pancreatic duct. As a result, pancreatic enzymes cannot be excreted, and they instead begin to autodigest the organ’s parenchyma, resulting in inflammation and, if severe, necrosis. Patients can present with epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea/vomiting, and skin findings such as Cullen sign (periumbilical ecchymosis) or Grey Turner sign (flank ecchymosis).  

The diagnosis of gallstone pancreatitis can be made if the patient has: 1) acute upper abdominal pain radiating to the back; 2) amylase or lipase levels three-times the upper limit of normal; and 3) the presence of gallstones on imaging. In addition, patients may have elevated liver transaminase and bilirubin levels secondary to biliary tract obstruction and bile backflow.  

In regards to imaging, the first step is to visualize the gallstones using a right upper quadrant (RUQ) ultrasound, which is inexpensive, sensitive, and widely available. An alternative option is an abdominal CT scan. However, this modality is less preferred, since it unnecessarily exposes patients to ionizing radiation.  



Option Analysis

❌ Obtain serum amylase levels:
Incorrect: This patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back, lipase levels greater than three times the upper limit, and a likely history of gallstones. These findings are highly suggestive of gallstone pancreatitis. Amylase is a less specific marker of pancreatitis than lipase, and it is not needed on top of a lipase level to make the diagnosis.  
❌ Initiation of piperacillin-tazobactam therapy:
Incorrect: Piperacillin-tazobactam is a broad spectrum antibiotic that has gram-negative and anaerobic coverage. It can be used to treat infections arising from pancreatic necrosis. However, this patient has no signs of infection at this time (e.g. fever), and the use of prophylactic antibiotics is not recommended in sterile pancreatitis.
❌ Perform endoscopic gallstone removal:
Incorrect: This patient likely has gallstone pancreatitis. Endoscopic techniques can be used to remove stones obstructing the common bile duct. However, a right upper quadrant ultrasound should first be performed to first confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Order computed tomography of the abdomen:
Incorrect: This patient likely has gallstone pancreatitis. Computed tomography can be used to diagnose patients with pancreatitis and may reveal the presence of gallstones in the common bile duct. However, ultrasound is the preferred technique for visualizing the biliary tree, and therefore it is the first-line imaging modality for patients with gallstone-related etiologies. 
✅ Perform abdominal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and worsening abdominal pain for the last 12 hours. She states the pain started all of sudden with no inciting factors. Her symptoms were not associated with any particular meal, and she denies any recent travel. The patient has a history of mild asthma, for which she takes an albuterol inhaler as needed. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mmHg. Physical examination shows right lower abdominal pain that is elicited with deep palpation. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. A urine β-hCG test is ordered and returns negative. Leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This young woman presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, right lower abdominal pain for the last 12 hours, and positive Psoas sign. She most likely has appendicitis. However, in a woman of child-bearing age, it is important to determine whether or not she is pregnant as this information will determine what diagnostic test to order. If the patient is not pregnant, an abdominal CT scan should be ordered. If the patient is pregnant, right lower quadrant (RLQ) ultrasound should be ordered (to minimize fetal radiation exposure).

Differential diagnosis of right lower quadrant pain in a woman of child-bearing age includes appendicitis, nephrolithiasis, inflammatory bowel disease, ectopic pregnancy, pelvic inflammatory disease, ovarian torsion, endometriosis, ovarian cysts, and pancreatitis. Further tests can be considered following history and physical to narrow the differential diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography of the abdomen:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: Abdominal X-ray is used in the diagnosis of a variety of abdominal pathologies, such as small bowel obstruction or intestinal perforation secondary to peptic ulcers. However, it is not indicated in a patient with suspected appendicitis.  
❌ Right lower quadrant ultrasound  :
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound can be used to diagnose appendicitis in pregnant patients when clinical features are unclear. However, this patient has a negative urine beta-hCG. In non-pregnant adults, abdominal CT would be preferred over ultrasound.  
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy is used in the diagnosis of upper gastrointestinal pathologies, particularly those above the ligament of Treitz. Some specific diseases diagnosed via upper endoscopy include peptic ulcer disease, esophageal mucosal tears from forceful vomiting (Mallory-Weis tear), and gastric cancers.   
❌ Immediate surgery:
Incorrect: Immediate surgery would be indicated in a patient with hemodynamic instability secondary to a number of abdominal pathologies. However, in this patient with normal blood pressure and heart rate, diagnostics tests should be performed first to identify the exact cause of this patient’s abdominal pain.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to fever and a productive cough for three days. The patient has multiple comorbidities and several past surgeries but is unable to recall the details at this time. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), blood pressure is 165/89 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, and respiratory rate is 21/min. Physical examination demonstrates a well-healed, midline, sternal scar and rales in the bilateral lungs. A chest x-ray is ordered, revealing a focal consolidation in the right lower lobe and multiple radiopaque wires embedded in the sternum. Given these findings, the patient’s past history is most likely notable for which of the following?

choices.text: Placement of stent in left anterior descending artery
Treatment of dissection in the descending aorta
Surgical reduction and fixation of flail chest

questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of a previous median sternotomy, given a midline chest scar and imaging demonstrating multiple sternal wires. Among the answer choices, only coronary artery bypass surgery is typically performed via a median sternotomy.

A median sternotomy is a surgical approach in which the sternum is split in the median plane and retracted. This allows surgeons to access organs within the thoracic cavity, such as the heart and lungs. Procedures that may involve a median sternotomy include heart transplantation, surgical repair of congenital cardiac defects, and pneumonectomy. Following surgery, the two halves of the sternum are joined together using wires or sutures.  



Option Analysis

❌ Placement of stent in left anterior descending artery  :
Incorrect: Stents are often placed for the treatment of ST-elevated myocardial infarctions. Stents are overwhelmingly placed via a percutaneous approach, wherein the stent is introduced into a blood vessel and guided towards the coronary arteries. Stent placement would not commonly result in a midline chest scar or presence of surgical wires on x-ray imaging.  
❌ Repair of esophageal perforation:
Incorrect: An esophageal perforation can occur due to spontaneous perforation (e.g. Boerhaave syndrome), ingestion of foreign objects, or trauma. If the perforation site lies within the thoracic cavity, a left or right thoracotomy is performed. A midline sternotomy would not typically be performed to treat esophageal perforation.  
❌ Treatment of dissection in the descending aorta  :
Incorrect: Dissection of the descending aorta is managed medically with beta-blockers. The condition would not warrant surgical intervention or a midline sternotomy.  
❌ Surgical reduction and fixation of flail chest  :
Incorrect: Severe cases of flail chest may require surgical repair of the broken ribs. Postoperatively, imaging may reveal metallic plates and screws along the fractured ribs. This patient’s imaging and physical exam findings are more suggestive of a midline sternotomy, which is not used in the treatment of rib fractures.  
✅ Coronary artery bypass grafting  :
Correct: See main explanation.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left-sided shoulder pain. The patient was playing flag football when he tripped and fell on an outstretched left arm. Physical examination is notable for a gap along the lateral edge of the left acromion process. The left arm is in slight abduction and external rotation. A radiograph of the shoulder is obtained and shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset shoulder pain after falling on an outstretched arm. Physical examination is notable for a visible deformity of the left shoulder, and radiography demonstrates an anteriorly displaced glenohumeral head on the axillary Y-view. These findings are consistent with an anterior shoulder dislocation.

Anterior shoulder dislocations are a common orthopedic injury and typically occur after a fall onto an outstretched arm. Clinically, patients may present with a visible deformity of the shoulder and a “squared appearance” compared to the contralateral shoulder. In addition, patients will typically hold their arm in slight abduction and external rotation. Radiographs will demonstrate an anteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view.

Complications include axillary artery and nerve injury. As a result, patients should be assessed for neurovascular injury both pre- and post-reduction. In addition, associated bony injuries to the glenohumeral joint include the Hill-Sachs deformity (posterolateral humeral head compression fracture) and Bankart lesions (injury to the inferior glenoid labrum).

In contrast, posterior shoulder dislocations are rare and most commonly occur due to prolonged seizures, high speed motor vehicle accidents, or lightning injuries. Clinically, they are less commonly associated with a gross deformity. However, patients may demonstrate prominence of the coracoid process or posterior shoulder. In addition, the arm is often held in internal rotation. Complications include rotator cuff/labrum tears and humeral fractures.  

Option Analysis

✅ Anterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Posterior shoulder dislocations are rare but can occur in the setting of high speed motor vehicle accidents, status epilepticus, and lightning injuries. It will demonstrate a posteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view. In contrast, this patient’s shoulder radiograph demonstrates an anteriorly displaced humeral head.  
❌ Inferior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Inferior glenohumeral joint dislocations occur due to axial loading while the arm is fully abducted. Patients will have their arm fully abducted with the elbow flexed above their head. Plain films will demonstrate the humeral head inferior to the glenoid.  
❌ Sternoclavicular joint separation  :
Incorrect: Sternoclavicular joint separation involves a tear in the sterno-clavicular ligaments and is classified as either anterior or posterior. This radiograph does not capture the sterno-clavicular joint.  
❌ Superior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Superior glenohumeral joint dislocations are a rare occurrence and are due to a force in the anterior and superior direction.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. The patient was driving home from a party when he crashed into the concrete barrier lining the highway. He did not lose consciousness. Upon arrival, the patient is yelling in pain and holding his chest and abdomen. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 108/72 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. The patient is alert, in distress, and speaking in full sentences. Physical examination reveals diffuse pain over the anterior chest and abdomen. Strength and sensation are intact in all extremities. Laboratory testing is notable for an elevated blood alcohol level. A single-view chest x-ray is obtained and is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient’s condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident, and chest-x-ray reveals free air beneath the diaphragm–consistent with pneumoperitoneum. The patient should undergo an urgent exploratory laparotomy to evaluate for a traumatic perforation.  

Chest x-rays are typically the first-line imaging modality when a pulmonary or mediastinal etiology is suspected. Common indications for chest x-ray include chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough. It is also used as a part of a standard trauma evaluation.   

Chest x-rays should be reviewed systematically to minimize the risk of overlooking findings. For each chest x-ray, the following structures and regions must always be reviewed:  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Needle thoracostomy:
Incorrect: A needle thoracostomy should be performed in the setting of a tension pneumothorax. Imaging will reveal collapse of the affected lung and contralateral shift of the mediastinum. These findings are absent on this patient’s chest radiograph.
❌ Administration of fomepizole:
Incorrect: Fomepizole can be administered to treat ethylene glycol or methanol poisoning. However, it is not routinely used in cases of ethanol toxicity. 
❌ Endotracheal intubation :
Incorrect: This patient does not demonstrate evidence of airway compromise as he is speaking in clear, full sentences.  
❌ Placement of figure-of-eight brace:
Incorrect: A figure-of-eight brace can be used in the treatment of a clavicular fracture, but the bilateral clavicles appear unremarkable in this patient's chest x-ray. However, imaging does reveal pneumoperitoneum, which should be managed with an exploratory laparotomy. 
✅ Exploratory laparotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after vomiting bright red blood. The patient was at home eating almonds when he suddenly felt nauseous and vomited. He denies any recent trauma. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 95/68 mmHg, and pulse is 105/min. Examination of the eyes reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam reveals hepatomegaly and distended veins radiating from the umbilicus. While in the emergency department, the patient has another episode of bloody vomiting. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has hematemesis in the setting liver cirrhosis and subsequent portal hypertension, which is most consistent with a variceal bleed. Other cases of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding include peptic ulcers, Mallory-Weiss tears, esophageal perforation, and vascular malformations (e.g. Dieulafoy lesions). Patients can present with hematemesis (vomiting of fresh red blood), ‘coffee ground’ vomitus (vomiting of blood that has been oxidized by stomach acids), and melena (black and tarry stools).  

Since upper GI bleeding is potentially life-threatening, with a mortality rate of 2-10%, aggressive management is warranted. The first step is to place at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards, patients should be started on intravenous fluids and empiric intravenous proton pump inhibitors to reduce gastric acid production and enable clot formation. If the patient’s hemoglobin is low (hemoglobin < 7 g/dL), a blood transfusion may be required. Patients are allowed to consume nothing by mouth (NPO).    

Once the cause of bleeding has been determined (e.g., via endoscopy, imaging, etc.), patients can be started on medications more specific to the underlying condition.  



Option Analysis

❌ Perform upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Incorrect: An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy can be used to diagnose and treat variceal bleeding. However, this patient is tachycardic and borderline hypotensive. The patient should first be stabilized, which can be achieved by placing peripheral IVs and initiating fluid resuscitation. Only afterwards should endoscopy be performed. 
❌ Administration of propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol can be used for bleeding prophylaxis in patients with esophageal varices. However, this patient has active bleeding, as suggested by the bright red emesis, tachycardia, and borderline-hypotension. Propranolol is ineffective in stopping active variceal bleeding. 
❌ Perform fecal occult blood test :
Incorrect: This patient has gastrointestinal tract bleeding and will have a positive fecal occult blood test. However, it is important to first stabilize the patient before performing any diagnostic testing. 
✅ Placement of intravenous catheters:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Initiation of octreotide therapy:
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to stop acute variceal bleeding and should be continued for 3-5 days. However, this patient is tachycardic and borderline hypotensive. The patient should first be stabilized by placing peripheral IVs and initiating fluid resuscitation. Afterwards, octreotide can be administered.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department and complains of excruciating chest pain that radiates to the back. He also endorses shortness of breath and pain with swallowing. He denies any history of recent chest or abdominal trauma. The symptoms began two-hours ago, after the patient consumed large quantities of alcohol at a bar and had several episodes of forceful vomiting. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and hypertension. The patient’s temperature is 37.9°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 142/78 mmHg, pulse is 75/min, and respirations are 25/min. Physical exam is notable for crepitus on palpation of the upper chest wall. A chest radiograph reveals a widened mediastinum. Which of the following will be most useful in providing a definitive diagnosis of the patient’s condition?

choices.text: Order computed tomography of the chest

questions.solution:
This patient has Boerhaave syndrome, which is a type of esophageal perforation caused by increases in intraesophageal pressure (e.g. vomiting). Patients can develop chest pain that radiates to the back, vomiting, hematemesis, and melena.  

Diagnosis can be made using x-ray, which will show air that has escaped the esophagus and a resultant widened mediastinum, followed by a contrast esophagram, which will confirm the diagnosis as well as determine the size and location of the perforation. A CT scan can be used in cases when a contrast esophagram cannot be performed (e.g. patient is hemodynamically unstable or is uncooperative) or if the results come back inconclusive. Examples of imaging findings seen in esophageal perforation are shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1: Contrast esophagram and CT images with annotations

Images reproduced from Radiopedia

Legend: A) Contrast esophagram showing escape of ingested Gastrografin from the esophagus, B) CT scan revealing presence of mediastinal air pockets.  

Option Analysis

❌ Perform diagnostic endoscopy    :
Incorrect: This patient likely has Boerhaave syndrome, which is perforation of the esophagus due to sudden increases in esophageal pressure. The work-up process involves X-ray followed by esophagram to confirm the diagnosis. In contrast, endoscopy is not used since the air insufflation and instrumentation associated with the procedure may exacerbate the perforation.  
❌ Obtain twelve-lead electrocardiogram :
Incorrect: Acute coronary syndrome (e.g., angina, myocardial infarction) can cause chest pain and can be diagnosed using an electrocardiogram. However, this patient also has crepitus on palpation and a widened mediastinum on chest radiograph. These findings, in combination with a history of forceful vomiting, are most consistent with esophageal perforation. An electrogram is not needed in the work-up of esophageal perforation. 
❌ Perform exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: An exploratory laparotomy is a surgical procedure wherein the abdomen is opened and the organs are evaluated for injury. It can be used in cases of blunt or penetrating abdominal trauma. However, this patient has no history of trauma. Moreover, his symptoms of crepitus and chest pain, in combination with a history of forceful vomiting, are more consistent with esophageal perforation.  
❌ Order computed tomography of the chest:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation raises concerns for Boerhaave syndrome. A CT scan is an alternative work-up approach for patients who are hemodynamically unstable despite resuscitation attempts or have inconclusive esophagram results. In contrast, this patient is hemodynamically stable and an esophagram should be attempted first. 
✅ Perform contrast esophagram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with left shoulder pain. The pain started insidiously two weeks ago and tends to be worse at night. She has also experienced decreased range of motion in the left shoulder. The patient did not sustain any recent injuries. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. On physical examination, the patient demonstrates limited active and passive range of motion, with associated pain. A radiograph of the left shoulder is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with insidious subacute left shoulder pain with global stiffness, as well as limited active and passive range of motion. The shoulder radiograph is unremarkable. Together, these findings suggest adhesive capsulitis (also termed frozen shoulder syndrome).

Adhesive capsulitis is a poorly understood condition that results in global stiffness and pain of the glenohumeral joint. Current research postulates the condition results from spontaneous inflammation of the joint capsule, followed by the development of adhesions and fibrosis of the synovial lining. Clinically, patients present with subacute symptoms including deep, nagging shoulder pain and associated limitations in passive and active range of motion (particularly external rotation and abduction). The condition is often idiopathic but has been associated with a history of shoulder injury, diabetes, dyslipidemia, Parkinson disease, immobilization, and antiretroviral therapy.

The disease progresses through three distinct phases. First, patients experience an acute phase characterized by severe disabling shoulder pain that worsens at night, with some associated stiffness. This phase lasts 2-9 months. Next, an intermediate phase occurs wherein pain decreases but stiffness and severe loss of shoulder motion ensues. This phase lasts 4-12 months. Finally, a recovery phase occurs, wherein patients regain shoulder mobility.

Diagnosis of adhesive capsulitis is primarily clinical, as imaging findings are generally noncontributory, and radiographs are often normal. Since most cases are self-limited, management is conservative and involves a combination of rest, analgesia, and physical therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glenohumeral osteoarthritis  :
Incorrect: Glenohumeral osteoarthritis more commonly occurs in older adults with a prior history of shoulder surgery or trauma. In addition, this condition presents chronically, developing over the course of months to years. Radiographic findings of glenohumeral osteoarthritis include joint space narrowing, sclerosis, and osteophyte formation.  
❌ Subacromial bursitis  :
Incorrect: Subacromial bursitis falls into the category of rotator cuff impingement injuries and can present similarly to adhesive capsulitis. However, patients with subacromial bursitis will demonstrate limited active range of motion but preserved passive range of motion.  
❌ Anterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common form of shoulder dislocation. Patients with anterior shoulder dislocation will typically hold their arm in slight abduction and external rotation. The axillary Y-view will demonstrate an anteriorly displaced humeral head relative to the glenoid fossa.  
❌ Humeral head fracture  :
Incorrect: There is no evidence of a fracture pattern on this patient’s radiograph.

questions.text: A 40-year-old comes to the office for the evaluation of an abdominal lump. The patient also reports intermittent pain in the upper abdomen that gets worse when they lift heavy weights at the gym. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 2 cm midline bulge between the umbilicus and xiphoid process. The bulge is erythematous, tender to palpation, and increases in size when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s midline abdominal bulge in the epigastric region that increases in size with increased intraabdominal pressure is most likely an epigastric hernia, which results when there is a defect in the linea alba of the abdominal wall.

A hernia is when an organ protrudes through the body wall that normally contains it. Ventral abdominal hernias occur in the anterior abdominal wall and can be divided into:

  •  Epigastric hernia (as described above) 
  •  Umbilical (periumbilical) hernia: Occurs near the umbilicus, often associated with pregnancy 
  •  Spigelian hernia: Located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line 
  • Incisional hernia: Usually develops on a prior surgical incision site where the fascia never fully healed
Risk factors for ventral hernias include obesity, pregnancy, heavy lifting, genetic defects, aging, and intractable vomiting.



Reducible hernias can be pushed back into the abdomen by applying manual pressure, whereas irreducible (i.e. incarcerated) hernias are trapped within the hernia sac and cannot be reduced. An incarcerated hernia can progress to become a strangulated hernia due to the progressive edema secondary to impaired blood and lymphatic flow, leading to ischemic necrosis of the herniated contents.



Option Analysis

✅ Defect in the linea alba:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis:
Incorrect: A defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis can result in Spigelian hernia, which is located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line, which is the caudal-most extent of the posterior rectus sheath. It is not located in the epigastric region.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: Patent processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernia, in which the abdominal contents go through the inguinal ring and protrudes lateral to the epigastric vessels into the inguinal canal and sometimes the scrotum. This patient has an epigastric hernia.
❌ Weakness of the obturator membrane:
Incorrect: Weakness of the obturator membrane can cause an obturator hernia, in which the abdominal contents protrude through the obturator foramen, which is located on the anterolateral aspect of the pelvic wall. This patient has an epigastric hernia.
❌ Weakness of the transversalis fascia:
Incorrect: Weakness of the transversalis fascia can result in direct inguinal hernia, in which the abdominal contents protrude medially to the inferior epigastric vessels within the Hesselbach triangle and appear in the groin (unlike the epigastric bulge in this patient).

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department for evaluation of an intractable nosebleed after being hit in the face with a basketball during recess. He does not have any shortness of breath, hemoptysis, or hematemesis. There is no family history of bleeding disorders. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mm Hg. The physical exam is notable for clots in the nares, with moderate rebleeding when the clots are dislodged. Which of the following anatomic locations is the most likely site of ongoing bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with uncomplicated epistaxis (nosebleed) following facial trauma. The most common source of bleeding in patients with uncomplicated epistaxis is the Kiesselbach plexus–an area found in the anterior third of the nose. Anastomosis of the following blood vessels occurs in this region:  
  •  Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery 
  •  Lateral nasal branch of the sphenopalatine artery 
  •  Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of the facial artery) 

Posterior epistaxis, on the other hand, occurs from bleeding in the Woodruff plexus–a collection of arteries in the posteroinferior nasal cavity formed by the anastomoses of the sphenopalatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery) and pharyngeal artery. Posterior epistaxis often presents as difficult to control bleeding from the bilateral nostrils or hemoptysis. Posterior epistaxis is highly associated with brisk bleeding into the posterior pharynx and thus a higher risk of airway compromise or aspiration.




Option Analysis

❌ Inferior turbinate  :
Incorrect: The inferior turbinates, along with superior and middle turbinates, are involved in warming, filtering, and humidifying inspired air. They are unlikely sites of epistaxis.  
❌ Posterolateral wall  :
Incorrect: Branches of the sphenopalatine artery supply the posterolateral wall and are the most likely source of posterior nosebleeds. Epistaxis secondary to injury of the sphenopalatine artery or its branches results in brisk hemorrhage that is difficult to control with direct pressure or specific interventions.  
✅ Kiesselbach plexus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior choanae  :
Incorrect: Branches of the sphenopalatine artery supply the posterior choanae and are the most likely the site of posterior nosebleeds. Epistaxis secondary to injury of the sphenopalatine artery or its branches results in brisk hemorrhage that is difficult to control with direct pressure or specific interventions.  
❌ Middle meatus  :
Incorrect: The middle turbinate over the lateral nasal wall forms the middle meatus, a drainage pathway for the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinus. It is the most common site for nasal polyps to form but is unlikely to be involved in anterior nasal bleeds.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of an enlarging neck mass. The patient first noticed the mass several months ago but failed to visit a doctor until today, when her symptoms worsened. She states, “It's gotten so big, I’m having trouble breathing when going up or down stairs.” She also has dysphagia with both solids and liquids. Past medical history is unremarkable. She has a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are within normal limits. A CT of the neck is demonstrated below.  Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of obstructive goiter, as evidenced by the large anterior neck mass encircling the trachea and esophagus in the CT image shown. The most appropriate management in a patient with a large goiter and associated dyspnea or dysphagia symptoms is a total thyroidectomy.   

Goiter refers to an abnormal enlargement of the thyroid gland and has multiple etiologies, including thyroid malignancy, multinodular goiter, Hashimoto thyroiditis, Graves disease, and subclinical hyperthyroidism. Regardless of the etiology, an enlarging thyroid can result in a mass effect on adjacent structures resulting in obstructive symptoms. The thyroid gland most commonly grows outward because of its location in the anterior neck; however, bilateral lobar enlargement can extend posteriorly to the trachea–compressing the airway, esophagus, and surrounding blood vessels.  

Ultimately, this mass effect can result in dyspnea (the most common symptom), dysphagia, and hemorrhage into the goiter. In patients with symptomatic obstructive goiter, the most appropriate treatment is the complete surgical removal of the thyroid gland.   

Option Analysis

✅ Total thyroidectomy :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Subtotal thyroidectomy:
Incorrect: A subtotal thyroidectomy refers to partial or incomplete removal of the thyroid gland. This procedure is indicated in select cases for unilateral thyroid nodules. Removal of only a portion of the thyroid increases the risk for recurrent obstructive goiter or missed malignancy. 
❌ Radioactive iodine:
Incorrect: Surgery is the standard therapy for large goiters. Radioactive iodine is considered in cases of thyroid malignancy, hyperthyroidism or as an alternative for patients with large goiters who are not surgical candidates. Radioactive iodine therapy can also be considered in cases of nontoxic multinodular goiter, but it is only associated with a moderate reduction in thyroid volume. 
❌ Repeat CT-scan in one year :
Incorrect: Asymptomatic patients with normal flow-volume loops and whose goiters end at the level of the brachiocephalic vein or higher may elect to have serial CT scans. However, this patient presents with symptoms of airway obstruction and dysphagia, which should be addressed in a timely fashion.
❌ Recombinant human TSH:
Incorrect: Recombinant human TSH is a poorly studied therapy reserved for patients with obstructive goiter who are not surgical candidates.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a fever of unknown origin. After 24 hours, the patient's blood culture from the emergency department returns positive for Gram-positive cocci in clusters. The patient subsequently undergoes transesophageal echocardiography, which produces the image as demonstrated below. Which of the following correctly identifies the structure labeled with X?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a fever of unknown origin and undergoes transesophageal echocardiography due to concern for bacteremia and endocarditis. The above image demonstrates a 4-chamber view of the heart, with the structure labeled “X” representing the mitral valve and a superior structure suspicious for vegetation.  

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is an ultrasonographic technique wherein an endoscopic transducer is advanced into the esophagus to visualize cardiac structures. TEE offers superior imaging of the heart (particularly posterior cardiac structures) compared to transthoracic echocardiography, wherein ultrasound of the anterior and lateral chest is performed. Common indications for TEE include evaluation for a potential cardiac source of an embolus, valvular endocarditis, and left atrial appendage thrombi in patients with atrial fibrillation.  

Multiple views can be obtained with TEE to help visualize the cardiac structures. Visualized structures include the ventricles, atria, mitral and tricuspid valves, atrial appendage, aortic arch, aortic leaflets, root, and pulmonary arteries and veins.  

Option Analysis

✅ Mitral valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: On the above image, the tricuspid valve is located right and inferior to the area demarcated by the X. The tricuspid valve can be identified by first locating the right ventricle, which is smaller and has a thinner wall than the left ventricle.
❌ Aortic outlet :
Incorrect: The aortic outlet is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart. 
❌ Aortic valve:
Incorrect: The aortic valve has three leaflets and is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart. 
❌ Pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: The pulmonic valve has three leaflets and is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department after experiencing several episodes of non-bilious and non-bloody emesis, followed by a sudden onset of intense, sharp chest pain radiating to the back. The patient drinks a pint of vodka daily and regularly uses intranasal cocaine. He reports last using cocaine this morning. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 210/120 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a regurgitant murmur. ECG shows nonspecific T-wave abnormalities, and chest radiography is unremarkable. Which physical examination finding should be assessed next based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has concerning features for aortic dissection, including sudden onset, sharp chest pain radiating to the back. Aortic dissections are caused by longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media created by a dissecting column of blood, and the condition is often associated with a pulse deficit.  Patients may also have focal neurologic deficits or a new murmur. Although aortic dissection is typically visualized as a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray, a normal chest X-ray does not exclude the diagnosis.

A patient with chest pain poses a complicated diagnostic challenge given the broad differential diagnoses it encompasses, including cardiac, biliary, musculoskeletal, pulmonary, gastrointestinal and psychiatric etiologies. Several elements of a focused history and physical examination should be obtained for all adult patients presenting with chest pain. Patients should be questioned regarding the onset, quality, and radiation of the pain, in addition to associated symptoms and provoking/relieving factors; a thorough cardiopulmonary examination should also be performed.

Additionally, all patients should be assessed for red flag features of chest pain that may indicate a life-threatening diagnosis. For example, jugular venous distention and muffled heart sounds suggest pericardial tamponade. Pulmonary embolism should be suspected in patients with sudden-onset chest pain associated with dyspnea and hypoxia and risk factors for venous thromboembolism like malignancy, recent surgery, prolonged immobilization, or evidence of lower extremity swelling. Patients with a pneumothorax will often have unequal breath sounds, with decreased sounds over the involved lung. Consider esophageal rupture in patients whose chest pain developed after vomiting or retching or undergoing esophageal instrumentation like an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (or EGD). These patients may have evidence of subcutaneous emphysema over their chest wall. Only once these emergent causes of chest pain are ruled out should other causes be evaluated.


Option Analysis

✅ Bilateral radial pulses:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Jugular venous distension:
Incorrect: Jugular venous distension should be assessed in patients with concern for pericardial tamponade or volume overloaded states. This patient’s presentation suggests aortic dissection, and he should have pulses and blood pressures in both upper extremities evaluated.
❌ Lower extremity swelling:
Incorrect: Lower extremity swelling should be assessed in patients with features suggestive of pulmonary embolism. This patient's description of the pain, normal O2 saturation, and lack of thrombophilic risk factors make pulmonary embolism a less likely diagnosis compared to aortic dissection.
❌ Pulsus paradoxus:
Incorrect: Pulsus paradoxus refers to a systolic pressure drop greater than 10 mmHg during inspiration and is often found in patients with pericardial tamponade. This condition is associated with low voltage and electrical alternans ECG changes and a globular heart on radiography. While patients with aortic dissection may develop tamponade (due to dissection into the pericardium), it is usually a late complication.
❌ Palpation of the chest wall:
Incorrect: Subcutaneous emphysema is often noted in patients with Boerhaave syndrome; however, this patient has a normal chest radiograph, making Boerhaave less likely.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after several episodes of hematemesis, which began an hour ago. The patient was at home watching television when he suddenly felt nauseous and vomited. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hepatitis C infection. He has been inconsistent in coming to prior medical appointments due to a lack of insurance. During the physical exam, the patient is anxious but able to answer questions and is not in acute distress. Examination of the eyes reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam reveals hepatomegaly and distended veins radiating from the umbilicus. The patient is started in intravenous fluids and endoscopic band ligation is successfully performed. Which of the following medications will be most useful in providing secondary prophylaxis for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has hematemesis in the setting liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension, which is most consistent with the presentation of an esophageal variceal bleed.   

In patients with acute bleeding, the first step is to place at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards, intravenous fluids, octreotide, and broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered. Patients should also be made NPO. Lastly, once the patient has been stabilized, upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy should be performed. This will help both confirm the diagnosis and ligate the source of bleeding.    

Secondary prophylaxis to prevent future rebleeding can be achieved by administering a non-selective beta-blocker, such as propranolol or nadolol. The medication works by 1) allowing unopposed alpha adrenergic-mediated vasoconstriction to happen and 2) reducing cardiac output. The net result is splanchnic vasoconstriction and reduced portal blood flow, thereby improving portal hypertension.   

Option Analysis

❌ Ceftriaxone:
