Incorrect: This patient has hematemesis in the setting of physical exam findings consistent with liver cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, caput medusae). As a result, he most likely has an active variceal bleed. Ceftriaxone and other broad-spectrum antibiotics can be used for infection prophylaxis in the acute phase but are not useful in preventing future bleeding episodes. 
❌ Octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide induces splanchnic vasoconstriction, decreases portal blood flow, and ultimately reduces the amount of blood that is lost via the varices. However, octreotide is not useful in providing prophylaxis against subsequent episodes of variceal bleeding. 
❌ Pantoprazole:
Incorrect: Patients admitted for upper gastrointestinal bleeding are often given empiric proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy. PPIs can also reduce the risk of rebleeding from gastric ulcers. However, this patient’s history of hematemesis in the setting of liver cirrhosis is more consistent with the presentation of variceal bleeding. PPIs are not effective in providing prophylaxis for subsequent variceal bleeds.  
❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) can also be used for prophylaxis against infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, in patients with variceal bleeding. However, long-term TMP-SMX therapy does not reduce the risk of future bleeding. 
✅ Propranolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of epigastric pain that began two-hours ago. In addition, the patient has had nausea and one episode of emesis. Past medical history is notable for intermittent epigastric pain that is exacerbated by meals, which has prompted the patient to eat less. In addition, the patient has hypertension and atherosclerosis. She has a 50-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 102/68 mmHg, and pulse is 107/min. Physical exam is notable for epigastric tenderness and abdominal distention and rigidity. Which of the following will most likely confirm the patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a perforated peptic ulcer, which can manifest with the triad of sudden onset abdominal pain, tachycardia, and abdominal rigidity. Patients may also present with abdominal distention, secondary to free air accumulation, and with lightheadedness or syncope, secondary to blood loss or sepsis.    

Risk factors for the development of peptic ulcer disease include smoking, Helicobacter pylori infection, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use.    

The first step in diagnosis of a perforated peptic ulcer is to order an upright chest x-ray, which may show subdiaphragmatic free air. However, free air is present in only 75% of cases, likely because when patients arrive at the hospital shortly after symptom onset, not enough air has accumulated in the abdomen to be visible on x-ray. As a result, a CT should be performed in patients with high clinical suspicion, even if the chest x-ray is negative.



Option Analysis

❌ Twelve-lead electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: Acute coronary syndrome can lead to referred abdominal pain. However, this patient also has abdominal distention and a history of peptic ulcer disease. As a result, the patient’s pain is more likely due to a performed peptic ulcer. An electrocardiogram would not help in confirming this diagnosis. 
✅ Upright chest radiograph:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Mesenteric angiography:
Incorrect: Angiography is used in the work-up of mesenteric ischemia, which is characterized by postprandial abdominal pain. Patients with the condition will have little pain at baseline and will have a relatively normal physical exam. While this patient does have risk factors for mesenteric ischemia, the physical exam reveals abdominal distention and epigastric tenderness, favoring another diagnosis. 
❌ Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Incorrect: An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy can be used in the diagnosis of conditions such as variceal rupture or Dieulafoy lesions. However, endoscopy is generally contraindicated in patients with a gastrointestinal tract perforation. This is because the air insufflation and instrumentation associated with endoscopy may exacerbate the perforation.  
❌ Contrast esophagram :
Incorrect: A contrast esophagram is the gold-standard for diagnosing esophageal perforation, which most often occurs due to instrumentation or forceful vomiting. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with that of a perforated gastric ulcer. Contrast esophagram is not typically used in the work-up of this condition.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset sharp chest pain radiating to the back. The patient reports he has a history of long-standing hypertension, but he has not taken his medications in quite some time. His temperature is now 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination shows 1+ peripheral pulses in the right upper extremity and 2+ pulses in the left upper extremity. Neurological examination shows 3/5 power in the left upper and lower extremities compared to 5/5 power in the right upper and lower extremities. Cardiovascular examination reveals muffled heart sounds. An ECG is obtained, which shows non-specific T-wave changes as well as electrical alternans. Non-contrast CT-brain is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has concerning features for an aortic dissection including sudden onset, sharp chest pain radiating to the back, with associated findings of hypotension, pericardial tamponade, myocardial infarction, and focal neurologic deficits.  

Aortic dissections are caused by longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media created by a dissecting column of blood. They are a potentially catastrophic vascular complication that can cause end organ ischemia to a variety of organs - namely the brain and the heart. Aortic dissections are divided into two categories: Stanford type A and Stanford type B. Stanford type A dissection involves the ascending aorta and more commonly leads to hypotension, pericardial tamponade, stroke, and myocardial infarction (MI). The definitive management of Type A dissection is surgical repair.  

Stanford type B dissections occur distal to the ligamentum arteriosum and involve only the descending aorta. Type B dissections can also present with stroke-like symptoms, if for example the dissection were to progress retrograde and involve the left common carotid artery; however, this would produce right sided weakness, as opposed to left sided weakness seen in this patient. Type B dissections rarely dissect retrograde to yield tamponade, but they can progress anterograde to compromise blood flow to the renal arteries, resulting in acute renal failure. The definitive therapy for Stanford type B dissections is blood pressure control with either beta blockers, like esmolol, or vasodilators.  



Option Analysis

✅ Open vascular repair  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ IV esmolol:
Incorrect: Blood pressure management is the definitive therapy for type B aortic dissections, which occur distal to the ligamentum arteriosum and involve only the descending aorta.  The patient in this vignette has concerning features for pericardial tamponade given the muffled heart sounds and the electrical alternans on ECG. Pericardial effusions and subsequent tamponade are uncommon sequelae of type B aortic dissections and more common with type A aortic dissections.  
❌  Thrombolytic therapy  :
Incorrect: Thrombolytic therapy may be the treatment for an ischemic stroke or massive PE; however, the definitive treatment for this patient’s condition is endovascular repair of the ascending aorta. While PE is possible, the patient is this vignette is not hypoxic, and no signs of right ventricular strain are noted on his ECG, making the diagnosis of a massive PE less likely. The patient in this vignette is likely suffering a stroke from an aortic dissection; however, administration of thrombolytics in this situation may precipitate uncontrolled bleeding into the dissection and worsen the hemodynamic compromise.  
❌ Coronary revascularization:
Incorrect: While aortic dissections can mimic findings of acute MI due to compression on the coronary vessels, definitive therapy for type A aortic dissection involves endovascular repair of the ascending aorta. Patients with a true MI usually present with dull, pressure like pain, worsened on exertion, and relieved with rest or nitroglycerin. Neurologic deficits are an uncommon feature of isolated myocardial infarctions.   
❌ Pericardiocentesis:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette does have exam features concerning for pericardial tamponade, including electrical alternans, muffled heart sounds, hypotension and tachycardia. While pericardiocentesis may improve this patient’s hemodynamic instability, the definitive treatment for this patient’s condition involves repair of the aorta to prevent further pericardial tamponade.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the emergency department after being stabbed in the chest. The patient's primary survey is notable for decreased breath sounds over the right chest. Secondary survey reveals a single stab wound to the right lateral thorax, tracheal deviation, and jugular venous distension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 126/min, and blood pressure is 77/42 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Which of the following best describes the correct anatomic space for emergent intervention to manage this patient's condition?

choices.text: Fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line
Sternal head and clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid

questions.solution:
This patient has decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation, jugular venous distension, and hemodynamic instability in the setting of a stab wound to the right chest. He most likely has a tension pneumothorax. This clinical diagnosis must be recognized rapidly and treated by placing a large-bore angiocatheter (14-16G) at the second or third intercostal space at the midclavicular line.  

With correct placement, a gush of air is often audible, with subsequent lung reexpansion and improvement in oxygenation, heart rate, and blood pressure. Tube thoracostomy should always follow needle thoracostomy, with placement of a chest tube on the affected side at the fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line.  

Tension pneumothorax occurs in many clinical scenarios such as in penetrating trauma, blunt trauma, and mechanically ventilated patients. Regardless of the cause, the clinical features remain the same. Patients will develop dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, reduced breath sounds over the affected lung, and hyperresonance to percussion. In severe cases, patients can develop tracheal deviation. Patients can also have hypotension and elevated jugular venous pulsations secondary to compression of the heart and vena cava.

Option Analysis

✅ Second intercostal space midclavicular line  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line:
Incorrect: The fourth or fifth intercostal space describes the correct anatomic site for chest tube placement. While chest tubes are the definitive treatment for a pneumothorax, rapid intervention with needle thoracostomy should be performed first in patients with a tension pneumothorax to relieve pressure on mediastinal structures.
❌ Left lateral subxiphoid space:
Incorrect: A left lateral subxiphoid approach is often used in emergent pericardiocentesis to treat patients with cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade can present with the Beck triad (hypotension, jugular venous distention, and muffled heart sounds). However, it would not present with hyperresonance or tracheal deviation.  
❌ Sternal head and clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid:
Incorrect: Central venous access is commonly obtained by cannulating the internal jugular vein, which is found above the clavicle and between the two heads of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Central venous access is obtained for the administration of vasopressors, large volume transfusions, frequent blood draws, hemodynamic monitoring, and emergent dialysis. However, obtaining central venous access would not help treat this patient’s tension pneumothorax.
❌ Mid-infraclavicular space  :
Incorrect: The infraclavicular approach is another method to obtain central venous access. However, this technique has fallen out of favor since it does not allow for ultrasound confirmation of successful line placement.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man comes to the emergency department seeking evaluation for back pain. The pain began three hours ago when he fell while climbing a flight of stairs. He reports that the pain is worse with movement and improves when he lies down in bed. The patient has not had recent night sweats or unintentional weight loss. Past medical history is notable for osteoporosis and benign prostatic hyperplasia managed with prazosin. Vitals are within normal limits. Cardiac and pulmonary examination are noncontributory. Musculoskeletal exam is notable for tenderness over the thoracic spine. Neurological exam is notable for 3+ reflexes in the lower extremities and 2+ reflexes in the upper extremities. In addition, the patient has reduced sensation to soft touch and pinprick in the lower extremities. Imaging is ordered, and the results are as follows:



Reproduced from: Radiopedia  

Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a spinal compression fracture secondary to osteoporosis. Most patients with osteoporosis are generally asymptomatic until a fracture occurs. Symptoms of a spinal compression fracture include height loss, back pain, and kyphosis (excess outward curvature of the spine).  Neurological symptoms such as reduced sensation, reduced strength, and hyperreflexia in the lower extremities may be seen if the fracture causes spinal cord compression.

Radiographic imaging will often show vertebral height loss, retropulsed fragment (fracture fragment displaced into the spinal canal), or sharp fracture lines. Of note, there is prominent vertebral height loss in the image presented in this vignette (see Figure 1).  

Figure 1: Spinal Compression Fracture with Annotation  


The majority of patients with a spinal compression fracture without neurological symptoms are treated with conservative pain management. Medications used include acetaminophen, NSIADs, and opioid analgesics. Bisphosphonates can be used for the long-term management of osteoporosis. For patients with neurological deficits, surgical intervention should be performed to decompress the spinal cord.  

Option Analysis

❌ Order a PET-CT scan  :
Incorrect: A PET-CT scan can be used to detect occult malignancies. Metastasis of prostate cancer to the spine can result in compression fractures. However, this patient has no constitutional symptoms of cancer, such as night sweats or cachexia. Moreover, the patient’s recent fall provides a more likely explanation for the spinal fracture.
❌ Initiate ibuprofen treatment:
Incorrect: Analgesics such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can be used for pain management after a spinal fracture. However this patient also has neurological deficits, which are concerning for spinal cord compression, and surgical intervention is warranted.  
❌ Initiate bisphosphonate treatment:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates can be used for long-term osteoporosis management. However, they are not used in the management of acute spinal fractures secondary to osteoporosis.
✅ Surgical decompression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Provide back brace:
Incorrect: A back brace can give support and reduce spinal range of movement. It can be used to manage spinal fractures that do not have neurological symptoms. However, this patient has increased reflexes and decreased sensation in the lower extremities. These findings raise concerns for spinal cord compression, and surgical management is necessary.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of intermittent headaches and palpitations that have been ongoing for the past 3 months. The patient has no other medical problems and takes no medications. Further evaluation reveals markedly elevated plasma metanephrines, with abdominal imaging showing a 3 cm right adrenal mass. Surgical resection of the mass is scheduled in 2 weeks. Initiation with which of the following medications is necessary in preparation for surgery?
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytomas are neoplasms composed of chromaffin cells and are typically found within the adrenal medulla. The diagnosis can be made through biochemical confirmation of catecholamine hypersecretion, followed by identification of the tumor’s location via imaging studies.  

Non-selective alpha-receptor antagonists, such as phenoxybenzamine, are essential in the preoperative management of patients with pheochromocytoma. Administration of phenoxybenzamine in the preoperative period helps control hypertension intraoperatively, since manipulation of the tumor tissue can lead to catecholamine release; alpha blockade prevents these catecholamines from having an effect on the systemic vasculature and causing vasoconstriction. Beta-receptor antagonists, such as propranolol, may be administered after alpha-receptor blockade has been initiated to prevent the cardiac effects of excessive catecholamines.  

It is extremely important to note that beta antagonists should NOT be used prior to establishing effective alpha-receptor blockade, since unopposed beta-receptor blockade causes the circulating catecholamines to bind to alpha receptors, resulting in systemic vasoconstriction and life threatening elevations in blood pressure.  



Option Analysis

✅ Non-selective alpha blocker:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Alpha-1 selective antagonist :
Incorrect: Alpha 1-selective antagonists, such as prazosin and tamsulosin, are used in treating hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Preoperative treatment of a pheochromocytoma, however, requires a nonselective alpha antagonist.
❌ Alpha-2 selective agonist:
Incorrect: Alpha 2-selective agonists are used in the treatment of a variety of conditions, such as hypertension, ADHD, and as a muscle relaxant. The treatment of pheochromocytoma, however, requires a nonselective alpha antagonist. 
❌ Beta-1 selective agonist:
Incorrect: Selective beta-1 agonists, such as dobutamine, are used in patients with cardiogenic shock or acute heart failure, as they have a positive inotropic effect. The treatment of pheochromocytoma, however, requires a different treatment.  
❌ Non-selective beta blocker:
Incorrect: Although non-selective beta blockers, such as propranolol, can be used in the preoperative management of pheochromocytomas, they should NOT be used prior to establishing effective alpha-receptor blockade. This is because unopposed B-receptor blockade causes the circulating catecholamines to bind to alpha receptors, causing vasoconstriction and life threatening elevations in blood pressure.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a bicycle accident. The primary survey is unremarkable and secondary survey is notable for scattered abrasions over the face and chest wall. There is marked tenderness to palpation over the right mid-clavicle with overlying ecchymosis and crepitus. The patient has 2+ pulses in the right upper extremity and is otherwise neurovascularly intact. A radiograph of the right shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the next best step in management of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: CT-angiogram of the right upper extremity

questions.solution:
This patient presents with tenderness to palpation over the mid-clavicle with overlying ecchymosis and crepitus. The radiograph demonstrates a fracture of the mid-clavicle, which should be managed conservatively with analgesics and placement in a shoulder sling.

Clavicle fractures are a common injury, with a predilection towards affecting males and young children. In fact, it is the most commonly fractured bone in pediatric patients. Most injuries occur due to a direct force applied to the lateral aspect of the shoulder as a result of a fall, sporting injury, or motor vehicle collision. The most common area of fracture is the middle third of the clavicle, which accounts for approximately 80% of all clavicle fractures.

Clinically, most fractures will demonstrate swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness over the site of fracture. Associated features may include crepitus or visible deformity, depending on the degree of displacement. The majority of clavicle fractures are managed nonoperatively via placement in a shoulder sling with adequate analgesia and orthopedic referral. Indications for surgical management include open fractures, neurovascular compromise, and tenting of the skin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Shoulder sling  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Open reduction and internal fixation  :
Incorrect: Open reduction and internal fixation is rarely indicated in the management of clavicle fractures. Indications for surgical repair include open fractures, neurovascular compromise, and tenting of the skin.  
❌ Shoulder spica splint  :
Incorrect: Shoulder spica splints are most commonly used for temporary immobilization of the shoulder or elbow following open or closed fracture reduction. They are not indicated in the management of clavicular fractures that are non-operative.  
❌ Figure of eight sling  :
Incorrect: Figure of eight slings were historically recommended for clavicle fractures. However, they are no longer recommended.  
❌ CT-angiogram of the right upper extremity  :
Incorrect: This patient is without evidence of neurovascular compromise, making a CT-angiogram of the right upper extremity of limited utility.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound (GSW) to the chest. Per paramedics, the patient was shot several times over the right chest. He was initially alert and anxious but became more obtunded en route to the emergency department. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 137/min, respirations are 7/min, blood pressure is 71/40 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 85% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have three GSWs to the anterior chest with corresponding exit wounds on the back. Breath sounds are absent over the right lung. The trachea is midline, and there is no jugular venous distension. A Mayo stand is subsequently prepared for emergency tube thoracostomy. Which of the following best describes the correct anatomic placement for tube thoracostomy?

choices.text: Fourth intercostal space, midaxillary line, superior aspect of the rib
Second intercostal space, midclavicular line, inferior aspect of the rib
Second intercostal space, midclavicular line, superior aspect of the rib
Fourth intercostal space, midaxillary line, inferior aspect of the rib
Third intercostal space, midaxillary line, superior aspect of the rib

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features concerning for a traumatic hemothorax, thereby necessitating an emergent tube thoracostomy. The correct anatomic location for performing tube thoracostomy is at the fourth or fifth intercostal space, mid-axillary line, on the superior aspect of the rib.   

Tube thoracostomy, or chest tube placement, is a standard emergency medicine and trauma critical care procedure. Indications for tube thoracostomy include pneumothorax, hemothorax, extension of mediastinal air, air leak following pulmonary resection, and management of bronchopleural fistula. Care must be taken during placement to avoid injury to surrounding anatomic structures.  

Specific anatomic considerations include ensuring placement within the triangle of safety, which is formed anteriorly by the lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle, posteriorly by the lateral wall of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and inferiorly by the 5th intercostal space (or a horizontal line from the nipple). In addition, care should be taken when placing the tube, as it should be advanced over the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damage to the inferior neurovascular bundle. For pneumothoraces, the tube should advance superiorly into the chest cavity. In contrast, for hemothoraces, the tube should be advanced inferiorly into the chest cavity for adequate drainage.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Fourth intercostal space, midaxillary line, superior aspect of the rib:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Second intercostal space, midclavicular line, inferior aspect of the rib:
Incorrect: This anatomic site references the incorrect location for needle decompression. A needle and catheter should be placed on the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damage to the intercostal vasculature and nerve. 
❌ Second intercostal space, midclavicular line, superior aspect of the rib:
Incorrect: This anatomic site references the correct location for needle decompression. However, this question is about tube thoracostomy. 
❌ Fourth intercostal space, midaxillary line, inferior aspect of the rib:
Incorrect: This anatomic site references the incorrect location for tube thoracostomy. A chest tube should be placed over the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damage to the intercostal vasculature and nerve. 
❌ Third intercostal space, midaxillary line, superior aspect of the rib:
Incorrect: Placement of a chest tube in this anatomic space is more likely to result in iatrogenic harm to structures such as the brachial plexus and subclavian vasculature.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department after having a near-syncopal episode at home. The patient was sitting on the toilet when he passed a large volume of black tarry stool and felt lightheaded thereafter. Past medical history is notable for constipation and hyperlipidemia, for which he takes daily docusate and atorvastatin. The patient lost his job three-months ago and has been under significant stress. He drinks approximately 4-6 beers daily and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 127/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 90/71 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears pale and ill, and he is in moderate respiratory distress. A digital rectal examination reveals melena in the rectal vault. A complete blood count, type and screen, liver function tests, and coagulation studies are obtained, and the results are shown below. Based on this patient’s clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely source of bleeding?  

 Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Sodium  142 mg/dL  142 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.8 mg/dL  3.8 mmol/L 
 Chloride  100 mg/dL  100 mmol/L 
 Bicarbonate  16 mg/dL  16 mmol/L 
 Albumin  4.7 g/dL  47 g/L 
 BUN  45 mg/dL  16.06 mmol/L 
 Creatinine  1.3 mg/dL  1149.46 µmol/L 
 Coagulation studies   
 PT  12s  - 
 PTT  30s  - 
 Type and Screen  O+  - 
 Liver function tests   
 ALT  76 U/L  76 U/L 
 AST  167 U/L  167 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase  68 U/L  68 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with gastrointestinal bleeding, melena, and an elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level. Together, these findings are consistent with an upper gastrointestinal bleed, with the most likely source being a peptic ulcer.  

The assessment of acute gastrointestinal bleeding begins with determining hemodynamic stability versus instability. This step can be achieved by measuring vital signs and performing a comprehensive physical examination, which should include a digital rectal exam. Afterwards, two large bore IVs (18 gauge or larger) should be placed for intravenous access, and initial laboratory studies including a type and screen, complete blood count, liver function tests, and coagulation parameters should be obtained.  

Certain laboratory parameters can provide clues to the underlying cause of the patient’s gastrointestinal bleeding. In particular, a BUN/creatinine ratio exceeding 30 is suggestive of an upper gastrointestinal bleed in patients without renal failure due to increased intestinal absorption and breakdown of heme. In contrast, the BUN/creatinine ratio tends to be either low or normal in patients with a lower gastrointestinal bleed. Furthermore, liver function tests and coagulation parameters can help assess for liver cirrhosis and underlying coagulopathy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Peptic ulcer :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Esophageal varices  :
Incorrect: This patient most likely has an upper gastrointestinal bleed given the presence of melena and elevated BUN. While an elevated BUN can be seen in the setting of esophageal varices (also an upper gastrointestinal bleed), it is a less likely culprit in this patient. Esophageal varices usually develop in the setting of cirrhosis, which leads to decreased liver synthetic function, elevated PT, and reduced albumin level.  
❌ Diverticulosis:
Incorrect: Diverticulosis is one of the most common sources of lower gastrointestinal bleeding. Bleeding from a diverticulum will more likely result in the presence of bright red blood mixed with stool in the rectum as well as a normal BUN. In contrast, this patient has melanotic stools and a BUN/creatinine ratio > 30, which are more suggestive of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. 
❌ Internal hemorrhoids :
Incorrect: Internal hemorrhoids are an overall benign cause of lower gastrointestinal bleeding. In contrast, this patient has melanotic stools and a BUN/creatinine ratio > 30, which are more concerning for an upper gastrointestinal bleed. Furthermore, it would be rare for a hemorrhoid bleed to cause hemodynamic instability. 
❌ Colon adenocarcinoma  :
Incorrect: Colon cancer and other gastrointestinal malignancies can cause bleeding. However, they rarely present with acute signs of hemodynamic instability and hemorrhage. Furthermore, this patient has a BUN/creatinine ratio > 30, which is more suggestive of an upper gastrointestinal source of bleeding.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner after she experienced a sudden onset of right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began several hours ago. She also describes nausea and states she had a single episode of vomiting, which prompted her to come to the hospital. She describes similar episodes in the past that self-resolved after several hours, but this time, the pain persisted and worsened. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 122/68 mmHg, and pulse is 104/min. Physical examination reveals intense pain on palpation of the right upper quadrant, as well as diffuse rebound and guarding. An ultrasound is performed and reveals a normal common bile duct with concomitant gallbladder wall thickening and free fluid around the gallbladder. An abdominal CT is performed and reveals a perforation of the gallbladder. In addition to administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and intravenous fluids, which of the following is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, acute right upper quadrant pain, and peritonitis (e.g., rebound, guarding); in conjunction with ultrasound imaging demonstrating a thickened gallbladder wall, she likely has acute calculous cholecystitis, the most common complication of cholelithiasis. Additionally, the abdominal CT imaging revealed a perforated gallbladder, making this a surgical emergency.   

Acute cholecystitis is an acute inflammation of the gallbladder caused by obstruction of the cystic duct. When the cystic duct becomes obstructed by a stone, there is distension and inflammation of the gallbladder triggering an inflammatory response within the gallbladder. Clinical features typically include intense RUQ pain, fever, and nausea. In patients with uncomplicated and mild cases of acute cholecystitis, treatment consists of intravenous fluid therapy and empiric intravenous antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone with metronidazole, piperacillin-tazobactam). Patients with clinical improvement will also need an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy within 72 hours of symptom onset (preferably during the same admission) to prevent future recurrence or complications.  

In certain cases of acute cholecystitis, gallbladder gangrene/necrosis, gallbladder perforation, or emphysematous cholecystitis can occur, which necessitates an emergent cholecystectomy. These complications should be considered in patients with progressive symptoms and signs, such as high fever, hemodynamic instability, and/or peritonitis (such as in this patient).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Observation and expectant management :
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs of acute cholecystitis, as well as peritonitis (e.g., rebound, guarding). Observation and expectant management is not appropriate in this patient whose abdominal imaging revealed a perforated gallbladder. 
❌ Ursodeoxycholic acid therapy:
Incorrect: Therapy with ursodeoxycholic acid may be necessary in patients with symptomatic gallstones who are poor surgical candidates (e.g., concomitant underlying conditions such as uncontrolled diabetes or congestive heart failure). However, it is not appropriate in this patient presenting with signs of peritonitis and whose abdominal imaging revealed a perforated gallbladder.
❌ Elective cholecystectomy within 72 hours:
Incorrect: An elective cholecystectomy within 72 hours is appropriate in patients with mild cases of acute cholecystitis (e.g., no signs of peritonitis, gallbladder gangrene/necrosis, or gallbladder perforation). 
❌ Cholecystostomy :
Incorrect: Cholecystostomy involves the placement of a tube into the gallbladder to drain fluid, and it is often used as a temporizing measure in patients that cannot undergo cholecystectomy. This patient has no contraindications to surgery and therefore requires a different approach. 
✅ Emergent cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman is brought to the hospital for evaluation of constant and stabbing abdominal pain that began 28 hours ago. In addition, the patient has had several episodes of emesis. Medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia, for which she is taking atorvastatin and gemfibrozil. She immigrated from Thailand nine years ago. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 119/72 mmHg, and pulse is 83/min. Physical exam is notable for tenderness in the right upper abdominal quadrant. No abdominal distention is observed. Examination of the eyes reveals scleral icterus. The patient has dry mucosal membranes and a delayed capillary refill time. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?  

Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Hemoglobin  13.5 g/dL  135 g/L 
 Leukocyte Count  15,200/mm3  15.2*109/L 
 Neutrophils  88%  88% 
 Eosinophils  3%  3% 
 Lymphocytes  7%  7% 
 Total Bilirubin  5.1 mg/dL  87.21 µmol/L 
 Conjugated Bilirubin  4.6 mg/dL  78.66 µmol/L 
 Aspartate Aminotransferase  93 U/L  93 U/L 
 Alanine Aminotransferase  85 U/L  85 U/L 
 Lipase*  38 U/L  38 U/L 
*Reference range: 12-70 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice. These symptoms raise concern for acute cholangitis, which is an infection of the biliary tree in the setting of biliary obstruction. In addition, the patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and fibrate use. These are risk factors for the development of gallstones, which can potentially obstruct the biliary tract.  

Biliary tract infections are usually caused by gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria from the intestines. The most common is Escherichia coli, which accounts for 25-50% of cases. Additional pathogens include the Klebsiella, Enterococcus, and Enterobacter species.    

Patients should be started on empiric antibiotic regimens with gram-negative and anaerobic coverage. Single-agent regimens include piperacillin-tazobactam or carbapenems. Multi-drug regimens generally consist of a cephalosporin or fluoroquinolone used in combination with metronidazole.  

Option Analysis

❌ Echinococcus granulosus:
Incorrect: Infection by the Echinococcus tapeworms can result in the formation of hydatid cysts, which most often arise in the liver. Large cysts can obstruct biliary outflow, potentially accounting for many of the patient’s laboratory and physical exam findings. However, helminth infections typically cause eosinophilia, whereas this patient’s eosinophil count is within normal limits.  
❌ Clonorchis sinensis:
Incorrect: Clonorchis sinensis is a trematode that is endemic in East and Southeast Asia. The patient’s history of having previously lived in Thailand places her at increased risk. The pathogen can cause right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and weight loss. However, patients would typically also have eosinophilia. In contrast, this patient’s eosinophil count is within normal limits, and the acute nature of her symptoms suggests another diagnosis.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: This patient has the Charcot triad (i.e. the combination of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice), which raises concern for acute cholangitis. The condition is most commonly caused by gram negative and anaerobic bacteria that have entered the biliary tree. In contrast, Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacteria.   
❌ Hepatitis C virus:
Incorrect: Viral hepatitis can manifest with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes. However, patients with hepatitis generally have unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, while this patient has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, raising concern instead for a biliary tract obstruction. 
✅ Escherichia coli:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department after falling from a ladder. The patient was standing on a six-foot ladder when he suddenly lost balance, fell, and landed on his right side. He currently reports pain in the shoulder and over the right rib cage. He does not take any medications and does not have other medical conditions. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 132/63 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 20/min and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds at the right lung base, as well as a 5 cm x 5 cm area of ecchymosis over the lateral rib cage. A chest CT is obtained, and the results are shown below:

Image reproduced from

Which of the following best describes the correct anatomic space for emergent intervention to manage this patient's condition?

choices.text: Fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line
Fifth or sixth intercostal space midaxillary line
Sternal head and clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid

questions.solution:
This patient sustained blunt trauma to the chest, and the CT scan demonstrates fluid in the right pleural cavity. He most likely has a hemothorax, which should be managed with a tube thoracostomy.  

A hemothorax refers to blood in the pleural cavity. The condition is commonly associated with blunt or penetrating thoracic trauma. It is most commonly caused by injury to lung parenchyma, but it can also result from injury to the internal mammary arteries or the intercostal arteries.  

In most hemothoraces, bleeding is venous and manifests with mild tachypnea, borderline hypoxia, and tachycardia. If arterial injury occurs, hemorrhage into the pleural may become severe, resulting in hemodynamic instability and tension physiology.  

Hemothorax is diagnosed primarily by an upright chest x-ray, which will show a meniscus of fluid blunting the costophrenic angle and tracking up the pleural margins of the chest wall. Chest CT can also be used and will demonstrate fluid in the pleural cavity.  

Management of a hemothorax involves tube thoracostomy, which entails placing a chest tube at the 4th or 5th intercostal space midaxillary line. Afterwards, small hemothoraces (immediate drainage < 1500 mL and continued output < 200 mL/h over 4 hours) can be managed with observation. Large hemothoraces (if immediate drainage > 1500 mL and continued output > 200 mL/h over 4 hours) should be managed with an urgent thoracotomy.

Option Analysis

✅ Fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Second intercostal space midclavicular line  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes correct placement for emergent needle decompression in the setting of a tension pneumothorax. This patient does not have physical examination findings (e.g., tracheal deviation, jugular venous distention) or imaging findings (e.g. mediastinal shift) consistent with a tension pneumothorax. Instead, the imaging findings reveal fluid accumulation in the right chest.
❌ Fifth or sixth intercostal space midaxillary line  :
Incorrect: The patient has a right hemothorax. A tube thoracostomy should be performed to drain the blood. However, it would be inappropriate to perform the procedure at this anatomic location, as it places the patient at risk for diaphragmatic or intra-abdominal injury.
❌ Sternal head and clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid  :
Incorrect: Central venous access is commonly obtained by cannulating the internal jugular vein, which is found above the clavicle and between the two heads of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Central venous access is obtained for the administration of vasopressors, large volume transfusions, frequent blood draws, hemodynamic monitoring, and emergent dialysis. However, obtaining central venous access would not help treat this patient’s hemothorax.
❌ Mid-infraclavicular space  :
Incorrect: The infraclavicular approach is another method to obtain central venous access. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and does not need central venous access. Moreover, the infraclavicular approach has fallen out of favor since it does not allow for ultrasound confirmation of successful line placement.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. The patient is an avid weightlifter. However, over the past several months, he has experienced worsening left shoulder pain that is exacerbated by overhead movements. He has no history of major trauma or surgery. On physical examination, the patient has weakness in the left shoulder after downward pressure is applied while both arms are at 90° elevation in the scapular plane with full internal rotation. Which of the following anatomic structures is most likely to be disrupted given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with left shoulder pain that is exacerbated by overhead activities. There is reproducible weakness with the empty can test. These findings are consistent with rotator cuff injury. The most commonly injured rotator cuff muscle is the supraspinatus.

The rotator cuff muscles include the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis. These muscles coordinate complex movements of the shoulder joint and are commonly injured in athletes as well as older adults, resulting in a rotator cuff injury. The etiology of injury is often multifactorial and often stems from repetitive movements against resistance, rather than a single episode of trauma or injury to the shoulder.

The majority of rotator cuff injuries involve the supraspinatus, which is responsible for abduction of the arm. Patients often describe nagging pain localized to the deltoid that worsens with overhead movements. If a full thickness tear is present, patients may have weakness or an inability to raise the arm overhead.

The empty can test (also termed Jobe test) has a high specificity for supraspinatus injuries. In this test, the patient is placed in a standing or sitting position, and the arm is raised parallel to the ground in the scapular plane with the arm rotated to full internal rotation. Once rotated, the clinician pushes down on either the wrist or elbow, and the patient is instructed to resist the downward pressure. Weakness or pain in the tested shoulder elicits a positive test.  

Option Analysis

✅ Supraspinatus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subscapularis  :
Incorrect: While the subscapularis muscle is a part of the rotator cuff muscle group, it is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus muscle. The patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Infraspinatus  :
Incorrect: The infraspinatus is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus. In addition, this patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Teres minor  :
Incorrect: The teres minor is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus. In addition, this patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Biceps brachii  :
Incorrect: The biceps brachii is not a part of the rotator cuff muscle group.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound to the abdomen. The patient's primary survey is intact. A secondary survey reveals two bullet wounds 2.5 cm lateral to the umbilicus in the right lower quadrant and a single gunshot wound to the lateral right hemithorax. A focused sonographic assessment for trauma demonstrates free-fluid in the Morrison pouch. The patient is taken to the operating room for surgical exploration. Which of the following locations is the most appropriate incision site for this patient’s procedure?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after sustaining penetrating trauma to the abdomen. The FAST exam is positive, indicating the need for emergent operative exploration. The most appropriate surgical approach for an exploratory laparotomy is a midline incision.

The knowledge of several abdominal incisions for indicated procedures is critical, and selecting an incision relies on understanding the relevant abdominal anatomy. Key abdominal incisions include the Kocher (subcostal), midline, paramedian, Gridiron, Lanz, Pfannenstiel, and Rutherford Morrison.



Option Analysis

✅ Incision A  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incision B  :
Incorrect: The incision labeled B reflects a Kocher or subcostal incision. This approach is typically indicated for open biliary tract surgeries.
❌ Incision C  :
Incorrect: The incision labeled C reflects a Rutherford Morison incision, which is used for a partial colectomy or sigmoidectomy.  
❌ Incision D  :
Incorrect: The incision labeled D reflects a McBurney point incision, which is indicated for open appendectomies.  
❌ Incision E  :
Incorrect: The incision labeled E reflects a Pffanasteal incision, also termed a “bikini” incision. This surgical incision is used for gynecologic surgeries, such as cesarean sections.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of jaw pain. The pain started two hours ago after yawning, and now he cannot open or close his mouth. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness over the bilateral periauricular areas with palpable indentation of the preauricular space. The patient’s mouth is open and fixed. The coronoid process of the mandible is prominent and palpable just below the maxilla. Persistent spasm of which of the following muscles contributes to this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an anterior temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dislocation. TMJ dislocations occur when the mandibular condyle travels anteriorly and becomes locked at the superior anterior aspect of the articular eminence of the temporal bone, preventing closure of the mouth. Anterior TMJ dislocations are associated with stretching of the ligaments surrounding the TMJ and severe spasms of the muscles that open and close the mouth (i.e., the masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis muscles).

Anterior dislocations are the most common type of TMJ dislocation and often result from atraumatic mechanisms that involve excessive translational movement of the mandible. Examples include excessive yawning, singing, recurrent vomiting, intubation, or dental procedures. Anterior dislocations often present with jaw pain and decreased range of mandible motion (e.g. mandibular depression or elevation). Posterior dislocations are uncommon, as posterior translation is significantly resisted by the presence of the postglenoid tubercle and the strong intrinsic lateral ligament.  



Option Analysis

❌ Buccinator  :
Incorrect: The buccinator compresses the cheek inwards and pulls the corner of the mouth laterally, which aids in swallowing, mastication, blowing, and sucking. The buccinator contributes to mandibular protrusion and retrusion but not depression.  
❌ Genioglossus  :
Incorrect:  The genioglossus is responsible for tongue protrusion rather than the movement of the mandible.  
✅ Lateral pterygoid  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Omohyoid:
Incorrect: The omohyoid travels from the hyoid bone to the clavicle and helps depress the hyoid during speech or swallowing. It is not involved in the movement of the mandible.  
❌ Zygomaticus major:
Incorrect: The zygomaticus major pulls the angle of the mouth laterally and superiorly to facilitate smiling. It is not involved in the movement of the mandible.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate right wrist pain. The patient was outside skateboarding when she fell directly onto an outstretched right hand. The pain is primarily in the radial aspect of the wrist. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for tenderness to palpation over the radial fossa on the dorsal aspect of the hand. An initial radiograph of the right wrist is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Follow up radiograph in one week
Placement in the ulnar gutter splint

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH”) with reproducible pain in the anatomic snuffbox on physical examination – which is concerning for a scaphoid fracture. In patients with this injury, nearly 25% will have normal radiographs on initial presentation and thus should undergo repeat imaging in one week to assess for a fracture pattern.

The scaphoid is the most commonly injured carpal bone and accounts for nearly 70% of fractured carpal bones. The most common mechanism of injury involves a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH”), which leads to hyperextension of the wrist and axial loading. Clinically, patients will experience pain at the radial aspect of the wrist, with swelling or reproducible tenderness to palpation at the anatomic snuffbox. 

Diagnosis of scaphoid fractures remains challenging, as many initial radiographs are negative, leading to the underdiagnosis of occult fractures. Thus any patient with a suspected scaphoid fracture should undergo repeat imaging in one week to assess for fracture. When a fracture pattern is present, it will typically manifest as a lucent line across the waist of the scaphoid and possible displacement of the fracture fragments.

If undiagnosed, patients with scaphoid fractures are at an increased risk of avascular necrosis of the scaphoid due to its tenuous blood supply from two different branches of the radial artery. Ultimately, avascular necrosis can result in debilitating pain, wrist deformity, and premature osteoarthritis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Follow up radiograph in one week  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Percutaneous screw fixation  :
Incorrect: Percutaneous screw fixation is the most common method of surgical repair for scaphoid fractures. This patient does not have definitive radiographic evidence of a fracture pattern. As a result, surgical intervention would be inappropriate at the moment.  
❌ Closed reduction:
Incorrect: Closed reduction is not typically performed in the setting of a scaphoid injury.  
❌ CT-angiography of the upper extremity  :
Incorrect: While the proximal end of the scaphoid is at risk for avascular necrosis, CT-angiography is generally not helpful in assessing scaphoid injuries.  
❌ Placement in the ulnar gutter splint  :
Incorrect: Patients with scaphoid injuries should be placed in a thumb spica splint, not an ulnar gutter splint.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presents for follow-up evaluation regarding surgical treatment options for recently diagnosed non-small cell lung cancer. After several months of fatigue and dyspnea on exertion, the patient underwent CT imaging of the chest and was found to have a 6 cm mass occupying the medial segment of the right middle lobe. Biopsy of the lesion was consistent with large-cell carcinoma. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option based on this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer – specifically large cell carcinoma, an aggressive malignancy amenable to surgical resection. Of the surgical resection options listed, the most appropriate course of action is a right middle lobe resection, referred to as a lobectomy.   

Lung resections are often required in clinical practice to control aggressive malignancies or infectious processes. The right lung consists of ten bronchopulmonary segments, organized into three lobes. The left lung is also composed of ten segments, but it is organized into two lobes. In general, most tumors are removed through a lobectomy, wherein the entire lobe is removed to ensure an adequate margin of tumor removal.  

Other resection methods include a segmentectomy, wherein a single segment of the lung is removed. However, this procedure is reserved for those with associated pulmonary or cardiovascular comorbidities who would be unable to tolerate the removal of a full lobe. Other procedures include pneumonectomy, in which the entire lung is removed, and wedge resection, which refers to the non-anatomic removal of a portion of the lung (often reserved for biopsies).    

Option Analysis

✅ Right middle lobectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right pneumonectomy:
Incorrect: Right pneumonectomy refers to removing the entirety of the right lung. Based on the anatomic location of this patient’s malignancy, removing the entire lung would be inappropriate. 
❌ Right medial middle lobe segmentectomy:
Incorrect: A segmentectomy (anatomic sublobar resection) removes one or more segments by dividing their contributing arterial, venous, and bronchial elements. This procedure is often reserved for treating patients with tumors who cannot tolerate larger pulmonary resection due to underlying pulmonary disease or cardiovascular comorbidities. 
❌ Wedge resection:
Incorrect: Wedge resection is the non-anatomic removal of a portion of the lung, meaning the contributing vessels and minor airways are not individually dissected and ligated. This procedure is more commonly performed for biopsy of a lesion rather than curative resection.  
❌ Right sleeve resection:
Incorrect: A sleeve resection is an alternative to a pneumonectomy that involves removing a lobe containing a target lesion with a portion of the lobar bronchus to an uninvolved lobe.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a hand injury. The patient was jogging when he tripped and fell onto an area of concrete with scattered glass shards. He sustained lacerations to the left hand. He is otherwise healthy and does not take medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, and pulse is 103/min. Visual inspection of the left hand demonstrates a 4 cm laceration extending from the base of the hypothenar eminence to the thenar eminence. Which of the following should be evaluated to assess for underlying nerve injury?

choices.text: Sensation to the first, second, and third digits
Sensation to the medial fourth digit and entire fifth digit

questions.solution:
This patient sustained a laceration to the palm, which may lead to injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve that travels superficially in the palm. Among the physical examination maneuvers listed, assessment of active thumb abduction is paramount in evaluating for potential injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

Assessment of hand motor and sensory function after an injury is essential for appropriate treatment, disposition, and follow-up. All patients should undergo an assessment of strength, radial, ulnar, and digital pulses characterization, and a sensory examination. Patients with evidence of deficits should be assessed for associated tendinous, vascular, or nerve injury and, if discovered, should undergo consultation with a hand surgeon.

The median nerve provides sensation to the palmar aspect of the first, second, third, and half of the fourth digit. In addition, the nerve provides motor innervation to muscles in the thenar eminence and flexor muscles of the hand and wrist.

Injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve will manifest with pure motor deficits, as it innervates the three muscles of the thenar eminence: the abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and the superficial head of the flexor pollicis brevis. 

Option Analysis

✅ Active thumb abduction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sensation to the first, second, and third digits  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained a laceration of the palm, which can result in injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve. If the nerve is injured, patients will develop motor dysfunction without sensory deficits.  
❌ Active extension of the digits  :
Incorrect: Extension of the digits of the hand is mediated via the radial nerve, which courses on the dorsal aspect of the hand, not the palmar aspect.  
❌ Sensation to the medial fourth digit and entire fifth digit  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained a laceration of the palm, which can result in injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve. Sensation to these digits is mediated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve.  
❌ Active extension of the wrist  :
Incorrect: Extension of the wrist is mediated by the radial nerve, which courses on the dorsal aspect of the wrist, not the palmar aspect of the hand.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman is intubated for elective knee replacement surgery. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, obesity, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Following the surgery, the patient is noted to have paralysis of the upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the neck demonstrates spinal cord compression with attenuation of the transverse ligament. Which of the following was the most likely predisposing factor for this complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
The powerful forces associated with extreme flexion or extension injuries can result in fractures of C1 or C2, rupture of the transverse ligament, or anterior dislocation of the atlas on the axis, which is known as atlantoaxial subluxation.

Aside from trauma, other conditions are known to cause atlantoaxial subluxation. First, there can be pathological softening or loosening of the joint at the level of the transverse ligament, leading to an inability of the ligament to maintain the position of the atlantoaxial joint. These joint changes typically occur in the setting of inflammatory disorders like rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and ankylosing spondylitis.

Second, the transverse ligament itself may have increased laxity, a complication often associated with congenital connective tissue conditions like Marfan syndrome, Ehlers Danlos syndrome, or Down syndrome. Lastly, there can be agenesis of the transverse ligament entirely, as may be the case in Down syndrome.

Even though most individuals with atlantoaxial subluxation are asymptomatic or experience mild neck pain, a sudden or large movement, such as during intubation for surgery, may lead to compression and injury of the spinal cord if the cord becomes impinged between the posterior arch of the atlas and the dens. This injury can result in sensory loss and paralysis of all four extremities or even injury to the brainstem, leading to death.

Option Analysis

❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Although obesity is associated with worse postoperative outcomes, this patient’s atlantoaxial subluxation resulting in paralysis was likely due to another underlying risk factor.  
❌ Gender:
Incorrect: Gender is not significantly associated with atlantoaxial subluxation. Instead, this patient’s atlantoaxial subluxation resulting in paralysis was likely due to another underlying risk factor.  
❌ Type 2 diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Although uncontrolled diabetes is associated with worse postoperative outcomes, this patient’s atlantoaxial subluxation resulting in paralysis was likely due to another underlying risk factor.  
✅ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type of surgery:
Incorrect: While the type of surgery is not a risk factor for atlantoaxial subluxation, the act of intubation is significantly correlated with an atlantoaxial subluxation in patients with underlying risk factors due to manipulation of the neck.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man, who was brought into the emergency department by his friend, suddenly collapses in the waiting room. His t-shirt is saturated in blood, and he is immediately brought to the trauma bay. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a 1 cm stab wound over the left anterior chest wall, in addition to jugular venous distension. The jugular venous pulse is noted at the level of the mandible. The patient speaks in clear, complete sentences, and bilateral breath sounds are present. The telemetry rhythm strip is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?


Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with cardiac tamponade following penetrating chest trauma. He has jugular venous distension in addition to electrical alternans noted on telemetry. Given this patient’s unstable vital signs, he should immediately undergo transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and pericardiocentesis before definitive operative repair.

The acute management of adult chest pain follows a stepwise approach. First, patients should be evaluated for stability–including vital sign assessment, protection of airway, and mental status. Patients should immediately receive any necessary interventions to stabilize their airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients deemed unstable should be assessed for life-threatening causes of chest pain, such as myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, pericardial tamponade, tension pneumothorax, aortic dissection, and Boerhaave syndrome so appropriate intervention can be performed in a timely fashion. For example, immediate TTE and pericardiocentesis is indicated in the case of cardiac tamponade, and thrombolytics are indicated in the setting of massive pulmonary embolism.

Stable patients with chest pain should undergo further diagnostic workup to evaluate for more subtle presentations of a life-threatening diagnosis. All patients should receive an electrocardiogram to evaluate for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) or signs of ischemia. Specific ECG changes that suggest a life-threatening diagnosis include electrical alternans (pericardial tamponade) or an S1Q3T3 pattern (pulmonary embolism – though remember, the most common ECG finding in pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia).

Next, most patients with chest pain who have ECG changes should be further evaluated with laboratory testing using serial troponin assays to evaluate for underlying cardiac ischemia and non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). Stable patients should also have chest radiography, which can assess for the presence of a pneumothorax, mediastinal air suggestive of esophageal perforation, or a widened mediastinum suggestive of aortic dissection.


Option Analysis

✅ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Thoracotomy:
Incorrect: Bedside thoracotomy should be reserved for pulseless patients who received CPR less than 15 minutes after traumatic thoracic injury. This trauma patient has evidence of unstable vital signs but is not pulseless.
❌ Needle decompression:
Incorrect: Needle decompression is indicated for patients with suspected pneumothorax. Patients with this condition will have evidence of diminished breath sounds following trauma.
❌ Intubation:
Incorrect: This patient is currently protecting his airway, and thus intubation is not currently indicated. Moreover, intubation may worsen this patient’s hypotension, resulting in cardiac arrest.
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: Chest radiography should only be obtained once this patient is stabilized and is therefore not currently indicated.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient had spent the evening at a bar with friends and consumed 9 shots of liquor. Shortly after leaving the bar, he felt nauseated and vomited multiple times. The last episode of vomiting produced bright red emesis. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he uses an albuterol inhaler. Upon arrival, vitals are within normal limits. During the physical exam, the patient has slurred speech but is able to answer questions. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. The patient has no additional episodes of hematemesis. Which of the following describes the most likely long-term prognosis for this patient?

choices.text: Spontaneous cessation of bleeding with no complications
Recurrent episodes of bleeding from same site
Development of pneumonia secondary to aspiration
Dysphagia secondary to esophageal stricture formation

questions.solution:
This patient has a Mallory-Weiss tear, also termed gastro-esophageal laceration syndrome, which manifests as a longitudinal, partial-thickness tear of the gastroesophageal junction mucosa. The condition frequently occurs due to forceful vomiting, which increases intra-abdominal pressure. Mallory-Weiss tears can also be due to coughing, abdominal trauma, or abdominal straining.    

Patients with hiatal hernias are at increased risk of developing Mallory-Weiss tears. One proposed explanation is that the hernia experiences a greater pressure gradient than the rest of the stomach. Additional risk factors for Mallory-Weiss tears include alcoholism and eating disorders with purging behaviors.    

Individuals with Mallory-Weiss tears can be asymptomatic, or they can present with painful hematemesis. In most cases, the condition spontaneously resolves within 72 hours.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spontaneous cessation of bleeding with no complications:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Progression to full-thickness esophageal perforation:
Incorrect: This patient likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear, which is a partial-thickness laceration to the esophageal mucous that often occurs after repeated vomiting. Most Mallory-Weiss tears self-resolve, particularly once the vomiting stops, and it would be atypical for a tear to progress to a full-thickness esophageal perforation. 
❌ Recurrent episodes of bleeding from same site :
Incorrect: Patients with esophageal varices, which often arise secondary to portal hypertension, are likely to experience recurrent bleeding episodes. However, this patient has hematemesis in the setting of forceful vomiting and no history of portal hypertension, which is most consistent with a Mallory-Weiss tear. Most Mallory-Weiss tears stop bleeding spontaneously and heal within 72 hours. 
❌ Development of pneumonia secondary to aspiration:
Incorrect: Patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding and altered consciousness are at increased risk of aspiration pneumonia. Although this patient is intoxicated, he is able to talk and therefore protect his airway, thus making aspiration pneumonia unlikely. 
❌ Dysphagia secondary to esophageal stricture formation:
Incorrect: An esophageal stricture refers to abnormal narrowing of the esophageal lumen. It can be caused by conditions ranging from malignancy to long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, it would be unusual for a single Mallory-Weiss tear to result in stricture formation.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to sudden onset right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began several hours ago. The patient has a past medical history significant for severe Crohn disease that required a small bowel resection 1 year ago, and, since that time, she has been on total parenteral nutrition. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 124/84 mmHg, and pulse is 96/min. Physical examination shows a thin woman in mild distress. Abdominal examination reveals right upper quadrant tenderness. Laboratory studies are shown below. An ultrasound is performed, which produces exquisite pain and inspiratory arrest when the physician places the probe in the right upper quadrant. Imaging reveals a normal common bile duct with concomitant gallbladder wall thickening, but no gallstones are visualized. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?  

 Laboratory value  Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL  145 g/L 
 Leukocyte count  14,500 mm3  14*109/L 
 Total bilirubin  1.5 mg/dL  25.65 µmol/L 
 Direct bilirubin  0.5 mg/dL  8.55 µmol/L 
 Alanine aminotransferase  55 U/L  55 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  60 U/L  60 U/L 
 Lipase  45 U/L  45 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   95 U/L  95 U/L

choices.text: Ascending infection of the biliary tract
Mechanical obstruction of the cystic duct
Obstruction of the common bile duct

questions.solution:
This patient with severe Crohn disease and prolonged therapy with total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is presenting with fever and acute right upper quadrant pain; in conjunction with her laboratory values showing leukocytosis and her ultrasound imaging demonstrating a thickened gallbladder wall with no visible gallstones, she likely has acute acalculous cholecystitis. This is more common in elderly patients, those who are already seriously ill, or those who have been on TPN for a prolonged period of time. The cause is gallbladder hypomotility and bile stasis which concentrates the bile, making it toxic to the gallbladder walls, eventually leading to inflammation and necrosis. This patient has been on prolonged therapy with TPN, causing bile stasis, which is the likely cause of her acalculous cholecystitis.  

Clinical features typically include intense RUQ pain, fever, and nausea. Additionally, this patient demonstrated a positive sonographic Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory pause upon placing the ultrasound probe on the gallbladder). Laboratory findings typically demonstrate leukocytosis with an increased number of band forms (i.e. left shift). Mild elevations in the serum total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and liver enzymes can also be seen in patients with acalculous cholecystitis.  

The best initial step for diagnosing acute acalculous cholecystitis is an ultrasound of the right upper quadrant. If there are no stones visualized on an ultrasound, or if the diagnosis is uncertain, a CT scan or HIDA scan would be the next appropriate step. Since HIDA scans take longer, it should only be considered in hemodynamically stable patients. For a HIDA scan, a radioactive tracer is injected into a vein, which then enters the bile-producing cells in the liver that will secrete the tracer into bile. The bile carries the tracer through the entire hepatobiliary system and allows visualization; therefore, in acute cholecystitis, the tracer will not fill the gallbladder, indicating a positive test.    

Option Analysis

❌ Ascending infection of the biliary tract:
Incorrect: This describes acute cholangitis, which is characterized by inflammation of the biliary ducts. This condition is most commonly caused by gallstones, which impair bile outflow, causing biliary stasis, and thus creating an environment for the bacteria that have ascended the biliary tract to proliferate. This patient’s imaging shows no gallstones, and the lack of jaundice makes this unlikely. 
❌ Mechanical obstruction of the cystic duct :
Incorrect: This describes calculus cholecystitis, which occurs when a gallstone obstructs the cystic duct and causes gallbladder distention and inflammation. Patients can develop right upper quadrant pain and fever, similar to the patient seen here. However, this patient was not found to have a visible gallstone, which suggests a different diagnosis.  
✅ Gallbladder hypomotility :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obstruction of the common bile duct:
Incorrect: This answer describes choledocholithiasis, which can cause right upper quadrant pain, nausea/vomiting, and extrahepatic cholestasis. However, the condition is not associated with infection. As a result, patients with choledocholithiasis would not have fever or leukocytosis.
❌ Gallstone obstructing the small bowel:
Incorrect: In cases of gallbladder perforation and fistula formation between an inflamed gallbladder and the bowel, gallstones can pass into the bowel lumen and cause mechanical obstruction. Patients with gallstone ileus typically present with signs of small bowel obstruction, such as abdominal pain and distension, as well as nausea and vomiting. Although this patient’s underlying Crohn disease predisposes her to this condition, ultrasound imaging classically demonstrates pneumobilia (air in the biliary ducts).

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the clinic with persistent leg pain with exertion. Three months ago, the patient was found to have an ankle-brachial index of 0.6, and he was started on atorvastatin, chlorthalidone, and aspirin. Since then, the patient has successfully quit smoking and has participated in a supervised exercise therapy program where he has achieved a 10 lb (4.5 kg) weight loss. The pain, characterized by aching in the right thigh and buttock after walking more than 3 blocks, has not improved. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg, and BMI is 32 kg/m2. Pulses in the right femoral artery are diminished compared to the left. Which of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with claudication and an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.6, confirming the diagnosis of moderate peripheral artery disease (PAD). He was appropriately started on lifestyle modifications (weight reduction, exercise therapy, smoking cessation) and pharmacologic astherosclerotic risk-reduction therapies (statin for cholesterol reduction, calcium channel blocker for blood pressure reduction, and antiplatelet drugs to reduce thrombotic risk) but has had no noticeable improvement in symptoms after three months.

At this point, the most appropriate next step is to start cilostazol, a phosphodiesterase type 3 (PDE3) inhibitor. By inhibiting PDE3 and thereby increasing cAMP, active protein kinase A (PKA) levels are boosted, leading to an inhibition of platelet aggregation and enhanced arterial vasodilation. If symptoms still fail to improve after an additional three months, advanced vascular imaging (CT or MR angiography) should be performed to identify potential invasive therapeutic targets.    


A percutaneous revascularization approach called percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is the first choice for individuals with a single, short segment of blood vessel that has uniform occlusion. In this procedure, a deflated balloon is introduced into the target vessel and inflated to open the vessel and increase blood flow. In some cases, a stent is also placed. Once blood is flowing freely through the artery, the balloon catheter is taken out. This treatment is less invasive but not as durable as open surgery.  

Open surgery is reserved for occlusions that affect long, multifocal segments or contain calcified lesions. Surgical options for revascularization are endarterectomy, where the artery is opened up and plaque is removed, or bypass, where a graft is used to create a new conduit that reroutes blood around a blocked artery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Trial of a P2Y12 inhibitor  :
Incorrect: Dual antiplatelet therapy (usually a combination of aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor like clopidogrel) has not been shown to improve outcomes in patients with peripheral artery disease, and it can place the patient at unnecessary risk for severe bleeding.  
✅ Trial of a PDE3 inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Aortoiliac angioplasty:
Incorrect: Aortoiliac angioplasty is reserved for patients with peripheral artery disease who fail conservative pharmacologic and lifestyle management and have significant aortoiliac disease confirmed on advanced vascular imaging (CT or MR angiography).   
❌ Femoropopliteal angioplasty:
Incorrect: Femoropopliteal angioplasty is reserved for patients with peripheral artery disease who fail conservative pharmacologic and lifestyle management and have significant, lifestyle-limiting femoropopliteal disease confirmed on advanced vascular imaging (CT or MR angiography).   
❌ Femoropopliteal bypass:
Incorrect: Femoropopliteal bypass is reserved for patients with peripheral artery disease who fail conservative pharmacologic and lifestyle management and have significant, lifestyle-limiting, long-segment femoropopliteal disease confirmed on advanced vascular imaging (CT or MR angiography).

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of facial weakness. Earlier in the morning, she had trouble drinking coffee as it was drooling from the right side of her face. Her partner mentioned that her face was drooping, and she noticed that she could not move her mouth or eyebrows on that side. She has not had hearing loss, ringing sensation in the ears, or difficulty walking. She underwent a right superficial parotidectomy for the resection of a pleomorphic adenoma in the parotid gland two days ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows asymmetry of the face with smiling. There is also loss of the right nasolabial fold, with drooping of the eyelids and lips on the right side.
