The rest of the examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings seen in this patient?

choices.text: Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve

questions.solution:
This patient has new-onset right-sided facial weakness causing drooling from the right side of the face, facial droop, asymmetric smile, and inability to move the eyebrow after recent surgery involving the parotid gland. She likely suffered intraoperative facial nerve injury causing ipsilateral facial muscle paralysis.

During its extracranial course, the motor component of the facial nerve enters the parotid gland, where it forms the parotid plexus. This plexus then divides into the terminal branches to innervate the facial muscles. Injury to this area (e.g., secondary to trauma, iatrogenic, etc.) can lead to ipsilateral paralysis of the facial muscles. Since the nerves to the stapedius and chorda tympani branch proximal to this area, the patient does not experience hyperacusis or abnormalities in taste.

Patients with paralysis need to keep the eye lubricated (with artificial tears) and closed while sleeping (with a taping of the eye) to prevent corneal trauma and desiccation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Tick-borne illness:
Incorrect: Early disseminated Lyme disease can involve CN VII, leading to facial nerve palsy. However, it is usually accompanied by a macular rash, arthralgia, and aseptic meningitis. Considering the recent surgery, the temporal association of symptoms makes it a more likely cause.
❌ Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve:
Incorrect: Unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face due to dual UMN control of the upper face, thereby sparing it. This patient has paralysis of upper facial muscles, making UMN lesion less likely.
❌ Reactivation of a dormant virus:
Incorrect: The major complication of reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus is the Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which typically includes the triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the auditory canal and auricle. This patient does not have otalgia, and physical examination of the auricle and auditory canal is unremarkable.
✅ Recent surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tumor at the cerebellopontine angle:
Incorrect: Even though a tumor at a cerebellopontine angle (e.g. schwannoma) can sometimes involve facial nerve, it is usually preceded by the symptoms of CN VIII impingement (i.e., tinnitus, ataxia, vertigo, or sensorineural hearing loss), none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after sustaining a shoulder injury while playing football. The patient was diving towards the end-zone when another player collided directly with his left shoulder. On physical examination, the patient is holding the left arm adducted. Swelling is present over the lateral aspect of the left shoulder. A radiograph of the left shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lateral shoulder pain after a direct blow to the acromioclavicular joint. The radiograph demonstrates widening of the acromioclavicular joint, which is consistent with acromioclavicular joint separation.

Acromioclavicular joint separation is a common injury. It is most often seen in young males engaged in bicycle accidents or high impact sports such as football. The most common mechanism of injury occurs due to a direct blow to the lateral aspect of the shoulder while the arm is held in adduction.

Clinical features include swelling and tenderness to the lateral aspect of the shoulder. A physical examination maneuver known as the crossover test, wherein passive cross-body adduction of the arm compresses the acromioclavicular joint, may elicit pain. Radiography will demonstrate widening of the acromioclavicular joint, superior displacement of the clavicle, and widening of the coracoclavicular ligament.

Injuries to the acromioclavicular joint are classified based on the degree of damage sustained by the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments. In general, most injuries are managed nonoperatively via placement in a sling and immobilization.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acromioclavicular separation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sternoclavicular separation  :
Incorrect: Sternoclavicular joint separations will often demonstrate a deformity and swelling along the medial aspect of the clavicle. They are more often anterior and without significant complications. Posterior dislocations are associated with increased morbidity due to their propensity to disrupt vascular structures.  
❌ Posterior shoulder dislocation  :
Incorrect: Posterior shoulder dislocations are rare but can occur in the setting of high speed motor vehicle accidents, status epilepticus, and lightning injuries. Plain films will demonstrate a posteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view.  
❌ Anterior shoulder dislocation  :
Incorrect: Anterior shoulder dislocations are the most common form of shoulder dislocation and present with a squared-off appearance of the shoulder. The dislocated arm is typically in slight abduction and external rotation. The axillary Y-view will demonstrate an anteriorly placed humeral head relative to the glenoid fossa.  
❌ Clavicle fracture  :
Incorrect: There is no evidence of a left clavicle fracture on this patient’s radiograph.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. He can no longer do bench presses or shoulder presses at the gym due to weakness and pain. The pain is primarily located over the lateral shoulder, is worse at night, and is preventing him from obtaining adequate rest. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. He has no history of recent trauma or surgeries to the left shoulder. The patient subsequently undergoes a MRI of the left shoulder, which reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to yield a positive test, given this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening left shoulder pain and weakness. MRI imaging demonstrates a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon. Of the physical examination techniques listed, the one most likely to demonstrate a positive finding is the empty can test.

The shoulder is made up of the rotator cuff muscles, the glenohumeral and acromioclavicular ligaments, and connective tissue. In the assessment of shoulder pain, several tests can aid in the diagnosis of a specific injury. For instance, the empty can test (also termed Jobe test) has a high specificity for supraspinatus injuries. In this test, the patient is placed in a standing or sitting position, and the arm is raised parallel to the ground in the scapular plane and fully internally rotated. Once rotated, the clinician pushes down on either the wrist or elbow, and the patient is instructed to resist the downward force. Weakness or pain in the tested shoulder represents a positive test result.

Another test known as the full can test also assesses for supraspinatus instability. It is performed in the same manner as the empty can test, with the only difference being that the patient's arms are not rotated to full internal rotation (e.g. thumbs are up).

Additional tests include the Neer test and Hawkins-Kennedy test, which assess for subacromial impingement syndrome. The Scarf test assesses for stability of the acromioclavicular joint and is commonly positive with partial or full tears of the acromioclavicular or coracoclavicular ligaments.  

Option Analysis

✅ Empty can test  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lift off test  :
Incorrect: The lift off test is performed to assess for instability of the subscapularis. In this test, the patient actively lifts the dorsum of the hand off the back with resistance. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Scarf test  :
Incorrect: The Scarf test is used to assess for stability of the acromioclavicular joint. It is performed by passively adducting the patient's arm across the body horizontally, approximating the elbow to the contralateral shoulder. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Neer test  :
Incorrect: The Neer test is used to assess for subacromial impingement syndrome. This test is performed by stabilizing the patient's scapula with one hand and passively flexing the arm while it is internally rotated. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Yergason test  :
Incorrect: The Yergason test is used to assess for tear or rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii. In this test, pain is reproduced at the anterior shoulder as the patient attempts to supinate the arm against resistance when the arm is pronated and flexed at the elbow to 90 degrees. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. Per emergency medical services, the patient sustained a stab wound to the right anterior chest. Prompt physical examination demonstrates a pocket knife lodged in the anterior chest wall. It is located in the parasternal space at the level of the fourth intercostal space. Given this patient's trauma mechanism, which of the following regions of the heart is at the most significant risk of injury?
questions.solution:
Cardiac injury secondary to penetrating trauma to the thorax is a leading cause of death due to urban violence (approximately 80% mortality rate). Understanding the anatomic locations of chambers in the heart can help predict the area of injury. Most penetrating trauma to the heart is to the right ventricle (43%) compared to the left ventricle (34%), owing to its anterior anatomic location. The atria are also less commonly injured, given their more posterior anatomic location and shielding via the sternum. Following injury, patients may exsanguinate into the pleural space if the cardiac lesion communicates freely with the pleural cavity, or they may suffer cardiac tamponade if the hemorrhage is contained within the pericardium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right ventricle:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right atrium:
Incorrect: While the right atrium also lies anteriorly in the thorax, it is relatively protected by the sternum. Given this patient's mechanism of injury, the right ventricle is more susceptible to injury. 
❌ Left ventricle :
Incorrect: The left ventricle lies most posterior in the thorax, thus shielding it from anterior penetrating stab wounds. 
❌ Left atrium:
Incorrect: Like the left ventricle, the left atrium lies most posterior in the thorax, thus shielding it from anterior penetrating stab wounds. 
❌ Aortic outflow tract :
Incorrect: The aortic outflow tract is protected posteriorly in the thorax. Penetrating stab wounds are unlikely to injure this vessel.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of acute-onset hematemesis that began around three hours ago. The patient denies any recent abdominal trauma. Past medical history is notable for peptic ulcer disease and hypertension. He is currently taking pantoprazole and propranolol. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 135/74 mmHg, and pulse is 81/min. During the physical exam, the patient is anxious but is able to answer questions and does not appear to be in acute distress. Abdominal exam is notable for epigastric tenderness that is elicited with light palpation. Cardiovascular and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. Two peripheral intravenous catheters are placed, and a saline infusion is started. The patient is started on intravenous pantoprazole. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has upper gastrointestinal tract bleeding. Given his history of peptic ulcer disease and hematemesis, a peptic ulcer bleed is the most likely cause. At this time, a subsequent gastrointestinal tract perforation is unlikely due to the patient’s hemodynamic stability and lack of abdominal distention.  

For patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding, the first step in management is to place at least two large-border intravenous catheters. Afterwards, intravenous fluids and empiric proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy should be initiated. PPIs have been shown to reduce the risk of subsequent bleeding. This is largely because PPIs reduce gastric acid production and in turn promote blood clot stabilization. Patients should also be made NPO (nothing by mouth).    

Once stabilized with the aforementioned measures, an upper endoscopy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and achieve hemostasis at the bleeding site.   

Option Analysis

❌ Perform urease breath test:
Incorrect: A urease breath test can be used in the work-up of a suspected Helicobacter pylori infection, which can predispose patients to peptic ulcers. However, it would be inappropriate to perform the test right now. This patient has an active bleed, and the next steps should involve identifying the source and achieving hemostasis. 
❌ Initiation of ceftriaxone therapy:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone and other broad-spectrum antibiotics can be used for prophylaxis in patients with variceal bleeds or gastrointestinal tract perforation. In contrast, this patient’s presentation of hematemesis, history of peptic ulcer disease, and lack of abdominal distention or crepitus is more consistent with a peptic ulcer bleed. Acute-management of this condition does not require antibiotics.   
✅ Perform upper gastrointestinal endoscopy :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Order chest radiograph:
Incorrect: A chest radiograph can be used to detect gastrointestinal (GI) tract perforations, which can manifest with a mediastinal widening or subdiaphragmatic free air. Patients can develop hemodynamic instability, abdominal pain, and distention. In contrast, this patient is hemodynamically stable and has no abdominal distention. The epigastric pain can be better explained by his peptic ulcer disease.   
❌ Initiation of octreotide therapy :
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to stop acute variceal bleeding. Esophageal varices usually develop in patients with portal hypertension. In contrast, this patient has no history or physical exam findings suggestive of liver cirrhosis or portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, caput medusae, jaundice), making a variceal bleed unlikely.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presented to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain radiating to the back. He was diagnosed with a type A aortic dissection and proceeded to the operating room for emergent open repair. Following the procedure, the patient is brought to the post-operative care unit for further monitoring. During the patient’s postoperative assessment, he reports thoracic back pain and an inability to move the bilateral lower extremities. The patient's temperature is 98.6.0 °C (37 C °F), pulse is 30/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 195/95 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air.  Pinprick testing demonstrates bilateral loss of pain sensation below the xiphoid process. The patient has preserved proprioception, vibratory sense, fine touch, and two-point discrimination. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Ischemia of the anterior spinal artery
Ischemia of the posterior spinal arteries
Acute inflammation of gray and white matter spinal cord tracts
Expansion of a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord

questions.solution:
This patient who underwent surgery for repair of an aortic dissection is found to have several neurologic deficits postoperatively. Given his findings, there is a concern for damage to the corticospinal tracts and anterior spinothalamic tracts reflective of ischemia to the anterior spinal artery.    

The spinal cord receives its blood supply through three primary arteries–one anterior spinal artery and two posterior spinal arteries. The anterior spinal artery provides blood to the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, which houses the lateral corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts. The posterior spinal arteries provide blood supply to the posterior one-third of the spinal cord, which houses the dorsal column pathways.  

Ischemia to the spinal cord is an overall rare event but can occur in the setting of trauma, surgery, infection, embolic events, vasculitis, or malignancy. Ischemia of the anterior spinal artery most commonly occurs after aortic surgery–typically due to prolonged cross-clamping of the aorta. The most common area of ischemia is at the level of the Artery of Adamkiewicz, or T8. Clinically, this manifests after surgery with findings of acute back pain at the level of injury, bilateral flaccid paralysis, and loss of pain and temperature sensation, preserving the dorsal column pathway functions. Additional findings include autonomic dysfunction, respiratory failure, and spinal shock with higher thoracic and cervical lesions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ischemia of the anterior spinal artery  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ischemia of the posterior spinal arteries  :
Incorrect: Occlusion of the posterior spinal arteries would result in diminished proprioception, vibratory sense, fine touch, and two-point discrimination as these arteries supply the dorsal column pathways.  
❌ Acute inflammation of gray and white matter spinal cord tracts :
Incorrect: Transverse myelitis does not typically occur in the setting of trauma or recent surgery but rather as a post-infectious or progressive autoimmune syndrome.  
❌ Expansion of a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord  :
Incorrect: A syrinx may present with bilateral loss of temperature and pain sensation due to the anterior white commissure disruption. It does not typically involve the lateral corticospinal tract, and therefore, motor function is preserved.  
❌ Anterior thoracic epidural hematoma:
Incorrect: Spinal epidural hematomas rarely occur outside the setting of trauma or fracture to the vertebral bodies. This patient’s presentation is instead concerning for ischemia to the anterior spinal artery.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department from a nursing home for evaluation of altered mental status and fever for the past three days. Medical history includes well-controlled type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a right middle cerebral artery stroke that occurred five years ago. The patient has limited mobility and is largely bedbound. Temperature is 38.7°C (102°F), blood pressure is 179/98 mmHg, and pulse is 83/min. Physical examination reveals a 10 x 10 x 3 cm wound in the gluteal region as shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s physical examination findings?

choices.text: Prolonged pressure over the affected region

questions.solution:
This patient has an area of soft tissue necrosis and surrounding erythema in the gluteal region. These findings combined with a history of immobility are most suggestive of a pressure-induced soft tissue injury.   

Pressure-induced soft tissue injury (also termed pressure ulcers or bed sores) describes damage to the skin and underlying soft tissues caused by prolonged pressure. Pressure injuries most commonly develop over bony prominences, such as the sacrum, greater trochanter, scapula, and occiput. Prolonged pressure decreases blood flow to the affected skin and soft tissues, leading to hypoxia, ischemia, and necrosis.  

Patients often have a history of risk factors such as immobility, malnutrition, neurological diseases (e.g., stroke, neuropathy), diabetes mellitus, or perfusion disorders (e.g., heart failure, peripheral vascular disease). Affected patients typically experience pain at the site of injury.  

It is important to assess the wound bed and depth since they are the most important factors in determining the grade of the injury which will determine the treatment. The soft tissue surrounding the wound should be checked for skin color and edema, which can identify the presence of infection. There may be signs of wound healing, such as granulation tissue and epithelialization.  

Option Analysis

❌ Infection with spore-forming gram-positive bacteria  :
Incorrect: Bacillus anthracis is a spore-forming gram-positive rod. The pathogen can cause cutaneous anthrax, which manifests with areas of tissue necrosis termed eschars. A pressure-induced soft tissue injury and not anthrax is more likely the cause of this bed bound patient’s lesion.  
❌ Infection with flea-borne gram-negative bacteria  :
Incorrect: Yersinia pestis is a gram-negative bacillus transmitted by fleas. The pathogen is responsible for the historical bubonic plague. Clinically, infection with Yersinia pestis leads to swollen and painful lymph nodes, but it can also lead to cutaneous manifestations (e.g., eschars, pustules). It is more likely that this bed bound patient has a pressure-induced ulcer.  
❌ Neoplastic proliferation of malignant cells  :
Incorrect: This patient has a history of prior stroke and immobility. Physical examination reveals tissue necrosis in the left gluteal region. These findings favor a pressure ulcer over a neoplastic process.  
✅ Prolonged pressure over the affected region  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chronic hyperglycemia  :
Incorrect: In general, diabetes mellitus and hyperglycemia can increase a patient’s risk of developing pressure ulcers and infection, and patients with peripheral neuropathy from poorly controlled diabetes can develop diabetic foot ulcers. In this bed bound patient with well-controlled diabetes, prolonged sacral pressure would be the primary underlying cause of the decubitus ulcer. Prolonged pressure causes tissue hypoxia, ischemia, and necrosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the emergency department with crampy abdominal pain and nausea and vomiting for the past 3 days. The patient has no significant medical history and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 39.4ºC (103ºF), pulse is 122/min, blood pressure is 108/63 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals an ill-appearing male visibly in pain on the stretcher. There is guarding and tenderness to palpation over the right lower abdominal quadrant. A palpable mass is present in the right lower quadrant. Initial blood work demonstrates a leukocytosis with left shift. Which of the following findings, if present, would suggest a complicated presentation of the underlying disease process?

choices.text: Surrounding appendiceal abscess on abdomen pelvis CT
Appendiceal diameter less than 6 mm on abdomen pelvis CT
Periappendiceal fat stranding on abdomen pelvis CT
Appendiceal wall less than three millimeters in thickness on abdomen pelvis CT

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of acute, complicated appendicitis, including severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain, palpable mass, high fever, and overall toxic appearance. Of the answer choices listed, a periappendiceal abscess is considered complicated appendicitis.

A focused history and physical examination should be obtained for stable patients with suspected appendicitis, specifically noting the pain's timing, duration, and migration. Initial workup may include chemistry panels, urinalysis, a complete blood count, and inflammatory markers. Typical findings include leukocytosis with left shift and elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate).

Adult patients should undergo CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis to help confirm the diagnosis. Patients are considered to have complicated appendicitis if imaging demonstrates evidence of abscess, phlegmon, extraluminal air signifying perforation, and/or an intraluminal appendicolith are present. Patients with uncomplicated appendicitis will have a dilated appendix (> 6 mm), wall thickening, and periappendiceal fat stranding seen on CT without the other findings described above. If none of these findings are present on CT, an alternative diagnosis besides appendicitis should be considered.

Option Analysis

✅ Surrounding appendiceal abscess on abdomen pelvis CT:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Appendiceal diameter less than 6 mm on abdomen pelvis CT:
Incorrect: The patient’s clinical history and physical examination findings are concerning for acute appendicitis with abscess. An appendiceal diameter of fewer than six millimeters suggests an alternative diagnosis for the patient’s symptoms rather than acute appendicitis.  
❌ Periappendiceal fat stranding on abdomen pelvis CT:
Incorrect: Periappendiceal fat stranding is suggestive of uncomplicated, acute appendicitis.  
❌ Appendiceal wall less than three millimeters in thickness on abdomen pelvis CT  :
Incorrect: The patient’s clinical history and physical examination findings are concerning for acute appendicitis with abscess. An appendiceal wall of less than three millimeters suggests an alternative diagnosis for the patient’s symptoms rather than acute appendicitis.  
❌ Elevated creatinine:
Incorrect: Elevated creatinine does not predict the clinical course of acute appendicitis and cannot help differentiate between complicated and uncomplicated appendicitis. However, it may provide information regarding the patient’s hydration status and associated electrolyte derangements.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of fever and chills. The patient underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis ten days ago. She reports pain at the incision site with purulent discharge and surrounding redness. Past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis. Medications include methotrexate. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. BMI is 31 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 119/76 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, one of the surgical wounds is tender with purulent drainage, dehiscence, and surrounding erythema. A tender fluctuant mass is palpated. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis with left shift and an elevated CRP. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Bed-side point of care ultrasound of the surgical site

questions.solution:
This patient presents with peri-incisional pain, erythema, purulent drainage, dehiscence, and a tender fluctuant mass in the setting of SSI predisposing factors (e.g. immunosuppressive medication, obesity). These findings, along with clinical and laboratory signs of systemic infection (e.g. fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis, elevated CRP) are suggestive of a deep surgical site infection with abscess formation. The best next step in management is to obtain a bed-side ultrasound for diagnosis and to guide management.
 

Surgical site infections can be subdivided into three types based on the depth of the infection. Superficial incisional SSI refers to an infection limited to the skin and subcutaneous tissue and presents within 30 days following surgical intervention with peri-incisional pain, warmth, erythema, and purulent discharge. Superficial SSI is diagnosed clinically and further evaluated via wound culture and blood culture if systemic signs present. Point of care ultrasound may be performed to rule out an associated abscess or to guide drainage. Antibiotics should be provided if peri-incisional signs of infection extend more than five centimeters from the wound edge, if there is failure to improve after bedside wound opening, if implanted material is present, if the patient is immunocompromised, or if systemic signs of infection are present.

Deep incisional SSI is an infection that extends into the peri-incisional muscles and fascial layers. Signs and symptoms include peri-incisional signs of infection (e.g. pain, erythema, warmth, purulent drainage) with additional deeper signs of infection. These include wound dehiscence or a fluctuant mass indicating abscess. Diagnosis involves clinical examination, deep wound and blood cultures, and bed-side ultrasound of the surgical site to assess for abscess formation. Unlike superficial SSIs, management of deep incisional SSIs always includes empiric systemic antibiotic therapy followed by tailored antibiotic therapy based on culture results, bedside wound opening, and possible surgical re-exploration.

Organ/space SSI typically occurs with surgeries that involve implants (due to the increased risk of bacterial colonization) or bowel anastomosis (from bacterial leak). An organ space SSI usually lacks peri-incisional signs of infection but presents with systemic signs of infection, such as fever or hypotension and pain/tenderness where the operation was performed. It is diagnosed by the identification of an abscess or fluid collection in the affected organ/space on CT or MRI or with a positive culture from a previously installed surgical drain. Management includes systemic antibiotic therapy followed by tailored antibiotic therapy based on culture results, image-guided percutaneous drain placement of the affected organ/space, and possible surgical re-exploration and removal of implanted foreign devices.  

Option Analysis

✅ Bed-side point of care ultrasound of the surgical site:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bed-side incision and drainage:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of a deep surgical site infection with abscess formation. A bed-side point of care ultrasound should be performed to confirm the presence of an abscess prior to incision and drainage.  
❌ IV antibiotics and surgical re-exploration:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of a deep surgical site infection with abscess formation. Although IV antibiotics and surgical exploration may be appropriate management, a bed-side ultrasound is initially required for diagnosis.  
❌ IV antibiotics and observation:
Incorrect: IV antibiotics alone are not sufficient to treat a suspected deep surgical site infection with abscess formation. Ultrasound-guided drainage or surgical exploration may be required if the presence of an abscess is confirmed.  
❌ Topical antibiotic and observation:
Incorrect: Topical antibiotics are not sufficient for treatment of a suspected deep surgical site infection with abscess formation.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman undergoes a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy for ovarian cancer. Past medical history includes diabetes mellitus type 2 and dyslipidemia. On postoperative day 2, the patient develops severe pain at the surgical site with associated fever and fatigue. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure is 97/69 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Examination of the wound reveals purulent, cloudy-gray discharge from the wound and palpable crepitus of the surrounding skin. Serum blood glucose is 350 mg/dL. IV Wound and blood cultures are sent and IV fluids are started. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and schedule urgent surgical re-exploration and debridement
Administer IV antibiotics and transfer to the intensive care unit for monitoring
Obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Order consult for image-guided percutaneous drainage
Administer IV antibiotics and perform bed-side incision and drainage

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe peri-incisional pain, fever, and fatigue on post-op day 2. Vitals are significant for systemic signs of infection, including fever, hypotension, and tachycardia. Physical examination is significant for “dishwater drainage” (cloudy-gray discharge) and subcutaneous crepitus on palpation. Together, these findings are suggestive of a necrotizing surgical site infection, which should be treated with IV antibiotics and emergency surgical debridement.
 

Necrotizing SSI is a deep surgical site infection complicated by necrotizing fasciitis. It is commonly caused by Strep. Pyogenes or Clostridium species, but it can also be polymicrobial. It presents more commonly in patients with diabetes and within 24-48 hours following surgery. It is a surgical emergency that requires urgent surgical exploration and debridement and IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, as the infection progresses rapidly.

In general, treatment of SSI depends on the type of and depth of infection. Superficial incisional SSIs are managed with bedside wound opening, wound care by secondary intention, and tailored antibiotic therapy in certain cases. Antibiotics are indicated if one of the following is present: peri-incisional signs of infection > 5 cm from wound edge, peri-incisional signs of infection not improved after wound opening, immunocompromised state, systemic signs of infection, or implanted material.

Deep incisional SSI are managed with empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy followed by tailored antibiotic therapy based on culture results, bedside wound opening and drainage of abscesses confirmed by point of care ultrasound, and possible surgical re-exploration.

Organ/space SSI are managed with empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy followed by tailored antibiotic therapy based on culture results, image-guided percutaneous drain placement in the affected organ/space, and possible surgical re-exploration and removal of implanted foreign devices.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV antibiotics and schedule urgent surgical re-exploration and debridement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV antibiotics and transfer to the intensive care unit for monitoring:
Incorrect: Although IV antibiotics are required in the management of suspected necrotizing SSI, surgical debridement is required to control the source of infection and decrease the risk of morbidity and mortality.  
❌ Obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is helpful for detecting the presence of gas in soft tissue and confirming the diagnosis of necrotizing SSI; however, it should not delay surgical intervention due to risk of rapid dissemination of the infection.  
❌ Order consult for image-guided percutaneous drainage:
Incorrect: Image-guided percutaneous drainage would be appropriate for the management of patients with organ/space SSI. It is not indicated for the management of patients with suspected necrotizing surgical site infection.  
❌ Administer IV antibiotics and perform bed-side incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Although IV antibiotics are required in the management of suspected necrotizing SSI, early surgical debridement allows for better exploration, irrigation, and removal of necrotic material compared to bed-side incision and drainage. Emergency surgical exploration is essential in the management of necrotizing SSI.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. The patient has no previous surgical history. Sevoflurane is used for anesthesia. Thirty minutes into the procedure, the patient becomes tachycardic and tachypneic. Temperature is 39.0 °C (102.2 °F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 122/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on the ventilator. On physical examination, the patient has jaw muscle tightness. Hypercarbia is noted on end-tidal CO2 monitoring. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s tachypnea, tachycardia, and hyperthermia soon after initiating a volatile anesthetic (sevoflurane) is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. Masseter muscle rigidity and a high-end-tidal CO2 further support the diagnosis.

This condition is caused by abnormal calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and is associated with genetic defects in ryanodine or dihydropyridine receptors. As a result, continuous muscle contraction occurs, leading to hypermetabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, increased CO2 production, lactic acidosis, heat production, and cell destruction.

Vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, tachycardia, and hyperthermia. Physical examination may demonstrate masseter muscle or generalized muscle rigidity. Hypercarbia (despite adequate ventilation), evidenced by an increased end-tidal CO2 measurement, is a crucial finding. Prompt recognition of malignant hyperthermia is essential as it carries a high mortality rate if not managed quickly.

Once malignant hyperthermia is suspected, dantrolene should be administered immediately. Dantrolene works on ryanodine receptors to inhibit calcium release and muscle contraction. Additional acute management should include discontinuing the triggering anesthetic, hyperventilation, increasing the oxygen flow rate, and initiating cooling measures if the patient’s temperature is > 39 °C. If not already in place, endotracheal intubation, arterial line, and urinary catheter placement are also necessary.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer dantrolene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer cyproheptadine:
Incorrect: Cyproheptadine is used for treating serotonin syndrome which is characterized by mental status changes, autonomic hyperactivity, and neuromuscular abnormalities caused by drugs that increase serotonin activity in the central nervous system. However, this patient’s clinical course is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia.  
❌ Administer succinylcholine:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical course is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. Succinylcholine is a depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant and a “triggering” agent for malignant hyperthermia, not a treatment for it.  
❌ Administer diltiazem:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical course is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia caused by unregulated calcium release in skeletal muscle cells. Calcium channel blockers, such as diltiazem, should be avoided.  
❌ Administer bromocriptine:
Incorrect: Bromocriptine is used for treating neuroleptic malignant syndrome, characterized by mental status changes, rigidity, fever, and dysautonomia caused by antipsychotic medications. However, this patient’s clinical course is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia caused by anesthetic medication.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman is undergoing a laparoscopic hysterectomy and receiving desflurane for anesthesia maintenance. An hour into the procedure, the patient becomes tachycardic. Temperature is 39.3 °C (102.7 °F), pulse is 142/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 130/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on the ventilator. On examination, generalized muscle rigidity is noted. The patient is over-breathing the ventilator, and end-tidal CO2 is high. An ECG is obtained. Which of the following would most likely be seen on the ECG?
questions.solution:
This patient’s hyperthermia, tachycardia, tachypnea, and muscle rigidity during anesthesia administration with desflurane is concerning for malignant hyperthermia. This is an anesthetic complication with a high mortality rate if not promptly treated. Certain anesthetics can trigger excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscles in genetically-sensitive individuals. As a result, continuous muscle contraction occurs, leading to hypermetabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, increased CO2 production, lactic acidosis, heat production, and cell destruction.

In addition to performing a physical examination, an initial evaluation for suspected malignant hyperthermia should include obtaining end-tidal CO2 measurement and an ECG. An elevated end-tidal CO2 despite adequate ventilation is a key finding, as it demonstrates increased CO2 production from hypermetabolism. Additionally, potassium release due to muscle cell destruction can result in hyperkalemia, disrupting the heart's normal electrophysiologic function. This may include ECG changes, such as peaked T waves, wide QRS complexes, or ventricular arrhythmias.

Laboratory studies may show hyperkalemia, elevated creatine kinase (from muscle breakdown), and lactic acidosis. Blood gasses would likely show mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. Coagulation studies should also be sent, as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a potential complication. Urinalysis might show myoglobinuria due to rhabdomyolysis.

Remember, while these studies are important in identifying and managing malignant hyperthermia manifestations and complications, they should not delay acute management. This includes discontinuing the offending anesthetic agent, administering dantrolene, and addressing the patient’s hyperthermia and hypercarbia.  

Option Analysis

❌ ST elevations:
Incorrect: ST elevations can occur in myocardial infarction and pericarditis. However, the patient’s history and examination are more consistent with malignant hyperthermia.  
✅ Peaked T waves:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ J waves (Osborn waves):
Incorrect: Osborn waves can occur with hypercalcemia. While malignant hyperthermia is associated with increased myoplasmic calcium within the muscles, it is not associated with hypercalcemia in the blood. It is associated with hyperkalemia.  
❌ Prominent U waves:
Incorrect: U waves can be normal in patients without pathology but are frequently associated with pathology. Prominent U waves are seen with electrolyte abnormalities, such as hypokalemia. However, malignant hyperthermia is associated with hyperkalemia.  
❌ Notched P wave:
Incorrect: Notched P waves usually indicate left atrial enlargement. They are not related to malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated on hospital rounds for worsening abdominal pain and ongoing bloody diarrhea. The patient initially presented 2 days prior with new-onset atrial fibrillation and abdominal pain and subsequently underwent colonoscopy with biopsy, which showed ischemic colitis. The patient has been medically managed with bowel rest, intravenous fluids, as needed analgesics, and piperacillin/tazobactam. Currently temperature is 38.3 °C (101.0 °F), blood pressure is 89/63 mmHg, and pulse is 108/min. The patient appears uncomfortable and physical examination demonstrates diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation with guarding. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with confirmed ischemic colitis has developed a fever, hypotension, ongoing bloody diarrhea, and worsening abdominal pain. Surgical consultation should be obtained for exploratory laparotomy, as this patient has been treated with conservative therapy but continues to worsen clinically.

Ischemic colitis refers to reduced intestinal blood flow, usually due to small vessel occlusion (e.g. from a thromboembolism) or hypoperfusion of the colon. Patients typically present with worsening cramping abdominal pain, tenesmus, and hematochezia. Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, hypertension, recent aortic surgery (due to cross-clamping), and untreated atrial fibrillation (patients may suffer from thromboembolic events).

Patients with suspected ischemic colitis should receive supportive care, including intravenous fluids, bowel rest, and empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics (such as piperacillin/tazobactam). Patients should subsequently undergo CT imaging, which may demonstrate thickening and edema of the bowel, thumbprinting, or target sign.

Patients with uncomplicated ischemic colitis should undergo a colonoscopy with biopsy. Colonoscopy often shows fragile mucosa, erythema, erosions, or petechial hemorrhage. Once ischemic colitis is confirmed, supportive care should be continued while the patient is monitored for any changes in clinical status. If worsening pain or bloody diarrhea, fever, or significant hemodynamic changes occur prompt surgical consultation should be obtained for emergent laparotomy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Repeat colonoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient's clinical presentation is concerning for worsening and/or complicated ischemic colitis. This patient should have prompt surgical consultation.  
❌ Administer amikacin:
Incorrect: This patient has been receiving intravenous antibiotics; administration of additional broad-spectrum antibiotics is not indicated at this time.  
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy is not indicated in the management of acute ischemic colitis. This patient already had a colonoscopy that diagnosed ischemic colitis and now requires surgical consultation due to fever and worsening symptoms.  
❌ Flexible sigmoidoscopy:
Incorrect: This procedure is often indicated in the management of sigmoid volvulus. This patient already had a colonoscopy that diagnosed ischemic colitis and now requires surgical consultation due to fever and worsening symptoms.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after an episode of hematemesis. The patient has otherwise had no recent vomiting. The patient has no abdominal pain, early satiety, or excessive belching and does not take NSAIDs. The patient has had several black tar-like stools over the past few days. Temperature is 37.3 ºC (99.1 ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 102/71 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and SpO2 is 98% on room air. Physical examination is notable for scleral icterus, splenomegaly, and abdominal distention. Serum international normalized ratio (INR) is 1.6. Stool H. pylori antigen is negative. An upper endoscopy is scheduled. Which of the following will likely be seen on upper endoscopy?

choices.text: Diffusely erythematous and nodular gastric mucosa
Cherry red nodules in the gastric fundus
Mucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction
Ulcerated, round-edged and exudative lesion in the gastric antrum
Serpiginous structures covered by normal mucosa in the gastric fundus

questions.solution:
Patients with upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding may present with hematemesis and melena, or bright red blood per rectum with brisk upper GI bleeds. Melenic (not “melanotic”) stools are black tar-like stools that do not resemble regular bowel movements and indicate a significant upper GI bleed. In patients with a suspected upper GI bleed who are stable, history and physical examination will guide further testing and treatment. In most cases, upper endoscopy (EGD) must be performed for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. Thus, it is important to know the EGD findings associated with the various causes of upper GI bleeding and the recent and past history and associated signs and symptoms with each cause of upper GI bleed.

Patients with gastritis, duodenitis, or peptic ulcer disease often present with abdominal pain (frequently related temporally to eating) and dyspepsia (discomfort along with belching, bloating, or other symptoms), and anemia. In the case of gastritis or duodenitis, EGD may show erythematous mucosa with nodularity and diffuse oozing. Patients with retrosternal pain and reflux symptoms, especially if there is a history of food impaction, may have esophagitis which can appear on EGD as erythema, stenosis, ulceration, and  mucosal erosions. Mallory-Weiss tears occur after prolonged retching and vomiting and will be evidenced by a gastroesophageal junction tear on EGD. Arteriovenous malformations appear on EGD as small ectatic vessels and cherry red nodules.

Based on the physical exam findings and elevated INR, this patient  likely has cirrhosis. Patients with cirrhosis can have GI bleeding from any of the above sources, but they can also develop esophageal and gastric varices. These can be visualized on EGD. A varix is a dilated submucosal vein caused by increased portal system pressures. They most frequently appear on EGD as serpiginous or oval structures covered by normal mucosa. They retreat when they are pressed on when trying to obtain a biopsy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Diffusely erythematous and nodular gastric mucosa:
Incorrect: This would be seen with gastropathy or gastritis. While possible in this patient, it is unlikely given the lack of dyspepsia and abdominal discomfort, lack of NSAID use, and negative H. pylori testing.  
❌ Cherry red nodules in the gastric fundus:
Incorrect: This would be seen with arteriovenous malformations (AVM). While possible in this patient, given the lack of skin findings (e.g., hemangiomas, telangiectasias), and the features consistent with cirrhosis, this is less likely than a variceal bleed.  
❌ Mucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction:
Incorrect: This would be seen with a Mallory-Weiss tear. Given that this patient has not had retching or vomiting before the hematemesis, this diagnosis is unlikely.  
❌ Ulcerated, round-edged and exudative lesion in the gastric antrum:
Incorrect: This would be seen with peptic ulcer disease. While possible in this patient, the lack of dyspepsia, abdominal pain, NSAID use, and negative H. pylori testing (though positivity it is more commonly seen in duodenal ulcers) makes this diagnosis less likely. Given her physical exam findings and laboratory studies that are consistent with cirrhosis, gastric varices are more likely the cause of her upper GI bleed.  
✅ Serpiginous structures covered by normal mucosa in the gastric fundus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman who is being treated on the floors for NSTEMI complains of fever and abdominal pain on day 3 of her hospitalization that has been complicated by many factors. The patient has a history of obesity, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.3°F), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and pulse is 101/min. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant, and palpation in the right upper quadrant during inspiration causes the patient to stop inspiring. The patient is provided with intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics. Laboratory results demonstrate leukocytosis with white blood cell count of 18,100 /mm<sup>3</sup>. Liver function testing and lipase levels are within normal limits. A diagnostic ultrasound is ordered and pending. Which of the following findings on abdominal ultrasound would be most suggestive of an acalculous disease process?
questions.solution:
This hospitalized patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, a positive Murphy sign, and likely sepsis, which is concerning for acute acalculous cholecystitis. Acalculous cholecystitis is gallbladder inflammation that is not caused by gallstones. It results from gallbladder stasis and ischemia that leads to inflammation. Acalculous cholecystitis is typically seen in patients who are hospitalized and critically ill.

When acute acalculous cholecystitis is suspected, patients should have laboratory testing, which should include CBC, ALP, GGT, CMP, AST, ALT, total bilirubin, ESR, CRP, lactate, amylase, and lipase levels. Diagnostic ultrasound should be performed. The presence of gallbladder wall thickening, sonographic Murphy sign, and cholecystic fluid indicates acute cholecystitis. If no gallstones are seen and/or echogenic bile or sludge is seen, then acalculous cholecystitis can be diagnosed. If there is uncertainty, CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis or a HIDA scan can be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Echogenic bile:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gallbladder wall thickening (>3.5mm):
Incorrect: Gallbladder wall thickening is found in patients with both calculous and acalculous cholecystitis and is a diagnostic feature of acute cholecystitis despite the cause.  
❌ Pericholecystic fluid:
Incorrect: Pericholecystic fluid is found in patients with both calculous and acalculous cholecystitis and is a diagnostic feature of acute cholecystitis despite the cause.  
❌ Dilated common bile duct:
Incorrect: A dilated common bile duct is not suggestive of acute cholecystitis but, rather, reflects a hepatobiliary process such as choledocholithiasis or acute cholangitis.  
❌ Sonographic Murphy sign:
Incorrect: Sonographic Murphy sign (i.e. pain elicited when the sonographer presses directly over the gallbladder with the ultrasound probe) is found in patients with both calculous and acalculous cholecystitis and is a diagnostic feature of acute cholecystitis despite the cause.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain. The patient reports right upper abdominal pain for the past 2-3 days that radiates to his shoulder blade. Today he was feeling significantly worse and told his wife to bring him to the emergency department. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 95/73 mmHg, pulse is 121/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal tenderness and guarding. The patient is provided with intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics. Laboratory results demonstrate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 24,100 /mm<sup>3</sup>. An abdominal ultrasound is performed and demonstrates pericholecystic fluid, thickened gallbladder wall, and evidence of perforation. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of right upper abdominal pain and is ultimately found to have evidence of acute cholecystitis complicated by gallbladder perforation. This patient should have an emergency cholecystectomy for this potentially life-threatening complication. Other complications that require emergent cholecystectomy are gallbladder gangrene, abscess, and necrosis.

Stable patients with suspected acute cholecystitis should undergo diagnostic abdominal ultrasonography, which will typically identify the disease based on the presence of pericholecystic fluid, gallbladder wall thickening, or a positive Murphy sign. Stable patients with uncomplicated calculous cholecystitis should receive continued supportive care and be monitored for worsening response (e.g. continued pain and fever, worsening leukocytosis). Those that respond well and are good surgical candidates can be scheduled for  cholecystectomy, while those with poor response should have urgent surgical consultation for cholecystectomy. Patients with acalculous cholecystitis should also receive supportive care and be considered for cholecystectomy or percutaneous drainage via interventional radiology if they are not good surgical candidates.  

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Supportive care and scheduled cholecystectomy:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings of gallbladder perforation which is a life-threatening complication of acute cholecystitis that requires emergent cholecystectomy.  
❌ HIDA scan:
Incorrect: A HIDA scan is indicated for patients with suspected cholecystitis when a diagnostic ultrasound or CT of the abdomen and pelvis is inconclusive.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) can be used to treat gallstones in the bile duct. But it is not appropriate treatment for acute cholecystitis complicated by gallbladder perforation.  
❌ Serial abdominal exams:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings of gallbladder perforation, sepsis, and hemodynamic instability. He should have an emergent cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with three days of right upper quadrant abdominal pain and fever. The patient has previously had three to four episodes of right upper quadrant pain, occasionally with vomiting, that were worse after eating and resolved within two to three hours. Vital signs include temperature of 38.6 ºC (101.5 ºF), heart rate of 108/min, blood pressure of 140/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18/min, and SpO2 of 100% on room air. The patient is sent to the emergency department for bloodwork and imaging. Bloodwork shows leukocytosis. Which of the following findings on physical exam would be most suggestive of the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of three to four episodes of biliary colic, usually described as intense right upper quadrant abdominal pain that is typically constant and caused by gallstones. The pain typically occurs when the biliary duct contracts on an impacted gallstone–often set off by eating, especially fatty foods, with increased pressure within the gallbladder. Patients often report associated nausea and vomiting.  

Acute cholecystitis presenting as fever, right upper quadrant pain, and leukocytosis can develop as a complication of gallstones from gallbladder inflammation. Physical examination will show right upper quadrant tenderness to palpation or epigastric tenderness. A positive Murphy sign is highly suggestive of acute cholecystitis. It is tested for by palpating the gallbladder during deep inspiration and is considered positive if the pain significantly worsens or if the patient stops inspiring because of the pain.



Abdominal ultrasound should be performed when acute cholecystitis is suspected. The gallbladder will appear distended and thickened with surrounding edema and gallstones may be seen. Acute cholecystitis can be definitively diagnosed in the right clinical setting with demonstration of gallbladder wall thickening or edema on imaging, a sonographic Murphy sign, or failure of the gallbladder to fill during cholescintigraphy.

Option Analysis

✅ Positive Murphy sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tenderness at McBurney point:
Incorrect: Tenderness at McBurney point, which is 1.5 to 2 inches from the anterior superior iliac spine on a straight line to the umbilicus, is indicative of acute appendicitis not acute cholecystitis.
❌ Positive Rovsing sign:
Incorrect: Pain elicited in the right lower quadrant while the examiner pushes on the left lower quadrant is a positive Rovsing sign. This is suggestive of acute appendicitis, not acute cholecystitis.
❌ Positive Courvoisier sign:
Incorrect: A positive Courvoisier sign is a palpable gallbladder in the presence of jaundice. This is most suggestive of pancreatic or gallbladder malignancy, not acute cholecystitis.
❌ Epigastric tenderness to palpation:
Incorrect: Both epigastric and right upper quadrant tenderness can be seen on physical exam in acute cholecystitis. However epigastric tenderness can also be seen in other conditions such as pancreatitis and peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 2 days of progressive abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He has not had a bowel movement in 3 days. He has not noticed blood in his stools, or experienced fevers. His past medical history includes hypertension, chronic constipation, and a ventral hernia repair 7 years ago. Temperature is 36.6 ℃ (97.9 ℉), pulse 90/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 140/82, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. On physical examination, his abdomen appears distended, is tympanic to percussion, and tender. High-pitched bowel sounds are heard on auscultation. There is no rebound or guarding. CT demonstrates distended small bowel with 2 transition points. The distal bowel appears collapsed. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history and examination demonstrating abdominal pain and distention, nausea, vomiting, obstipation, tympany to percussion, and high-pitched bowel sounds are concerning for a small bowel obstruction (SBO). SBO occurs when a blockage in the small bowel prevents the passage of intraluminal contents (e.g., gas, chyme), which results in distention of the bowel proximal to the obstruction. This condition manifests as pain, abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting. SBO is often mechanical (physical), and secondary to adhesions or tumors.

Imaging can aid in the diagnosis and identify the underlying etiology of mechanical obstruction. An abdominal X-ray is typically the first step, which may demonstrate distended small bowel loops and air-fluid levels. It can also evaluate for signs of perforation, such as pneumoperitoneum. An abdominal CT can provide additional information, such as the identification of a transition point (where the bowel is distended to the point of obstruction but collapsed beyond it). Conservative management is often appropriate for these cases of SBO.

Two or more transition points, as seen on this patient’s CT, indicate a closed-loop obstruction, which may be due to adhesions, hernias, or volvulus. Closed-loop obstructions are unlikely to resolve with supportive care and are at risk for progression to bowel ischemia and perforation. These patients require surgical intervention.

Other CT findings that indicate the need for surgical intervention include evidence of bowel ischemia (e.g., pneumatosis, portal venous gas), small bowel tumors, gallstone ileus, an ingested foreign body, and intussusception.  

Option Analysis

✅ Volvulus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gallstone ileus:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are concerning for a small bowel obstruction. Gallstone ileus is a potential cause of SBO, but it is typically not associated with a closed-loop obstruction.  
❌ Acute diverticulitis:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are more consistent with a small bowel obstruction. Additionally he lacks CT findings of acute diverticulitis which include colonic diverticula, thickening of the colon wall, and pericolonic fat stranding.  
❌ Acute colonic pseudo-obstruction:
Incorrect: Acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie’s syndrome) presents similarly to small bowel obstruction. CT findings in acute colonic pseudo-obstruction demonstrate a transition point in the colon with distention of the proximal colon but without a mechanical obstruction like a volvulus or malignant lesion.  
❌ Intussusception:
Incorrect: Intussusception is a potential cause of small bowel obstruction. However, CT findings would be consistent with a segment of the bowel “telescoping” into itself. This would typically appear as concentric rings of bowel.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital following an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. On postoperative day two the patient develops shortness of breath. The patient does not wear oxygen at home but has required 2 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula since surgery. Past medical history is significant for hypertension which is well-controlled with losartan. Temperature is 37.8 ºC (100.0 ºF), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 133/77 mmHg and respirations are 18/min. Chest radiograph obtained six hours after surgery shows decreased aeration and increased opacification at the bases of both lungs. The costophrenic angles are intact and all lung markings extend out to the periphery in both lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing risk factor for the development of this patient’s radiographic findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of postoperative atelectasis. Atelectasis refers to partial or complete collapse of a portion of the lung resulting in poor aeration (ventilation) and gas exchange. It is common in hospitalized patients, especially after intra-abdominal or intra-thoracic surgery. Most patients develop atelectasis in small portions of the lung or in a specific lobe. Atelectasis can be separated into obstructive (mechanical obstruction in the lumen of the airway blocks airflow) or non-obstructive (no intraluminal lesion).



Obstructive atelectasis is caused by physical obstruction of an airway, with multiple etiologies including endobronchial tumor, aspirated foreign body, or severe mucus plugging. Chest physiotherapy and mucus clearance maneuvers (including medications) can usually help resolve mucus plugging. Bronchoscopy is often needed to resolve obstructive atelectasis.

Non-obstructive atelectasis does not involve a luminal lesion and often occurs secondary to inadequate deep breathing and resultant lung expansion. This frequently occurs after surgery, in bedbound patients, and in patients without adequate analgesia who are unable to take deep breaths due to pain. This type of atelectasis is best treated with incentive spirometry, patient mobilization, and analgesia.

Option Analysis

✅ Recent intra-abdominal surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endobronchial tumor:
Incorrect: An endobronchial tumor can cause obstructive atelectasis. This patient has bilateral opacification of small portions of the bottoms of the lungs that is most likely non-obstructive atelectasis. Making obstructive atelectasis from an endobronchial tumor unlikely.
❌ Bronchial mucus plug:
Incorrect: Mucus plugging can cause obstructive atelectasis and volume loss of a significant amount of lung. This patient has opacification of small portions of the bottoms of the lungs, making non-obstructive atelectasis more likely.
❌ Pleural effusion:
Incorrect: Pleural effusions can cause non-obstructive atelectasis, however this patient has preserved costophrenic angles ruling out clinically significant pleural effusion.
❌ Pneumothorax:
Incorrect: Pneumothorax can cause non-obstructive atelectasis as air outside the lung pushes on lung parenchyma and resultant collapse. The lung markings extending out to the periphery makes pneumothorax unlikely.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old female presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain for the past 4 days. The patient reports that the pain began near her umbilicus and migrated to her right lower abdomen, but now involves the entire abdomen. The patient is otherwise healthy and is not sexually active. Temperature is 37.8 ºC (100.0 ºF), pulse is 101/min, blood pressure is 123/77 mmHg and respirations are 18/min. The patient has evidence of abdominal distention, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and rebound pain on physical examination. Bloodwork is obtained and the results are pending. An upright chest radiograph is obtained and is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical evidence of peritonitis, which is caused by inflammation of the peritoneum. It is demonstrated on physical exam with abdominal distention, diffuse abdominal tenderness, rigidity, guarding, and rebound pain. Patients with evidence of peritonitis should first have an upright chest radiograph to evaluate for free air and pneumoperitoneum. If negative, the next best step involves obtaining a CT of the abdomen and pelvis to better differentiate between primary, secondary, and tertiary etiologies of peritonitis.  

Depending on the etiology, peritonitis can be divided into primary (caused by intra abdominopelvic fluid), secondary (caused by a process in the gastrointestinal tract), or tertiary (caused by postoperative inflammatory process). Clinical clues that may point to an underlying etiology include early history of the pain (e.g. right sided pain in a young patient may suggest ruptured appendicitis, or left sided pain in an elderly patient may suggest a perforated diverticulitis). Primary peritonitis may be suggested by history of liver disease or endometriosis and should be diagnosed with paracentesis.

Option Analysis

✅ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform paracentesis:
Incorrect: A paracentesis should be considered in a patient presenting with peritonitis if there is evidence of a fluid wave on abdominal exam, or ascites seen on CT or ultrasound imaging. If imaging does not demonstrate a secondary or tertiary etiology of peritonitis, then a diagnostic paracentesis should be performed.
❌ Order abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of peritonitis, a transabdominal ultrasound may show evidence of free fluid, but it is unlikely to be diagnostic for secondary or tertiary cause of peritonitis.
❌ Order transvaginal ultrasound:
Incorrect: A transvaginal ultrasound is unlikely to provide useful diagnostic information given findings of peritonitis suggestive of an intraabdominal disease process as opposed to a pelvic disease process.
❌ Administer packed red blood cells:
Incorrect: This patient has no evidence of bleeding on history or suggested by physical examination findings.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus is admitted for evaluation of discharge from a surgical incision site. He had emergent exploratory laparotomy and splenectomy 8 days ago after sustaining abdominal injuries in a motor vehicle collision. His postoperative course was complicated by the development of a surgical site infection with a small abscess 4 days postoperatively treated with antibiotics and drainage. He was bending down to pick something up and heard a popping sound, followed by the sensation of bulging at the site of his incision with a large amount of pink-colored discharge. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 110/minute, and blood pressure is 92/60 mmHg. Which of the following findings on physical examination of the abdomen would warrant emergent surgical intervention?

choices.text: Complete incisional separation with visible bowel loops
Palpable fluctuant area within the wound with clear discharge and no surrounding erythema
Palpable fluctuant area within the wound with bloody discharge and no surrounding erythema

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of serosanguinous discharge from his recent surgical incision site, after experiencing a popping sensation and bulging at the incision site. On physical examination, he has a fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. If complete separation of his incision site with visible bowel loops is seen on physical exam, the diagnosis would be deep fascial wound dehiscence complicated by evisceration (herniation of intra-abdominal organs through the open wound).  

Complete fascial dehiscence (complete separation of wound edges) has a mortality rate of 10 percent and poses an increased risk for herniation of the bowel and strangulation. Complete fascial dehiscence and evisceration both require immediate surgical evaluation. The wound can be covered with sterile saline dressing while the patient is prepared for surgery.



Dehiscence occurs when there is a partial or total separation of wound edges due to a failure of proper wound healing. It usually occurs in the early stages of wound healing, approximately 5 to 8 days following surgery. Risk factors for dehiscence include poor perfusion (due to vascular diseases), infection of the wound site, increased abdominal pressure, diabetes, malnutrition, smoking, and obesity. It is typically caused by mechanical stresses like lifting more than 15 pounds. If this patient was stable and without signs of evisceration, CT with contrast could be obtained to evaluate the presence and size of the fascial defect.  

Another postoperative wound complication that warrants emergent surgical intervention is an anterior neck hematoma. This should be suspected in patients who present with progressive difficulty breathing after undergoing neck surgery. The limited space in the neck for swelling and fluid leads to easy compression of the airway which is a life-threatening complication.

Option Analysis

✅ Complete incisional separation with visible bowel loops:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Erythema around the incision site:
Incorrect: Erythema around the incision site is a sign of a possible infectious process and surgical site infection. A superficial site infection with an abscess might need localized drainage but would not require an emergent procedure.
❌ Palpable fluctuant area within the wound with clear discharge and no surrounding erythema:
Incorrect: This can be seen with a seroma. Further imaging with ultrasound should be done to confirm the diagnosis before interventions such as observation or drainage. Emergent surgery would not be necessary in most cases.
❌ Visualization of a tract opening:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen with a fistula with likely continuous drainage. Further evaluation with imaging such as CT or fistulogram would be needed before surgery if indicated.
❌ Palpable fluctuant area within the wound with bloody discharge and no surrounding erythema:
Incorrect: This finding can be seen with a hematoma. Hematomas are more common in patients with risk factors for bleeding (such as history of coagulopathy or use of anticoagulation medications). Hematomas can be treated with observation or drainage. Emergent surgery would not be necessary in most cases.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a burn injury. According to paramedics, the patient was involved in a house fire with delayed extrication. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 107/63 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and oxygen saturation is 78% on room air. Physical examination reveals partial-thickness burns over the chest, back, arms, and legs. The patient is ill-appearing and unable to provide a history. The patient has evidence of soot about the nares and mouth and lip swelling. The patient is provided with intravenous fluids and a nonrebreather face mask is applied. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of partial-thickness burns and evidence of inhalation injury on examination. Given the patient's ill appearance, evidence of hypoxia, and concerns for impending respiratory failure the best next step in management is rapid sequence intubation.

Burns injuries caused by heat, friction, radiation, electricity, or chemical exposure can result in irreversible tissue destruction. Extensive tissue destruction, particularly burns larger than 40% of the total body surface area (TBSA) can cause fluid loss and evidence of shock. Burns are classified based on the depth of injury into first-, second-, third-, and fourth-degree burns, as well as burns accompanied by smoke inhalation, or inhalation injuries.

Acute management of patient's presenting with burn injuries includes assessment of the airway, breathing, and circulation. With specific regards to the airway, patients with evidence of significant edema, hypoxia, or other evidence of inhalation injury (e.g. soot around the nose or mouth) should undergo rapid sequence intubation. Delays in performing this procedure may result in airway compromise secondary to rapidly progressing edema. Additional management considerations include obtaining intravenous access, administering intravenous fluids, and addressing any associated bleeding or unstable traumatic injuries.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rapid sequence intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Arterial blood gas analysis:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of hypoxemia, tongue and lip swelling, as well as concern for inhalation injury. This patient should receive rapid sequence intubation for acute airway stabilization.  
❌ Chest x-ray:
Incorrect: A chest x-ray may provide useful information including associated trauma or evidence of airway edema. However, this patient's acute airway instability should be addressed first via rapid sequence intubation.  
❌ Escharotomy:
Incorrect: An escharotomy should be performed for patients presenting with circumferential full-thickness burns and evidence of ischemia. This patient has evidence of partial-thickness burns.  
❌ Hi-flow nasal cannula:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of hypoxemia, tongue and lip swelling, as well as concern for inhalation injury. The patient should receive rapid sequence intubation for acute airway stabilization.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a burn. The patient was opening the lid of his grill and was exposed to a large flame. The patient is currently experiencing pain to the lips, mouth, and nose. He has no other medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 127/63 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a singed mustache as well as wheezing during inspiration and expiration. The patient is coughing up sputum with specks of carbonaceous material. An arterial blood gas and chest radiograph are obtained, both of which are unremarkable. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of inhalation injury including singed facial hair, carbonaceous sputum, and wheezing on examination. The best next step in management is admission for bronchoscopy and airway monitoring. Bronchoscopy is used to diagnose inhalation injury in patients with history and physical findings, like singed facial hair, that are suggestive. Bronchoscopy can also be used to clear secretions.

Burns injuries caused by heat, friction, radiation, electricity, or chemical exposure can result in irreversible tissue destruction. Extensive tissue destruction, particularly burns larger than 40% of the total body surface area (TBSA) can cause fluid loss and evidence of shock. Burns are classified based on the depth of injury into first-, second-, third-, and fourth-degree burns, as well as burns accompanied by smoke inhalation, or inhalation injuries.

Stable patients presenting with a burn injury should undergo a thorough history and physical examination to better characterize the type of burn present. The mechanism of exposure may reveal the type of injury.  For example, patients with prolonged extrication, facial burns, or prolonged smoke exposure may be at increased risk of inhalation injury. In contrast, patients with thermal burns will typically have exposure to heated water, fire, or chemicals.

Patients with concerns for inhalation injury should undergo a thorough evaluation to better characterize the extent of injury. The face should be closely examined for evidence of singed facial hair, oropharyngeal edema, voice changes, as well as evidence of wheezing or respiratory distress. Patients with suspected inhalation injury should have an arterial blood gas and carboxyhemoglobin level, as well as a chest radiograph. However, ABG and chest radiographs may be normal early after the injury. Serial chest radiographs may be obtained.

Management of inhalation injury in a stable patient  includes administering high-flow oxygen to maintain oxygen saturations above 90%. If the patient develops drooling, wheezing, or stridor, or is unable to maintain oxygen saturations higher than 90%, they should be intubated.  

Option Analysis

✅ Admit for bronchoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge with primary care follow-up:
Incorrect: Discharge with primary care follow-up is not appropriate management for this patient. This patient has evidence of inhalation injury and should be admitted for further monitoring and workup.  
❌ Administer piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Administration of empiric antibiotics is not indicated in the management of acute inhalation injury.  
❌ Perform surgical escharotomy:
