Incorrect: Damage to the infraorbital nerve manifests with sensory deficits over the lower eyelid, side of the nose, moveable part of the nasal septum, anterior cheek, or upper lip.  
❌ Mental nerve:
Incorrect: The mental nerve is the terminal branch of the inferior alveolar nerve and provides sensory information to the chin and lower lip. This patient’s presentation is consistent with the entire inferior alveolar nerve damage.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s recent surgery.

questions.text:
A pharmacist compares several inhaled anesthetic agents in a series of experiments. The obtained results are summarized below. Which of the following best describes the property of halothane when compared to that nitrous oxide?
 
Table 1: Properties of different inhaled anesthetic agents

Blood-gas partition coefficient  
Brain-blood partition coefficient  
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)
Nitrous oxide
0.47
1.1
>104%
Desflurane
0.42
1.3
6-7%
Isoflurane
1.402.61.4%
Halothane
2.302.90.75%
questions.solution:
Inhaled anesthetics are gasses or volatile liquids given through a mask or endotracheal tube for the patient to inhale. The anesthetics then pass from the lungs' alveoli into the blood and finally to different body parts.

Uptake of the anesthetic into the blood depends on several factors, including:

  • Blood-gas partition coefficient, which is the ratio of anesthetic concentrations in the blood and alveolar space when partial pressures in the two compartments are equal—the higher the blood-gas partition coefficient, the greater the anesthetic’s solubility in the bloodstream.
  • Lung ventilation, volumes, and perfusion
Distribution and uptake into the brain directly depend on the brain-blood partition coefficient, the ratio of anesthetic concentrations between brain tissue and blood when partial pressures are equal. A higher brain-blood partition coefficient signifies greater solubility of the anesthetic in brain tissue.

Inhaled anesthetics' onset of action and recovery time depends on the blood-gas partition coefficient. Drugs with high blood-gas partition coefficients are more soluble in blood, demonstrate slower equilibrium with the brain, and have longer onset and recovery times.

Finally, minimum alveolar concentration (MAC), which is the alveolar concentration of an inhaled anesthetic that prevents movement in 50% of patients in response to a noxious stimulus, is inversely related to anesthetic potency. The lower the MAC value, the more fat-soluble the anesthetic.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Lower blood solubility:
Incorrect: The blood-gas coefficient measures how soluble an anesthetic is in the bloodstream. Halothane has a higher blood-gas coefficient, meaning it is more soluble in blood than nitrous oxide.  
❌ Lower potency:
Incorrect: Potency is inversely correlated to an anesthetic’s MAC. Halothane has a lower MAC than nitrous oxide. Therefore, halothane is more potent.  
❌ Lower brain solubility:
Incorrect: The brain-blood partition coefficient is the ratio of anesthetic concentrations in the brain tissue and bloodstream when partial pressures are equal. The higher the brain-blood partition coefficient, the greater the solubility of the anesthetic in brain tissue. Therefore, halothane has higher brain solubility than nitrous oxide.  
✅ Longer recovery time:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Shorter induction time:
Incorrect: The lower the blood-gas partition coefficient of an inhaled anesthetic, the faster the medication takes effect (faster induction). Halothane has a higher blood-gas partition coefficient and requires more time to take effect (slower induction).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and confusion for the past 24 hours. The pain is stabbing in character, worse in the upper abdomen, and is associated with nausea and non-bloody vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows that the patient is oriented to the person but not to time and place. Mucous membranes are dry and capillary refill is delayed. Skin and sclera are icteric. Abdominal examination shows marked tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastric region without rebound tenderness or guarding. Laboratory results are shown below. Ultrasound of the abdomen is suggestive of an impacted gallstone. Which of the following is the most likely location of gallstone impaction due to this patient’s symptoms?  

 Laboratory features 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  150,000/mm3 
 Platelet count    230,000 mm3 
 Serum electrolytes  
 Sodium  137 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.5 mEq/L 
 Chloride  106 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  17 mEq/L 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   2.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  2.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT  65 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT  30 U/L 
 Lipase  65 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain (RUQ) (aka Charcot triad) most likely has ascending cholangitis, secondary to the gallstone impaction in the common bile duct (CBD). Confusion and hypotension (Reynold pentad) are also sometimes seen in severe cases.  

Gallstones can migrate from the gallbladder into the cystic duct where it can obstruct the bile outflow, causing biliary colic (intense, spasmodic pain located in the right hypochondrium) when the gallbladder contracts. The accumulation of bile can subsequently lead to the development of cholecystitis, which presents clinically as a positive Murphy’s sign, which is pain and discomfort on inspiration when the inflamed gallbladder comes into contact with the examiner's hand in the RUQ.  

Gallstone impaction at the CBD can lead to bacterial invasion of bile from the intestinal flora. This can lead to the development of ascending cholangitis, characterized by Charcot triad. Additionally, when impacted in the main pancreatic duct, it can cause pancreatitis (e.g., anorexia, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain).  

Finally, an enlarged and inflamed gallbladder can develop communications with adjacent viscera (cholecystoenteric fistula), most commonly between the gallbladder and the duodenum. The stone from here passes freely until it reaches the ileum. It is characterized by signs and symptoms of bowel obstruction.  



Option Analysis

❌ Ileum:
Incorrect: Gallstone ileus is a complication of long-standing cholelithiasis where the gallstone forms a cholecystoenteric fistula between the gallbladder and the adjoint gut (duodenum). The stone from here passes freely until it reaches the ileum (narrowest portion of the intestine). It is characterized by signs and symptoms of bowel obstruction (abdominal pain/distention, nausea/vomiting, high-pitched bowel sounds, and abdominal tenderness). This patient’s presentation is consistent with ascending cholangitis.  
✅ Common bile duct:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Main pancreatic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones can migrate from the common bile duct and obstruct the main pancreatic duct, leading to pancreatitis, which is inflammation of the pancreas. Symptoms of pancreatitis include anorexia, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain. Serum lipase levels are usually elevated (unlike this patient). Charcot’s triad in this patient is suggestive of common bile duct obstruction.  
❌ Cystic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones are usually located in the gallbladder but can migrate in the cystic duct, obstructing the bile’s way out of the gallbladder. When the gallbladder contracts, this further leads to biliary colic, which is an intense, spasmodic pain located in the right upper quadrant (RUQ) of the abdomen. The accumulation of bile can also lead to the inflammation and irritation of gallbladder (cholecystitis), presenting as Murphy’s sign (pain/tenderness in the RUQ sufficient to cause an abrupt halt in inspiration) on physical examination. Charcot’s triad in this patient is suggestive of common bile duct obstruction.  
❌ Duodenum:
Incorrect: The caliber of duodenum is typically sufficient to allow the passage of larger gallstones.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain. The pain started suddenly six hours ago after she had dinner at a barbeque at her friend’s place. The pain is continuous, sharp, radiates to the right scapula, and is 8/10 in severity. The patient reports similar abdominal pain of lesser severity in the past 2 months. The review of systems is significant for nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 37 kg/2. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness with deep palpation. The rest of the examination is within normal limits. Laboratory investigation shows a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3 and an elevated serum total bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase concentrations. An abdominal ultrasound reveals gallstones, thickened gallbladder wall with edema, and a normal common bile duct. Intravenous fluids are started. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute cholecystitis (e.g., right upper quadrant pain and tenderness associated with nausea and vomiting with ultrasound evidence of thickened gallbladder wall with gallstones).  

Patients with uncomplicated cholecystitis should be managed with early (<72 hours) cholecystectomy. Other indications of cholecystectomy include:  

  •  Uncomplicated cholecystitis 
  •  Asymptomatic cholelithiasis in patients who are at increased risk for gallbladder carcinoma 
  •  Acalculous cholecystitis 
  •  Gallbladder polyps >0.5 cm 
  •  Porcelain gallbladder 
  •  Choledochoithiasis 
  •  Biliary pancreatitis 
Cholecystectomy can be performed either laparoscopically or via an open surgical technique. During the procedure, it is important to identify the Triangle of Calot (cystohepatic triangle) to avoid damage to the cystic duct and artery. The triangle is bounded by the cystic duct inferiorly, common hepatic duct medially, and the inferior surface of the liver superiorly. The cystic artery lies within the triangle and is used to locate it during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. It may also contain anomalous sectoral bile ducts or an accessory right hepatic artery. Therefore, dissection in the triangle of Calot is ill-advised until the lateral-most structures have been cleared and identification of the cystic duct is definitive.  



The bile duct can also be damaged during a gallbladder removal, which causes leakage of bile into the abdomen, leading to peritonitis. Moreover, the surgical instruments used to remove the gallbladder can also injure surrounding structures, such as the bowel and blood vessels.

Option Analysis

❌ Urgent percutaneous gallbladder drainage:
Incorrect: Percutaneous cholecystostomy is an image-guided placement of a drainage catheter into the gallbladder lumen. It is usually indicated in complicated cholecystitis (e.g., emphysematous cholecystitis) or unexplained sepsis in critically ill patients.  
❌ Delayed cholecystectomy after hospitalization:
Incorrect: Early cholecystectomy within 72 hours reduces the duration of disease and hospitalization and reduces mortality as compared to delayed cholecystectomy.  
✅ Cholecystectomy within 72 hours:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan:
Incorrect: The hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan is indicated if the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis remains uncertain following ultrasonography. It uses a nuclear tracer that is excreted in bile. Failure to visualize the gallbladder suggests an obstruction. This patient’s ultrasound is suggestive of acute cholecystitis and, therefore, further imaging is not required.   
❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is usually performed to evaluate for concurrent choledocholithiasis in patients with acute cholecystitis with elevations of liver transaminases, total bilirubin, or evidence of common bile duct dilatation on ultrasound. It is not indicated in this patient.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of epistaxis and rash on her lower extremities. She frequently participates in fighting tournaments.The patient was initially diagnosed with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura over a year ago after developing irregular menstrual bleeding. The following year, the patient developed frequent mucosal bleeding after mild trauma. The patient has received multiple medications, including intravenous immunoglobulin and prednisone. The patient’s response to treatment has been transient with platelet counts dropping below 10,000/mm3. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows diffuse epistaxis and multiple erythematous, brown macules noted on her lower extremities that do not blanch with pressure. Workup for chronic autoimmune disorder and viral infections is negative. Bone marrow biopsy shows normocellular marrow with slightly increased megakaryocytes. The patient is scheduled for elective splenectomy. The patient is at increased risk of injury to which of the following structures during this procedure?
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura has bleeding and thrombocytopenia requiring repeated pharmacologic interventions and should be considered for second-line therapies (e.g., splenectomy).  

A splenectomy is the surgical procedure that partially or completely removes the spleen. Complications associated with splenectomy include increased risk of sepsis due to encapsulated organisms, such as S. pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae.    

The location of the spleen in the left upper abdominal quadrant places it in close proximity to a number of important structures and their vasculature supplies, including the stomach, pancreas, left kidney, and splenic flexure of the colon. Further, the splenic blood supply is very rich. It is worth mentioning that the tail of the pancreas passes anterior to the left kidney and is closely related to the splenic hilum and left colic flexure. The tail is mobile and can pass between the layers of the splenorenal ligament, along with the splenic vessels. This is important because, during splenectomies, the tail of the pancreas can be damaged and a distal pancreatectomy, which is the surgical removal of the pancreatic tail, can be necessary.   

Option Analysis

❌ Cystic artery:
Incorrect: Cystic artery is at risk of injury during cholecystectomy. It is important to identify the Calot’s triangle (cystohepatic triangle) to avoid damage to the cystic duct and artery. It is not at risk of injury during splenectomy.   
✅ Pancreatic tail:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: Left gastric artery runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is at risk of bleeding in perforated gastric ulcer. During splenectomy, the short gastric arteries or hilar vessels can be injured.  
❌ Common bile duct:
Incorrect: A bile duct injury is damage to the bile ducts that happens during gallbladder surgery. A bile duct can get cut, burned, or pinched. As a result of an injury, the bile duct will not be able to function properly, leaking bile into the abdomen or blocking the normal flow of bile from the liver. Splenectomy does not affect the bile duct.  
❌ Left ureter:
Incorrect: The left ureter is adjacent to the descending and sigmoid colon and is crossed ventrally by inferior mesenteric artery and its branches. It is at risk of iatrogenic injury during colorectal surgery due to their anatomical proximity to the colon and rectum. Splenectomy does not affect the left ureter.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. He was the restrained driver that skidded on ice hitting a tree at 50 miles per hour (80 kilometers per hour). In the emergency department the patient has an x-ray of the lower extremities that reveals a comminuted left tibial fracture. After a prolonged emergency surgery, the patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. The next day, he endorses severe left leg pain unresponsive to several rounds of intravenous morphine. The patient further endorses a pins and needles sensation and pain with movement in the left lower extremity. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates tense, swollen and an exquisitely tender left calf with loss of sensation between the first and second toes. The overlying skin is shiny and cool to the touch. The patient has 2+ dorsalis pedis pulse in the left lower extremity. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Place the leg in balanced traction
Elevate the leg and apply ice packs
Obtain doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of excruciating leg pain following tibial fracture repair, worsened with passive leg movements, in combination with sensory loss, tense compartments, and cool extremities is consistent with compartment syndrome (CS).   

CS is an orthopedic emergency that commonly results from direct trauma (e.g. long bone fracture) or prolonged compression of an extremity but may also occur following revascularization of an acutely ischemic limb.  

CS typically involves significant swelling within a compartment of an injured extremity that compromises blood flow to the limb muscles and nerves.  

Signs and symptoms can be remembered as the six Ps:  



Pain with passive stretch of the affected muscles is the earliest symptom, followed by paresthesias ( pins and needle sensations), that can progress to neurologic deficits (e.g., loss of sensation and muscle weakness). Pallor and poikilothermia result from arterial occlusion and is uncommon. Arterial pulses are present in the majority of the patients.  

Diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring compartment pressures. Compartment pressures of >30-40 mmg are highly suggestive of CS. In addition, a value known as the delta pressure is often obtained, which is calculated by subtracting the compartment pressure from the patient’s diastolic blood pressure. Values less than 30 are consistent with CS. In high-risk patients (e.g., sensory loss and cool extremities), it can be diagnosed on clinical grounds alone. Time to fasciotomy is the most critical prognostic factor and should be performed immediately.  

Option Analysis

❌ Place the leg in balanced traction:
Incorrect: Traction can precipitate the development of compartment syndrome (CS). In patients with suspected CS, all external pressures on the compartment (e.g., dressing, splint, cast, or other restrictive covering) should be removed.   
❌ Obtain a lower extremity arteriogram:
Incorrect: A Lower extremity arteriogram provides detailed arterial mapping and is helpful when preparing for revascularization. This patient has a 2+ dorsalis pedis pulse.   
✅ Operative fasciotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevate the leg and apply ice packs:
Incorrect: The limb should neither be elevated nor placed in a dependent position. Placing the limb level with the heart helps to avoid reductions in arterial inflow and increases in compartment pressures from dependent swelling, both of which can exacerbate limb ischemia.  
❌ Obtain doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremity:
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound of lower extremity is used for the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) as well arterial insufficiency. Although DVT can present with increasing pain and swelling, the onset is usually insidious and less severe. This patient’s clinical findings are more consistent with compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of pain, swelling, and erythema over his left lower extremity, as well as associated fever and chills for the past three days. An insect bite preceded the symptoms. Medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 104/66 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a 4 cm x 4 cm area of induration, fluctuance, and erythema over the posterior left calf. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the left lower extremity
X-ray of the left tibia and fibula
CT-angiography of the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a suspected skin abscess over the left lower calf. Given the associated systemic signs (fever, tachycardia, low-normal blood pressure), the next best step in management is to perform soft tissue ultrasonography to characterize the extent and depth of the abscess.

A skin abscess is a common skin/soft tissue infection that occurs when a collection of pus accumulates, usually in the dermis or subcutaneous space. An abscess can result from a disruption in the skin barrier or prior skin infection, which allows the bacteria to get into the subcutaneous space. The most common cause of a skin abscess is bacteria, especially Staphylococcus aureus (either methicillin-susceptible or methicillin-resistant). When it comes to presentation, a skin abscess can present with or without systemic symptoms.

The diagnosis of a skin abscess is largely clinical. Patients without systemic symptoms (e.g. fevers, hypotension) can be treated with simple incision and drainage, followed by monitoring for recurrence. Patients with large abscesses, systemic signs or symptoms, associated cellulitis, or significant laboratory abnormalities (e.g. markedly elevated leukocytosis) require formal soft tissue ultrasonography, cultures (e.g. purulent material, blood), and empiric antibiotics. These tests provide insight into the depth of infection and causative organism, which can guide incision, drainage, and antimicrobial therapy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Soft tissue ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ MRI of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: An MRI is utilized for the evaluation of osteomyelitis. This patient's presentation is more consistent with abscess formation with systemic signs of infection, making ultrasound the next best step in diagnosis.  
❌ X-ray of the left tibia and fibula:
Incorrect: An X-ray may be used to identify evidence of gas gangrene or osteomyelitis. However, this patient's presentation is more consistent with a skin abscess with systemic signs of infection, making ultrasound the next best step in diagnosis.  
❌ Deep venous ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Deep venous ultrasonography is used to evaluate for the presence of deep vein thrombosis, not skin or soft tissue abscesses, which is likely in this patient with an indurate, erythematous, fluctuant mass.  
❌ CT-angiography of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: CT-angiography would be a useful study for the evaluation of arterial thrombosis or peripheral vascular disease, not an abscess.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the right arm. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination demonstrates a 2 cm stab wound over the medial aspect of the cubital fossa with ongoing brisk, pulsatile bleeding. Neurologic examination demonstrates loss of sensation over the thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of the lateral 3 1⁄2 fingers. The patient also exhibits inability to flex the joints of the thumb, second and third digits, and inability to pronate the forearm. Injury to which of the following vascular structures is responsible for this patient’s ongoing bleeding?
questions.solution:
This patient’s stab wound is consistent with injury to the brachial artery and the median nerve, which lie next to each other in the cubital fossa. The cubital fossa contains four main vertical structures (lateral to medial): the radial nerve, biceps brachii tendon, brachial artery, and median nerve.   

The axillary artery terminates beyond the teres major's lower margin as it continues down the ventral surface of the arm to become the brachial artery. Once the brachial artery reaches the cubital fossa, it branches into the radial and ulnar arteries. Injury to the brachial artery  at the medial cubital fossa results in pulsatile, brisk bleeding, often with hematoma formation. Associated median nerve injury is common.    

In addition, the cubital fossa is a common site for venous blood sampling and intravenous line placement  due to its prominent and easily accessible veins. The most commonly accessed vein in this region is the median cubital vein, which connects the basilic and cephalic veins and lies superficial to the bicipital aponeurosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: The brachial artery bifurcates at the inferior portion of the cubital fossa into the radial artery (superficial) and ulnar artery (deeper). The radial artery accompanies the superficial branch of the radial nerve in the forearm. This patient has evidence of median nerve injury, which lies close to the brachial artery in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa.  
✅ Brachial artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ulnar artery:
Incorrect: The brachial artery bifurcates at the inferior portion of the cubital fossa into the radial artery (superficial) and ulnar artery (deeper). The radial artery accompanies the superficial branch of the radial nerve in the forearm. This patient has evidence of median nerve injury, which lies close to the brachial artery in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa.  
❌ Deep brachial artery:
Incorrect: The deep brachial artery courses posterior to the humerus and is vulnerable to injury with proximal humeral fractures (e.g. humeral shaft fracture).  
❌ Anterior interosseous artery:
Incorrect: The anterior interosseous artery originates in the forearm distal to the cubital fossa.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate right upper quadrant abdominal pain. The patient has experienced recurrent episodes of right upper quadrant pain after eating. However, the current episode is more severe. The pain is 10 out of 10 in severity, radiates to the right shoulder, and is associated with nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), blood pressure is 132/89 mmHg, and pulse is 107/min. Physical examination reveals a positive Murphy sign, and bedside ultrasound demonstrates pericholecystic fluid. The patient is subsequently provided with intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and general surgery is consulted. Which of the following is the most appropriate analgesic treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an acute surgical abdomen in the setting of cholecystitis. Patients with moderate-severe pain in the setting of an acute surgical abdomen are best treated with strong opiate agonists, such as morphine.    

The primary indication for opiate analgesics in the treatment of acute moderate-severe pain. Opiates have been well-known to provide analgesia in patients presenting with acute pain that is often refractory to other analgesic medications, such as acetaminophen or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Morphine, as the prototypical opiate agonist, is commonly administered intravenously, with desired effects peaking between 15-20 minutes and lasting for 2-4 hours.    

Fentanyl, another opiate agonist, has a much faster onset of action (1-2 minutes) with a duration of action of approximately 60 minutes. Due to these characteristics, fentanyl is more commonly used in acute trauma patients or those requiring frequent neurologic assessments.  

Hydromorphone is also becoming more widely used as an analgesic for acute pain management. This medication is more potent than fentanyl or morphine and is often used in patients with pain refractory to other opioid analgesics. 

Option Analysis

✅ Morphine :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ketorolac :
Incorrect: Ketorolac is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). This patient has evidence of acute cholecystitis and will likely undergo cholecystectomy. Administration of an NSAID could worsen intraoperative bleeding.   
❌ Acetaminophen :
Incorrect: Acetaminophen provides analgesic relief for those with mild to moderate pain and is typically administered orally. Given the severity of this patient’s pain, administration of a stronger medication is warranted.   
❌ Tramadol :
Incorrect: Tramadol functions as a weak opioid agonist and also inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. Given the severity of this patient’s pain, the administration of a stronger opiate agonist is warranted.   
❌ Oxycodone :
Incorrect: Oxycodone is an opiate agonist administered orally. Given this patient has acute cholecystitis and will likely undergo surgery, she should not take any medications by mouth.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the office to evaluate episodic headaches, which have been ongoing for  two months. The headache is bilateral, throbbing, and 10 out of 10 in severity. The headaches last for 10-15 minutes, accompanied by generalized sweating and palpitations, and subsequently resolve spontaneously. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for thyroid cancer in her mother at 30. She smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and does not consume alcohol or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 158/89 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated plasma metanephrines. An abdomen CT reveals a 4 cm adrenal mass without evidence of metastasis. Surgical resection of the mass is scheduled for the following week, and a preoperative drug is administered during the current visit. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with episodic headaches, palpitations, elevated plasma metanephrines, and a 4 cm adrenal mass imaging. These findings indicate a pheochromocytoma, which is a catecholamine secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla. To prevent intraoperative catecholamine crisis, the patient should be started on a non-selective ɑ-adrenergic antagonist.   

Non-selective ɑ-blockers work by blocking both ɑ1 and ɑ2 adrenergic receptors and include phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine. ɑ1 blockade causes vasodilation, resulting in a lowering of blood pressure. Phenoxybenzamine is an irreversible ɑ-blocker that is administered at least one to two weeks before the resection of a pheochromocytoma to prevent a catecholamine crisis during surgery. It binds to a different site on the receptor from catecholamines. It alters the receptor's shape so that it can no longer bind to catecholamines released from the adrenal medulla.  

On the other hand, phentolamine is a reversible inhibitor. It is primarily indicated to treat  hypertensive crises in patients who co-ingested a monoamine oxidase inhibitor with tyramine-containing foods (e.g., cheese, wine, beer).  

Common side effects of these medications include orthostatic hypotension and reflex tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

❌ ɑ1-receptor antagonist :
Incorrect: ɑ1-receptor antagonists (e.g., prazosin, doxazosin) can sometimes be used to improve the symptoms of a metastatic pheochromocytoma that is not amenable to surgical resection. However, for surgical candidates, phenoxybenzamine is the preferred drug for preoperative blood pressure control and the prevention of arrhythmias.  
✅ Non-selective ɑ-receptor antagonist:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is elevated secondary to a pheochromocytoma. The patient should be pretreated with an irreversible non-selective ɑ-blocker to reduce the incidence of a catecholamine crisis during surgery.  
❌ β-adrenergic blocker:
Incorrect: This patient has a pheochromocytoma, and β-adrenergic blockers should not be administered before ɑ-adrenergic antagonists. Otherwise, the patient is at risk of unopposed ɑ-adrenergic receptor stimulation, further exacerbating the patient’s hypertension.  
❌ Muscarinic receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Preoperative administration of a muscarinic receptor antagonist would not alter the patient’s vascular tone. It may, however, increase the patient’s heart rate and further increase blood pressure.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of dental pain. The patient has wisdom teeth pain, and it may be infected. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication on a regular basis. The patient has had an allergic reaction to tetracaine in the past while having a laceration repaired. The patient broke out in hives around the injection site. On physical examination, a periapical abscess is identified at the base of the left inferior third molar. Prior to incision and drainage the patient has an inferior alveolar nerve block performed with subsequent reduction in pain. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with dental pain is found to have a periapical abscess, requiring an inferior alveolar nerve block for pain relief. Given his report of an allergic reaction to tetracaine (an ester anesthetic), the most appropriate alternative choice is an amide anesthetic. The only amide anesthetic listed is bupivacaine.    

Local anesthetics are divided based on their chemical structure into two major categories: ester anesthetics and amide anesthetics. All local anesthetics consist of a lipophilic aromatic ring linked to a hydrophilic tertiary amine. Ester anesthetics are named for the ester linkage (-COO-) that connects the aromatic group to the amine group and includes the medications procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine and chloroprocaine.  Conversely, the amide anesthetics lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine consist of an aromatic group connected to an amine group via an amide linkage (-NCO-). One way to remember the difference between these two groups is based on nomenclature--amides have two I’s in their name.    

Notable differences between these two groups are demonstrated in the table below. While extremely rare, the risk of allergic reaction is higher in ester anesthetics, due to possible para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) formation.  



Option Analysis

✅ Bupivacaine :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Procaine:
Incorrect: Procaine is an ester anesthetic, and has a very short duration of action. It is no longer used due to its side effect profile including central nervous system and cardiovascular toxicity. Procaine is also thought to be more likely than other local anesthetics to trigger an allergic reaction, as it is metabolized to para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA).   
❌ Cocaine:
Incorrect: Cocaine is not used as a local anesthetic in current medical practice. The only current medical use of cocaine is via intranasal spray for vasoconstriction in the setting of uncontrolled epistaxis.   
❌ Thiopental:
Incorrect:  Thiopental is a barbiturate medication used for intravenous anesthesia. This medication is not used as a local anesthetic.   
❌ Pentazocine :
Incorrect: Pentazocine is a κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor weak antagonist or partial agonist used for moderate to severe pain. It is not used as a local anesthetic.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents to the oncologist for follow-up of inflammatory breast cancer.  She was diagnosed by her gynecologist after the rapid onset of breast pain, redness and swelling prompted imaging and biopsy.  Initial staging scans revealed no evidence of distant metastatic disease and she has completed a course of neoadjuvant chemotherapy with a significant reduction in tumor size.  She has no complaints outside of continued breast pain and otherwise feels she is in her usual state of health.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg.  On chaperoned examination, it is noted that the erythema and tenderness of the left breast have significantly improved from the previous visit.  Which of the following is the best treatment plan at this time?

choices.text: Non-skin-sparing mastectomy with axillary dissection followed by radiation

questions.solution:
This patient with inflammatory breast cancer without metastatic disease has had a favorable response to neoadjuvant therapy, and is able to undergo surgery. The next step is to perform a non-skin-sparing mastectomy with axillary dissection followed by radiation therapy.

The treatment approach in inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is determined by the stage of disease.  The TNM staging system is used to classify tumor size and extent, nodal metastases and distant metastases.  When distant metastatic disease is present, the cancer is classified as stage IV and treatment is palliative, attempting to prolong survival, minimize symptoms and optimize quality of life.  Chemotherapy is the primary method of palliative treatment when considerable skin necrosis is present.  Palliative mastectomy may be considered.

In the absence of distant metastases, inflammatory breast cancer is always considered stage III disease due to skin involvement.  The standard treatment approach in stage III IBC is neoadjuvant chemotherapy, followed by non-skin-sparing mastectomy with axillary dissection and postoperative radiation if there is a favorable response to chemotherapy.  Response to chemotherapy is gauged by reduction in tumor size and symptom improvement.  After completion of surgery and radiation, long-term hormone therapy or immunotherapy may be indicated depending on the features of the cancer (e.g., hormone-sensitive tumors or HER2-positive tumors).  If reconstruction is desired, it should be delayed until after completion of radiation.  Palliative care is indicated if there is no improvement of disease following neoadjuvant chemotherapy.  All eligible patients with inflammatory breast cancer should be enrolled in clinical trials.  

Option Analysis

✅ Non-skin-sparing mastectomy with axillary dissection followed by radiation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Skin-sparing mastectomy followed by radiation:
Incorrect:  Skin-sparing mastectomy is not a surgical option when tumor cells are close to or involving the skin.  This patient has inflammatory breast cancer which by definition involves the skin, therefore a skin-sparing mastectomy is contraindicated, and axillary dissection at the time of surgery is standard in patients with inflammatory breast cancer.  
❌ Radiation followed by additional chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Radiation followed by additional chemotherapy could be considered for palliative therapy in a patient who is unable to have surgery or who does not have an operable tumor. This patient has had a favorable response to chemotherapy and is otherwise healthy, making her a good surgical candidate.  
❌ Palliative chemotherapy alone:
Incorrect:  Palliative chemotherapy alone is used in metastatic disease to prolong survival and maximize quality of life.  This patient does not have evidence of distant metastatic disease, therefore she should have surgically removed the diseased tissue and complete radiation to the area.  
❌ Radical mastectomy followed by chemotherapy:
Incorrect: In a radical mastectomy, the chest wall muscle under the breast is removed in addition to the breast tissue.  Radical mastectomy is indicated when disease has spread to the muscle but it is not otherwise the routine surgical approach. Radiation therapy after surgery is standard in patients with inflammatory breast cancer.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man had an incision and drainage performed in the emergency department three days ago for an infection over the gluteal cleft. He presents to the surgical office today for a follow-up evaluation. The patient continues to have pain in the area. Drainage continued from the first day after the procedure but has since stopped. Temperature is 37<sup>o</sup>C (98.6<sup>o</sup>F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/82 mmHg. Examination reveals tenderness and erythema over the left medial gluteal area with a fluctuant lump at the cleft.  Sinus tracts can be seen opening to the overlying skin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing an acute pilonidal infection with abscess formation. Acute pilonidal disease occurs when infection develops in sinus tracts, pits, or other cavities under the surface of the skin in the intergluteal or sacrococcygeal region. These spaces are often filled with hair or other skin debris. Incision and drainage are necessary to treat acute pilonidal infection with abscesses; however, recurrence is common. If refractory infection or abscess is present after incision and drainage, repeat incision and drainage should be performed and systemic antibiotics should be considered.

Stepwise management of acute pilonidal infection involves oral antibiotics if there is no abscess, and surgical consultation for incision, drainage and curettage if an abscess is present. Despite initial incision and drainage, the abscess can reaccumulate or have persistent loculations following the procedure. Therefore patients need to be reassessed within 48 to 72 hours. Repeat incision drainage may be necessary and oral antibiotics should also be considered.

Chronic pilonidal disease is diagnosed when the sinus tracts or pits of the natal cleft persist, with or without drainage, but without signs of active bacterial infection. Options for the definitive management of pilonidal infection include surgical excision or phenol injections to destroy the sinus tracts and skin pits. Techniques to remove hair from the natal cleft can also help prevent recurrences. Weight loss, good hygiene, and increased movement throughout the day should also be recommended for prevention.  

Option Analysis

❌ Injection of phenol:
Incorrect: This treatment could be considered for definitive treatment of chronic pilonidal disease, but the highest priority for this patient is treating the acute infection with repeat incision and drainage.  
✅ Repeat incision and drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sphincterotomy:
Incorrect: Sphincterotomy is a procedure used to treat chronic anal fissures or hemorrhoids and would not be appropriate treatment for acute pilonidal disease.  
❌ Prescribe topical antibiotics:
Incorrect: The addition of systemic antibiotics could be considered for this patient along with incision and drainage, but topical antibiotics would not be adequate treatment.  
❌ Localized hair removal treatment:
Incorrect: Localized hair removal treatment can help prevent recurrent episodes of pilonidal disease, however, this would not be appropriate management for acute infection.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fever, fatigue, and left breast pain. She is currently breastfeeding and had a plugged duct one week ago which she was not able to clear.  Her breast has since become red and swollen, and she began having chills today.  She works as a nurse in the hospital.  Temperature is 38.9°C (102.1°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 102/72 mmHg. Chaperoned examination of the left breast reveals a 10 cm area of erythema and warmth laterally with central fluctuance and tissue necrosis.  Ultrasound reveals a 7.5 cm fluid collection under the surface of the skin.  White blood cell count is 18.2 × 109/L.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Vancomycin followed by incision and drainage
Dicloxacillin followed by ultrasound-guided needle aspiration
Cephalexin followed by incision and drainage
Urgent mammogram and incision and drainage
Ampicillin/Sulbactam followed by ultrasound-guided needle aspiration

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of breast pain with associated fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis. Physical exam and ultrasound are consistent with a breast abscess, which should be treated with IV antibiotics, incision, and drainage. Given the extensive soft tissue involvement, signs of systemic illness, and the patient’s work as a nurse, empiric coverage for MRSA with vancomycin is indicated until culture and sensitivities are available. Incision and drainage are warranted when a breast abscess exceeds 5 cm in size or when tissue necrosis is present, both of which are present in this patient.

A breast abscess can occur as a complication of existing mastitis, which is likely in this patient, or it can be the initial presentation of a breast infection. Ultrasound is used to evaluate for the presence of a fluid collection and to assess the size. When an abscess is present, fluid must be drained and sent for studies. Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration can be used to drain abscesses that are less than 5 cm on ultrasound and for those without tissue necrosis. Incision and drainage is the preferred method of drainage when the abscess is > 5 cm, or when tissue infarction or necrosis is present, or when previous needle aspirations have been attempted and failed. Fluid should be sent for culture and sensitivities.

The antibiotic class and route of administration should be determined by the extent of the infection. Patients with signs of severe infection (e.g. extensive soft tissue involvement, rapid progression of disease, systemic illness, or sepsis) require treatment with IV antibiotics after stabilization. The initial antibiotics should include MRSA coverage until culture and sensitivities are available. Coverage for MRSA is also indicated for patients with a prior history of MRSA or with high exposure rates to MRSA, such as in this patient who is a healthcare worker. Breastfeeding should be continued despite infection, with use of a breast pump if the child cannot directly feed. Additionally, pain medication is often needed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Vancomycin followed by incision and drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dicloxacillin followed by ultrasound-guided needle aspiration:
Incorrect: Dicloxacillin is an oral antibiotic indicated for outpatient management of mastitis or a breast abscess. This patient has signs of systemic illness, which requires inpatient management with IV antibiotics. Additionally, incision and drainage should be used to drain abscesses that are > 5 cm or when there is evidence of tissue necrosis.  
❌ Cephalexin followed by incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Cephalexin is an oral antibiotic indicated for outpatient management of mastitis or a breast abscess. This patient has signs of systemic illness, which requires inpatient management with IV antibiotics.  
❌ Urgent mammogram and incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Workup for inflammatory breast cancer, including mammogram, should be considered for patients with breast abscesses that fail to respond to initial management. This patient is lactating and has not attempted treatment. She should be treated for infection first and if that fails imaging can be performed.  
❌ Ampicillin/Sulbactam followed by ultrasound-guided needle aspiration:
Incorrect: Given this patient’s signs and symptoms of systemic toxicity, she should be treated with antibiotics that cover MRSA while awaiting culture results. Incision and drainage are necessary instead of ultrasound-guided needle aspiration due to the size of the abscess and associated tissue necrosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to his primary care physician’s office for a routine physical exam. He is in his usual state of health. He has hypertension and takes amlodipine. He has sleep apnea and uses a CPAP machine nightly. He smokes ½ pack of cigarettes daily. He does not drink and smokes marijuana approximately once a month at social gatherings. He has been exposed to asbestos through his job doing construction. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 75. Temperature is 36.4 °C (97.5 °F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 130/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. BMI is 24 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Carotid upstroke is normal bilaterally. Abdominal examination is normal. There is no lower extremity edema. In addition to hypertension, which of the following is an indication for ultrasound evaluation for carotid artery disease?
questions.solution:
This patient is at increased risk for carotid artery disease (CAD) and should undergo a carotid duplex ultrasound. His increased risk is based on the presence of hypertension and a significant smoking history.

Atherosclerotic build-up in arterial vessels causes carotid artery disease. This build-up develops over years, therefore the prevalence of carotid artery stenosis increases with age. Patients can be asymptomatic. If stenosis becomes severe, it can lead to symptoms and complications, the most worrisome being ischemic stroke.

Society guidelines for screening asymptomatic patients for carotid artery disease differ. Screening recommendations discussed here are based on guidelines from the American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines. Screening for carotid artery disease in asymptomatic patients is based on personal and family history which helps determine the patient’s risk for carotid artery disease. Patients who are at high risk for carotid artery disease should undergo a carotid artery duplex ultrasound. Patients who have a history of atherosclerotic disease, such as peripheral arterial disease or coronary artery disease are considered high-risk for carotid artery stenosis. In addition, patients who have 2 or more of the following are also at high-risk for carotid artery stenosis: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, tobacco use, a family history of atherosclerosis diagnosed before age 60, and a family history of ischemic stroke. For patients at low risk, no screening is recommended.  

Option Analysis

✅ Smoking history:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Body mass index:
Incorrect: This patient has a normal body mass index which does not place him at increased risk for carotid artery stenosis.  
❌ Family history of cardiovascular disease:
Incorrect: History of cardiovascular disease in first-degree relatives before age 60 can help define high-risk for carotid disease. In this case, the patient’s father was 75 years old when he had cardiovascular disease.  
❌ Occasional marijuana use:
Incorrect: Occasional marijuana use has not been shown to increase risk of carotid artery disease.  
❌ Asbestos exposure:
Incorrect: Asbestos exposure has not been shown to increase risk of carotid artery disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with vomiting, abdominal pain, and distension. She has been experiencing nausea and vomiting for the past 3-days which started after watching her grandchildren. She has not passed flatus or stool since then. She denies recent surgeries or trauma. Her medical history is notable for hypertension, for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide daily. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 134/88 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended, tympanic to percussion, and mildly tender to palpation. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Abdominal radiographs show dilated loops of small and large bowels without evidence of mechanical obstruction. Which of the following tests should be ordered next to help determine the underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of ileus, which is supported by abdominal X-ray findings. She has had no recent surgeries, but does take a thiazide diuretic, predisposing her to electrolyte derangements. Additionally she has had vomiting likely caused by a gastrointestinal virus. Hypokalemia may be present and should be evaluated by ordering serum electrolytes.

Ileus refers to a functional obstruction of the intestines that may arise due to reduced or absent peristalsis without an underlying mechanical blockage. The diagnosis is often suspected based on the history and examination, and can be confirmed with imaging. An abdominal X-ray may show dilated small bowel without evidence of a transition point.

Non-postoperative causes of ileus include medications that slow peristalsis (e.g., opiates, anticholinergics), systemic conditions (e.g., electrolyte abnormalities, sepsis), intraabdominal pathology (e.g., diverticulitis, appendicitis), and radiation. For nonsurgical ileus, the etiology can usually be gleaned from the patient’s history or from the supportive workup. In addition to imaging, workup should include laboratory studies, such as CBC, CMP, and urinalysis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Serum electrolytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal CT scan:
Incorrect: An abdominal CT can identify localized conditions, such as abscesses, masses, or inflammatory changes. However, in a patient with generalized distension and symptoms suggestive of ileus, serum electrolyte measurement would be more appropriate as an initial diagnostic test. Certain electrolyte abnormalities including hypokalemia (which may have been caused by gastrointestinal illness with vomiting combined with thiazide use in this case) can contribute to ileus.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy can be used to diagnose and treat mechanical obstructions of the colon; however, this patient’s presentation is more suggestive of a non-mechanical, functional obstruction (ileus) likely from hypokalemia secondary to vomiting and thiazide diuretic use.  
❌ Stool guaiac test:
Incorrect: This test is used to detect occult blood in the stool, which may be useful in patients with suspected gastrointestinal bleeding. It is not the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of ileus.  
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: This procedure is typically used to visualize the upper gastrointestinal tract. An upper endoscopy would not be the initial diagnostic test of choice to diagnose the cause of an ileus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to fever and altered mental status. His partner states that, after coming home following a night of drinking alcohol, the patient vomited many times and began to have severe chest pain and mild abdominal discomfort. Past medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient is oriented to person only. Physical examination reveals a crunching sound in sync with the heart sounds, crepitus over the chest, and mild tenderness to palpation over the epigastrium. Breath sounds are equal bilaterally. ECG shows sinus tachycardia without ST- or T-wave abnormalities. IV access is obtained, and fluids are administered. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden intense chest pain and mild upper abdominal pain following intense retching and vomiting. Physical exam findings of crunching heard with each heartbeat (Hamman's sign) and crepitus over the chest are highly suggestive of Boerhaave syndrome (spontaneous esophageal perforation from straining or vomiting). The patient should be started on supportive care, and once stabilized, he should have a contrast esophagram to confirm the diagnosis and guide management.

Esophageal perforation can lead to mediastinitis, which can be life threatening. This results from contamination of the mediastinum with gastric contents. Early signs of mediastinitis include fever, tachycardia, and chest pain. As the condition progresses, patients can develop sepsis and hemodynamic instability.

Immediate management of esophageal perforation involves hemodynamic stabilization, including IV fluid resuscitation and the administration of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics. Contrast esophagram is the diagnostic tool of choice. Intravenous proton pump inhibitors can be prescribed to decrease gastric acid secretion, which can further damage mediastinal structures, and the patient should be placed on NPO. A surgery consult should be called for possible surgical repair.  

Option Analysis

✅ Contrast esophagram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum amylase and lipase levels:
Incorrect: Elevated serum amylase and lipase levels can be seen in acute pancreatitis. This patient's presentation of recurrent vomiting with evidence of subcutaneous emphysema is highly suggestive of esophageal perforation, and lab work is typically not helpful for making the diagnosis.  
❌ CT angiography:
Incorrect: This patient's presentation is more consistent with esophageal perforation than with aortic dissection. Therefore, contrast esophagram is the most appropriate diagnostic study.  
❌ Emergent esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD):
Incorrect: Boerhaave syndrome is suspected in this patient. Performing an EGD in a patient with an esophageal perforation can potentially worsen the tear.  
❌ Cardiology consult:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest pain and abnormal heart sounds are most likely due to Boerhaave syndrome given the history, physical examination findings, and lack of ST- and T-wave abnormalities on ECG.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department after experiencing forceful vomiting and retching numerous times over the past six hours. He saw blood in the last vomitus. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 95/min, blood pressure is 155/92 mmHg, and respirations are 22/min. The patient appears comfortable. He is awake and oriented. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Abdominal examination reveals no hepatomegaly or fluid wave. There is no peripheral edema. Blood work is obtained, and results are shown below. Which of the following additional historical features is most likely to be present?

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Leukocyte count  13,500/mm3 
 Hemoglobin  15.2 g/dL 
 Sodium  132 mEq/L 
 Potassium  3.2 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  27 mEq/L 
 AST  28 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase  57 U/L 
 Bilirubin  1.0 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This stable patient with normal laboratory values had one episode of hematemesis after vomiting for several hours; this presentation is most consistent with Mallory-Weiss syndrome. The most frequently associated risk factor for Mallory-Weiss syndrome is a history of heavy alcohol ingestion.   

Mallory-Weiss syndrome, also known as a Mallory-Weiss tear, is a superficial longitudinal mucosal tear at or near the gastroesophageal junction, often presenting as acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The tear can cause severe bleeding if there are other comorbidities, such as portal hypertension or esophageal varices. These mucosal tears typically occur after repetitive and forceful retching and vomiting from any cause; however, the most common presentation is in the setting of heavy alcohol use. Other conditions that cause a sudden increase in intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, blunt abdominal injury, or straining, can also infrequently result in Mallory-Weiss syndrome.   

Option Analysis

✅ Recent heavy alcohol use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pruritus:
Incorrect: Pruritus and an upper gastrointestinal bleed may be indications of liver cirrhosis and esophageal varices. However, this patient does not have evidence of cirrhosis, which can include splenomegaly, ascites, and spider angiomata; and his liver function tests and bilirubin level are normal. 
❌ History of food allergies:
Incorrect: Patients with eosinophilic esophagitis commonly have seasonal and food allergies and present with dysphagia, odynophagia, and food intolerance; they rarely have hematemesis.
❌ Use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs:
Incorrect: Patients who use nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs regularly are at risk for peptic ulcer disease and gastritis and will commonly present with abdominal pain, especially if they have an erosive ulcer with bleeding. However, hematemesis associated with peptic ulcer disease usually starts at the beginning of vomiting, not several hours later as is seen in this patient.
❌ Recent endoscopic procedure:
Incorrect: Having a recent endoscopic procedure increases the risk of iatrogenic complications, such as esophageal perforation and bleeding, which can lead to hematemesis. This patient does not have signs or symptoms associated with esophageal perforation (neck or chest pain, odynophagia, fever, chills, and crepitus in the neck or chest).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for 10-12 episodes of forceful vomiting over the past 12 hours. His vomiting began after drinking 16 beers the previous night during a celebration. He vomited 10 times, and there has been bright red blood in the vomitus for the past hour. He has no known medical conditions and takes no medications. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks six beers on the weekends. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, and respirations are 18/min. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. There is no peripheral edema. Intravenous fluids and proton pump inhibitors are administered. Initial hemoglobin is 15.2 g/dL. Serial vital signs and hemoglobin levels are obtained and charted below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Time after presentation (hrs)Blood Pressure (mmHg)Pulse (/min)Hemoglobin (g/dL)
2132/769513.5
4125/729012.5
6135/758812.1

choices.text: Urgent inpatient upper endoscopy within 24 hours
Oral proton pump inhibitors and outpatient upper endoscopy within 72 hours
Oral proton pump inhibitors and outpatient office follow-up

questions.solution:
This patient with hematemesis that started after several hours of vomiting most likely has Mallory-Weiss syndrome. His blood pressure and pulse are stable. However, his hemoglobin level has been decreasing, indicating active bleeding. Hemodynamically stable patients with active upper gastrointestinal bleeding from a suspected Mallory-Weiss tear should remain in the hospital and undergo an urgent upper endoscopy within 24 hours of presentation.      

Patients with Mallory-Weiss syndrome should be stabilized with intravenous fluids and blood transfusions, if necessary. Intravenous (IV) or oral proton pump inhibitors (PPI) should be given. All patients will receive an upper endoscopy to confirm the diagnosis, though the timing of the endoscopy will be determined by the acuity of the presentation.        

For an unstable patient, an emergent upper endoscopy would be performed after IV PPIs (and antiemetics if needed). For stable patients, like in this case, serial hemoglobin levels or nasogastric tube output can be used to evaluate for active bleeding. An active bleed can be diagnosed if the patient has continued bloody nasogastric tube output or downtrending hemoglobin, in which case an urgent upper endoscopy should be performed within 24 hours of presentation. Otherwise, endoscopy may be performed in the outpatient setting within 72 hours. Upper endoscopy will usually show a single, longitudinal mucosal tear at or near the esophagogastric junction with some bleeding from the tear. Although most patients with Mallory-Weiss syndrome heal spontaneously, therapeutic measures, such as electrocautery or epinephrine injection, may be performed during EGD if active bleeding is present.  

Option Analysis

✅ Urgent inpatient upper endoscopy within 24 hours:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emergent upper endoscopy :
Incorrect: This patient does not have an indication for emergent upper endoscopy. Emergent endoscopy is recommended in the setting of massive hematemesis, hypotension, and tachycardia. This patient’s vital signs are stable on presentation and have been stable over the six hours since presentation. 
❌ Oral proton pump inhibitors and outpatient upper endoscopy within 72 hours:
Incorrect: Oral proton pump inhibitors and outpatient upper endoscopy within 72 hours is indicated in patients who do not have evidence of active bleeding. Active bleeding is diagnosed if the patient continues to have bloody nasogastric tube output or if they have downtrending hemoglobin levels as is seen in this patient. Upper endoscopy is recommended prior to discharge for patients with active bleeding.
❌ CT scan of the abdomen :
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy is the diagnostic modality of choice for upper gastrointestinal bleeding, the timing of which is based on the acuity of bleeding. A CT scan of the abdomen will not provide additional useful information.
❌ Oral proton pump inhibitors and outpatient office follow-up :
Incorrect: Oral proton pump inhibitors and outpatient follow-up is not recommended in patients with hematemesis, even if they no longer have active bleeding; an upper endoscopy would still need to be performed within 72 hours. This patient has evidence of active bleeding (i.e. downtrending hemoglobin levels) and should have an urgent upper endoscopy prior to discharge.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her dermatologist with concerns regarding a mole on her left arm. She works as a surfing instructor and spends prolonged hours in direct sunlight daily. She often forgets to wear protective clothing and sunscreen. She has a history of intermittent sunburns, especially during family vacations in tropical regions. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several pigmented lesions on her arms and face. On her left arm, there is an irregularly shaped, elevated lesion, with varying shades of red and black. The lesion measures approximately 5 mm in diameter. The surrounding skin shows signs of chronic sun damage. Which of the following features is most indicative of the need for further evaluation of the lesion?

choices.text: Varying shades of red and black
Presence of chronic sun damage to the surrounding skin

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of significant sun exposure and prior sunburns, presents with a skin lesion that has irregular borders and varying shades of red and black. These features raise suspicion for melanoma–warranting further investigation with a biopsy.    

Melanoma refers to a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes that often presents with unique clinical characteristics that distinguish it from benign skin lesions. A number of factors determine whether or not a lesion is suspicious for melanoma and should be biopsied. Clinically, the ABCDE criteria can serve as a guide for identifying suspicious lesions that may need to be biopsied: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variegation, Diameter over 6mm, and Evolution (change in size, color, or shape of a pre-existing lesion or report of a new growing lesion). Patient-reported symptoms such as itching, bleeding, or sensory changes in the lesion should heighten the suspicion of malignancy. Additionally, when a lesion looks conspicuously different (“ugly duckling” sign) from surrounding nevi (nevus phenotype), then a biopsy should be performed. The Glasgow Seven-point Checklist seen below can also help determine when lesions should be biopsied.    

During a skin exam, trained physicians may use a dermatoscope which magnifies skin lesions and can detect features that may be suspicious for malignancy but are not visible to the naked eye. For example, a dermatoscope can reveal subsurface skin structures within the epidermis, dermoepidermal junction, and papillary dermis. Visualizing these structures can increase the diagnostic accuracy of skin exams.





Option Analysis

❌ Occupation with frequent sun exposure:
Incorrect: While frequent sun exposure increases the risk of skin cancer, the appearance and features of the lesion are more pertinent to the diagnosis and evaluation of suspected melanoma.
❌ Lesion diameter of 5 mm:
Incorrect: Lesions greater than 6 mm should be biopsied. This lesion is small and based on size would not need to be biopsied. However the irregular shape and varying colors of the lesion warrant biopsy.
❌ Location on the left arm:
Incorrect: The location alone is not a significant factor in predicting malignancy. Morphological features of the lesion, such as irregular borders and varying colors, are more concerning features for a melanoma that necessitate biopsy.
✅ Varying shades of red and black:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Presence of chronic sun damage to the surrounding skin:
Incorrect: Chronic sun damage is a common finding in individuals with prolonged sun exposure but is not directly suggestive of malignancy. Specific features of the mole itself, such as irregularity and color variation, are more important indicators of potential malignancy.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with concerns about a lesion on her right upper arm that her partner noticed 2 weeks ago. She has not had any itching or bleeding at the site. Past medical history includes hypertension managed with lisinopril. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the lesion seen below is present on the lateral aspect of the right upper arm. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

Taken from STATdx
questions.solution:
A number of factors taken together can help identify lesions that are suspicious for melanoma that should be evaluated with excisional biopsy.

Excisional biopsy involves the removal of the entire lesion along with a small rim of surrounding normal skin. This approach provides an accurate measurement of the thickness (Breslow depth) of the melanoma, which is crucial for staging and subsequent management.

For large lesions in facial, mucosal, or acral locations that are suspicious of melanoma, an incisional biopsy can be considered, where only a representative portion of the lesion is removed. However, care must be taken to ensure the most raised or thickest part of the lesion is biopsied to allow for the most accurate measure of the Breslow depth. Histopathology findings consistent with melanoma include atypical melanocytes with hyperchromatic nuclei, or other abnormal nuclei or nucleoli characteristics, in addition to asymmetric, poorly circumscribed nests of melanocytes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Excisional biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Observation and follow-up in 1 year:
Incorrect: The lesion is suspicious for malignant melanoma given its asymmetry, irregular border, and color variegation. Observation is inappropriate for a lesion that is suggestive of melanoma due to the rapid progression and high potential for metastasis. Delay in diagnosis can result in a worse prognosis.  
❌ Shave biopsy:
Incorrect: The lesion is suspicious for malignant melanoma given its asymmetry, irregular border, and color variegation. A shave biopsy involves removing only a portion of a lesion, which can be insufficient for assessing the full depth of a suspected melanoma. This can lead to inappropriate staging and can compromise optimal management.  
❌ Liquid nitrogen cryotherapy:
Incorrect: The lesion is suspicious for malignant melanoma given its asymmetry, irregular border, and color variegation. Liquid nitrogen cryotherapy is primarily used for benign skin lesions like molluscum contagiosum, and squamous cell carcinoma (SSC) in-situ. It is not appropriate for use with suspected melanoma, as it does not provide tissue for histopathological analysis.  
❌ Mohs micrographic excision:
Incorrect: The lesion is suspicious for malignant melanoma given its asymmetry, irregular border, and color variegation. While Mohs micrographic surgery is a precise method for treating certain skin cancers like basal and squamous cell carcinomas located in cosmetically sensitive areas, it is not typically used for initial diagnosis or treatment of melanoma due to concerns about potentially missing invasive components of the tumor.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a thyroid nodule that was found on chest imaging performed for lung cancer screening two weeks ago. She has no pain, dysphagia, or symptoms of thyroid dysfunction. She has a 25-pack-year smoking history and stopped smoking two years ago. Her medical history is unremarkable for thyroid disorders, irradiation, or surgery. There is no family history of thyroid disorders or syndromes. Temperature is 36.6 °C (97.9 °F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, blood pressure is 127/77 mmHg, and BMI is 41. Her skin is warm and dry. On physical examination, there are no palpable thyroid masses and no cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Laboratory testing shows a serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 3.4 µU/L. Ultrasonography demonstrates a 1-cm hypoechoic mass with microcalcifications in the left lobe of the thyroid. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the thyroid gland

questions.solution:
This patient has an asymptomatic and nonpalpable thyroid nodule found incidentally on unrelated imaging. Her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is within reference range, so the nodule is not producing thyroid hormone and is therefore a non-functioning thyroid nodule. Ultrasound shows a 1-cm hypoechoic mass with microcalcifications, characteristics with an intermediate to high suspicion for malignancy. In this situation, it is necessary to order a fine needle aspiration (FNA) of the nodule for cytological analysis.    

The initial evaluation of a patient with an incidental thyroid nodule (ITN) involves obtaining a history with an emphasis on thyroid-related concerns, including medications, symptoms of hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism, and risk factors for thyroid malignancy. Physical examination should include a thorough examination of the neck and lymph nodes. Initial workup should include measuring serum TSH and performing a dedicated ultrasound of the thyroid and neck.      

If TSH is high or within reference range, the patient is hypothyroid or euthyroid, indicating a non-functioning nodule. If TSH is low, the patient is hyperthyroid and requires a radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scan to determine whether the nodule is hypofunctioning (“cold”) or hyperfunctioning (“hot”). When RAIU shows a solitary focus of uptake or patchy uptake that is concordant, or consistent, with ultrasound findings, then treatment of hyperthyroidism is indicated.    

However, patients with a non-functioning, hypofunctioning, or nonconcordant hyperfunctioning nodule should undergo FNA and cytology if ultrasound shows features suggestive of malignancy and the lesion is > or equal to 1 cm, as illustrated in the image below. Nodules with a low suspicion of malignancy should be biopsied when they measure ≥ 1.5 cm. If they are smaller, they can be followed up with a repeat ultrasound after 12–24 months.  



Option Analysis

✅ Fine-needle aspiration and cytology:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Repeat ultrasound in 12 to 24 months:
Incorrect: Waiting to obtain a repeat ultrasound would only be appropriate if a hypothyroid or euthyroid nodule, as seen in this case, has ultrasound findings, such as a cystic mass that is < 1 cm, that is likely benign. This patient has microcalcifications seen on ultrasound which raise suspicion for malignancy.
❌ Radioactive iodine uptake scan:
Incorrect: A radioactive iodine uptake (or RAIU) scan would be ordered only if the patient is hyperthyroid. This patient is euthyroid, both clinically and by laboratory testing of TSH.
❌ Surgical resection of the thyroid gland:
Incorrect: While this patient’s thyroid nodule is suspicious of malignancy, a biopsy would be required for cytological analysis before surgical treatment.  
❌ Repeat ultrasound within 6 months:
Incorrect: This nodule is 1 cm in diameter and has several ultrasound findings that are suspicious of malignancy. It would not be appropriate to wait instead of proceeding with further evaluation.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the clinic with episodic lower abdominal discomfort, bloating, and hematochezia for 4 months. She has not had diarrhea and the amount of stool she passes with each bowel movement has been smaller than usual. She reports weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lbs) over the past 4 months. Her appetite has remained unchanged, but she feels "full" earlier than usual after starting meals. Past medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) managed with omeprazole and irritable bowel syndrome diagnosed in her 30s. Family history is positive for endometrial cancer in her mother at the age of 32. Her diet is significant for high consumption of dairy products. Body mass index (BMI) is 20 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 124/80 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Abdominal examination shows mild distention with hyperactive bowel sounds and mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant without palpable masses. Digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals stool with blood in it and no evidence of hemorrhoids or fissures. Laboratory results are significant for a hemoglobin of 10.3 g/dL, and an MCV of 72 fl. Which of the following features would most significantly increase this patient’s risk for the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Family history of endometrial cancer at an early age
Chronic use of proton pump inhibitors (PPI)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with episodic lower abdominal discomfort, bloating, early satiety, weight loss, change in stool caliber, hematochezia, and microcytic anemia. This clinical presentation is highly suggestive of colorectal cancer (CRC). Multiple risk factors can contribute to the development of CRC. In this patient, family history of endometrial cancer in a first-degree relative at an early age raises the possibility of Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer or HNPCC).

Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a high risk of developing CRC, endometrial cancer, and ovarian cancer. Defective DNA mismatch repair genes, predominantly MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2, lead to a rapid accumulation of errors in the DNA, especially in areas known as microsatellites. These genetic errors accelerate the progression from adenoma to carcinoma in the colon.
