Signs and symptoms associated with CRC can vary based on the location of the tumor. Right-sided (proximal) colon tumors, encompassing the cecum to the right half of the transverse colon, lead to occult blood loss and iron-deficiency anemia. In contrast, left-sided (distal) tumors, involving the left transverse colon to the sigmoid, frequently cause changes in bowel habits, colicky abdominal pain, and sometimes blood-streaked stool. Tumors located in the rectum may produce symptoms of tenesmus, rectal bleeding, and stool caliber changes.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of endometrial cancer at an early age:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS):
Incorrect: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder. While its symptoms can mimic those seen in colorectal cancer, IBS itself does not increase the risk of developing colorectal cancer.  
❌ Body mass index (BMI) <21 kg/m2  :
Incorrect: A low BMI can be seen in colorectal cancer due to cancer-related weight loss. However, having a low BMI is not a risk factor for developing CRC. Conversely, obesity is a recognized risk factor for colorectal cancer.  
❌ Chronic use of proton pump inhibitors (PPI)  :
Incorrect: Chronic use of PPIs like omeprazole has been associated with various gastrointestinal problems including Clostridium difficile infection, atrophic gastritis, malabsorption of minerals and vitamins, and an increased risk of developing gastric polyps. It has not been directly correlated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer.  
❌ Diet high in dairy:
Incorrect: High dairy consumption has been suggested to have a protective effect against colorectal cancer due to its calcium content. Conversely, a diet high in red and processed meats is recognized as a risk factor for colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine checkup. She has been feeling tired over the past few months. She also reports constipation which is new for her. She has not had abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes managed with metformin and a hysterectomy 10 years ago for fibroids. Family history is significant for colon cancer in her maternal aunt at the age of 71. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva and unremarkable abdominal findings. Digital rectal examination shows no hemorrhoids or anal fissures. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL, and an MCV of 71 fl. Iron studies indicate low serum iron, low ferritin, and increased total iron-binding capacity. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous iron administration and re-evaluation in 3 months

questions.solution:
The patient's presentation is consistent with iron-deficiency anemia, as indicated by the low hemoglobin, low MCV, low serum iron, and low ferritin levels. In postmenopausal women, the most common cause of iron-deficiency anemia is gastrointestinal blood loss. Given her age, family history of colon cancer, and symptoms of fatigue and constipation, colorectal cancer (CRC) should be ruled out as a source of occult bleeding. Colonoscopy serves as the gold standard for diagnosis and evaluation of suspected CRC. It allows for visualization of the entire colon and rectum, biopsy of suspicious lesions, and removal of polyps.

On colonoscopy, distinctive indicators of colon cancer include irregularly raised masses or fungating growths that can constrict the colon's lumen; and polyps, especially adenomatous ones that have a high potential to become malignant. The morphology of polyps (i.e. sessile or pedunculated) can indicate malignancy risk. Additionally, ulcers with characteristic raised, uneven edges can be indicative of CRC. One of the most recognizable signs is the "apple-core" or "napkin-ring" lesion, typically representing annular constricting tumors frequently observed in the descending or sigmoid colon. The colonoscopy findings seen in colon cancer are the same as those seen with rectal cancer. Masses will be endoluminal, exophytic, and polypoid, with possible bleeding and necrosis, and malignant cells will be seen on biopsy.

Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fecal immunochemical test (FIT)  :
Incorrect: This patient with fatigue, change in bowel habits, and microcytic anemia is suspected of having colorectal cancer (CRC). The FIT test can detect occult blood in the stool, which can be a sign of CRC. While less invasive than a colonoscopy, it doesn't allow for direct visualization or biopsy of lesions. A direct examination via colonoscopy is more appropriate in this patient to diagnose CRC.  
❌ Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having colorectal cancer (CRC). CEA is a tumor marker that may be elevated in CRC. However, it's not used for screening or initial diagnosis due to its low sensitivity and specificity. It is used for monitoring disease progression or recurrence in patients already diagnosed with CRC.  
❌ Intravenous iron administration and re-evaluation in 3 months:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having colorectal cancer (CRC). Treating the anemia without investigating its cause would be inappropriate, especially given the patient's age, family, and clinical findings.  
❌ Barium enema:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having colorectal cancer (CRC). A barium enema may show "apple core" or "napkin ring" lesions in cases of colon cancer, which represent circumferential growths that constrict the lumen of the colon. However, barium enema is less sensitive than a colonoscopy and doesn't allow for biopsy or polyp removal.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of intermittent rectal bleeding and recent unintentional weight loss of 10 kg (22 lbs). He reports no other significant gastrointestinal symptoms. His past medical history includes hypertension controlled with lisinopril. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. His father died of colon cancer at the age of 75. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is significant for pallor. Digital rectal examination reveals blood without evidence of fissures or hemorrhoids. A colonoscopy is performed, showing a 4 cm ulcerating mass in the sigmoid colon, with biopsy confirming adenocarcinoma. A subsequent abdominal CT demonstrates a solitary 3 cm lesion in the right lobe of the liver. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Partial colectomy, partial hepatectomy, and adjuvant chemotherapy
Systemic chemotherapy and targeted liver radiotherapy

questions.solution:
The patient's biopsy confirming adenocarcinoma and abdominal CT findings indicate that this patient has colorectal cancer with an isolated liver metastasis. With isolated liver metastases, surgical resection of both the primary tumor (partial colectomy) and the hepatic lesion (partial hepatectomy), followed by adjuvant chemotherapy is the recommended treatment strategy.

Patients with non-metastatic colorectal cancer with small primary tumors can be treated with endoscopic transanal excision. More advanced tumors necessitate neoadjuvant therapy, the efficacy of which is subsequently assessed via proctoscopy and MRI. If a positive therapeutic response is observed, then surgical resection of the tumor can follow. If there are non-clear margins or lymphatic involvement adjuvant chemotherapy should be given. In cases with distant metastases, therapeutic decisions become more complex. Patients with solitary hepatic or pulmonary metastases may qualify for initial surgical removal of the colorectal tumor and the metastatic lesion. For inoperable cases, chemotherapy is recommended initially. Post-chemotherapeutic tumor restaging informs the subsequent therapeutic. A marked reduction in metastatic burden suggests a successful chemotherapeutic response and opens the possibility for surgical intervention. However, no response or an inadequate response indicates the need to shift to second-line chemotherapeutic agents or immunotherapeutic modalities, complemented by palliative care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Partial colectomy, partial hepatectomy, and adjuvant chemotherapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Systemic chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Systemic chemotherapy is used to treat metastatic colorectal cancer with multiple unresectable distal mets. When a solitary liver metastasis is present, a combination of surgical resection of the primary tumor and the liver lesion is often the optimal initial approach.  
❌ Neoadjuvant chemotherapy and partial colectomy:
Incorrect: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is used to shrink the size of tumors before surgery. This might prove beneficial for locally advanced tumors, but patients with resectable primary tumors and resectable isolated liver metastases may first have surgery.  
❌ Partial colectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy:
Incorrect: While a partial colectomy addresses the primary tumor, the presence of liver metastasis also requires urgent intervention. Adjuvant chemotherapy is used post-operatively to eradicate remaining microscopic disease, but an isolated resectable liver metastasis should be removed surgically first.  
❌ Systemic chemotherapy and targeted liver radiotherapy:
Incorrect: Systemic chemotherapy and targeted liver radiotherapy can be used to treat liver metastases, but the primary tumor should be removed with partial colectomy. Radiotherapy can be a valuable adjunct for liver metastases, especially when surgical resection is not feasible; however, in cases with a solitary liver metastatic lesion, surgical intervention is the preferred approach.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents to the primary care office for a rash on his chest and back which has been present for three days. The rash is slightly itchy. He does not have fever, chills, or other associated symptoms. Several people who went on a recent vacation with him have had a similar rash. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg. Examination of the trunk reveals a diffuse, papular rash over the hair follicles as seen below. Occasional pustules are noted and a culture is taken from the fluid within a pustule. The culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following would be the greatest risk factor for this patient’s infection?


Image by Lsupellmel is licensed under CC0 1.0 Universal Public Domain Dedication.  Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a diffuse, itchy, papulopustular rash located on the trunk, with Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth on culture, and has “hot tub” folliculitis caused by exposure to contaminated water, usually from a hot tub or swimming pool.  It is common for other individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water to also develop an infection.  

Folliculitis is most commonly caused by a superficial infection of hair follicles, which leads to a rash made up of itchy or painful red papules and pustules in the affected area. Bacterial folliculitis is usually caused by normal skin flora such as Staphylococcus aureus, and it is important to consider risk factors for MRSA such as working in a hospital setting or living in close quarters with large numbers of people. Fungal, viral, parasitic, and non-infectious etiologies of folliculitis occur as well. Patient activities that increase the risk of folliculitis include shaving and waxing, attempting to “pop” a pimple, wearing tight-fitting clothing, frequent sweating, and using a hot tub or swimming pool. Other risk factors include long-term antibiotic use, overuse of topical corticosteroids, and immunocompromised states such as HIV infection and diabetes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hot tub use :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Work in a hospital:
Incorrect: Working in a hospital is a risk factor for folliculitis caused by MRSA.  Although healthcare workers have increased exposure to pseudomonas, it does not typically lead to folliculitis.
❌ Adolescent age:
Incorrect:  Some forms of folliculitis are more common in certain age groups such as Malassezia (pityrosporum) folliculitis, a fungal folliculitis, which is more common in adolescents due to the increased activity of sebaceous glands. This patient has “hot tub” folliculitis caused by pseudomonas which can affect individuals of all ages
❌ HIV infection:
Incorrect: Patients living with HIV infection are at increased risk of folliculitis caused by Staphylococcus aureus.  Patients with a low CD4 count are also prone to eosinophilic folliculitis, a clinically similar process to bacterial folliculitis but with eosinophilia and elevated IgE levels. They are not at increased risk of developing “hot tub” folliculitis.
❌ Recent shaving of the area:
Incorrect: Shaving or waxing is a risk factor for folliculitis, which may be inflammatory from ingrown hairs or infectious from normal skin flora bacteria; however, folliculitis caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa is highly associated with recent exposure to contaminated water in a swimming pool or hot tub and not shaving.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man presents to the emergency department with crampy diffuse abdominal pain, constipation, and bloating that has been going on for three days. Today, the patient started vomiting. He reports a four-year history of constipation that has typically responded to miralax. He has no other significant past medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 123/85 mmHg. Laboratory studies reveal leukocytosis and an elevated lactate level. Hyperactive bowel sounds are heard on auscultation of the abdomen. The abdomen is distended and tympanitic with diffuse tenderness and guarding without rebound tenderness. Digital rectal exam is unremarkable. A plain radiograph of the abdomen is shown below. In addition to supportive care, which is the most appropriate management for this patient?
 

Credit: Flickr

choices.text: Urgent endoscopic decompression with rectal tube placement

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of chronic constipation and new-onset diffuse crampy crampy abdominal pain, and physical exam findings of diffuse abdominal tenderness with a tympanic abdomen without rebound. A coffee bean sign is seen on abdominal x-ray. These findings seen in an older man with chronic constipation are most consistent with sigmoid volvulus. In stable patients presenting with sigmoid volvulus, acute management via urgent endoscopic decompression with rectal tube placement is the initial recommended treatment.

Colonic volvulus occurs when an air-filled loop of the colon twists about its mesentery. Colonic volvulus can be categorized as either a cecal or sigmoid volvulus. Sigmoid volvulus most commonly occurs in older adults (≥ 70 years of age) and has a slightly higher incidence in men. The coffee bean sign that is seen with sigmoid volvulus, results when the sigmoid colon (the lower part of the large intestine) twists upon itself, causing a bowel obstruction. Also, multiple air-fluid levels will be seen on imaging typically in the right upper quadrant.

Once urgent endoscopic decompression has successfully detorsed (untwisted) the sigmoid, patients should be monitored for several days to assess response. Recurrent sigmoid volvulus, after an initial episode that is not treated with surgery, occurs in up to 84% of patients. Due to this high risk of recurrence, definitive treatment consists of elective surgical resection (sigmoid colectomy) of the affected bowel.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Urgent endoscopic decompression with rectal tube placement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Appendectomy:
Incorrect: Appendicitis typically presents with periumbilical or right lower quadrant pain, tenderness, and rebound on palpation associated with fever, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting. This patient’s presentation and abdominal x-ray showing a coffee bean sign are more consistent with sigmoid volvulus.  
❌ Cholecystectomy:
Incorrect: Cholecystitis results from blockage of the common bile duct with gallstones and presents with right upper quadrant pain (+/- radiation to the shoulder or back), abdominal tenderness, nausea, vomiting, and fever. This patient’s presentation and abdominal x-ray showing a coffee bean sign are more consistent with sigmoid volvulus.  
❌ Emergent exploratory laparoscopy:
Incorrect: Emergent exploratory laparoscopy is not indicated for the acute management of uncomplicated sigmoid volvulus in stable patients. Urgent endoscopic decompression with rectal tube placement is the first step in treatment.  
❌ Emergent colectomy:
Incorrect: Emergent colectomy is reserved for unstable patients presenting with complicated colonic volvulus (e.g., peritonitis, perforation, ischemic bowel, septic shock). This is not an appropriate treatment, given that this patient is stable without signs of peritonitis or sepsis. Elective colectomy should be performed at a later date after urgent endoscopic decompression with rectal tube placement.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with rectal bleeding, anal pain, and discomfort during bowel movements for the past five weeks. She has not had recent weight loss, changes in bowel habits, or abdominal pain. The patient has a history of receptive anal intercourse with multiple partners over the past ten years. The patient’s father died from colon cancer at the age of 60 years. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is a hard fixed mass palpated in the anal canal. Inguinal lymphadenopathy is present bilaterally. Which of the following would be most associated with a malignant cause of this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
Family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2
History of recent travel to a tropical region

questions.solution:
This patient with rectal bleeding, anal pain, and a hard fixed anal mass on digital rectal exam most likely has anal cancer. Anal cancer is a malignancy of the anal canal or perianal area. The two main subtypes of anal cancer are squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) which is the most common type, and adenocarcinoma. Although rare, the incidence of anal cancer has been increasing over the last two decades likely due to the spread of human papillomavirus (HPV) which is the primary cause of anal SCC. A history of anogenital warts, which HPV causes, is a significant risk factor for the development of anal cancer.

Patients with suspected anal cancer should have a thorough history taken to evaluate for risk factors. Anal cancer is strongly associated with a history of HPV infection (anal, cervical, vaginal, vulvar), particularly the high-risk strains HPV 16 and 18. HPV-related anal cancers often arise from precursor lesions, and individuals with a history of anogenital warts are at increased risk of developing these lesions and subsequently anal cancer. HPV is transmitted sexually therefore a high lifetime number of sexual partners, as well as receptive anal intercourse, increase the likelihood of contracting the virus and developing anal cancer. Patients who are immunocompromised, including those living with HIV infection, are also at an increased risk for anal cancer, and cigarette smoking increases the risk.

Patients may present with anal pain, rectal bleeding, and a sensation of a mass within or around the anus. On digital rectal exam (DRE) the clinician may note a palpable perianal or anal mass, which can be firm, fixed, or ulcerated. A thorough digital rectal examination is essential to assess the size, mobility, and characteristics of the tumor. Anogenital warts may be present. Lymphadenopathy in the inguinal or femoral regions can suggest regional spread of the disease.  

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of von Hippel-Lindau syndrome:
Incorrect: Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is a hereditary condition associated with hemangioblastomas of the brain and spine, retinal capillary hemangioblastomas (retinal angiomas), clear cell renal cell carcinomas (RCCs), and pheochromocytomas, among other findings. However, it is not associated with anal cancer.  
❌ Family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2:
Incorrect: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) is a hereditary condition associated with medullary thyroid cancer, parathyroid tumors, and pheochromocytoma. It is not associated with anal cancer.  
✅ History of anogenital warts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of early menarche:
Incorrect: Early menarche and late menopause are risk factors for ovarian cancer, but not for anal cancer, which is most commonly caused by HPV infection.  
❌ History of recent travel to a tropical region:
Incorrect: Travel to tropical regions may increase the risk of bladder cancer due to schistosomiasis, a disease caused by parasitic worms found in tropical regions; however, there is not an established link between travel to tropical regions and anal cancer.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for a painful red area on her left forearm. It has been present for 5 days and is getting worse. She frequently shaves her forearms but has never had an infection before.  She has a history of type II diabetes and does not regularly take her medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg. Examination of the forearm reveals a 3.5 cm cluster of pustular lesions with surrounding erythema. There is fluctuance and tenderness to palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a cluster of tender, fluctuant pustules on the forearm that can be diagnosed as a carbuncle. Shaving and diabetes are both risk factors for hair follicle infections including folliculitis, furuncles, and carbuncles.    

A hair follicle infection that is limited to the superficial dermis will appear as a superficially inflamed papule or pustule around a hair follicle and is diagnosed as folliculitis.  When the infection goes deeper and creates a painful pocket of pus in the subcutaneous space with overlying erythema of the skin, it is referred to as a furuncle. When a cluster of several furuncles connects through the subcutaneous space, it is diagnosed as a carbuncle which is a deeper, more severe infection with fluctuance, and possibly surrounding cellulitis. Patients diagnosed with a carbuncle should have a culture of the purulent fluid to guide antibiotic selection. A complete blood count should be done if systemic symptoms are present. Also if folliculitis or a furuncle fails to improve with empiric treatment, a culture of the purulent fluid is warranted.

Option Analysis

✅ Carbuncle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Furuncle:
Incorrect: A furuncle is a single pustular lesion under the skin caused by an infected hair follicle. This patient has a cluster of furuncles which would lead to the diagnosis of a carbuncle.
❌ Folliculitis:
Incorrect: When a hair follicle infection stays confined to the superficial structures of the dermis, it is diagnosed as folliculitis. This patient has multiple, deeper infections that have coalesced into a single structure that is referred to as a carbuncle.
❌ Cystic acne:
Incorrect: Cystic acne is more superficial and usually contains smaller lesions than a carbuncle. Cystic acne is also more likely to occur on the upper arm than the forearm.
❌ Hidradenitis suppurativa:
Incorrect: Subcutaneous hair follicle infections are characteristic of hidradenitis suppurativa, however; hidradenitis occurs in a chronic, recurring pattern and in locations where there are increased sweat glands or where skin touches skin such as the axilla, groin, buttocks, and breasts. This patient’s isolated forearm infection would not be consistent with a diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of bilateral breast pain and lumpiness that worsens the week prior to menstruation and improves afterward. She denies nipple discharge, and there is no family history of breast cancer. Her temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure 120/74 mmHg, heart rate 78 beats/min, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. On physical examination, the breasts are tender bilaterally, and there are tender nodular areas in both breasts. No skin changes or nipple retraction is observed. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following characteristics of the palpable nodules, if present, would be most suggestive of a benign process?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with breast tenderness and changes in the breast consistency that are cyclic and related to menstruation, and physical examination findings are consistent with fibrocystic breast changes. Mobile and well-demarcated masses are characteristic of benign breast changes, including fibrocystic breast changes.  

Fibrocystic breast changes represent a spectrum of benign alterations in the breast tissue, that includes fibrous tissue formation and cysts. This condition is most commonly found in reproductive-aged women between the ages of 30 and 50 years. While the precise cause remains elusive, hormonal imbalances, specifically an excess of estrogen coupled with insufficient progesterone, are believed to play a crucial role.  

Patients with fibrocystic breast changes may describe their breasts as feeling “lumpy” or they may notice distinct masses, and experience breast pain (mastalgia), swelling, and potentially a straw-colored discharge from the nipple. The symptoms have a tendency to worsen before menstruation each month. A physical examination may reveal numerous nodular regions, a “ropey” or “lumpy” texture of the breast tissue, and the breasts may be tender to touch. Palpable breast lumps may represent underlying cysts, which are usually discrete, well-circumscribed, mobile, and compressible.

Option Analysis

✅ Mobile and well-demarcated:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Irregular shape:
Incorrect: An irregular shape of breast masses is concerning for malignancy, as benign masses are usually round or oval.
❌ Fixation to the chest wall:
Incorrect: Fixation of breast masses to the chest wall can be a concerning sign, often associated with malignancy or advanced breast disease.
❌ Attachment to overlying skin:
Incorrect: Attachment of breast masses to overlying skin or the chest wall is a concerning sign that may suggest malignancy.
❌ Associated with bloody discharge:
Incorrect: A mass associated with bloody discharge could suggest an intraductal papilloma or, less commonly, breast cancer; both are more serious than benign fibrocystic changes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with cyclic breast pain that is worse with menstruation each month and a lumpy consistency of both breasts. The patient reports that these symptoms have been occurring on and off for the past year. She has no family history of breast cancer and is otherwise healthy. Her temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure 118/70 mmHg, heart rate 66 beats/min, respiratory rate 14 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. On physical examination, there are multiple areas in both breasts that have a lumpy or nodular texture with palpation. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. What is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s age, symptoms, and examination findings are consistent with fibrocystic breast changes. Ultrasound is the preferred initial diagnostic test for evaluating breast symptoms in women under 35 due to their dense breast tissue. It can help distinguish between solid and cystic masses, and it is especially helpful for evaluating fibrocystic changes that are suspected in this case.  

Fibrocystic breast changes represent a spectrum of benign alterations in the breast tissue that can include fibrous tissue formation and cysts. This condition is most commonly found in reproductive-aged women between the ages of 30 and 50 years.    
This diagnosis of fibrocystic breast changes can be confirmed with breast ultrasound, which may show fibroglandular tissue, clustered microcysts, distorted breast parenchyma, and absence of discrete masses. In women aged 35 years or older, a mammogram should also be performed. Findings on mammography may include heterogeneous and dense breast parenchyma, partially circumscribed cysts, and crescent-shaped calcifications.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mammography:
Incorrect: Mammography is typically not the first-line diagnostic study for breast symptoms in women under 35 due to their denser breast tissue.
❌ Fine needle aspiration:
Incorrect: Fine needle aspiration is generally reserved for cystic lesions, and while cystic changes may be present in this case, ultrasound is a better initial test to evaluate the nature of the breast changes.
❌ Core needle biopsy:
Incorrect: Core needle biopsy is an invasive procedure that is typically reserved for when there is a specific area of concern identified on imaging that needs tissue sampling for diagnosis; it is not indicated in this case.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging:
Incorrect:  Breast MRI is a more advanced imaging modality that is typically reserved for specific indications, such as screening high-risk individuals or evaluating the extent of known breast cancer; it is not necessary for initial evaluation of fibrocystic breast changes.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is evaluated in the post-anesthesia care unit for abrupt onset of hypotension after surgery. The patient underwent emergent exploratory laparotomy for a strangulated inguinal hernia. Peripheral intravenous access was lost after extubation and a left subclavian central venous catheter was subsequently placed. The patient’s past medical history is significant for severe chronic obstructive lung disease and hypertension. Current medications include albuterol, budesonide-formoterol, lisinopril, and tiotropium. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, blood pressure is 79/41 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 86% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in respiratory distress. A left subclavian central line is in place. The trachea is deviated to the right. Heart sounds are distant but are normal with no murmurs. Lung sounds are absent at the left apex. The abdominal surgical dressing has scant serosanguineous discharge and the abdomen is mildly tender to palpation at the incision sites. Which of the following tests would confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is found to have postoperative hypotension which occurred after placement of a subclavian central venous catheter. This in combination with respiratory distress, absent breath sounds and tracheal deviation away from the side of the absent breath sounds can be used to clinically diagnose a tension pneumothorax, which should be treated emergently with needle decompression. Tension pneumothorax occurs when a large amount of air accumulates outside the pleural space (can result from lung puncture during placement of central venous catheter) and pushes on mediastinal structures, impairing cardiac filling and resulting in life-threatening hypotension. A chest radiograph can confirm the diagnosis.

When postoperative hypotension occurs, life-threatening causes should be considered first. The clinical picture will help guide subsequent evaluation (e.g., laboratory studies, imaging) and management (e.g. needle decompression for tension pneumothorax). This may include CT angiography with anticoagulation, thrombolytic therapy, or mechanical thrombectomy for pulmonary embolism. Myocardial infarction should be suspected when there is elevated serum troponin, electrocardiographic changes, and/or new wall motion abnormalities on echocardiogram. Cardiac tamponade may be suspected in patients with muffled heart sounds and characteristic ECG and/or echocardiography findings, and would require pericardiocentesis or a “pericardial window.” Anaphylaxis can be suspected in patients with respiratory distress and lip and oropharyngeal swelling and should be treated with epinephrine.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chest radiograph:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum lactate level:
Incorrect: Lactate levels are frequently elevated in cases of hypotension due to poor cellular perfusion. However, lactate levels do not directly correlate with the degree of hypotension and cannot diagnose the underlying cause of hypotension.  
❌ Serum basic metabolic panel:
Incorrect: While basic blood work is generally ordered in patients with new-onset hypotension, the findings of the basic metabolic panel would not confirm the most likely diagnosis of tension pneumothorax which can be best visualized with chest radiography.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of new-onset hypotension and hypoxic respiratory distress is more consistent with a pulmonary pathology and not an abdominal process. The most likely diagnosis is tension pneumothorax which can be best visualized with chest radiography  
❌ Arterial blood gas:
Incorrect: An arterial blood gas (ABG) can help diagnose hypercarbia or determine the degree of hypoxia, especially if pulse oximetry is inaccurate. However, an ABG cannot be used in this case to determine the underlying cause of hypoxia. The most likely diagnosis is tension pneumothorax which can best be visualized with chest radiography.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 26 weeks gestation presents to the clinic after finding a breast mass in her right breast on self-examination. She has no significant past medical history and takes only folic acid. Temperature is 37.5 °C (99.5 °F), heart rate is 90 bpm, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg. Breast examination reveals a 1 cm irregular-shaped fixed breast mass in the lower medial quadrant of the right breast. No axillary lymphadenopathy is noted. The left breast shows no abnormality. The abdomen is gravid. Which of the following is the best next step for evaluating this patient’s breast mass?
questions.solution:
Breast ultrasound is considered the best initial study for evaluating suspicious breast masses in pregnant and lactating patients. Ultrasound is better than mammography for evaluating breast masses in patients with dense breast tissue (e.g., pregnancy, age < 40 years). Breast ultrasound can be used to characterize breast masses without the risk of fetal radiation exposure. Additionally, axillary ultrasound can be used to evaluate clinically suspicious lymph nodes and guide further fine needle aspiration or core needle biopsy.  

Breast ultrasound should be used to rule out other causes of breast masses in pregnant and lactating patients including mastitis with abscess and galactocele. Ultrasound reporting of breast masses is based on the breast imaging reporting and data system (BI-RADS) where BIRADS=1 indicates benign breast lesions and BIRADS=5 indicates lesions that are highly suggestive of malignancy. If lesions are found to be suspicious of malignancy, mammography should be performed next.

Option Analysis

✅ Breast ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mammography:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, mammography is only done if an initial ultrasound suggests malignancy in order to limit fetal exposure to radiation. Mammography is less sensitive during pregnancy and lactation because of the increased water content of the breasts, higher density of breast tissue, and loss of contrasting fat.
❌ Gadolinium-enhanced MRI:
Incorrect: The role of MRI has not been fully studied for evaluating breast masses in pregnant women. Gadolinium contrast is associated with potential fetal harm, especially if used during the first trimester.
❌ Core needle biopsy:
Incorrect: Core needle biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis of breast cancer regardless of pregnancy status; however, it should be performed only if ultrasound and mammography show lesions suspicious of malignancy.
❌ Fine needle aspiration:
Incorrect: FNA has lower sensitivity for diagnosing malignant breast lesions when compared to core needle biopsy. Tissue diagnosis should be performed only after appropriate imaging is first performed.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after developing severe abdominal pain and subsequently passing out. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension and atrial fibrillation for which he takes warfarin. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 75/40 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, pulse is 126/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is pale and diaphoretic and unable to provide a clinical history, but he is responsive to painful stimuli.  Abdominal examination shows abdominal tenderness and guarding; and a tender, nonpulsatile palpable abdominal mass on the right side of the abdomen above the umbilicus with overlying ecchymoses. It is unclear if it crosses the midline. Hemoglobin is 10.6 g/dl at presentation and decreases to 8.9 g/dl after imaging is performed. Which of the following complications is most likely to occur without prompt intervention?
questions.solution:
This patient who is on anticoagulation presents with hypotension, altered mental status, a lower abdominal mass on physical examination, and a decreasing hemoglobin. These findings are concerning for a rectus sheath hematoma. This patient is at risk of developing hemorrhagic shock without immediate intervention since a large volume of blood can be lost before a rectal sheath hematoma is suspected and diagnosed.

A rectus sheath hematoma is caused by arterial bleeding that leads to abdominal pain and a tender abdominal wall mass. Patients on anticoagulation are at an increased risk of developing this condition, as are patients who have recently undergone abdominal surgery. It often can be difficult to diagnose and differentiate from other causes of acute abdominal pain. If patients can raise their legs or head, and with that, the abdominal pain gets worse, then they have a positive Carnett sign, which indicates that the origin of the pain is the abdominal wall rather than an intra-abdominal source.

The first step in assessing a patient presenting with an abdominal wall mass is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if they are stable or unstable. If the patient is unstable, acute management should include stabilizing the airway, breathing and circulation. IV access should be established and IV fluid resuscitation should be initiated.  Clinical findings that suggest instability in patients with abdominal masses include severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation or obstipation, a distended abdomen, diffuse tenderness, rebound, and guarding.

Option Analysis

✅ Hemorrhagic shock:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Small bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: This patient who is on anticoagulation and has a lower abdominal wall mass with ecchymoses, hypotension, and a decreasing hemoglobin most likely has a rectal sheath hematoma. Without intervention this patient is at risk for hemorrhagic shock.  
❌ Septic shock:
Incorrect: Hemorrhagic shock, not septic shock, is more likely to result from a rectus sheath hematoma. Septic shock is more likely to occur with an abdominal mass that is a strangulated hernia with bowel necrosis.  
❌ Bowel necrosis:
Incorrect: Bowel necrosis is more likely to occur with an abdominal wall mass that is a strangulated hernia. Hemorrhagic shock is more likely to result from a rectus sheath hematoma.  
❌ Limb ischemia:
Incorrect: Limb ischemia is a potential complication of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. This patient’s mass is nonpulsatile, and more consistent with a rectal sheath hematoma. Without intervention, this patient is at risk of developing hemorrhagic shock.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of bright red blood per rectum. His recent colonoscopy two weeks ago revealed multiple colonic diverticula. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.1 ℃  (98.8℉), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/55 mm Hg. Laboratory evaluation shows a hemoglobin of 8 g/dL, and the coagulation profile is unremarkable. Arterial angiography demonstrates ongoing bleeding from the sigmoid colon. The patient is taken to the interventional radiology suite and prepared for catheter embolization. The artery used for cannulation and catheter insertion in this patient can be accessed at which of the following anatomic sites?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ongoing gastrointestinal hemorrhage and concern for an arterial source. The patient is subsequently taken for arterial embolization, which will require catheter insertion and cannulation via the femoral artery. The landmark used to locate and palpate the femoral artery is at the mid-inguinal point halfway between the pubic symphysis and anterior superior iliac spine.    

The femoral artery enters the thigh posterior to the inguinal ligament to continue as the external iliac artery. It can be palpated lateral to the femoral vein in the femoral triangle and is often accessed for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes (e.g. embolization). Moreover, the femoral artery can be used for arterial blood draws when the radial or brachial arteries cannot be accessed.  

The femoral artery is a frequent site of peripheral arterial disease, leading to claudication symptoms.  Moreover, its superficial position within the femoral triangle makes it vulnerable to traumatic injury (e.g. laceration).

Option Analysis

❌ Midline of the popliteal fossa:
Incorrect: The popliteal artery and vein pass through the popliteal fossa together with the tibial nerve. It is not likely to be accessed for catheter embolization.
✅ Mid-inguinal point:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lateral aspect of the foot:
Incorrect: The small saphenous vein is found at the lateral aspect of the foot and courses posteriorly to drain into the popliteal vein. It is not used for catheter insertion.
❌ Inferolateral to the pubic tubercle:
Incorrect: The long saphenous vein can be accessed just inferolateral to the pubic tubercle as it courses through the proximal anterior thigh before joining the femoral vein. Embolization via this vessel will not help reduce the ongoing hemorrhage in this patient.
❌ Superior to the inguinal ligament:
Incorrect: The deep circumflex iliac vessels course parallel and just superior to the inguinal ligament.  Embolization via these vessels will not help reduce the ongoing hemorrhage in this patient.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe posterior right thigh pain. He experienced sudden right posterior thigh pain with an associated popping sound while performing a high-kick during martial arts practice. He is unable to bear weight on his right leg. The pain is constant and does not radiate. The patient does not have associated back or buttock pain. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness at the posterior thigh with surrounding ecchymosis. Musculoskeletal examination reveals limited knee flexion and hip extension on the right side. Sensation of the lower extremities is intact, and deep tendon reflexes are +2 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset of posterior thigh pain following a high kick which involves forced flexion at the hip with the knee and hip in extension. These findings suggest the patient has most likely suffered a hamstring tear due to an injury of the biceps femoris.  

Hamstring injuries classically occur during high-speed running and following low-speed mechanisms that involve stretching the hip and knee joints at their end ranges of motion. Hamstring strains are classified as either a pull (grade I), partial tear (grade II), or complete tear (grade III). Patients often present with sudden onset, minimal to severe pain over the posterior thigh, sometimes with an associated “popping” sound. Swelling and ecchymosis of the posterior thigh more commonly occur with complete tears. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness, loss of motion, and decreased strength with isometric contraction. An associated avulsion fracture of the ischial tuberosity may also occur with complete hamstring tears.

Option Analysis

❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Prolonged strenuous activity is associated with the development of stress fractures. This condition presents dull, chronic pain of the affected region (e.g. lateral hip pain in femoral head stress fracture). Burning pain and paraesthesia over the lateral thigh suggest cutaneous nerve compression injury.
✅ Biceps femoris tear:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lumbar radiculopathy:
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy can cause posterior thigh pain; however, the pain also typically involves the low back and often radiates below the knee. This patient has evidence of tenderness over the hamstrings better explained by a biceps femoris strain. 
❌ Piriformis muscle spasm:
Incorrect: Piriformis syndrome occurs when the piriformis compresses the sciatic nerve. Symptoms include pain in the buttock area, accompanied by sciatica-like pain, numbness, and weakness that travels down the back of the thigh, calf, and foot.
❌ Hip adductor muscle strains:
Incorrect: Hip adductor strains can occur while sprinting or performing explosive hip movements. This condition typically results in focal pain in the groin or the medial thigh and pain with resisted hip adduction.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to her breast surgeon to discuss the results of a core needle biopsy that was performed in the right upper outer breast after findings suspicious for malignancy were noted on routine mammographic screening. She has no history of breast masses or malignancy, and no abnormal breast discharge or axillary lymphadenopathy. There is no family history of breast or ovarian cancer. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 86 bpm, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. A well-healing incision site is noted over the right breast without signs of infection. No axillary lymphadenopathy is detected. Pathology shows that the breast parenchyma is predominantly glandular with no suspicious cystic or solid masses, but a solid proliferation of small cells with small, uniform, round-to-oval nuclei is identified with estrogen receptor positivity consistent with LCIS. The basement membrane is intact with no signs of invasion. Which of the following should be recommended?

choices.text: Clinical breast exam every 3-6 months and yearly breast imaging
Clinical breast exam and imaging follow up in 5 years

questions.solution:
This patient's pathological findings are consistent with classic lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). LCIS is typically seen in premenopausal women, with the median age at diagnosis between 49 and 50 years. LCIS increases the risk that patient’s will develop breast cancer in either breast in the future. Classic LCIS diagnosed on core needle biopsy can be managed with close follow up and surveillance. Surgical excision is not necessary. Clinical breast exams should be performed every 6-12 months, and breast imaging with mammography and possibly breast MRI should be performed yearly.  

LCIS is usually diagnosed as an incidental finding when biopsies are performed because of other unrelated begin or malignant lesions found on mammography. Histologically, LCIS originates from the proliferation of the epithelial cells present in the lobules and terminal ducts of the breast. Differentiation between the different subtypes of LCIS (i.e., classic, pleomorphic, and florid) is essential for determining the management strategy. Classic LCIS shows solid proliferation of small cells with small, uniform, round-to-oval nuclei and variably distinct cell borders with a strong expression of the estrogen receptors.   

Option Analysis

❌ Prophylactic right breast mastectomy:
Incorrect: Some patients with aggressive types of LCIS and/or high risk features like prior breast cancer or BRCA positivity can be considered for prophylactic bilateral, and not unilateral, mastectomy. This patient does not have high risk features and has classic LCIS which can be followed with breast exams every 3-6 months and imaging with mammography and possibly breast MRI every year.
❌ Surgical excision:
Incorrect: This patient’s core needle biopsy shows findings consistent with classic LCIS, therefore surgical excision is not necessary, and the patient can be followed with breast exams every 3-6 months and imaging with mammography and possibly breast MRI every year.
✅ Clinical breast exam every 3-6 months and yearly breast imaging :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Clinical breast exam and imaging follow up in 5 years:
Incorrect: Patients with classic LCIS should have surveillance with breast exams every 3-6 months and imaging with mammography and possibly breast MRI every year.
❌ Chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Classic LCIS is not considered a malignant lesion. Chemotherapy is not recommended, and patients can be followed closely with regular breast exams and imaging.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the breast surgeon to discuss management of a right breast cyst that was diagnosed as benign. The patient is requesting removal of the lesion because it is causing pain and the continual follow-up is causing emotional stress. Medical history is significant for hypertension which is treated with olmesartan. There is no family history of breast or ovarian cancer. Breast examination reveals a mobile 1 cm mass in the inner upper quadrant of the right breast with no change since the last visit. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Core needle biopsy is performed and a section of the breast shows florid lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Follow-up with clinical and radiologic surveillance

questions.solution:
This patient has florid lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). Florid and pleomorphic LCIS are considered more aggressive than classic LCIS, and they are associated with a higher risk of developing breast cancer in either breast in the future. Nonclassic lesions (florid, pleomorphic) found incidentally on core needle biopsy require surgical excision with clear margins.  

Chemoprevention with tamoxifen should be considered and patients should be counseled on breast cancer risk reduction strategies like regular exercise, maintaining a normal BMI, and limiting alcohol use. Prophylactic bilateral mastectomy may also be considered in high-risk patients.

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical excision:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Unilateral mastectomy:
Incorrect: Prophylactic bilateral mastectomy, and not unilateral, after surgical excision of the lesion is occasionally recommended for florid LCIS.
❌ Tamoxifen:
Incorrect: Chemoprevention with tamoxifen may be indicated in patients with florid LCIS; however, only after surgical excision of the lesion. 
❌ Follow-up with clinical and radiologic surveillance :
Incorrect: Incidentally discovered classic LCIS may be managed with clinical and radiological follow-up and close surveillance. However, in this patient with florid LCIS, surgical excision is recommended.   
❌ No further management required:
Incorrect: Florid LCIS is considered more aggressive than classic LCIS. Surgical excision with clean margins, chemoprevention, and possible prophylactic mastectomy is recommended. Not pursuing further management would be inappropriate.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of an abnormality found in her left breast. Three weeks ago she noticed an area of firmness in the outer portion of the left breast. Her last mammogram was 9 months ago and was normal. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg. Chaperoned exam of the left breast reveals a non-tender firm area in the upper, outer quadrant. The right breast is normal. Lymphadenopathy is present in the left axilla. An irregular mass is noted on mammography, and biopsy shows small, uniform, malignant epithelial cells of lobular origin. Which of the following, if present, would be the greatest risk factor for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a firm area of the breast, lymphadenopathy, an abnormal mammogram, and malignant cells of lobular origin on biopsy has invasive lobular carcinoma.  Early menarche is a significant risk factor for developing breast cancer.  The average age of menarche is 12.4 years and this patient, with menarche at age 10, is at increased risk for developing breast cancer.     

Invasive lobular carcinoma originates from the milk-producing glands of the breast and is the second most common type of breast cancer after invasive ductal carcinoma. Risk factors for invasive lobular carcinoma include age greater than 40, early menarche, late menopause, exogenous hormone use, nulliparity or first pregnancy after age 30, a personal or family history of breast or ovarian cancer or BRCA mutation, and dense breast tissue.  Alcohol use also increases the risk of breast cancer, especially for hormone-sensitive cancers and lobular carcinoma.  

Patients with invasive lobular carcinoma may report a breast lump, firmness, asymmetry or they may have nipple changes or discharge. Occasionally it may be detected during a screening mammogram. However, the sensitivity for detecting invasive lobular carcinoma by physical exam or mammography is relatively low and patients often present with late-stage disease. Because of the diffuse growth pattern of invasive lobular carcinoma, well-circumscribed masses are not as commonly seen. Physical exam should include a thorough, bilateral evaluation of the breast tissue, skin, nipples, and axillary lymph nodes. The exam findings in lobular carcinoma are variable and may be subtle, therefore any visible or palpable skin or tissue changes should prompt further evaluation and a normal exam should not deter further workup when cancer is suspected based on symptoms or imaging. 

Option Analysis

✅ Menarche at age 10:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Menopause at age 51:
Incorrect: Late menopause is a risk factor for breast cancer; however, 51 is considered an average age for menopause. 
❌ First pregnancy at age 18:
Incorrect: Women who are nulliparous or who have their first pregnancy after the age of 30 are at increased risk of developing breast cancer. An early first pregnancy at age 18 would not increase the risk of breast cancer.
❌ Prior history of breastfeeding:
Incorrect:  Breastfeeding is considered protective against breast cancer due to its impact on reducing lifetime exposure to estrogen. 
❌ Fatty breast tissue:
Incorrect: Patients with fatty breast tissue have a lower risk of developing breast cancer than patients with dense breast tissue.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man was referred to the vascular clinic for a four-month history of atraumatic leg pain and an ulcer. The patient has bilateral calf pain when doing tasks around the house. The pain is typically relieved after resting for a few minutes. An ulcer on the top of the left foot appeared 3 weeks ago. There is no associated chest pain, shortness of breath, unintentional weight loss, or fatigue. The patient’s past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, semaglutide, atorvastatin and hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.7 °F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 122/83 mmHg. Physical examination of the lower extremities reveals cool legs with little to no hair, delayed capillary refill in the toes, and diminished pulses bilaterally. There is a 1 cm ulcer with a dry base on top of the left forefoot. There is no edema in either extremity. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension presents with intermittent bilateral lower extremity claudication and a new lower extremity ulcer likely has peripheral arterial disease (PAD) with an ischemic ulcer. Auscultation of the femoral arteries may reveal bruits which signify turbulent blood flow through narrowed (i.e. stenotic) vessels.      
PAD occurs when there is impaired blood flow to the lower extremities. Claudication is a hallmark feature of PAD and refers to pain that is induced by exercise and relieved with rest.    

Risk factors for PAD include smoking, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease. Associated physical examination findings include cool lower extremities with hair loss, absent or reduced distal pulses, abnormal capillary refill, and femoral artery bruits on auscultation.    

Option Analysis

✅ Femoral artery bruit:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stasis dermatitis:
Incorrect: Stasis dermatitis (i.e. venous eczema) is a dry skin condition associated with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI). Patients with CVI usually present with bilateral lower extremity edema, varicose veins and leg cramps. This patient’s symptoms and physical examination are more consistent with arterial insufficiency with an ulcer.   
❌ Ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 1.2:
Incorrect: A normal ABI range is between 0.9 and 1.4. An ABI of 1.2 is within the normal range and would not be expected in this patient who likely has peripheral arterial disease. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) less than 0.9 would be expected.
❌ Elevated cardiac troponins:
Incorrect: Elevated cardiac troponins are seen in cases of acute myocardial infarction (AMI). This patient’s history and presentation are not consistent with an AMI.
❌ Elevated D-dimer:
Incorrect: An elevated D-dimer can be seen with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), cerebrovascular accident (CVA), myocardial infarction (MI), and certain malignancies. This patient has no evidence of unilateral leg swelling, which would be expected with DVT.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of leg pain. The patient is a retired architect and spends most of his time reading. During the past three months, the patient has experienced intermittent calf pain that occurs while he is doing chores around the house. The pain is relieved after sitting for a few minutes. There is no associated dyspnea, orthopnea, or chest pain. The patient has hyperlipidemia and hypertension that are well controlled with ezetimibe and enalapril, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 117/78 mmHg. His pre-exercise ankle-brachial index is 0.95 and post-exercise ABI is 0.65. On physical examination, the lower extremities are cool and hairless and the bilateral distal lower extremity pulses are weak. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with hyperlipidemia and hypertension presents with intermittent claudication (pain relieved with rest), weak peripheral pulses, and a post-exercise ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.65, which is consistent with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). In patients with PAD that is not severe (no rest pain, ulcers, necrosis, or gangrene), initial management should include a supervised graded exercise program along with risk factor modification.  

A supervised graded exercise program has been shown to improve function, reduce symptoms, and potentially delay the progression of PAD.    

Patients should be assessed for risk factors, and risk factor modification and secondary prevention of CAD should be initiated. Smoking cessation has been shown to improve blood flow and reduce the severity of PAD. Patients should be provided support, counseling, and referral to smoking cessation programs or pharmacotherapy (e.g. nicotine replacement therapy).    

Medical management to manage comorbidities, such as antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin or clopidogrel) should be offered. In patients with diabetes mellitus, HbA1c should be maintained below 7%. This patient has well-controlled hyperlipidemia and hypertension and does not need changes to his medications. However, for patients with PAD and inadequately controlled hyperlipidemia or hypertension, management with a high-intensity statin (e.g., atorvastatin) with an LDL-C goal < 70, and maintenance of blood pressure < 140/90 mmHg is recommended.    

If symptoms fail to improve following a 4-6 week trial of conservative management including graded exercise and risk factor modification, then cilostazol should be added to the treatment regimen. If there is still no improvement, then patients should be referred to surgery for assessment with angiography. Patients with PAD and ischemic ulcers should be referred to wound care or surgery, depending on the severity.  



Option Analysis

✅ Supervised graded exercise program:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emergent limb amputation:
Incorrect: Emergent limb amputation should be considered in cases of severe CTLI where there is severe tissue loss, gangrene, or severely compromised blood flow to the affected limb. This patient does not have pain at rest or ulcers on the legs or feet.
❌ Surgical arterial revascularization:
Incorrect: Revascularization is used in the treatment of severe cases of PAD or critical limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) which this patient does not have, as there is no foot pain at rest, ulceration, or tissue necrosis. 
❌ Debridement :
Incorrect: Debridement is typically reserved for severe cases of necrosis. This patient does not have any lower extremity ulcers.
❌ Treatment with cilostazol:
Incorrect: Cilostazol is usually reserved for patients with PAD who fail to improve after 4-6 weeks with other treatments (e.g., exercise program, smoking cessation, antiplatelet therapy).

questions.text:
A 79-year-old man is sent to the emergency department from an assisted facility for persistent fever for five days and new-onset disorientation. He has been in the facility for four months since having an ischemic cerebrovascular stroke. Medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes, vascular dementia, and osteoarthritis. Current medications include insulin, amlodipine/valsartan, and donepezil. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), heart rate is 105 bpm, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. He is oriented only to person. The rest of the neurologic exam is within normal limits. On lung auscultation, there are decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. Cardiac auscultation is significant for a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard over the aortic area. Chest X-ray shows a moderate-sized left convex pleural effusion and point of care ultrasound shows a uniloculated pleural effusion with pleural thickening and an adjacent consolidation. Ultrasound guided thoracentesis is performed and shows frank pus. Pleural fluid analysis is shown below. Which of the following additional findings would be expected on examination given the likely diagnosis?

 Laboratory values  Result 
 Pleural pH  7.1 
 Pleural glucose  15 mg/dl 
 Pleural protein   105 g/L

choices.text: Dullness to percussion at the left lung base
Bronchial breath sounds at the left lower lung
Rales at the left lower lung
Increased tactile fremitus at the left lower lung

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, productive cough, and disorientation and radiological findings of a left lower lobe effusion with an adjacent consolidation. These findings along with pus in the pleural fluid and the findings of pleural fluid analysis are consistent with a left lung empyema. Empyema is defined as a collection of pus in the pleural space that can occur when organisms invade, colonize, and proliferate in the pleural space either from an adjacent pneumonic lesion (i.e. complicated parapneumonic effusion) or from adjacent trauma. On physical examination, dullness to percussion would be expected at the site of the empyema.  

Pneumonia is the most common cause of empyema. Multiple risk factors have been linked to the development of empyema, including age < 18 years and > 65 years, aspiration, poor dental hygiene, malnutrition, alcohol use, intravenous drug use, immunosuppression, and underlying pneumonia.    

In addition to classic symptoms of pneumonia (e.g. fever, cough, pleuritic chest pain), patients with empyema typically report a longer course of fever and malaise that may be up to weeks. Physical examination may show dullness to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and decreased tactile fremitus. Diagnosis of empyema is typically made with a combination of clinical, laboratory, and imaging findings. Treatment includes IV antibiotics and drainage and may include local tissue plasminogen activator and video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS).   

Option Analysis

✅ Dullness to percussion at the left lung base:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bronchial breath sounds at the left lower lung:
Incorrect: Bronchial breath sounds are typically heard over cavitary lung lesions and patent bronchi (i.e. large airways). They are louder and longer than typical breath sounds This patient has a pleural fluid collection, and decreased breath sounds would be expected. 
❌ Rales at the left lower lung:
Incorrect: Rales are typically heard in patients with pulmonary congestion. With a pleural effusion, normal basal breath sounds would be decreased or absent, and rales would not be expected. 
❌ Left tracheal shift:
Incorrect: Clinically detected tracheal shift is seen with major lung pathologies. Massive pleural effusion may lead to contralateral tracheal shifting. This patient has a moderate sized left pleural effusion with adjacent consolidation, and tracheal shift would not be expected. 
❌ Increased tactile fremitus at the left lower lung:
Incorrect:. The presence of a pleural effusion decreases the transmission of lower frequency sound vibrations, and tactile fremitus would be decreased with a pleural effusion.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department (ED) with a gunshot wound to the head. Emergency responders report that there was significant blood loss at the scene, she was unresponsive upon their arrival, and she was intubated en route to the ED for airway protection. In the ED, her temperature is 35.7 ºC (96.2 ºF), pulse is 145/min, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on a ventilator. Primary survey demonstrates secured airway (intubated), bilateral breath sounds, faintly palpable distal pulses, and 2 large-bore IVs in place, GCS f 7 (no eye-opening, no verbal response, motor score 5) and no additional penetrating injuries are present. She is covered with warm blankets, fluid resuscitation is initiated, and the secondary survey is performed, demonstrating two gunshot wounds to the head with active oozing that is controlled with pressure; equal, round, and reactive pupils; and reduced strength in the bilateral upper extremities. A computed tomography (CT) head and basic labs are obtained, as demonstrated below. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   137 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   108 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.78 mg/dL 
 BUN  18 mg/dL 
 Complete blood count 
 Leukocyte Count  18 g/dL 
 Hemoglobin  5.1 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  15.3 % 
 Platelet Count  225,000/mm3 


https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1878875020306100

choices.text: Transfer to OR for emergent neurosurgical exploration

questions.solution:
The initial workup and management of both blunt and penetrating head trauma consists of primary and secondary surveys. In this patient, the primary survey demonstrates altered mental status (GCS 7) with an appropriately secured airway (intubated), but also reveals hypotension, tachycardia, and faintly palpable distal pulses, which is concerning for hypovolemic/hemorrhagic shock. Significant blood loss can occur in patients with penetrating head injuries, as in this patient who reportedly had significant blood loss at the scene of the injury. This is in contrast to blunt head injuries with intracranial bleeding, in which case bleeding is contained within a fixed space, and is therefore likely to result in intracranial pressure (ICP) elevation and its sequelae before there is sufficient blood loss to cause hemorrhagic shock.  

In cases of penetrating traumatic brain injury (TBI), history may reveal a gunshot or foreign body, like shrapnel, penetrating trauma with loss of consciousness, amnesia, post-traumatic seizures, headaches, nausea, or vomiting. Upon examination, an open wound is present, often with exposed skull or brain matter. Neurologic exam typically demonstrates altered mental status with GCS below 15 and may show dilated, unequal, non-responsive, or slowly reactive pupils. There may also be focal neurologic deficits like sensory or motor deficits. CT can help identify the foreign object and determine the extent of the injury including associated skull fractures, hematoma or intracranial bleeding, parenchymal edema, or herniation due to increased ICP.  

If ICP is increased, either due to parenchymal swelling, intracranial hemorrhage, or a combination of the two, you may see dilated, unequal, non-reactive, or slowly reactive pupils. You may also see a combination of hypertension and bradycardia, known as the Cushing reflex. If a patient is demonstrating signs of acutely elevated ICP, then ICP-lowering treatments such as hyperosmolar therapy and/or hyperventilation should be prioritized, as should neurosurgical intervention. However, in a patient without signs of ICP elevation, these therapies are not indicated and may cause harm.

Option Analysis

✅ Transfuse packed red blood cells (pRBCs):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Initiate hyperosmolar therapy :
Incorrect: While hyperosmolar therapy (i.e. mannitol, hypertonic saline) is used to lower intracranial pressure (ICP), this patient is not showing signs of acutely elevated ICP and is in hemorrhagic shock. Therefore, transfusion should be prioritized. 
❌ Initiate hyperventilation :
Incorrect: While hyperventilation is used to lower intracranial pressure (ICP), this patient is not showing signs of acutely elevated ICP and is in hemorrhagic shock. Therefore, transfusion should be prioritized. 
❌ Transfer to OR for emergent neurosurgical exploration:
Incorrect: While neurosurgery should be consulted, this patient is currently in hemorrhagic shock; therefore, transfusion should be initiated prior to any operative management. 
❌ Place central line :
Incorrect: While this patient may eventually require central venous access for prolonged vasopressor and/or hyperosmolar therapy, they currently have two large-bore IVs in place which is sufficient for transfusion.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a three-month history of voice hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. She has no significant past medical history and takes a daily oral contraceptive pill. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 118/73 mmHg. BMI is 38.6 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination reveals a palpable, solitary, immobile anterior neck mass. TSH is within normal limits. Ultrasound of the neck reveals a solid lesion measuring 1.39 cm in diameter with irregular margins. Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration reveals malignant cells and histology shows multiple finger-like projections or papillae with fibrovascular cores lined with differentiated epithelial cells with clear nuclei with intracytoplasmic inclusions that appear as holes. Which of the following types of thyroid cancer does this patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history and clinical presentation of hoarseness, dysphagia, a new neck mass, and a normal TSH is suggestive of thyroid carcinoma. Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration (FNA) shows malignant cells and histology demonstrating papillae lined with differentiated epithelial cells with pale nuclei with the appearance of “holes” secondary to intracytoplasmic inclusions (Orphan Annie-Eye Nuclei), which is pathognomonic for papillary carcinoma. Calcified psammoma bodies, which represent scarred remnants of tumor papillae that have likely infarcted, may also be seen in papillary carcinoma.

Evaluation of a palpable neck mass that is suspicious for thyroid malignancy includes TSH and  ultrasound. Malignant thyroid lesions seen on ultrasound typically are larger than 1 cm in diameter with microcalcifications, hypervascularity, and irregular margins. Cystic lesions that are < 1cm in diameter are not consistent with thyroid cancer.  

Following the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, cancer staging using the TNM staging system (Tumor size, Node involvement, Metastasis) and a CT scan should be performed to determine the appropriate treatment. The vast majority of thyroid cancers are differentiated tumors; this includes papillary, follicular, and oncocytic (Hurtle cell) carcinomas. Patients with these types of tumors typically have a good prognosis.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Papillary carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Follicular carcinoma:
Incorrect: The histopathology in follicular carcinoma is characterized by epithelial cells in a follicular pattern. The histological findings seen in this case are consistent with papillary carcinoma.  
❌ Oncocytic carcinoma:
Incorrect: The histopathology in oncocytic carcinoma is characterized by pink oncocytic epithelial cells with large amounts of granular acidophilic cytoplasm arranged in a follicular or solid pattern. The histological findings seen in this case are consistent with papillary carcinoma.  
❌ Medullary carcinoma:
Incorrect: The histopathology in medullary carcinoma is characterized by sheets of round, oval or spindle-shaped neoplastic cells that originate from parafollicular C-cells. The histological findings seen in this case are consistent with papillary carcinoma.  
❌ Anaplastic carcinoma:
Incorrect: The histopathology in anaplastic carcinoma is characterized by ovoid or spindle-shaped epithelial cells with giant, irregular nuclei, increased mitotic activity, and extensive lymphovascular invasion. The histological findings seen in this case are consistent with papillary carcinoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. A non-contrast computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis is obtained and does not demonstrate any acute injuries, but does show a 2 cm mass in the body of the pancreas. Serum laboratory studies including a complete blood count and complete metabolic panel, demonstrate no abnormalities. The patient is discharged from the emergency department with follow-up with her primary care physician in one week. At that time she has no abdominal pain and a normal abdominal exam. Which of the following studies should be performed to further evaluate the pancreatic mass?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen/pelvis with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient has an asymptomatic pancreatic mass that was incidentally identified on cross-sectional imaging and therefore requires further workup. The next steps include obtaining specific imaging and laboratory tests. Computed tomography (CT) imaging with pancreatic protocol (triphasic CT) is the most appropriate imaging modality. Tumor markers associated with pancreatic cancer should also be checked, including CA 19-9 and CEA.

Pancreatic masses are either cystic or solid lesions, and they can be benign or malignant. Often these masses are found incidentally during abdominal imaging performed for unrelated reasons. Cystic pancreatic lesions are the most common type of pancreatic mass, and they fall into three categories: non-neoplastic pancreatic cysts, pancreatic cystic neoplasms, and inflammatory fluid collection.

Solid masses are less common and include tumors of the exocrine pancreas, such as adenocarcinoma and benign adenomas, as well as pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. In general, solid pancreatic lesions are more concerning because of the elevated risk of malignancy. Given this, timely diagnosis and intervention are important.  

Option Analysis

✅ CEA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CA-125:
Incorrect: CA-125 is a tumor marker for ovarian cancer and is not used in the diagnostic workup for pancreatic masses. CA 19-9 is a tumor marker for pancreatic cancer and should be checked in a patient with a pancreatic mass.  
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen/pelvis with IV contrast:
Incorrect: This patient with a known pancreatic mass needs a CT pancreatic protocol, which is a triphasic scan that is specifically timed to optimally examine the pancreas. A regular generic contrast-enhanced CT would not be as good for this indication as a specific pancreatic protocol CT.  
❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP):
Incorrect: This patient with a known pancreatic mass needs computed tomography (CT) imaging with pancreatic protocol, which is a triphasic scan that is specifically timed to optimally examine the pancreas. An MRCP would be appropriate for a patient with a pancreatic head mass and signs of biliary obstruction (e.g. elevated bilirubin).  
❌ Endoscopic ultrasound:
Incorrect: While endoscopic ultrasound can be used to image and biopsy pancreatic lesions, it is not the initial imaging test performed in the evaluation of a pancreatic mass.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the primary care office for his yearly visit. He has been fasting since yesterday evening for bloodwork that was done that morning. While in the waiting room, the patient becomes diaphoretic, lightheaded, and then confused. A fingerstick glucose is checked and is 46 mg/dL. He is given a carton of juice and thirty minutes later, fingerstick glucose is 110 mg/dL. The patient has experienced several similar episodes over the last few weeks, all of which have improved with food intake. A review of systems is positive for heartburn, diarrhea, constipation, and anxiety. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical exam, the abdomen is nontender and nondistended, with a reducible umbilical hernia present. Computer tomography imaging with pancreatic protocol is shown below and demonstrates a well-defined 2 cm mass in the tail of the pancreas that enhances during the arterial phase.
