Which of the following historical or physical exam-related elements is associated with the likely underlying diagnosis?
 
Image courtesy of STATdx
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent episodes of diaphoresis, lightheadedness, and confusion that improves with food intake. During one of these episodes he has a documented glucose <55 mg/dL, and he has resolution of symptoms with food intake. He also has imaging showing a mass in the tail of the pancreas. The most likely underlying diagnosis is insulinoma. The most common symptom in patients with insulinomas is fasting hypoglycemia with symptoms.

Patients with symptoms of hypoglycemia, low blood plasma glucose concentration, and relief of symptoms when plasma glucose concentration are considered to have Whipples Triad which indicates a possible insulinoma. Patients with Whipples Triad should have further workup with computed tomography (CT) imaging with pancreatic protocol to evaluate for pancreatic lesions consistent with insulinoma.

Insulinoma, while uncommon overall, is the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET). Insulinomas are typically benign and can be located in the body or tail of the pancreas. On CT, typical findings include a well-defined small tumor which is usually hypervascular and more prominent in the arterial phase.
 
 
Figure 1. A pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor which appears as a bright hypervascular mass in the pancreas  Image courtesy of STATdx 
The second most common type of PNET is gastrinoma, which can cause Zollinger-Ellison syndrome; this is characterized by abdominal pain, gastroduodenal ulcers, and diarrhea. Other rare PNETs include VIPoma, which can cause watery diarrhea, hypoglycemia, and achlorhydria; glucagonoma, which can cause new-onset diabetes mellitus; and somatostatinoma, which can cause gallstones and other issues.

In contrast to PNETs, which cause specific symptoms due to the neuroendocrine substances they secrete, other types of pancreatic lesions may be asymptomatic, or cause symptoms related to pancreatic dysfunction (i.e. diarrhea, new-onset diabetes) or their location and size (i.e. jaundice, abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, early satiety, weight loss).  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypoglycemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Weight loss:
Incorrect: While weight loss is commonly seen in patients with certain pancreatic tumors like glucagonoma and pancreatic adenocarcinoma. This patient likely has an insulinoma which typically causes weight gain and not weight loss.  
❌ Heartburn:
Incorrect: Heartburn is a common symptom in the general population and is not specifically associated with any pancreatic lesions.  
❌ Diarrhea:
Incorrect: The pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors: VIPoma, glucagonoma, and somatostatinoma can be associated with diarrhea. However, diarrhea is not common in patients with insulinoma, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.  
❌ Umbilical hernia:
Incorrect: Reducible umbilical hernias are common and are typically not associated with any underlying intra-abdominal parenchymal pathology.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with one week of abdominal pain and nausea. She has a history of hyperlipidemia for which she takes pravastatin. Past medical history is also significant for alcohol use disorder. She was admitted to another hospital approximately two months ago for abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and she was treated with intravenous fluids and pain medication for several days. Temperature is 36.2 °C (97.2 ºF), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 123/90 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 100%. Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the abdomen and pelvis is performed and demonstrates an encapsulated, fluid-filled collection adjacent to the pancreas. Endoscopic ultrasound and fine needle aspiration of the lesion is planned. Which of the following findings would be expected from the fluid analysis?

choices.text: High viscosity, low CEA, high amylase
High viscosity, high CEA, high amylase
High viscosity, high CEA, low amylase
Low viscosity, high CEA, low amylase
Low viscosity, low CEA, low amylase

questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol use disorder was recently hospitalized for abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting and treated with intravenous fluids and pain medication. The most likely cause of her symptoms is pancreatitis. She now presents with similar symptoms and CT imaging shows a pancreatic pseudocyst, which is an inflammatory fluid collection. When fluid from a pancreatic pseudocyst is sampled, it typically shows high viscosity, low CEA, and high amylase.

Pancreatic pseudocysts are walled-off fluid collections that tend to form as a complication of repeated episodes of pancreatic inflammation. History may include recurrent episodes of pancreatitis, alcohol use disorder, or gallstone disease. Symptoms can be similar to pancreatitis and include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and steatorrhea. Patients may also describe more abdominal fullness and early satiety. On physical exam, patients will have abdominal tenderness and distention. Jaundice may be present in severe cases. Laboratory studies may be normal or may show elevated transaminases and bilirubin. On imaging, the pseudocyst will appear as a unilocular simple cyst with no communication with the pancreatic duct. Pseudocysts take approximately 4 weeks to form and can persist for months.
 
 
Figure 1. Pancreatic pseudocyst. A single, well-defined, non-enhancing, unilocular cyst with no solid elements, no septa, and no communication with the pancreatic duct   Image courtesy of STATdx  

Option Analysis

✅ High viscosity, low CEA, high amylase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ High viscosity, high CEA, high amylase:
Incorrect: These findings would be seen in a patient with intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). This patient who has had a recent episode of pancreatitis and is found to have an encapsulated, fluid-filled collection adjacent to the pancreas found on imaging most likely has a pancreatic pseudocyst.  
❌ High viscosity, high CEA, low amylase:
Incorrect: These findings would be seen in a patient with mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN). This patient with a recent episode of pancreatitis and an encapsulated, fluid-filled collection adjacent to the pancreas found on imaging most likely has a pancreatic pseudocyst.  
❌ Low viscosity, high CEA, low amylase:
Incorrect: These findings are not characteristic of any particular pancreatic cystic lesion. This patient with a recent episode of pancreatitis and an encapsulated, fluid-filled collection adjacent to the pancreas found on imaging most likely has a pancreatic pseudocyst.  
❌ Low viscosity, low CEA, low amylase:
Incorrect: These findings would be seen in a patient with a serous cystadenoma or solid pseudopapillary neoplasm (SPN). This patient with a recent episode of pancreatitis and an encapsulated, fluid-filled collection adjacent to the pancreas found on imaging most likely has a pancreatic pseudocyst.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being stabbed in the chest with a knife. On initial airway assessment, the patient is unresponsive to voice and he is promptly intubated in the trauma bay. Bilateral lung sounds are present and circulation is intact.  Temperature is 35 °C (95 °F), heart rate is 128/min, blood pressure is 72/30 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Labs are drawn and pending. GCS is 3. On physical exam, there is a laceration from a knife wound located in the third intercostal space on the right in the midclavicular line. There are decreased lung sounds with auscultation and dullness to percussion on the right. An extended FAST shows fluid within the right pleural space. A chest tube thoracostomy is performed on the right with an immediate return of 1700 mL of sanguinous fluid. While the trauma team continues exposing the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is unstable with penetrating chest trauma. Primary survey reveals hypotension, decreased breath sounds, and dullness to percussion on the right, and an extended FAST exam reveals blood in the right pleural space. With chest tube thoracostomy, > 1500 mL of blood is evacuated, suggesting a massive hemothorax. The next best step is to perform a right anterolateral thoracotomy in the operating room for repair of a suspected great vessel injury.      

In general, any trauma that occurs within the “cardiac box” indicates the potential for a serious cardiac injury. This space is bordered by the clavicles and sternal notch superiorly, costal margin inferiorly, and the nipple lines laterally. This patient was stabbed over the right third intercostal space in the midclavicular line, which is consistent with an injury within the cardiac box.    

The location of injury, along with the presence of hypotension, decreased breath sounds, and dullness to percussion, indicates a possible hemothorax. Immediate output of >1500 mL of blood or more than 200 mL per hour for the first 2-4 hours with tube thoracostomy indicates a massive hemothorax that requires operative repair via thoracotomy. In addition to transporting this patient to the operating room, a massive transfusion protocol should be initiated. This involves administering red blood cells, plasma, and platelets in a 1:1:1 ratio. 

Option Analysis

❌ Additional tube thoracostomy :
Incorrect: In cases when there is immediate return of blood from chest tube thoracostomy that is > 1500 mL, a massive hemothorax can be diagnosed and operative intervention with thoracotomy is required. 
❌ Embolization of the intercostal artery :
Incorrect: This patient requires immediate operative repair of a large vessel via thoracotomy. While bleeding from an intercostal artery can cause significant blood loss, it usually requires an extended period before causing clinically significant hemodynamic instability. A bleed from a large vessel is more likely in this case. 
✅ Anterolateral thoracotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Continuation to the secondary survey:
Incorrect: In a stable patient, the secondary survey should be performed next after the primary survey. However, this patient is unstable and requires immediate operative repair via thoracotomy.  
❌ Initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR):
Incorrect: CPR should be initiated when a patient loses pulse. In this case, a pulse is present. The patient has a massive hemothorax requiring operative repair.

questions.text: An 83-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a rectal mass. She states that she feels a mass protruding from her rectum when she strains to use the bathroom. She has not had rectal pain, drainage, fevers, or chills, but she has been experiencing incomplete defecation and noticing streaks of blood on the toilet paper. She has four children, all born via spontaneous vaginal deliveries. She takes a stool softener for constipation. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 84/min, blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. Physical exam is notable for circumferential rings of soft rectal mucosa protruding from the rectum with Valsalva. Digital rectal exam is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a clinical presentation, risk factors, and physical exam consistent with rectal prolapse. Risk factors for rectal prolapse include multiparity, prior vaginal deliveries, chronic straining, chronic diarrhea, and pelvic floor dysfunction. Patients like this one with full thickness rectal prolapse can present with incomplete bowel evacuation, mucus and/or stool discharge associated with altered bowel habits, and a "mass" that prolapses through the anus that may reduce spontaneously or require manual reduction.  

Physical examination can help distinguish rectal prolapse from other conditions that can cause a rectal mass or bleeding, including prolapsing internal hemorrhoids, solitary rectal ulcers, anal warts, and anal cancer. Inspection of the anus during valsalva will reveal circumferential rings of mucosa (stacked coins) and a full-thickness protrusion in patients with full-thickness rectal prolapse.  

For patients suspected of having rectal prolapse, but the prolapse cannot be reproduced on physical examination with Valsava, or when symptoms are present that suggest additional pelvic floor disorders, functional imaging can be helpful. Defecography, either via traditional  fluoroscopy or dynamic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), can reveal defects associated with rectal prolapse in up to 80 percent of patients with obstructive defecation symptoms. 

Option Analysis

❌ Prolapsed internal hemorrhoids:
Incorrect: Internal hemorrhoids are swollen and/or inflamed veins in the walls of the anal canal. Prolapsed internal hemorrhoids result in linear folds. This patient has circumferential rings of mucosa (“stacked coins”) and a full-thickness protrusion on exam, which is consistent with rectal prolapse.
❌ Peri-anal abscess:
Incorrect: Peri-anal abscesses are mainly caused by blocked anal mucus glands. They usually present with peri-anal pain, and physical exam is notable for fluctuance and erythema at the site of the abscess. This patient does not have clinical symptoms or physical exam findings consistent with a peri-anal abscess.
✅ Rectal prolapse:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anal warts:
Incorrect: The majority of anal warts are asymptomatic, but some can cause itching and bleeding. On physical examination, they appear as soft lumps that are yellow or pink in color, not as circumferential rings or “stacked coins” as seen in this patient who has rectal prolapse.
❌ Anal cancer:
Incorrect: Rectal bleeding is the most common initial symptom of anal cancer. While anal cancer can also present as a protruding mass, it is typically not in the form of circumferential rings, which is more consistent with rectal prolapse.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the dermatology office for evaluation of a new skin lesion on the right calf. Twelve years ago, the patient had a cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) removed from the same area with curettage and electrodesiccation. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. On physical exam, there is a well-defined 0.8 cm diameter lesion on the right calf. A punch biopsy is performed and shows a well-differentiated cSCC that is 1 mm in thickness without invasion beyond the subcutaneous fat. The patient is otherwise healthy aside from bilateral hip osteoarthritis for which he occasionally takes naproxen. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient’s lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a recurrent cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) of the right calf. The lesion has features that are low risk for recurrence. His initial lesion 12 years ago was treated with curettage and electrodessication. However, since this is a recurrent lesion, curettage, and electrodessication are contraindicated. Instead, he should undergo surgical excision.         

For low-risk primary cSCC, the National Comprehensive Cancer Network guidelines recommend a standard excision with 4 to 6 mm clinical margins of uninvolved skin to a depth of the mid- or deep subcutaneous adipose tissue. For incompletely excised cSCC, further excision with circumferential histologic margin control or Mohs micrographic surgery is recommended.        

Recurrent and high-risk lesions should be treated with surgical excision. Mohs surgery, which is a specialized tissue-sparing procedure that involves histologic assessment of 100 percent of the excised tumor margins, has also been used for the treatment of tumors without high-risk features.   

Option Analysis

❌ Curettage and electrodessication  :
Incorrect: This can be used for small, superficial, well-defined cSCCs that are located in noncritical, low-risk sites. Recurrent lesions, such as in this patient, are a contraindication to this treatment.  
❌ Radiation therapy :
Incorrect: Radiation therapy is indicated in patients with low-risk cSCC who cannot undergo surgery. This patient does not have a contraindication for surgery so this would not be the preferred treatment.  
✅ Surgical excision  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Photodynamic therapy :
Incorrect: Photodynamic therapy is based upon the ability of porphyrins to produce cytotoxicity in the presence of oxygen after stimulation by light of an appropriate wavelength. It is currently not approved for invasive cSCC but is approved for squamous cell carcinoma in situ.  
❌ Cryosurgery  :
Incorrect: Cryosurgery destroys malignant cells by freezing and thawing. Since cryosurgery does not permit histologic confirmation of the adequacy of treatment margins, it may be used for small, well-defined, low-risk invasive cSCC. Recurrent lesions are a contraindication for cryosurgery.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought by his parent to the emergency department for evaluation of severe, crampy abdominal pain. The parent states that the patient woke up in the morning with severe abdominal pain and had a single episode of vomiting. He quickly became inconsolable, drawing his knees up towards his abdomen. Within 30 minutes, his pain resolved. However, later in the day, his symptoms recurred, and he passed stool with blood and mucus. He attends daycare and recently had an upper respiratory infection. He has no significant past medical history and is up to date on vaccinations. He appears to be in severe pain and is crying. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 98/55 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 22/min. Physical examination reveals focal tenderness to palpation in the right mid abdomen without distension, rebound, or guarding. Laboratory studies show an elevated white blood count of 15.5 x 109/L. An abdominal ultrasound shows a target sign in the right lower quadrant. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous fluids and observation for two hours
Surgery consultation and attempted reduction with hydrostatic enema

questions.solution:
This patient’s history, clinical presentation, and ultrasound findings are consistent with intussusception. Because this patient is stable, the next best step in management is to consult surgery and attempt reduction with a hydrostatic enema.        

Intussusception is a type of intestinal obstruction that occurs when one segment of the intestine telescopes inside another segment of the intestine. It most commonly occurs at the ileocecal junction. Intussusception typically presents in infants and toddlers aged 4 to 36 months, and patients may have a history of preceding viral illness (e.g. upper respiratory infection).        

Patients can present with crampy, intermittent, severe abdominal pain. They may have nausea, vomiting, and bloody stool with or without mucus. Oftentimes, patients will draw their knees up toward their abdomen to relieve the pain. Physical examination can reveal hypotension and tachycardia. Abdominal examination may show no tenderness or point tenderness in the mid or lower right abdomen. A “sausage-shaped” mass may be palpated in the mid-right abdomen or right lower quadrant. In cases of perforation or peritonitis, abdominal distention, rebound tenderness, and guarding may be seen. The classic finding of a “target sign” may be seen on ultrasound.       

Management depends on the stability of the patient. In stable patients without evidence of bowel perforation, peritonitis, or shock, nonoperative bowel reduction using an enema (pneumatic or hydrostatic) is the treatment of choice. Enema reduction has high success rates in children with ileocolic intussusception. In settings in which nonoperative reduction is not available (e.g., resource-limited countries) or when the attempt fails to achieve reduction, patients should be managed with surgical reduction.        

Before attempting reduction by enema, the patient should be stabilized and given intravenous fluids if there is evidence of volume depletion. The surgical team should be notified before attempting nonoperative reduction and should remain immediately available due to the risk of perforation and tension pneumoperitoneum during the procedure. Surgical intervention may also be necessary if nonoperative reduction cannot be achieved with an enema.   

Option Analysis

❌ Surgery consultation for evaluation :
Incorrect: This 2-year-old patient has signs, symptoms, and findings consistent with a diagnosis of intussusception. He is currently stable; therefore, a hydrostatic enema should be given to attempt reduction, in addition to consulting surgery. 
❌ Intravenous fluids and observation for two hours   :
Incorrect: This 2-year-old patient has signs, symptoms, and findings consistent with a diagnosis of intussusception. Intravenous fluids and observation would delay care and increase the potential for severe complications (e.g. perforation). An attempt at reduction with an enema should be made. 
✅ Surgery consultation and attempted reduction with hydrostatic enema  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Attempted reduction with hydrostatic enema  :
Incorrect: In stable patients with intussusception, a hydrostatic enema should be used to try to achieve reduction. However, surgery should also be consulted when attempting bowel reduction, given the increased risk of perforation and tension pneumoperitoneum with the procedure.  
❌ Diagnostic laparoscopy :
Incorrect: Diagnostic laparoscopy would be the preferred next step in treating a patient with intussusception who is unstable (peritonitis or intestinal perforation), or if non-operative management is unsuccessful. This 2-year-old patient is stable, and therefore nonoperative management should be attempted first.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with persistent nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain, and bloody stools that have the consistency of “jelly”.  Symptoms began about three hours before arrival. His mother says she gave him ibuprofen, but it did not relieve his pain. He has not had any sick contacts. The patient’s temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), heart rate is 90/min, blood pressure is 96/56 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 20/min. The child has his knees drawn upward to his abdomen. On abdominal examination, he has right lower quadrant tenderness without distension rebound, or guarding. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test to evaluate for the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: History and physical are sufficient to make a diagnosis
Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient with nausea, vomiting, intermittent abdominal pain, bloody “jelly” like stools, and right lower quadrant abdominal tenderness most likely has intussusception. The patient is hemodynamically stable and therefore abdominal ultrasound should be performed next to look for the most likely diagnosis and rule out other potential diagnoses like appendicitis.        

Abdominal ultrasound performed by an experienced sonographer has a very high sensitivity and specificity for intussusception. It can be used to diagnose intussusception and rule out other diagnoses in the differential like appendicitis and hydronephrosis. The classic finding of intussusception on ultrasound is a "target sign", representing layers of the intestine within the intestine. Color duplex imaging may reveal a lack of perfusion in the intussusceptum, indicating the development of ischemia. Ultrasound can be used to determine the lead points and monitor the success of reduction procedures.  

 


 Image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons       

Option Analysis

❌ History and physical are sufficient to make a diagnosis :
Incorrect: This child’s presentation is most consistent with intussusception; however, the diagnosis should be confirmed with imaging via ultrasound. It is not a clinical diagnosis.  
❌ Plain film abdominal x-ray :
Incorrect: This child’s presentation is most consistent with intussusception. An initial evaluation in a stable patient can include two-view plain abdominal radiographs to quickly exclude perforation, which, if present, requires immediate operative management. However, plain radiographs are not sufficiently sensitive or specific to make a diagnosis of intussusception and abdominal ultrasound is used for diagnosis since it has a high sensitivity and specificity for intussusception. 
✅ Abdominal ultrasound :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis :
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis can be used to diagnose intussusception but is generally reserved for patients in whom other imaging modalities are unrevealing where suspicion remains high, or to characterize pathologic lead points if intussusception is first detected by ultrasound. Ultrasound has a very high sensitivity and specificity for intussusception and limits the amount of radiation to the child. 
❌ Diagnostic laparoscopy  :
Incorrect: Diagnostic laparoscopy is reserved for patients with presumed intussusception who are unstable, with evidence of perforation or intestinal ischemia. However, diagnostic laparoscopy is not the modality of choice for diagnosing uncomplicated intussusception in stable patients.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with moderate pain in the right leg. About three hours ago, he developed non-radiating pain in the right calf without any associated trauma. The patient has occasionally experienced pain at night in the right calf that has been relieved by dangling the right leg off the side of the bed. Past medical history is significant for recently diagnosed colon cancer and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. The patient has been preoccupied with his recent diagnosis of colon cancer and has not been taking his insulin regularly. HbA1c was 10.1% two months ago. Temperature is 37.0ºC, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg. A right lower extremity vascular exam is notable for non-palpable distal pulses, absent arterial doppler signals, and present venous doppler signals. The right lower extremity strength is intact but sensation is absent in the toes. A CT angiogram is ordered and pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate classification for this patient’s limb?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with acute, moderate right leg pain in the setting of chronic leg pain and poorly controlled diabetes. The new malignancy combined with likely underlying peripheral arterial disease likely created a hypercoagulable environment for a thrombosis to develop in the right leg. The physical exam is notable for absent arterial doppler signals but present venous signals, intact motor function, but absent sensation in the toes. Given the exam findings and the moderate nature of the pain, this patient likely has Rutherford Class IIa acute limb ischemia.        

Rutherford Class IIa describes a marginally threatened limb. These patients typically report moderate to severe pain and on exam have mild sensory loss without muscle weakness. Doppler arterial signals may or may not be audible, and venous signals will be audible. Treatment involves initiating an IV heparin infusion and ordering a CT angiogram (CTA) to confirm the diagnosis and assess vascular anatomy for surgical planning.        

CTA for Rutherford Class IIa would show acute arterial occlusion to the major vasculature of the affected limb, often with evidence of chronic vascular disease. The surgical team should be consulted urgently to evaluate for revascularization, usually within 6 to 24 hours.    

Option Analysis

❌ Rutherford Class I  :
Incorrect: This class is for viable limbs under no immediate threat of tissue loss. It is the mildest form of limb ischemia. With viable limbs, there would be no sensory loss or muscle weakness, and both arterial and venous Doppler signals would be audible. 
✅ Rutherford Class IIa :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rutherford Class IIb :
Incorrect: Rutherford Class IIb denotes immediately threatened limbs that are salvageable with immediate revascularization. Sensory loss would involve more than the toes and may be associated with rest pain in the forefoot (not just confined to toes). There would be mild-to-moderate muscle weakness, arterial Doppler signals would typically be inaudible, but there would be audible venous Doppler signals. 
❌ Rutherford Class III :
Incorrect: Rutherford Class III denotes non-viable limbs with severe and permanent nerve deficit. Sensory loss would be profound. Profound muscle weakness with paralysis and possible rigor would be present, and arterial and venous Doppler signals would be inaudible. 
❌ Rutherford Class IV  :
Incorrect: This class does not exist. The Rutherford classification system for acute limb ischemia is from I to III.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a fever and dull right upper quadrant pain for the past week. Two months ago, he returned from a vacation in Mexico. He has no significant past medical or surgical history. He does not take any medication and has not been exposed to any sick contacts. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate is 86/min, blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant and hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies are shown below. An abdominal CT shows a single round mass with an enhancing solid rim and central complex fluid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

 White Blood Cells      12x103/µL    
 Neutrophils     40%    
 Hemoglobin     14.0 g/dL anemia    
 Hematocrit     42%    
 Platelets     350x103/µL normal    
 Aspartate aminotransferase     110/L    
 Alanine aminotransferase     105/L    
 Alkaline Phosphatase      100/L    
 Bilirubin      1.1 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a week of fever and right upper quadrant pain after a trip to Mexico two months ago. He has right upper quadrant tenderness and hepatomegaly on exam and laboratory studies show elevated LFTs with an elevated WBC without a left shift and normal bilirubin. Abdominal CT reveals a single rounded mass with an enhancing solid rim and central complex fluid. These findings are consistent with an amebic liver abscess. 

When evaluating liver lesions, it is important to quickly determine whether the lesion is benign or infectious and requires immediate treatment, or malignant and requires further diagnostic evaluation. A focused history and physical exam followed by labwork, including serologies, and contrast-enhanced imaging can help make the diagnosis of infectious liver pathologies. These can include amebic abscesses, pyogenic abscesses, and echinococcal cysts. Patients with any of these lesions should be admitted to the hospital and treated appropriately. Treatment can involve medical management, aspiration, and surgery, depending on the type of infection.   

Option Analysis

❌ Pyogenic liver abscess:
Incorrect: Pyogenic liver abscesses typically occur in older patients after multiple hepatobiliary infections with bowel leakage and peritonitis. Patients typically have hyperbilirubinemia. This patient’s travel history, lab work, and CT findings are more consistent with amebic liver abscess.  
❌ Echinococcal hepatic cyst :
Incorrect: Echinococcal hepatic cysts occur in patients who have recently traveled to endemic areas, such as Central or South America. Most patients are asymptomatic until the cyst grows large enough to have a mass effect and cause abdominal discomfort and right upper quadrant pain. CT typically shows a large, well-defined, unilocular or multilocular liver cyst with multiple internal “daughter” cysts.  
✅ Amebic liver abscess :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Simple Cyst :
Incorrect: Simple cysts are small and benign, and only produce symptoms (e.g., right upper quadrant pain) if they become enlarged. Laboratory studies are typically normal, and constitutional signs and symptoms (e.g., fever, chills, diarrhea) are absent.  
❌ Focal nodular hyperplasia  :
Incorrect: Focal nodular hyperplasia is a benign liver lesion made up of hyperplastic hepatocytes surrounding a central stellate scar. Most patients are asymptomatic and have normal liver function studies. This patient's elevated LFTs, symptomatology, and CT findings are more consistent with amebic liver abscess.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of severe pain in his right leg. He first noticed redness in his right leg yesterday, which is now swollen with severe, excruciating pain. This morning, he had a fever and chills, which prompted him to seek urgent care at the emergnecy department (ED). Past medical history is significant for morbid obesity (body mass index > 35 kg/m2) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). He has been prescribed insulin for his T2DM, but he has not been taking it consistently during the past several months. His most recent HbA1c was 9.2%. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), heart rate is 126/min, his blood pressure is 92/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination of the right leg reveals erythema, edema, and palpable crepitus extending from the distal thigh to the mid-calf. Laboratory studies are pending. Computed tomography (CT) with IV contrast of the lower extremities shows extensive soft tissue edema of the right lower extremity with air tracking along the fascial plane of the superficial posterior compartment in the right lower leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with hemodynamic instability and signs of skin/soft tissue infection and sepsis (e.g., fever, tachycardia, hypotension) in the setting of uncontrolled diabetes. Given the presence of erythema and crepitus, along with pathognomonic findings of air tracking along a fascial plane on CT, necrotizing fasciitis is the most likely diagnosis. Intravenous fluids and intravenous antibiotics should be given. Definitive management consists of urgent operative debridement of all necrosed tissue and subsequent fluid resuscitation in an intensive care unit (ICU) setting.        

Necrotizing fasciitis is an infection of the deep soft tissues that results in progressive destruction of the muscle fascia and overlying subcutaneous fat. Infection typically spreads along the muscle fascia due to its poor blood supply; muscle tissue is frequently spared because of its generous blood supply. Risk factors include major trauma, immunosuppression (e.g., diabetes, cirrhosis, HIV), and obesity.        

Clinical manifestations of necrotizing infection include severe pain, fever, and findings of erythema, edema, crepitus, and bullae or necrosis. Treatment of necrotizing fasciitis consists of early and aggressive surgical exploration and debridement of necrotic tissue, together with broad-spectrum empiric antibiotic therapy and hemodynamic support. Administration of antibiotic therapy without debridement is associated with a mortality rate approaching 100 percent.   

Option Analysis

❌ Oral antibiotics :
Incorrect: This patient with a skin/soft tissue infection presents with sepsis; therefore, expeditious fluid resuscitation and intravenous antibiotics are necessary, and he should be taken to the operating room for debridement. 
❌ Antifungal medication :
Incorrect: While this patient’s uncontrolled diabetes increases his risk of a fungal infection, given findings of hemodynamic instability, palpable crepitus and the CT showing air tracking along the fascial plane, necrotizing fasciitis can be diagnosed. He should be treated with intravenous fluids and antibiotics and urgent operative debridement for definitive care.  
✅ Operative debridement  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Image-guided drain placement :
Incorrect: In patients with abscesses that cannot easily be superficially accessed, image-guided drain placement may be an option for source control. This patient does not have evidence of an abscess. Clinical and CT findings are consistent with sepsis from necrotizing fasciitis requiring intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and operative debridement.  
❌ Topical antibiotics  :
Incorrect: In patients with superficial cellulitis or impetigo, topical antibiotics are typically effective. However, this patient with life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis needs intravenous fluids and antibiotics, and urgent operative debridement of all necrotic tissue.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department after returning from a recent hiking trip. He was hiking through a densely wooded area of Long Island, NY. He did not have consistent access to clean water. The last several days of his trip, he noticed severe pain and swelling of the chin. He shaved every other day while on his trip. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. Physical examination reveals localized pain, erythema, edema, and tenderness of the chin with a cluster of tender pus-filled bumps. Gram stain of fluid expressed from one of the bumps shows gram positive cocci. Wound culture is pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 29-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after a week of hiking and poor hygiene with a skin infection on his chin. Given that he has been shaving with dirty water and now has focal erythema and tenderness with a cluster of boils that grow out gram-positive cocci (e.g. Staph aureus), folliculitis is the most likely diagnosis.       

Folliculitis is a superficial infection of hair follicles with pustules that develop around the hair follicles. Patients who frequently remove hair through shaving or waxing are at an increased risk, as are patients with diabetes and poor hygiene. Physical examination typically reveals erythema, edema, and tenderness around hair follicles with or without a single or cluster of boils.    

Option Analysis

❌ Herpes Zoster :
Incorrect: Patients with herpes zoster have pain and a vesicular rash in a dermatomal pattern. This patient with focal erythema, tenderness, and pus-filled bumps on the chin after shaving with dirty water is more likely to have folliculitis. 
❌ Hidradenitis suppurativa :
Incorrect: While a wound culture in patients with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) could show Staph Aureus, with gram-negative cocci on gram stain, HS is a chronic condition with painful, inflamed nodules or abscesses that form in the subcutaneous tissues of hairy areas or skin folds. This patient with focal erythema, tenderness, and pus-filled bumps on the chin after shaving with dirty water is more likely to have folliculitis.  
✅ Folliculitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lyme Disease :
Incorrect: The classic rash of lyme disease is an erythematous bull’s eye rash (erythema migrans). This patient with focal erythema, tenderness, and pus-filled bumps after shaving with dirty water is more likely to have folliculitis. 
❌ Candida intertrigo :
Incorrect: Patients with Candida intertrigo present with an erythematous rash with macerated plaques and erosions with peripheral scales in areas of the skin that are closely opposed (e.g., skin folds, axillae).

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He began feeling nauseous at dinner the night before. He initially attributed it to the food he ate, but during the night, he began feeling bloated. In the morning, he had an episode of non-bilious vomiting. Shortly after, he began having severe peri-epigastric pain that progressively worsened, prompting him to go to the ED (Emergency Department). He has a past medical history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and takes a proton pump inhibitor daily. He had a cholecystectomy three years ago. Temperature is 99.5°F (36.5°C), heart rate is 118/min, blood pressure is 165/100 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen, severe bilateral upper quadrant, and epigastric tenderness. Basic metabolic panel shows a creatinine of 1.6 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL). A CT (Computed Tomography) of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and PO contrast shows a strangulated type IV paraesophageal hernia without contrast seen in the jejunum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the ICU (Intensive Care Unit) for observation

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with the acute onset of nausea, vomiting, upper abdominal pain, acute kidney injury (i.e. elevated creatinine), and CT findings consistent with a strangulated type IV paraesophageal hernia. This patient should have urgent decompression of the stomach to prevent ischemia via nasogastric tube decompression and then surgical repair.        

A paraesophageal hernia is a true hernia with a hernia sac composed of peritoneum and is characterized by an upward dislocation of the gastric fundus through a focal defect in the phrenoesophageal membrane. Emergent repair is required for patients with a gastric volvulus, uncontrolled bleeding, obstruction, strangulation, perforation, and respiratory compromise secondary to a paraesophageal/hiatal hernia.        

In the acute setting, patients should have a nasogastric tube placed for decompression, intravenous fluid resuscitation, and optimization for the operating room. Surgical management involves minimally invasive laparoscopic reduction of the hernia with closure of the hiatal defect with or without a fundoplication.    

Option Analysis

❌ Upper endoscopy  :
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy can be used to diagnose a paraesophageal/hiatal hernia; however, it is not appropriate in the setting of a strangulated type IV paraesophageal hernia as seen in this patient. This patient should have nasogastric tube decompression and surgical repair. 
❌ Laparoscopic hernia reduction and repair  :
Incorrect: Laparoscopic hernia reduction and repair can be the definitive treatment for this patient. However, urgent decompression of the stomach should be performed first before proceeding to the operating room.  
✅ Nasogastric tube decompression :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Admit to the ICU (Intensive Care Unit) for observation :
Incorrect: Observation is not an appropriate treatment for a stage IV strangulated paraesophageal/hiatal hernia. Nasogastric decompression should be performed to prevent ischemia to the stomach and other affected organs and the patient should be taken to surgery for repair.  
❌ Gastrostomy tube placement   :
Incorrect: Placement of a gastrostomy tube is most commonly done to feed patients who cannot tolerate oral feeds or for decompression of chronically obstructed patients. It has no role in the management of a strangulated type IV paraesophageal/hiatal hernia as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was sent to the emergency department by his primary care doctor due to concern for malnutrition. Three months ago, the patient was in a motor vehicle crash resulting in a small bowel injury. This required an exploratory laparotomy and 225 cm of small bowel was resected. He recovered in the hospital for 10 days, but he was readmitted within the first month due to complications from short bowel syndrome. He was subsequently discharged and has been doing well, but upon review of his recent labs with his primary care physician, he was found to have multiple abnormal results, including low prealbumin and vitamin D levels. He has lost about 5 lbs in two weeks. Vital signs are unremarkable and additional laboratory studies, including a complete blood count (CBC) and electrolytes are ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Nil per os (NPO) status and enteral feeds via a naso-jejunal feeding tube

questions.solution:
This patient has signs and symptoms of short bowel syndrome in the adaptation phase. Lasting one to two years, this phase is characterized by structural and functional changes to the remaining small bowel and colon that will lead to increased nutrient absorption and slowed gastrointestinal transit. Treatment should always begin with supportive care, which may include both oral and IV nutritional supplementation. Oral food and fluid intake should be optimized first and then supplemented with IV if needed. At times, both oral and enteral feedings may be required. In severe cases, patients might require total parenteral nutrition (TPN), in which nutrition is delivered intravenously.        

Antisecretory and antidiarrheal medications should be considered. They can slow the gastrointestinal transit time to allow more time for absorption and reduce fluid loss. It is important to monitor for complications of short bowel syndrome, such as refeeding syndrome and metabolic bone disease. Refeeding syndrome refers to a rapid shift in electrolytes that can occur when a malnourished patient starts to receive nutrition. Metabolic bone disease can include osteoporosis from decreased bone density or osteomalacia from vitamin D deficiency, both of which usually occur in the setting of long-standing malabsorption.        

Surgical intervention is usually reserved for a select group of patients. In patients with anastomotic strictures, enteroplasty, strictureplasty, or serosal patching may be used. Autologous gastrointestinal reconstruction can be used if there is persistent intestinal failure. Finally, small bowel transplantation is reserved for patients with a lifelong need for parenteral nutrition and irreversible complications of parenteral nutrition.   

Option Analysis

❌ Nil per os (NPO) status and enteral feeds via a naso-jejunal feeding tube  :
Incorrect: In patients with short bowel syndrome, enteral nutrition will always be utilized alongside oral nutrition.  
❌ Nil per os (NPO) status and parenteral nutrition :
Incorrect: Parenteral nutrition is an important adjunct treatment for patients with short bowel syndrome who cannot get enough nutrition enterally. However, it is utilized in conjunction with enteral nutrition whenever possible. 
✅ Oral nutrition optimization, with consideration of intravenous (IV) nutrition, if necessary :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anti-diarrheal medications :
Incorrect: Anti-diarrheal medications can be used to treat patients who are getting adequate nutrition but continue to have uncontrollable diarrhea. However, this patient should have optimization of oral nutrition first.  
❌ Antisecretory medications :
Incorrect: Antisecretory medications, such as proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), are usually given to prevent hypergastrinemia in the first 6 to 12 months after resection. They are part of the armamentarium used to treat short bowel syndrome, but in this case the best next step is oral nutrition optimization.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the cardiology clinic for a follow-up visit for aortic stenosis. Three months ago, the patient had a transthoracic echocardiogram that showed severe aortic stenosis with an ejection fraction of 45%. Subsequent exercise tolerance testing showed the patient had significant worsening of chest pain and shortness of breath with exertion. She has no other past medical history and does not currently take any medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued but is not in distress. Cardiac auscultation reveals an S4 heart sound. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and there is mild bipedal edema. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical or transcatheter aortic valve intervention

questions.solution:
This patient with severe aortic stenosis with documented evidence of exertional symptoms and a reduced ejection fraction. These findings indicate the need for evaluation by cardiology and/or cardiac surgery for a transcatheter aortic valve implantation or surgical aortic valve repair. Given her early age and lack of medical comorbidities, she would be considered a good surgical candidate for a surgical aortic valve replacement.   

Patients with mild aortic stenosis should undergo surveillance transthoracic echocardiogram every 3-5 years, whereas patients with moderate aortic stenosis should undergo imaging every 1-2 years. In patients with severe aortic stenosis, further management depends upon the presence of symptoms. Asymptomatic patients need an assessment of ejection fraction and may require exercise tolerance testing. Both Symptomatic patients and asymptomatic patients with a documented reduced ejection fraction should be referred to cardiology or cardiac surgery for an aortic valve intervention.   

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical or transcatheter aortic valve intervention:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Repeat transthoracic echocardiogram in 6 months:
Incorrect: This approach is appropriate for patients with asymptomatic severe aortic stenosis and preserved ejection fraction who are poor surgical candidates. This patient has a reduced ejection fraction and has no indications of being a poor surgical candidate; therefore, surgical or transcatheter aortic valve intervention should be pursued. 
❌ Repeat transthoracic echocardiogram in 1-2 years:
Incorrect: This is appropriate for monitoring patients with moderate aortic stenosis. However, this patient has severe, symptomatic aortic stenosis with a reduced ejection fraction. 
❌ Repeat transthoracic echocardiogram in 3-5 years:
Incorrect: This approach is appropriate for monitoring patients with mild aortic stenosis. However, this patient has severe, symptomatic aortic stenosis with a reduced ejection fraction. 
❌ Dobutamine stress echocardiogram:
Incorrect: This patient has already undergone a transthoracic echocardiogram and exercise tolerance testing that documented exertional symptoms. A dobutamine stress echocardiogram is unnecessary currently as the patient already has several indications for surgical or transcatheter intervention.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is transported to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound to the abdomen. Paramedics report the patient was shot once in the abdomen and subsequently fell to the ground. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. Temperature is 36°C (96.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 86/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient appears disoriented, confused, and lethargic. He does not respond to voice or painful stimuli. Examination reveals capillary refill of 4-5 seconds, a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) of 6, and normal breath sounds bilaterally. A single gunshot wound is seen in the upper abdomen.  Which of the following should be performed next before proceeding to the remainder of the trauma evaluation?

choices.text: Cervical spine stabilization followed by rapid sequence intubation

questions.solution:
This 22-year-old trauma patient presents with evidence of hemodynamic instability and airway compromise following an abdominal gunshot wound, and he should have his airway secured. Before proceeding with the rest of the trauma survey, it is important that all trauma patients have cervical spine stabilization/immobilization during endotracheal intubation. It should be presumed that all trauma patients have a cervical spine injury until proven otherwise and manipulation of the neck during procedures (e.g. intubation) could worsen the injury from an unstable C-spine.

Traumatic injuries to the abdomen can occur from blunt forces like shearing from rapid deceleration, or penetrating mechanisms like gunshot or stab wounds. The liver, spleen, and intestine are the most commonly injured organs when there is blunt force abdominal trauma. The most common injury when there is a traumatic abdominal penetrating injury is a major abdominal vasculature injury. Although the majority of blunt and penetrating abdominal injuries can be managed non-surgically, it is important to quickly identify life-threatening injuries like intraabdominal hemorrhage, retroperitoneal hemorrhage, intraabdominal visceral organ injury, unstable pelvic fracture, and diaphragmatic injury or rupture, to provide timely operative intervention.

Regardless of the injury, all patients presenting with blunt and penetrating abdominal trauma require the same approach for the primary survey. First, the airway should be assessed, and if it is compromised, it should be secured via endotracheal intubation or surgical cricothyrotomy. Next, the patient’s breathing should be assessed. Absent or diminished breath sounds suggest traumatic pneumothorax that requires chest tube placement. Circulation should be assessed, and 2 large bore IVs (or intraosseous access) should be placed while continuously monitoring vitals. If the patient is hypotensive, administering intravenous fluids or blood products should be given. Finally, the patient should be exposed to assess for additional injuries and the Glasgow coma scale should be determined.

Option Analysis

✅ Cervical spine stabilization followed by rapid sequence intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rapid sequence intubation:
Incorrect: Rapid sequence intubation, without attention to cervical spine stabilization in a trauma patient, could potentially worsen a cervical spine injury, if one is present. This patient should have the cervical spine stabilized followed by intubation.
❌ Bilateral chest tube placement :
Incorrect: This patient has normal breath sounds bilaterally, making traumatic pneumothorax or other pulmonary-related injuries unlikely. This patient should have the cervical spine stabilized while intubation is performed before proceeding with the rest of the trauma assessment.
❌ Supraglottic device placement:
Incorrect: This patient should have cervical spine stabilization followed by endotracheal intubation. Placement of a supraglottic device is not indicated.
❌ Emergent laparotomy:
Incorrect: While this patient has evidence of a penetrating abdominal injury from a gunshot wound and signs of hemodynamic instability and therefore will require emergent laparotomy. He should first have the cervical spine stabilized and his airway secured.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services (EMS) after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. EMS reports the patient was the restrained driver of a vehicle traveling at high speed when he struck the median with airbag deployment. The patient had neck pain at the scene and a rigid cervical collar was placed. On primary survey, the patient can speak in full sentences, although the words are slurred. Breath sounds are intact bilaterally. The patient has 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities with capillary refill < 2 seconds. He is freely moving his upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is 14 with one point subtracted due to confusion. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 120/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The secondary survey does not reveal any obvious injuries or deformities aside from a small hematoma on the forehead. The patient does not exhibit tenderness to palpation over the cervical spine. He appears clinically intoxicated and is requesting discharge and the removal of the cervical collar. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Maintain cervical collar and obtain CT-cervical spine imaging
Remove cervical collar and obtain CT-cervical spine imaging
Maintain cervical collar and obtain X-ray cervical spine imaging
Remove cervical collar and obtain X-ray cervical spine imaging
Remove cervical collar and discharge patient home

questions.solution:
This 27-year-old patient presents after a motor vehicle collision with concern for blunt traumatic cervical spine injury. Given the mechanism of injury and associated neck pain (and intoxication), this patient should have CT-imaging of the cervical spine before clearing the cervical spine and removing the collar. A component of the secondary survey is assessing the need for more imaging via CT-imaging of the cervical spine. Patients who have major trauma or findings that are suspicious for neck injury should have CT-imaging of the cervical spine.         

Blunt traumatic cervical spine (c-spine) injury is an injury to the bone, discs, muscle, ligaments, or spinal cord of the c-spine. It commonly occurs from flexion-extension injuries from motor vehicle collisions and compression injuries from falls or contact sports. The cervical spine is particularly vulnerable to these mechanisms of injury because of its mobility and exposure.       

The secondary survey for patients with blunt traumatic cervical spine injury follows the same sequence as for all trauma patients: a head-to-toe physical examination followed by a history detailing the mechanism of injury, past medical history, surgeries, substance use, and current medications. History may reveal a concerning traumatic mechanism (e.g., axial loading or direct trauma to the neck). Physical examination may reveal neurologic deficits, tenderness, deformity, ecchymoses, or swelling at the cervical spine.    

Option Analysis

✅ Maintain cervical collar and obtain CT-cervical spine imaging :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Remove cervical collar and obtain CT-cervical spine imaging :
Incorrect: This patient requires additional imaging in order to clear the cervical spine given the mechanism of injury and finding of intoxication. The cervical spine cannot be clinically cleared, and thus the collar should not be removed, without obtaining CT-cervical spine imaging 
❌ Maintain cervical collar and obtain X-ray cervical spine imaging :
Incorrect: This patient requires maintenance of a rigid cervical collar and CT imaging to clear the cervical spine. X-ray imaging is not the standard of care for evaluation of blunt cervical spine injury. This patient should have a CT performed.  
❌ Remove cervical collar and obtain X-ray cervical spine imaging:
Incorrect: This patient requires additional imaging via CT given the mechanism of injury and intoxication before the cervical spine can be cleared and the collar removed. 
❌ Remove cervical collar and discharge patient home:
Incorrect: This patient had a high-speed mechanism of trauma and is intoxicated with neck pain at the scene. Therefore, his cervical spine cannot be clinically cleared. He requires additional imaging via CT given the mechanism of injury.

questions.text:
Note: If you or someone you know needs help, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.       

A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services (EMS) after a suicide attempt. He was found by friends after he attempted to hang himself using his belt. The patient had neck pain at the scene and a rigid cervical collar was placed. Past medical history is significant for depression and anxiety. The patient does not take any medications. On primary survey, the patient can speak in full sentences. Breath sounds are intact bilaterally. He has 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities with capillary refill < 2 seconds. He is freely moving his upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Glasgow coma scale (GC) is 15. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 155/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The secondary survey reveals bruising and soft tissue swelling to the anterior neck and tenderness to palpation of the cervical spine. The patient has bilateral, shooting, and burning pain in the upper extremities bilaterally with weakness. Computed tomography (CT) imaging is most likely to reveal which of the following types of fracture patterns?

choices.text: Fracture of C1 rings and vertebral mass

questions.solution:
This 26-year-old patient presents after a suicide attempt by hanging, and there is concern for blunt traumatic cervical spine injury given the mechanism of injury. He is found to have bruising and soft tissue swelling to the anterior neck and tenderness to palpation of the cervical spine, in addition to bilateral, shooting, and burning pain in the upper extremities bilaterally with associated weakness. These findings are most consistent with a Hangman’s fracture, which is a fracture of the C2 pedicles.        

Adjunctive workup for patients with this injury pattern includes CT of the cervical spine as well as a type and screen, complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), lactate, pregnancy test (if applicable), urinalysis, and urine toxicology screen. X-rays of the cervical spine should be obtained only when CT imaging is not available.       

P.S. If you or someone you know needs help, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone. 

Option Analysis

✅ Fracture of C2 pedicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dislocation of atlas (C1 from occiput) :
Incorrect: This fracture pattern describes atlanto-occipital dislocation, and patients typically presents with findings of neurogenic shock or quadriplegia rather than myelopathy as seen in this patient.  
❌ Fracture of C1 rings and vertebral mass:
Incorrect: Fracture of C1 rings and vertebral mass describes a Jefferson burst fracture. Patients with this fracture typically present following an injury involving a heavy axial load.  
❌ Odontoid process fracture:
Incorrect: Odontoid process fractures typically occur in elderly patients following minor trauma or high-energy trauma in younger patients. This patient's mechanism of injury of hanging is more consistent with fracture of C2 pedicles (i.e. a “Hangman’s fracture”) 
❌ C4 fracture:
Incorrect: Patients with C4 fractures are more likely to present with a focal neurologic deficit rather than radiculopathy or myelopathy (e.g. weakness) as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath and worsening lower extremity edema. She has a 3-year history of severe mitral stenosis. A transthoracic echocardiogram two months ago showed worsening mitral stenosis, as well as reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). Three weeks ago, she suffered a traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage after a fall. She also has a past medical history of hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Her current medications include amlodipine, furosemide, and metoprolol. The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous bumetanide and oral metoprolol. Temperature is 37.2ºC (99.0ºF), pulse is 54/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 98/66 mmHg, and SpO2 is 95% on 2 liters nasal cannula oxygen. Cardiac exam reveals a diastolic rumble, loud S1, and opening snap. Pulmonary exam reveals rales at the bases bilaterally. There is 2+ pitting edema to below the knees bilaterally. Intake and output reports show she is 1.3 liters net negative over the past 24 hours. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Urgent referral for mitral valve repair/replacement

questions.solution:
This 72-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with heart failure due to severe mitral stenosis. She is appropriately started on intravenous diuretics and a beta blocker and did not require inotropic support. The next best step is an urgent referral for mitral valve repair or replacement.   

Patients with decompensated heart failure from mitral stenosis leading to heart failure may present with hypoxia and acute kidney injury due to venous congestion. They should be started on intravenous diuretics to help offload fluid volume and venous congestion. Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers should be added if the heart rate can tolerate it. In cases where cardiogenic shock develops, inotropic support (e.g. milrinone) should be added. Once patients with severe mitral stenosis are stabilized, they should be urgently/emergently referred to interventional cardiology and/or cardiothoracic surgery for valvular repair or replacement.   

Option Analysis

✅ Urgent referral for mitral valve repair/replacement :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Start apixaban:
Incorrect: While this patient should be on anticoagulation due to atrial fibrillation, the recent subarachnoid hemorrhage is a contraindication to anticoagulation. Prophylactic heparin (or enoxaparin) may still be appropriate in some cases. 
❌ Switch metoprolol to diltiazem:
Incorrect: This patient’s heart rate and blood pressure are on the low side, and switching to diltiazem is unlikely to improve this. In addition, the patient is already on a (dihydropyridine) calcium channel blocker, so adding a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker would not be appropriate. 
❌ Start metolazone:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics can be added to loop diuretics to help augment diuresis. This patient had an adequate diuresis yesterday (1.3 liters), so there is no indication that a thiazide diuretic is needed. 
❌ Repeat transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: This patient recently had an echocardiogram two months ago, so a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram would not add any additional information.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to bright red blood noted on toilet paper over the past week. A caregiver reports blood streaks on the surface of formed stool. The child describes pain during defecation but otherwise appears healthy and active. There has been no vomiting, fever, or abdominal pain. There is no family history of bleeding disorders. Immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 92/60 mmHg, heart rate is 94 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals no tenderness, distension, or palpable masses. A chaperoned visual inspection of the anal region reveals a superficial tear in the anal mucosa and minimal bright red blood. Which of the following is most likely to be present in further history?

choices.text: Abdominal pain and bloating after eating gluten-containing foods

questions.solution:
This well-appearing 5-year-old child’s presentation of bright red blood streaks on stool, pain during defecation, and a superficial tear in the anal mucosa on examination is strongly suggestive of an anal fissure. Constipation can lead to the passage of hard stools, which may cause trauma to the anal mucosa and result in superficial tears.

When evaluating a child with hematochezia, first, confirm the red discoloration represents true blood. Ask about recent ingestion of beets, berries, tomatoes, candy, or crayons. Clarify stool appearance. Bright red streaks on formed stool suggest an anal fissure. Blood mixed with mucus is more consistent with intussusception. Painless, large-volume bleeding raises concern for Meckel diverticulum or juvenile polyps. Ask about fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, fatigue, or syncope, which may indicate infectious enterocolitis, inflammatory bowel disease, or anemia. Review diet changes, toilet-training stressors, travel, medications, and any family history of inflammatory bowel disease, polyps, or bleeding disorders.

On exam, assess general appearance and vital signs. Evaluate for abdominal tenderness, distension, or masses. Inspect the perineum for fissures, ulcers, hemorrhoids, rectal prolapse, or visible polyps. Visual inspection may confirm a fissure, and a digital rectal exam may detect active bleeding. Document stool color and perform occult blood testing at the bedside to support the diagnosis and guide further evaluation.

Option Analysis

❌ Recent travel outside the country:
Incorrect: Travel history becomes relevant when considering infections, such as parasitic causes of gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g. Entamoeba histolytica), which typically present with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and systemic symptoms. This patient’s history and physical examination findings are more consistent with an anal fissure.
✅ Constipation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic diarrhea:
Incorrect: Chronic diarrhea may irritate the perianal region but usually presents with loose or watery stools rather than formed stools with blood streaks. Pain during defecation is also less typical in chronic diarrhea. This patient’s history and physical examination findings are more consistent with an anal fissure.
❌ Family history of ulcerative colitis:
Incorrect: Although ulcerative colitis can cause rectal bleeding, it more often presents with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and systemic symptoms. The presence of a localized anal mucosal tear makes this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Abdominal pain and bloating after eating gluten-containing foods:
Incorrect: Celiac disease may present with abdominal pain and bloating in response to gluten. However, celiac disease would likely present with additional symptoms such as skin rashes (e.g. dermatitis herpetiformis) and symptoms of malabsorption like poor growth and weight gain and pale, foul-smelling stools. This patient’s history and physical examination findings are more consistent with an anal fissure.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of three weeks of worsening bloody diarrhea. The caregiver reports 5–7 bowel movements per day, often with bright red blood in the stool. The child has abdominal pain, urgency to defecate, and fatigue, and has lost approximately 2 kg (4.4 lb.) in the past month due to decreased appetite. The family returned from a vacation to the Caribbean 3 weeks ago. There is no history of fever or vomiting. The child has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, heart rate is 102 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The child appears mildly uncomfortable. Abdominal examination reveals mild diffuse tenderness without guarding or rebound. A chaperoned rectal examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in confirming the most likely diagnosis?

 Laboratory Value     Result    
 Hemoglobin     9.5 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     29%    
 Platelet count     450,000/µL    
 White blood cell count     14,200/µL    
 C-reactive protein     28 mg/L    
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     48 mm/hr  
 Fecal calprotectin     480 µg/g
questions.solution:
This 9-year-old boy presents with several weeks of bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, low-grade temperature elevation, and elevated inflammatory markers, findings that raise concern for ulcerative colitis (UC). The best next step to confirm the diagnosis is colonoscopy with biopsy, which allows for direct visualization of the colonic mucosa and histopathologic evaluation.

UC typically shows a continuous pattern of inflammation beginning in the rectum and extending proximally. Endoscopic findings may include friable, erythematous mucosa, erosions, and ulcerations. Histologic features include crypt abscesses, mucosal inflammation, and chronic architectural distortion.

The evaluation of pediatric hematochezia begins with assessing clinical stability. In well-appearing children, anal fissures are common and diagnosed clinically. In the absence of constipation, consider food protein–induced allergic proctocolitis or juvenile polyps; diagnosis may involve an elimination diet or colonoscopy. Ill-appearing children require evaluation for Meckel diverticulum, intussusception, and inflammatory bowel disease. Meckel diverticulum presents with painless, large-volume bleeding and is diagnosed via technetium-99m scan. Intussusception causes colicky abdominal pain and “red currant jelly” stools and is diagnosed with ultrasound. Fever raises concern for an inflammatory or infectious condition. Fecal calprotectin and colonoscopy help evaluate UC, while stool cultures and ova and parasite exams assess for infection.   

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound can detect bowel wall thickening and complications such as abscesses, particularly in Crohn disease. However, it is not diagnostic for ulcerative colitis and cannot provide the mucosal details or histology needed for confirmation.
✅ Colonoscopy with biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stool culture and ova/parasite exam:
Incorrect: Infectious causes of bloody diarrhea (e.g., Shigella, Salmonella, or Entamoeba histolytica) should be considered, especially in the setting of recent travel. However, the chronicity of symptoms, along with one month of reduced appetite and weight loss in the setting of elevated inflammatory markers, suggest inflammatory bowel disease. Stool studies may be performed concurrently but are not diagnostic.
❌ Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan:
Incorrect: This scan is used to identify Meckel diverticulum, which typically presents in younger children with painless, large-volume hematochezia. It is not useful for evaluating suspected ulcerative colitis.
❌ Capsule endoscopy:
Incorrect: Capsule endoscopy is used primarily to evaluate small bowel pathology, particularly in suspected Crohn disease. It does not adequately visualize the colon and rectum, which are the primary sites involved in ulcerative colitis, and is typically not the first step in the diagnostic process.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of two days of fever, with a maximum temperature at home of 39.1ºC (102.4ºF). The patient has been short of breath for the past day. There is no significant past medical history, and the patient takes no medications. Temperature is 38.6ºC (101.5ºF), pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals track marks on the bilateral upper extremities. Several fingers have a small, dark, straight line through the fingertip nail. There are painless lesions over the bilateral soles of the feet. A systolic murmur is heard on cardiac auscultation. There is mild tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant. Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the abdomen shows a hypodense round fluid collection with rim enhancement and an air-fluid level. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Positron emission tomography (PET) imaging of the abdomen

questions.solution:
This 41-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever. The presence of a new cardiac murmur, splinter hemorrhages, and Janeway lesions (painless lesions on the soles or palms) suggest infective endocarditis. Therefore, the splenic lesion seen on imaging is likely a splenic abscess, and blood cultures should be obtained followed by the administration of intravenous antibiotics.        

Patients with a splenic mass often present with left upper quadrant abdominal tenderness or fullness, although the lesion(s) may also be found on imaging in patients without abdominal symptoms. The history and physical examination will often suggest the underlying diagnosis, and follow-up abdominal ultrasound or computed tomography (CT) imaging can confirm it. In cases where the diagnosis remains unclear, additional tests, such as biopsy (for suspected splenic metastasis) or positron emission tomography (PET) imaging (for suspected splenic lymphoma), may be necessary. Treatment depends on the specific diagnosis and can vary significantly. For example, echinococcal cysts should be surgically excised, whereas other lesions like hemangiomas can be monitored.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Splenic artery aneurysm embolization:
Incorrect: Embolization may be indicated in cases of splenic artery aneurysms, which typically occur in the context of portal hypertension, atherosclerotic disease, or pregnancy. This patient's presentation, including signs of systemic infection, a murmur, splinter hemorrhages, and Janeway lesions, is more suggestive of infective endocarditis with a splenic abscess.   
❌ Surgical removal of splenic lesion:
Incorrect: In cases of an echinococcal cyst, surgical resection is the preferred management. However, this patient does not have a travel or exposure history to support this uncommon diagnosis. This patient's presentation, including signs of systemic infection, a murmur, splinter hemorrhages, and Janeway lesions, is more suggestive of infective endocarditis with a splenic abscess. 
❌ Positron emission tomography (PET) imaging of the abdomen:
Incorrect: PET imaging is typically indicated in cases of malignancy, such as splenic lymphoma. However, there is no clinical evidence to suggest this diagnosis, such as night sweats, unintentional weight loss, or lymphadenopathy. 
❌ Biopsy of splenic lesion:
Incorrect: Biopsy would be appropriate if the diagnosis were unclear or if there was suspicion of splenic metastasis without a known primary malignancy. In this case, the diagnosis of infective endocarditis with splenic abscess is strongly supported by the clinical and imaging findings, making biopsy unnecessary.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents for evaluation of painful bowel movements and pruritus in the perianal area. Digital rectal examination reveals a palpable purple lump in the perianal area. The patient has noticed streaks of blood occasionally covering his stool. He has not experienced any night sweats, weight loss, or decreased appetite. Past medical history includes hypertension, constipation, and type II diabetes mellitus. His family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 152/98 mmHg, and pulse is 82/min. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of painful bowel movements, pruritus, streaky hematochezia, and a palpable perianal lump in the setting of constipation. Together, these findings are consistent with combined hemorrhoids. While physical examination can diagnose external hemorrhoids, anoscopy is performed to evaluate for internal hemorrhoids.  

Hemorrhoids refer to varicose veins in the anorectum that form due to persistently elevated venous pressure in the hemorrhoidal plexus. Hemorrhoids can be classified as external (distal to the dentate line), internal (proximal to the dentate line), and combined (found on both sides of the dentate line).  

Patients with external hemorrhoids typically present with a history of palpable external lump, anal pruritis, and perianal pain. Bleeding from external hemorrhoids is atypical, therefore this patient should be checked with anoscopy for internal hemorrhoids as well.
