External hemorrhoids can be diagnosed with digital rectal examination and may appear as tender, soft, swollen, or red lumps. Patients may have non-tender skin tags from previous episodes of inflammation and thrombosis. Patients with internal hemorrhoids typically present with painless bleeding with defecation, anal pruritis, and possibly with prolapse. Anoscopy is typically required for the diagnosis of internal hemorrhoids.  

Option Analysis

✅ Anoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is most consistent with hemorrhoids. In individuals over 40 years old who present with hematochezia, colonoscopy can be used to evaluate for other causes of bleeding (e.g. colon cancer). A colonoscopy would not be indicated in this young patient without a family history of colon cancer.  
❌ Surgical consultation:
Incorrect: This patient’s history of painful bowel movements, streaky hematochezia, and a perianal lump in the setting of constipation is most concerning for hemorrhoids. Conservative management (e.g., high fiber diet, sitz bath, stool softeners) should be attempted before surgical consultation.  
❌ CT enterography  :
Incorrect: CT enterography is a non-invasive imaging technique to evaluate small bowel pathology. This patient’s clinical history and physical examination findings suggest hemorrhoids. CT enterography is not typically used to diagnose internal or external hemorrhoids.  
❌ Manual fecal disimpaction:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of painful bowel movements, pruritus, streaky hematochezia, and a palpable perianal lump in the setting of constipation. These findings are most suggestive of hemorrhoids. Fecal disimpaction is not indicated in the management of hemorrhoids.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents for evaluation of bloody bowel movements and itchiness in the perianal region. Over the past year, the patient has noticed bright red blood covering his stool. The patient has also felt a “lump” in the perianal region. He has not experienced unintentional weight loss, decreased appetite, pain with defecation, or change in stool caliber. His past medical history is notable for osteoarthritis and hypertension. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 160/83 mmHg, and pulse is 82/min. Perianal examination reveals a swollen mass that can be easily reduced. Anoscopy reveals several purplish-red swollen lumps at the anorectal junction. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with painless hematochezia, perianal pruritus, and a reducible mass in the perianal region. Anoscopy reveals purplish-red lumps at the anorectal junction. These findings are most consistent with grade III internal hemorrhoids, which can be treated conservatively with sitz baths.  

Treatment of external hemorrhoids is initially conservative management. However if patients present within 4 days of developing extreme pain from thrombosed hemorrhoids, in-office excision or surgical hemorrhoidectomy may be performed.  

Internal hemorrhoid management is based on prolapse severity (grades). Grade I hemorrhoids do not prolapse. Grade II hemorrhoids do prolapse during bowel movements or straining but reduce spontaneously. Grade III hemorrhoids prolapse and require manual reduction. Finally, grade IV hemorrhoids are irreducible even with manipulation.  

Grade I, II, III, and uncomplicated grade IV hemorrhoids should be treated initially with conservative management including a high-fiber diet, sitz bath, increased fluid intake, and stool softeners. However, if conservative treatment is ineffective, surgical interventions such as rubber band ligation and hemorrhoidectomy can be performed. Patients with complicated grade IV hemorrhoids (incarceration or strangulation) should proceed directly to surgical hemorrhoidectomy.  


Option Analysis

❌ Partial colectomy  :
Incorrect: This patient presents with painless hematochezia, perianal pruritus, and a reducible mass in the perianal region. Physical examination reveals purplish-red lumps at the anorectal junction. These findings are most consistent with internal hemorrhoids. A partial colectomy would be unnecessary for the treatment of hemorrhoids.  
❌ Incision and drainage  :
Incorrect: A perianal abscess can be treated with incision and drainage. However, this condition typically presents with pain and an indurated mass in the perianal region.  
❌ Rubber band ligation  :
Incorrect: This patient presents with internal hemorrhoids with prolapse that can be manually reduced. These findings are most consistent with grade III hemorrhoids, which can be treated conservatively with a high-fiber diet, sitz bath, increased fluid intake, and stool softeners.  
✅ Sitz bath  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Topical lidocaine ointment  :
Incorrect: This patient presents with painless internal hemorrhoids. Topical lidocaine is not indicated in the management of this condition.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department from a nursing home for evaluation of pain and increased irritability for three days. Medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, Alzheimer dementia, and a left middle cerebral artery stroke that occurred nine-years ago. The patient has limited mobility and is largely bedbound. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 129/73 mmHg, and pulse is 83/min. Physical examination reveals the findings seen below in the sacral region. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s cutaneous findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a lesion demonstrating partial loss of the dermis without exposure to subcutaneous fat, muscle, or bone. These findings are consistent with a stage II pressure ulcer, which can be managed conservatively with cushioned dressings.  

Pressure ulcer management depends on its staging. Stage I (intact skin with non-blanchable erythema and no signs of necrosis) and stage II wounds (shallow, open ulcer with partial thickness loss of dermis) require local management. Treatment involves keeping the wound moist with medicated gauze and decreasing pressure and friction with cushioned dressings. If the patient is bed or wheelchair-bound, pressure on affected areas can be reduced by frequent repositioning on specialized support surfaces such as foam wedges, cushioned seating, or water beds.  

Stage III (full-thickness loss of skin and exposure to subcutaneous fat) and stage IV (exposure of underlying muscle, tendon, or bone) require more invasive therapies. Deeper wounds tend to have more fibrinous exudate and necrotic tissue, which requires chemical or surgical debridement to prevent infection. Once the wound bed is clean, a negative pressure wound dressing can be applied to reduce bacterial growth and promote granulation tissue formation. Stage IV wounds heal poorly on their own and may require an autologous tissue graft.  
 

Option Analysis

❌ Surgical debridement:
Incorrect: Surgical debridement may be indicated for the management of stage III and IV pressure ulcers or to help stage wounds that cannot be visualized due to the presence of eschar. Stage III and Stage IV pressure ulcers are characterized by full-thickness skin loss and exposure of the underlying tissue (e.g., adipose, muscle, bone). This patient’s pressure ulcer is a shallow lesion with partial thickness loss extending to the dermis. It is most consistent with a stage II pressure ulcer, which does not require surgical intervention.  
✅ Cushioned dressings   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Skin biopsy  :
Incorrect: Biopsy is not typically indicated in the management of pressure ulcers.  
❌ Intravenous antibiotics   :
Incorrect: Local antibiotic ointments may be indicated if there is concern for concurrent cellulitis in patients with pressure ulcers. Systemic antibiotics would not be necessary in this case given the lack of severe localized infection (e.g. osteomyelitis) or systemic infection (e.g. sepsis)  
❌ Negative pressure dressing:
Incorrect: Negative pressure dressings help reduce bacterial growth and improve granulation tissue formation. They are used in the management of stage III and IV pressure ulcers. In contrast, this patient has a stage II pressure ulcer. Negative pressure dressings are not used in the management of stage II pressure ulcers.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided abdominal discomfort. Over the past 24 hours, he has lost his appetite and experienced several episodes of non-bilious vomiting after eating. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and 15 pack-year smoking history. He does not use alcohol or other recreational substances. Temperature is 37.4ºC (99.3ºF), pulse is 98/min, blood pressure is 123/73 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals focal tenderness to palpation over the right lower abdominal quadrant. The genitourinary examination is unremarkable. When the patient's left lower abdominal quadrant is palpated, he experiences concurrent pain in the right lower abdominal quadrant. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely present?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute, stable appendicitis symptoms, including right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and a positive Rovsing sign. A Rovsing sign is positive when the patient’s left lower quadrant is palpated, and the patient feels pain in the right lower quadrant. This finding is indicative of right-sided peritoneal irritation. Of the physical examination findings listed, the psoas sign is the most likely to also be present. Psoas sign is positive when passive extension of the patient’s right hip causes right lower quadrant pain. This finding indicates inflammation of an appendix that is retrocecal, or situated behind the cecum.

Patients with acute appendicitis typically develop pain around the umbilicus that migrates toward the right lower abdominal quadrant. Patients often experience associated nausea, anorexia, vomiting, and fevers. Additional symptoms may include diarrhea, bowel irregularity, indigestion, and malaise. A focused history and physical examination should be obtained for stable patients with suspected appendicitis, explicitly noting the pain's timing, duration, and migration.

Most patients with appendicitis will demonstrate focal, right lower quadrant tenderness to palpation at McBurney point, one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. Additional physical examination findings that can aid in diagnosing appendicitis include the Rovsing, psoas, and obturator signs. The obturator sign is positive when internal rotation of the hip with the knee and hip flexed induces pain in the patient’s right lower quadrant. This finding may indicate an appendix located in the pelvis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Psoas sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chandelier sign:
Incorrect: Chandelier sign is a term to describe cervical motion tenderness. Cervical motion tenderness is a gynecological examination finding that may indicate peritoneal infection. This finding would not be present in the setting of acute appendicitis.  
❌ Murphy sign:
Incorrect: Murphy sign refers to increased discomfort or inspiratory arrest (catching one’s breath) during deep inspiration when the examiner palpates the right upper abdomen. This finding is indicative of cholecystitis, not appendicitis.  
❌ Absent cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: The cremasteric reflex is a normal physical examination sign. It describes how stroking the inner thigh causes the ipsilateral testicle to pull upwards toward the inguinal canal. The absence of a cremasteric reflex may be seen in acute testicular torsion, but not in appendicitis.  
❌ Hamman sign:
Incorrect: Hamman sign describes a rasping crunching sound heard over the precordium that is synchronous with the heartbeat. This finding may be present in the setting of mediastinal emphysema.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to a primary care clinic with a 3-week history of severe peri-rectal pain with defecation. He reports a “small bump" by his anus that is tender to touch. The patient has had bright red blood on the toilet paper after wiping. He has not had abdominal pain, diarrhea, or weight loss. He has no significant past medical history, takes no medications, and denies tobacco or alcohol use. The patient is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates the findings seen below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient has a 3-week history of anal pain with defecation, hematochezia, and a new small bump by his anus that is very tender to touch. Physical examination is significant for the presence of a linear ulceration on the posterior midline of the anal canal. Together, these findings are mostly consistent with the diagnosis of anal fissure.


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
Anal fissures are longitudinal tears in the skin below the dentate line, a region innervated by somatic nerves. They most commonly present in pediatrics and middle-aged patients, although they can present in any age group. They are divided into two types: typical anal fissures, which are caused by local trauma due to constipation, straining during defecation, vaginal delivery, prolonged diarrhea, or anal intercourse; and atypical anal fissures which are caused by an underlying secondary disease such as Crohn disease and other granulomatous diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, sarcoidosis), malignancy, or communicable diseases (e.g., HIV infection, syphilis).  

Patients with anal fissures typically present with anal pain during and after defecation and bright red blood with wiping or on the stool surface. Patients may also report a history of local trauma in typical anal fissures or signs and symptoms related to the underlying etiology in atypical anal fissures.

Physical examination typically reveals a linear midline longitudinal laceration in the anal canal, most commonly in the posterior midline. The presence of a lateral longitudinal tear or multiple wide deep painless fissures with poor healing should raise concern for an underlying secondary etiology.  

Option Analysis

✅ Anal fissure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perianal abscess:
Incorrect: A perianal abscess refers to an infection of the anal crypt gland. This condition presents with constant pain and an area of fluctuance or erythema with surrounding induration about the anus. The presence of a linear ulceration on anorectal examination makes the diagnosis of anal fissure more likely.  
❌ Pilonidal cyst:
Incorrect: Pilonidal cyst refers to a hair follicle infection in the gluteal cleft. The presence of anal pain related to bowel movements, hematochezia, and the identification of a linear ulceration on anorectal examination makes the diagnosis of anal fissure more likely.  
❌ Internal hemorrhoids:
Incorrect: Internal hemorrhoids are typically painless. This patient’s history of anal pain with bowel movements and the presence of a linear ulceration on anorectal examination makes anal fissure the more likely diagnosis.  
❌ Anorectal cancer:
Incorrect: Anorectal cancer typically presents with anal pain and hematochezia in an immunocompromised patient with a history of HPV infection. Physical examination would reveal the presence of an ulcerating enlarging mass rather than a linear ulceration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with a 2-week history of anal pain during bowel movements, and bright red blood on the toilet paper after wiping. He reports straining with bowel movements and a history of constipation. He has not had abdominal pain, diarrhea, or perianal discharge. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. His diet consists of processed food low in fiber. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is a small linear ulceration at the posterior midline of the anal canal with increased internal sphincter tone. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Stool softener, sitz baths, and a fiber-rich diet

questions.solution:
This patient has a 2-week history of anal pain during bowel movements and hematochezia in the setting of constipation and straining during defecation. Physical examination reveals the presence of a small linear ulceration at the posterior midline of the anal canal. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of a typical anal fissure, which can be treated conservatively with supportive care.

Typical anal fissures are initially managed with supportive care which includes a 4-week trial of stool softeners, sitz baths, and a fiber-rich diet, with or without topical analgesics depending on the pain severity. If initial management fails, a topical calcium channel blocker (e.g., nifedipine) or a topical nitrate should be added for a duration of 4 weeks.

Patients with atypical anal fissures and typical anal fissures refractory to medical treatment should be endoscopically evaluated for a secondary underlying etiology. Management for the underlying condition is indicated for patients with an identified secondary etiology. Surgical management with botulinum A toxin injection, lateral internal sphincterotomy, or anal advancement flap should be considered for patients with atypical anal fissures and typical anal fissures refractory to medical management. All patients with anal fissures should be advised to avoid straining during defecation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stool softener, sitz baths, and a fiber-rich diet:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Topical nitrate:
Incorrect: Topical nitrates are indicated in the management of anal fissures that are unresponsive to supportive care. This patient has not tried supportive care yet.  
❌ Sigmoidoscopy:
Incorrect: Sigmoidoscopy is indicated for the evaluation of typical anal fissures unresponsive to conservative measures and atypical anal fissures to assess for an underlying secondary etiology. This patient has an untreated typical anal fissure.  
❌ Topical analgesics:
Incorrect: Although topical analgesics can help patients with pain control, they should not be used alone for management of anal fissures. They can be used in conjunction with stool softeners, sitz baths, and a fiber-rich diet for treating newly diagnosed typical anal fissures.  
❌ Lateral internal sphincterotomy:
Incorrect: Lateral internal sphincterotomy is indicated in the management of anal fissures that are refractory to medical treatment.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents for follow-up evaluation after an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy performed 14 days ago. The patient has been complaining of pain and warmth at the incision site for the past three days. He has not had fevers or chills. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled diabetes mellitus type 2 and seasonal rhinitis. Medications include metformin and glucocorticoid nasal spray. The patient has a 25-pack year smoking history and currently smokes. His most recent HbA1C is 6.1%. BMI is 23 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 125/78 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, one of the surgical wounds appears tender with purulent drainage and surrounding erythema. Which of the following factors confers an increased risk for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with peri-incisional pain, warmth, erythema, and purulent discharge from the surgical wound; which is highly suggestive of a surgical site infection.

Surgical site infection (SSI) is an infection related to a surgical procedure that typically occurs near the surgical site between days 4 and 30 following surgery. It is most often caused by skin flora, including streptococcal species, Staphylococcus aureus, and coagulase-negative staphylococci. It can also be caused by pathogens, such as anaerobic gut bacteria, encountered during bowel surgery. Patients typically present with pain or tenderness at the surgical site and peri-incisional signs of infection, including warmth, erythema, or purulent discharge. Patients can also develop systemic signs of infection (e.g. fever, hypotension, tachycardia), wound dehiscence, and a tender fluctuant mass under the skin suggestive of an abscess. SSI gets subdivided into three types depending on the depth of infection: superficial, deep, and organ-space.

The risk of surgical site infection is based on the surgical classification of wound contamination. The wound can be classified as clean, clean-contaminated, contaminated, or dirty based on factors like location of surgery, trauma history, or breaks in sterile technique. Patient factors also play a role in increasing the risk of SSI, including current smoking, uncontrolled diabetes, and immunosuppression.

Smoking is considered a primary risk factor for developing a surgical site infection due to the vasoconstrictive effects of nicotine and poor tissue perfusion, alteration in nutrient transportation, and immune response. Therefore, it is advisable for patients to stop smoking 4-6 weeks before an elective surgery.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Current smoking status:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: A history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is associated with an increased risk for surgical site infection (SSI) due to immunosuppression and impaired wound healing. However, this patient's diabetes mellitus is controlled and thus would not appreciably increase the risk of SSI.  
❌ Glucocorticoids usage:
Incorrect: Nasal glucocorticoids have limited systemic absorption and thus do not significantly increase the risk of SSI.  
❌ Laparoscopic surgical approach:
Incorrect: An open surgical approach is associated with an increased risk of SSI. This patient underwent laparoscopic surgery.  
❌ Body mass index:
Incorrect: Obesity is associated with an increased risk of developing a surgical site infection. This patient has a normal BMI.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with two days of worsening abdominal pain in the lower left quadrant. There is associated decreased appetite, constipation, and frequent urination. The patient has not experienced weight loss, diarrhea, or blood in the stools. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type II. The patient has a 20-pack-year smoking history and a diet consisting mainly of red meat. BMI is 30 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F), blood pressure is 137/75 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and room air oxygen saturation is 97%. Abdominal examination is significant for left lower quadrant tenderness with guarding. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and an elevated CRP. Urinalysis shows pyuria. Which findings will most likely be seen with further diagnostic studies?

choices.text: Multiple colonic inflamed diverticula with localized bowel wall thickening and pericolonic fat stranding on CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Growth of E. coli from the urine culture
Mucosal and chronic submucosal inflammation, erosion/ulceration, and crypt abscesses on histopathological examination of the colon
Dilated appendix with localized bowel wall thickening and periappendiceal fat stranding on CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Left solid ovarian mass with thick septations on pelvic ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has acute diverticulitis, characterized by diverticulum inflammation due to micro-perforation and bacterial seeding in the diverticulum wall. It most commonly occurs in Western societies in the sigmoid colon, where there is the highest intraluminal pressure. Risk factors for acute diverticulitis include older age, obesity, a diet high in red meat and low in fiber, a sedentary lifestyle, and aspirin and NSAID use. Patients with acute diverticulitis usually report acute, constant, crampy abdominal pain localized to the left lower quadrant. Other symptoms include fevers [typically below 39°C (102 °F)], nausea, change in bowel habits (e.g., constipation, diarrhea), and urinary symptoms (e.g., dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency) due to bladder irritation from the inflamed sigmoid colon. Abdominal examination typically shows hypoactive bowel sounds and tenderness localized to the LLQ.

Laboratory evaluation typically shows leukocytosis with a left shift and an elevated CRP. The most appropriate test for diagnosis is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast (water-soluble if perforation is suspected), which can show areas of inflamed diverticula with localized thickening of the bowel wall, pericolonic fat stranding, and potential findings of complications of acute diverticulitis (e.g., abscess, fistula, obstruction, perforation). Other laboratory findings may include sterile pyuria if urinary symptoms are present.  

Option Analysis

✅ Multiple colonic inflamed diverticula with localized bowel wall thickening and pericolonic fat stranding on CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Growth of E. coli from the urine culture:
Incorrect: Urinary frequency and pyuria, as seen in this patient, can occur with acute diverticulitis when there is irritation of the bladder from the inflamed sigmoid colon. The cause of this patient’s lower left quadrant abdominal pain, constipation, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers is likely acute diverticulitis with associated irritation of the bladder, not a urinary tract infection.  
❌ Mucosal and chronic submucosal inflammation, erosion/ulceration, and crypt abscesses on histopathological examination of the colon:
Incorrect: These histopathological findings are consistent with a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. The acute onset of the abdominal pain and the absence of diarrhea and blood in the stool make this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ Dilated appendix with localized bowel wall thickening and periappendiceal fat stranding on CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This finding on a CT scan indicates acute appendicitis. Although acute appendicitis can present with abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis, the localization of this patient’s abdominal pain on the left side makes acute diverticulitis more likely.  
❌ Left solid ovarian mass with thick septations on pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: This finding on pelvic ultrasound would suggest ovarian cancer. Although ovarian cancer can present with abdominal pain, the acute onset of her symptoms, the presence of fever, leukocytosis, elevated CRP, and the absence of weight loss make ovarian cancer less likely.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for severe lower left quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting that started abruptly two days ago. The patient had a fever of 38.4°C (101.1 ºF) at home and has not had a bowel movement since the symptoms started. There is no weight loss, diarrhea, or dysuria. The patient had a similar episode a year ago that resolved with dietary modifications and bowel rest. The patient was treated one month ago with ciprofloxacin for acute pyelonephritis. Temperature is 38.3 °C (100.9 °F), blood pressure is 119/76 mmHg, pulse is 91/min, and respirations are 20/min. The patient appears uncomfortable. Bowel sounds are hypoactive, and the abdomen is distended and tender to palpation in the left lower quadrant. Serum white blood cell count and CRP are elevated. Which of the following studies should be ordered to diagnose this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast
Clostridioides difficile stool antigen and toxin

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 2-day history of left lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation, fever, and signs of systemic inflammation. The most likely diagnosis is acute diverticulitis, likely complicated by significant bowel obstruction.

Uncomplicated diverticulitis results only in inflammation of the diverticula. Complicated diverticulitis is associated with frank perforation, peritonitis, obstruction, abscess, stricture, or fistula formation (most commonly colovesical or colovaginal).

The most appropriate test for diagnosing and classifying acute diverticulitis as uncomplicated versus complicated is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast (water-soluble if perforation is suspected). In uncomplicated diverticulitis, a CT scan reveals inflamed diverticula with localized thickening of the bowel wall and pericolonic fat stranding. In complicated diverticulitis, the CT scan can show signs of frank perforation [free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum)], fistula formation (air bubbles within the bladder in colovesical fistula), abscess formation (fluid collection consistent with an abscess), bowel obstruction (dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels and a transition point), or stricture formation. This classification can help in choosing the appropriate management.  

Option Analysis

✅ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urinalysis and urine culture:
Incorrect: Urinalysis and urine culture are used to diagnose acute cystitis. Urinary symptoms and pyuria on urinalysis can be seen with acute diverticulitis from bladder irritation from the inflamed sigmoid colon. This patient’s presentation of left lower quadrant abdominal pain, alteration of bowel habits, and fever support acute diverticulitis.  
❌ Clostridioides difficile stool antigen and toxin:
Incorrect: Stool antigen and toxin studies are used to diagnose C. difficile infection. Although this patient has risk factors for C. difficile infection (fluoroquinolone treatment), the absence of diarrhea makes this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is used to diagnose colorectal cancer, which can present with abdominal pain and alteration in bowel habits and can be an underlying cause of recurrent acute diverticulitis. Colonoscopy is contraindicated in the acute setting of diverticulitis due to the increased risk of perforation. It should be deferred until the complete resolution of symptoms (in six to eight weeks) to rule out underlying malignancy.  
❌ Plain abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: A plain abdominal radiograph can be used to diagnose bowel obstruction. Although this patient may have significant bowel obstruction presenting with nausea, vomiting, and distended abdomen, it is likely caused by underlying acute diverticulitis.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for sudden and severe abdominal pain, which began abruptly the evening prior to admission. There is associated hematochezia and she states she has a “fluttering sensation” in the chest. Past medical history includes diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a myocardial infarction five years ago. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 85/63 mmHg, pulse is 132/min, and O2 saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination shows a pale, ill-appearing woman with diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation. The patient's ECG is shown below. Which of the following is the next best step in management?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe abdominal pain and hematochezia in the setting of new-onset atrial fibrillation. This picture is consistent with ischemic colitis. The associated hypotension suggests an unstable presentation of this disease process that should be addressed first by administering intravenous fluids like lactated Ringer solution.

Ischemic colitis refers to reduced intestinal blood flow, usually due to small vessel occlusion (e.g. from a thromboembolism) or hypoperfusion of the colon. Patients typically present with worsening cramping abdominal pain, tenesmus, bloody diarrhea, and hematochezia. Atrial fibrillation, such as in this patient, can cause thromboembolic events. Other risk factors include diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and recent aortic surgery (due to cross-clamping).

Unstable patients with ischemic colitis typically present more than 24 hours after the onset of initial signs and symptoms like acute abdominal pain, and at that point they may have signs of peritonitis, hypotension, and tachycardia. Acute management of ischemic colitis presenting with hypotension involves airway stabilization, establishing intravenous access, and administration of intravenous fluids.

Once stabilized, patients should be given intravenous antibiotics and undergo abdominal radiography to evaluate for the presence of dilation, pneumoperitoneum, portal venous gas, or pneumatosis coli. The presence of any one of these findings confirms the diagnosis of complicated ischemic colitis infarction. These patients require emergent surgical consultation for emergent laparotomy.

Option Analysis

✅ Administer lactated Ringer solution:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Antibiotic therapy is indicated for treating unstable ischemic colitis; however, this patient's hypotension should be addressed first by administering intravenous fluids.  
❌ Intubate the patient:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette is speaking to the provider, implying airway protection. Endotracheal intubation is not indicated at this time.  
❌ Obtain surgical consultation:
Incorrect: While the surgical team should be consulted for this patient presenting with suspected ischemic colitis, addressing this patient’s hypotension takes precedence.  
❌ Administer norepinephrine:
Incorrect: This patient should receive fluid resuscitation as a first-line measure to treat hypotension. If hypotension is refractory to intravenous fluids (i.e. shock), then administration of vasopressors is appropriate.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of cramping abdominal pain, and yellow skin. The pain started last night and is associated with nausea and non-bloody vomiting. The patient has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 39 ºC (102.2 ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 140/75 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears ill with jaundice and scleral icterus. There is moderate tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory evaluation shows leukocytosis and hyperbilirubinemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Gastroenterology consult for endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
Administration of IV antibiotics with ceftriaxone

questions.solution:
Biliary colic is described as an intense, dull discomfort, typically constant in nature in the right upper quadrant, epigastrium, or substernal area with possible radiation to the back or right shoulder blade. Pain from biliary colic is often associated with fatty food intake, nausea, and vomiting. Biliary colic is typically caused by the gallbladder contracting and forcing a gallstone or sludge against the gallbladder outlet or cystic duct opening.    

Complications of gallstones include cholecystitis which is right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis from gallbladder inflammation secondary to gallstones. Another complication of gallstones is choledocholithiasis which is the presence of a gallstone in the common bile duct. This can be further complicated by acute cholangitis which presents with fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice caused by infection from biliary obstruction. This patient has evidence of right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, fever, leukocytosis, and hyperbilirubinemia suggesting acute cholangitis. The combination of fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice is known as Charcot’s triad, which is highly suggestive of acute cholangitis.  

Patients with biliary colic should have lab work including a CBC to assess for leukocytosis and a CMP, and liver function tests. The initial imaging for biliary colic is typically abdominal ultrasound to look for gallstones. For patients with obesity or other anatomic considerations endoscopic ultrasound can be used.  

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), with or without an initial ultrasound, should be performed in patients with suspected acute cholangitis since it can be used to both diagnose and treat the underlying obstruction via biliary duct decompression and removal of stones. In addition, patients with acute cholangitis should be admitted to the hospital and administered IV hydration, antiemetics, analgesia, and empiric antibiotics.

Option Analysis

❌ Emergent general surgery consult:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute cholangitis suspected because of the findings of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice (Charcot Triad). Gastroenterology should be consulted for an ERCP.
✅ Gastroenterology consult for endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast:
Incorrect: Abdominal CT can detect biliary duct dilatation and biliary stenosis; however, it has low sensitivity for detecting biliary tract stones. This patient has features suggestive of acute cholangitis–warranting ERCP for diagnosis and treatment.
❌ Administration of IV antibiotics with ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: This patient with acute cholangitis should have empiric antibiotics initiated to cover enteric streptococci, coliforms, and anaerobes. Ceftriaxone should not be used alone in acute cholangitis, but should be prescribed in combination with metronidazole.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain. The pain started last night after eating a cheeseburger and has not improved. The pain radiates  to the right shoulder. Past medical history is significant for obesity and hypertension, for which the patient takes amlodipine. Temperature is 38.5 ºC (101.3 ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 136/89 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and SpO2 is 99% on room air. Palpation of the right upper quadrant during inspiration causes significant pain and an abrupt cessation of inspiration. Serum white blood cell count is 18,000/mm3. Abdominal ultrasound shows a distended and thickened gallbladder with surrounding edema and gallstones. The common bile duct appears within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Consult gastroenterology for endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
Administer piperacillin-tazobactam and consult general surgery for non-emergent cholecystectomy

questions.solution:
This patient’s combination of right upper quadrant pain, fever, leukocytosis, and ultrasound findings confirm the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. Patients like this one, who are  diagnosed with acute cholecystitis and are good surgical candidates, should have intravenous antibiotics, supportive care, and surgical consultation for non-emergent cholecystectomy.    

Once acute cholecystitis is diagnosed, supportive care with empiric antibiotics should be initiated. Patients can either have early or delayed non-emergent cholecystectomy based on risk stratification.    

Patients who progress despite antibiotics, such as those with continuous high fevers or hemodynamic instability should have an emergent cholecystectomy. Patients with complicated acute cholecystitis should also have emergent cholecystectomy as these complications may be fatal. Complications include gallbladder gangrene/necrosis, perforation, and emphysematous cholecystitis. 

Option Analysis

❌ Consult gastroenterology for endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: ERCP can be used in the management and diagnosis of choledocholithiasis and acute cholangitis. It is not used to treat acute cholecystitis.
❌ Administer piperacillin-tazobactam without surgical management:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of acute cholecystitis and has no contraindications to surgery, thus cholecystectomy should be performed as part of the treatment.
✅ Administer piperacillin-tazobactam and consult general surgery for non-emergent cholecystectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform cholescintigraphy (hepatic iminodiacetic acid [HIDA]) scan:
Incorrect: The diagnosis of acute cholecystitis is confirmed based on the clinical history and supporting ultrasound findings. In cases where the diagnosis is unclear, a HIDA scan can be performed in place of or in addition to ultrasound. At this point a definitive diagnosis of acute cholecystitis has been made.
❌ Perform magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP):
Incorrect: MRCP can be used in cases where it is unclear if the patient has choledocholithiasis or cholelithiasis, and the clinical history and other imaging studies are non-diagnostic. This patient has a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for severe, constant abdominal pain that started this morning and subjective fevers. The patient states that for the past few days he has experienced intense abdominal pain after meals that is associated with nausea and vomiting. Temperature is 38.5 ºC (101.3 ºF), pulse is 122/min, blood pressure is 100/89 mmHg, respirations are 10/min, and SpO2 is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is ill-appearing and jaundiced. The right upper quadrant is tender to palpation. There is no tenderness in the epigastric region, and no rebound, rigidity, or guarding. Serum white blood cell count is elevated. Liver chemistries show elevations in AST, ALT, alkaline phosphatase, and direct bilirubin. Amylase and lipase are within normal limits. CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows a dilated common bile duct and no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute cholangitis is a potentially  life-threatening complication of gallstones. It presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, hyperbilirubinemia, and leukocytosis. Fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice is called Charcot triad and is suggestive of acute cholangitis. Clinical history, physical examination, and blood work demonstrating a cholestatic picture can guide the workup. Other causes of right upper quadrant pain and fever that should be In the differential are acute cholecystitis, liver abscess, and gallstone pancreatitis.  

ERCP can definitively diagnose the condition and also treat it with biliary drainage and stone removal. Abdominal ultrasound can demonstrate a dilated common bile duct and/or common bile duct stone. It should be treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and supportive care. Biliary drainage is required and can be performed endoscopically (ERCP), percutaneously, or with surgery in patients who have failed the other types of treatment or are not candidates for it. Elective cholecystectomy can be performed once the cholangitis is resolved.

Option Analysis

✅ Acute cholangitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute cholecystitis:
Incorrect: Acute cholecystitis presents with biliary colic and acute right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis from gallbladder inflammation from gallstones. Hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice would not be seen in acute cholecystitis.
❌ Gallstone pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Patients with gallstone pancreatitis can be jaundiced but typically have severe epigastric pain, although right upper quadrant pain can be seen. Significant elevations in serum lipase and amylase and findings on CT would be expected.
❌ Mirizzi syndrome:
Incorrect: Mirizzi syndrome can present with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever from hepatic duct obstruction from extrinsic compression from an impacted stone in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder. CT would demonstrate dilatation of the biliary system above the neck of the gallbladder or a stone.
❌ Liver abscess:
Incorrect: Liver abscess can cause right upper quadrant pain, fever, leukocytosis, and elevations in AST, ALT, and bilirubin; however findings would be seen on CT.
